tuple: ['What do you think about the information in this passage?', 'Think about all of the technological devices that you use on a regular basis.']
['What type of devices do you use on a regular basis?', 'Computers, wireless internet, smart phones, tablets, global positioning system (GPS), MP3 players, and satellite radio might come to mind.']

['What type of technology are they using to locate you?', 'Next, think about the most exciting modern technologies that you have heard about in the news, such as trains that levitate above their tracks, invisibility cloaks that bend light around them, and microscopic robots that fight diseased cells in our bodies.']
['What type of technology does this use?', 'All of these groundbreaking advancements rely on the principles of physics.']
['What is physics?', 'Physics is a branch of science.']

['What is science?', 'The word science comes from a Latin word that means having knowledge, and refers the knowledge of how the physical world operates, based on objective evidence determined through observation and experimentation.']

['What is a key requirement of any scientific explanation of a natural phenomenon?', 'A key requirement of any scientific explanation of a natural phenomenon is that it must be testable; one must be able to devise and conduct an experimental investigation that either supports or refutes the explanation.']

['What happens when the question is not testable?', 'It is important to note that some questions fall outside the realm of science precisely because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.']
['What is important about objective evidence?', 'This need for objective evidence helps define the investigative process scientists follow, which will be described later in this chapter.']
['What is the science aimed at describing the fundamental aspects of our universe?', 'Physics is the science aimed at describing the fundamental aspects of our universe.']
['What does physics describe?', 'This includes what things are in it, what properties of those things are noticeable, and what processes those things or their properties undergo.']
['What does physics attempt to describe in simpler terms?', 'In simpler terms, physics attempts to describe the basic mechanisms that make our universe behave the way it does.']
['What are some examples of how physics helps?', 'For example, consider a smart phone.']
['What can physics help you with?', 'Physics describes how electric current interacts with the various circuits inside the device.']

['How does this knowledge help engineers select the appropriate materials and circuit layout when building the smart phone?', 'This knowledge helps engineers select the appropriate materials and circuit layout when building the smart phone.']
['What other things can physics help us with?', 'Next, consider a GPS.']
['What does physics describe?', 'Physics describes the relationship between the speed of an object, the distance over which it travels, and the time it takes to travel that distance.']
['How does this help GPS?', 'When you use a GPS device in a vehicle, it utilizes these physics relationships to determine the travel time from one location to another.']
['What was physics?', 'As our technology evolved over the centuries, physics expanded into many branches.']
['What did ancient peoples study?', 'Ancient peoples could only study things that they could see with the naked eye or otherwise experience without the aid of scientific equipment.']
['What did ancient peoples study?', 'This included the study of kinematics, which is the study of moving objects.']
['What did ancient peoples study?', 'For example, ancient people often studied the apparent motion of objects in the sky, such as the sun, moon, and stars.']
['What was the result of studying the apparent motion?', 'This is evident in the construction of prehistoric astronomical observatories, such as Stonehenge in England (shown in Figure 1.3).']

['What are statics and dynamics?', 'Ancient people also studied statics and dynamics, which focus on how objects start moving, stop moving, and change speed and direction in response to forces that push or pull on the objects.']
['what did they study to invent simple machines?', 'This early interest in kinematics and dynamics allowed humans to invent simple machines, such as the lever, the pulley, the ramp, and the wheel.']
['What kind of machines did they invent?', 'These simple machines were gradually combined and integrated to produce more complicated machines, such as wagons and cranes.']

['What did the machines do?', 'Machines allowed humans to gradually do more work more effectively in less time, allowing them to create larger and more complicated buildings and structures, many of which still exist today from ancient times.']
['What else is included in the document?', 'As technology advanced, the branches of physics diversified even more.']
['What are the branches of physics?', 'These include branches such as acoustics, the study of sound, and optics, the study of the light.']

['When did physics first become relevant?', 'In 1608, the invention of the telescope by a Germany spectacle maker, Hans Lippershey, led to huge breakthroughs in astronomy—the study of objects or phenomena in space.']

['What did Galileo Galilei begin the first studies of the solar system and the universe using a telescope?', 'One year later, in 1609, Galileo Galilei began the first studies of the solar system and the universe using a telescope.']
['Who did Galileo work with to construct his three laws of motion?', 'During the Renaissance era, Isaac Newton used observations made by Galileo to construct his three laws of motion.']
['What else did he study?', 'These laws were the standard for studying kinematics and dynamics even today.']
['What is another major branch of physics?', 'Another major branch of physics is thermodynamics, which includes the study of thermal energy and the transfer of heat.']
['Who studied the nature of heat and its relationship to work?', 'James Prescott Joule, an English physicist, studied the nature of heat and its relationship to work.']

['What did Joule study?', 'Joule’s work helped lay the foundation for the first of three laws of thermodynamics that describe how energy in our universe is transferred from one object to another or transformed from one form to another.']
['What motivated the study of thermodynamics?', 'Studies in thermodynamics were motivated by the need to make engines more efficient, keep people safe from the elements, and preserve food.']
['What happened in the 18th and 19th centuries?', 'The 18th and 19th centuries also saw great strides in the study of electricity and magnetism.']
['What is the study of electric charges and their movements?', 'Electricity involves the study of electric charges and their movements.']

['What is magnetism?', 'Magnetism had long ago been noticed as an attractive force between a magnetized object and a metal like iron, or between the opposite poles (North and South) of two magnetized objects.']
['What did Oersted show?', 'In 1820, Danish physicist Hans Christian Oersted showed that electric currents create magnetic fields.']
['What did Faraday show?', 'In 1831, English inventor Michael Faraday showed that moving a wire through a magnetic field could induce an electric current.']

['What other discoveries happened?', 'These studies led to the inventions of the electric motor and electric generator, which revolutionized human life by bringing electricity and magnetism into our machines.']
['Who discovered radioactive substances?', 'The end of the 19th century saw the discovery of radioactive substances by the scientists Marie and Pierre Curie.']
['What does nuclear physics involve?', 'Nuclear physics involves studying the nuclei of atoms, the source of nuclear radiation.']
['What is nuclear fission?', 'In the 20th century, the study of nuclear physics eventually led to the ability to split the nucleus of an atom, a process called nuclear fission.']
['What does it lead to?', 'This process is the basis for nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons.']

['What is quantum mechanics?', 'Also, the field of quantum mechanics, which involves the mechanics of atoms and molecules, saw great strides during the 20th century as our understanding of atoms and subatomic particles increased (see below).']
['What was the most important aspect of the 20th century?', 'Early in the 20th century, Albert Einstein revolutionized several branches of physics, especially relativity.']

['What was the revolution that relativity brought to our understanding of motion and the universe in general?', 'Relativity revolutionized our understanding of motion and the universe in general as described further in this chapter.']
['How is that being used today?', 'Now, in the 21st century, physicists continue to study these and many other branches of physics.']

['What is the main purpose of this document?', 'By studying the most important topics in physics, you will gain analytical abilities that will enable you to apply physics far beyond the scope of what can be included in a single book.']
['What will analytical skills help you to do?', 'These analytical skills will help you to excel academically, and they will also help you to think critically in any career you choose to pursue.']
['What does the word physics mean?', 'The word physics is thought to come from the Greek word phusis, meaning nature.']
['What is the study of nature called?', 'The study of nature later came to be called natural philosophy.']
['what is natural philosophy?', 'From ancient times through the Renaissance, natural philosophy encompassed many fields, including astronomy, biology, chemistry, mathematics, and medicine.']

['Did natural philosophy become separated?', 'Over the last few centuries, the growth of scientific knowledge has resulted in ever-increasing specialization and branching of natural philosophy into separate fields, with physics retaining the most basic facets.']

['What is the name of the physics that developed from the Renaissance to the end of the 19th century?', 'Physics, as it developed from the Renaissance to the end of the 19th century, is called classical physics.']
['Did physics become modern physics?', 'Revolutionary discoveries starting at the beginning of the 20th century transformed physics from classical physics to modern physics.']

['What is a classical object?', 'Classical physics is not an exact description of the universe, but it is an excellent approximation under the following conditions: (1) matter must be moving at speeds less than about 1 percent of the speed of light, (2) the objects dealt with must be large enough to be seen with the naked eye, and (3) only weak gravity, such as that generated by Earth, can be involved.']
['What is a classical object?', 'Very small objects, such as atoms and molecules, cannot be adequately explained by classical physics.']
['How are these three conditions applicable to the real world?', 'These three conditions apply to almost all of everyday experience.']
['Are there any other important details regarding the description?', 'As a result, most aspects of classical physics should make sense on an intuitive level.']

["What's included in the section entitled Physics: Past and Present?", 'Many laws of classical physics have been modified during the 20th century, resulting in revolutionary changes in technology, society, and our view of the universe.']
['What are two main reasons for this change?', 'As a result, many aspects of modern physics, which occur outside of the range of our everyday experience, may seem bizarre or unbelievable.']
["What are the two main reasons for the student's answer?", 'There are two main reasons.']

['What are the two main reasons that knowledge of classical physics is necessary to understand modern physics?', 'The first is that knowledge of classical physics is necessary to understand modern physics.']

['What is the second reason classical physics is still relevant?', 'The second reason is that classical physics still gives an accurate description of the universe under a wide range of everyday circumstances.']
['What revolutionary theories do modern physics include?', 'Modern physics includes two revolutionary theories: relativity and quantum mechanics.']
['What do these theories deal with?', 'These theories deal with the very fast and the very small, respectively.']
['When was the theory of relativity developed?', 'The theory of relativity was developed by Albert Einstein in 1905.']
['where did einstein get his ideas from?', 'By examining how two observers moving relative to each other would see the same phenomena, Einstein devised radical new ideas about time and space.']

['What did he discover?', 'He came to the startling conclusion that the measured length of an object travelling at high speeds (greater than about one percent of the speed of light) is shorter than the same object measured at rest.']
['What was he discovering?', 'Perhaps even more bizarre is the idea the time for the same process to occur is different depending on the motion of the observer.']
['Why is this so bizarre?', 'Time passes more slowly for an object travelling at high speeds.']
['why is that?', 'A trip to the nearest star system, Alpha Centauri, might take an astronaut 4.5 Earth years if the ship travels near the speed of light.']
['What else is interesting about this?', 'However, because time is slowed at higher speeds, the astronaut would age only 0.5 years during the trip.']
['What were some of the problems with Einstein’s ideas of relativity?', 'Einstein’s ideas of relativity were accepted after they were confirmed by numerous experiments.']
['What is the force that holds us to the Earth?', 'Gravity, the force that holds us to Earth, can also affect time and space.']
['What are some of the things it affects?', 'For example, time passes more slowly on Earth’s surface than for objects farther from the surface, such as a satellite in orbit.']
['What are some examples of the effect of time dilation?', 'The very accurate clocks on global positioning satellites have to correct for this.']
['What is time dilation?', 'They slowly keep getting ahead of clocks at Earth’s surface.']
['What causes time dilation?', 'This is called time dilation, and it occurs because gravity, in essence, slows down time.']
['What does it explain?', 'Large objects, like Earth, have strong enough gravity to distort space.']
['How do we understand it?', 'To visualize this idea, think about a bowling ball placed on a trampoline.']
['What happens if you hit it?', 'The bowling ball depresses or curves the surface of the trampoline.']

['How would a marble react to this?', 'If you rolled a marble across the trampoline, it would follow the surface of the trampoline, roll into the depression caused by the bowling ball, and hit the ball.']
['How does it affect the Earth?', 'Similarly, the Earth curves space around it in the shape of a funnel.']
['What causes objects to be attracted to earth?', 'These curves in space due to the Earth cause objects to be attracted to Earth (i.e., gravity).']
['What was the premise of our study?', 'Because of the way gravity affects space and time, Einstein stated that gravity affects the space-time continuum, as illustrated in Figure 1.4.']
['Why is this?', 'This is why time proceeds more slowly at Earth’s surface than in orbit.']
['Where does it appear to have stopped?', 'In black holes, whose gravity is hundreds of times that of Earth, time passes so slowly that it would appear to a far-away observer to have stopped!']
['What is the final question?', 'In summary, relativity says that in describing the universe, it is important to realize that time, space and speed are not absolute.']
['What can they appear differently for?', 'Instead, they can appear different to different observers.']
['What is the most amazing thing about Einstein?', 'Einstein’s ability to reason out relativity is even more amazing because we cannot see the effects of relativity in our everyday lives.']
['What is the second major theory of modern physics?', 'Quantum mechanics is the second major theory of modern physics.']
['What does quantum mechanics deal with?', 'Quantum mechanics deals with the very small, namely, the subatomic particles that make up atoms.']
['What are the smallest units of elements?', 'Atoms are the smallest units of elements.']
['What are the subatomic particles?', 'However, atoms themselves are constructed of even smaller subatomic particles, such as protons, neutrons and electrons.']
['What does quantum mechanics strive to describe?', 'Quantum mechanics strives to describe the properties and behavior of these and other subatomic particles.']
['What is the reason subatomic particles are considered unknowable?', 'Often, these particles do not behave in the ways expected by classical physics.']
['What is another reason for this?', 'One reason for this is that they are small enough to travel at great speeds, near the speed of light.']

['What is a particle collider?', 'At particle colliders, such as the Large Hadron Collider on the France-Swiss border, particle physicists can make subatomic particles travel at very high speeds within a 27 kilometers (17 miles) long superconducting tunnel.']
['What can they do with this particles?', 'They can then study the properties of the particles at high speeds, as well as collide them with each other to see how they exchange energy.']

['What are the properties they study?', 'This has led to many intriguing discoveries such as the Higgs-Boson particle, which gives matter the property of mass, and antimatter, which causes a huge energy release when it comes in contact with matter.']

['What is the present physics?', 'Physicists are currently trying to unify the two theories of modern physics, relativity and quantum mechanics, into a single, comprehensive theory called relativistic quantum mechanics.']
['Why would that be important?', 'Relating the behavior of subatomic particles to gravity, time, and space will allow us to explain how the universe works in a much more comprehensive way.']
['What do you want to know about the application of physics?', 'You need not be a scientist to use physics.']
['How is the use of physics beneficial in everyday situations?', 'On the contrary, knowledge of physics is useful in everyday situations as well as in nonscientific professions.']

['What are some examples of everyday uses of physics?', 'For example, physics can help you understand why you shouldn’t put metal in the microwave, why a black car radiator helps remove heat in a car engine, and why a white roof helps keep the inside of a house cool.']

['What other useful applications of physics are there?', 'The operation of a car’s ignition system, as well as the transmission of electrical signals through our nervous system, are much easier to understand when you think about them in terms of the basic physics of electricity.']
['What is physics used for?', 'Physics is the foundation of many important scientific disciplines.']
['What is the relationship between physics and other disciplines?', 'For example, chemistry deals with the interactions of atoms and molecules.']
['What is chemistry rooted in?', 'Not surprisingly, chemistry is rooted in atomic and molecular physics.']
['What is the relationship between physics and engineering?', 'Most branches of engineering are also applied physics.']

['What is the relationship between physics and architecture?', 'In architecture, physics is at the heart of determining structural stability, acoustics, heating, lighting, and cooling for buildings.']

['What is the relationship between geology and physics?', 'Parts of geology, the study of nonliving parts of Earth, rely heavily on physics; including radioactive dating, earthquake analysis, and heat transfer across Earth’s surface.']
['Do physics and other scientific disciplines have a lot in common?', 'Indeed, some disciplines, such as biophysics and geophysics, are hybrids of physics and other disciplines.']
['What is an application of physics?', 'Physics also describes the chemical processes that power the human body.']
['What medical application of physics is also mentioned?', 'Physics is involved in medical diagnostics, such as x-rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasonic blood flow measurements.']
['What medical therapy application is also mentioned?', 'Medical therapy Physics also has many applications in biology, the study of life.']
['What is physics involved with?', 'For example, physics describes how cells can protect themselves using their cell walls and cell membranes.']
['What medical therapy application of physics is not mentioned?', 'Medical therapy sometimes directly involves physics, such as in using X-rays to diagnose health conditions.']
['What can physics explain?', 'Physics can also explain what we perceive with our senses, such as how the ears detect sound or the eye detects color.']
['What is the most important information about physics?', 'In summary, physics studies many of the most basic aspects of science.']
['What is the importance of physics?', 'A knowledge of physics is, therefore, necessary to understand all other sciences.']
['Why does physics help?', 'This is because physics explains the most basic ways in which our universe works.']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'However, it is not necessary to formally study all applications of physics.']
['What are some examples of application?', 'A knowledge of the basic laws of physics will be most useful to you, so that you can use them to solve some everyday problems.']
['How can the study of physics help with solving problems?', 'In this way, the study of physics can improve your problem-solving skills.']
['What are scientific methods?', 'Scientists often plan and carry out investigations to answer questions about the universe around us.']
['What may lead these investigations?', 'These investigations may lead to natural laws.']
['What do natural laws mean?', 'Such laws are intrinsic to the universe, meaning that humans did not create them and cannot change them.']
['What can we do with them?', 'We can only discover and understand them.']

['What is special about discovering natural laws?', 'Their discovery is a very human endeavor, with all the elements of mystery, imagination, struggle, triumph, and disappointment inherent in any creative effort.']
['What is the key to discovering natural laws?', 'The cornerstone of discovering natural laws is observation.']
['What is the most important thing to know about science?', 'Science must describe the universe as it is, not as we imagine or wish it to be.']
['What are some other things that people are curious about?', 'We all are curious to some extent.']
['What do we try to understand?', 'We look around, make generalizations, and try to understand what we see.']
['What do we see when we look up at the sky?', 'For example, we look up and wonder whether one type of cloud signals an oncoming storm.']
['What do we see as we become more serious about exploring nature?', 'As we become serious about exploring nature, we become more organized and formal in collecting and analyzing data.']
['Why are we more organized?', 'We attempt greater precision, perform controlled experiments (if we can), and write down ideas about how data may be organized.']
['What do we do after we have collected data?', 'We then formulate models, theories, and laws based on the data we have collected, and communicate those results with others.']
['What is the scientific method?', 'This, in a nutshell, describes the scientific method that scientists employ to decide scientific issues on the basis of evidence from observation and experiment.']
['What can we learn about the investigation?', 'An investigation often begins with a scientist making an observation.']
["What is the scientist's observation about?", 'The scientist observes a pattern or trend within the natural world.']
['What does the observer want to do next?', 'Observation may generate questions that the scientist wishes to answer.']
['What does the scientist do to solve the problem?', 'Next, the scientist may perform some research about the topic and devise a hypothesis.']
['What is a testable statement that describes how something in the natural world works?', 'A hypothesis is a testable statement that describes how something in the natural world works.']
['What is an educated guess that explains something about an observation?', 'In essence, a hypothesis is an educated guess that explains something about an observation.']
['How are scientists able to test hypotheses?', 'Scientists may test the hypothesis by performing an experiment.']
['What happens during an experiment?', 'During an experiment, the scientist collects data that will help them learn about the phenomenon they are studying.']
['How do scientists interpret the data?', 'Then the scientists analyze the results of the experiment (that is, the data), often using statistical, mathematical, and/or graphical methods.']
['What does the analysis do?', 'From the data analysis, they draw conclusions.']
['What conclusion do they draw from their experiment?', 'They may conclude that their experiment either supports or rejects their hypothesis.']
['What does that mean?', 'If the hypothesis is supported, the scientist usually goes on to test another hypothesis related to the first.']

['What happens if the hypothesis is rejected?', 'If their hypothesis is rejected, they will often then test a new and different hypothesis in their effort to learn more about whatever they are studying.']
['Can you explain why scientific processes are important?', 'Scientific processes can be applied to many situations.']
['Can you give an example of a situation that needs to be applied to scientific processes?', 'Let’s say that you try to turn on your car, but it will not start.']
['What will you do if you have a car that won’t start?', 'You ask yourself, "Why won’t my car start?"']
['Why does my car not start?', 'You can now use scientific processes to answer this question.']
['What steps do you take in scientific processes?', 'First, you generate a hypothesis such as, "The car won’t start because it has no gasoline in the gas tank."']
['What does it mean to test this hypothesis?', 'To test this hypothesis, you put gasoline in the car and try to start it again.']
['What does this prove?', 'If the car starts, then your hypothesis is supported by the experiment.']
['Is it rejected?', 'If the car does not start, then your hypothesis is rejected.']
['What happens if you want to test a hypothesis?', 'You will then need to think up a new hypothesis to test such as, "My car won’t start because the fuel pump is broken."']
['What can you do with this information?', 'Hopefully, your investigations lead you to discover why the car won’t start and enable you to fix it.']
['What is modeling?', 'A model is a representation of something that is often too difficult (or impossible) to study directly.']
['What can be done with a model?', 'Models can take the form of physical models, equations, computer programs, or simulations—computer graphics/animations.']

['What are models used for?', 'Models are tools that are especially useful in modern physics because they let us visualize phenomena that we normally cannot observe with our senses, such as very small objects or objects that move at high speeds.']
['What can we do with a model?', 'For example, we can understand the structure of an atom using models, despite the fact that no one has ever seen an atom with their own eyes.']
['Are models always correct?', 'Models are always approximate, so they are simpler to consider than the real situation; the more complete a model is, the more complicated it must be.']
['What can we do with models?', 'Models put the intangible or the extremely complex into human terms that we can visualize, discuss, and hypothesize about.']
['What are scientific models constructed based on?', 'Scientific models are constructed based on the results of previous experiments.']
['What problems do models have?', 'Even still, models often only describe a phenomenon partially or in a few limited situations.']
['What is the reason some models do not describe a phenomenon completely?', 'Some phenomena are so complex that they may be impossible to model them in their entirety, even using computers.']

['What is an example of a model?', 'An example is the electron cloud model of the atom in which electrons are moving around the atom’s center in distinct clouds, that represent the likelihood of finding an electron in different places.']
['What does the electron cloud model help us to visualize?', 'This model helps us to visualize the structure of an atom.']
['What does this model not show us?', 'However, it does not show us exactly where an electron will be within its cloud at any one particular time.']
['What are some models physicists use?', 'As mentioned previously, physicists use a variety of models including equations, physical models, computer simulations, etc.']
['What type of models are used in chemistry and physics to model molecules?', 'For example, three-dimensional models are often commonly used in chemistry and physics to model molecules.']

['What other type of models are used?', 'Properties other than appearance or location are usually modelled using mathematics, where functions are used to show how these properties relate to one another.']
['What type of computer simulations are used to model processes?', 'Processes such as the formation of a star or the planets, can also be modelled using computer simulations.']

['What can a simulation do for us?', 'Once a simulation is correctly programmed based on actual experimental data, the simulation can allow us to view processes that happened in the past or happen too quickly or slowly for us to observe directly.']
['How do scientists alter and affects the planet formation?', 'In addition, scientists can also run virtual experiments using computer-based models.']

['How are models used to study planet formation?', 'In a model of planet formation, for example, the scientist could alter the amount or type of rocks present in space and see how it affects planet formation.']
['What kind of models do scientists use?', 'Scientists use models and experimental results to construct explanations of observations or design solutions to problems.']
['What is a benefit of using models?', 'For example, one way to make a car more fuel efficient is to reduce the friction or drag caused by air flowing around the moving car.']
['How can this be done?', 'This can be done by designing the body shape of the car to be more aerodynamic, such as by using rounded corners instead of sharp ones.']
['What are some other methods for the car design?', 'Engineers can then construct physical models of the car body, place them in a wind tunnel, and examine the flow of air around the model.']
['What other methods do they use to design cars?', 'This can also be done mathematically in a computer simulation.']
['What can they examine?', 'The air flow pattern can be analyzed for regions smooth air flow and for eddies that indicate drag.']
['How is the design of the car altered?', 'The model of the car body may have to be altered slightly to produce the smoothest pattern of air flow (i.e., the least drag).']
['What is the purpose of altering the model?', 'The pattern with the least drag may be the solution to increasing fuel efficiency of the car.']
['What might be the solution to the car design problem?', 'This solution might then be incorporated into the car design.']
['What is a scientific law?', 'A scientific law is a description of a pattern in nature that is true in all circumstances that have been studied.']
['What do physical laws mean?', 'That is, physical laws are meant to be universal, meaning that they apply throughout the known universe.']
['What are the laws?', 'Laws are often also concise, whereas theories are more complicated.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about these laws?', 'A law can be expressed in the form of a single sentence or mathematical equation.']

['What is an example of how it is stated?', 'For example, Newton’s second law of motion, which relates the motion of an object to the force applied (F), the mass of the object (m), and the object’s acceleration (a), is simply stated using the equation']

['What are scientific ideas and explanations that are true in many, but not all situations in the universe called?', 'Scientific ideas and explanations that are true in many, but not all situations in the universe are usually called principles.']
['What are some examples of principles?', 'An example is Pascal’s principle, which explains properties of liquids, but not solids or gases.']
['What is the distinction between laws and principles?', 'However, the distinction between laws and principles is sometimes not carefully made in science.']

['What is an explanation for patterns in nature that is supported by much scientific evidence and verified multiple times by multiple researchers?', 'A theory is an explanation for patterns in nature that is supported by much scientific evidence and verified multiple times by multiple researchers.']

['What are the differences between a theory and hypothesis?', 'While many people confuse theories with educated guesses or hypotheses, theories have withstood more rigorous testing and verification than hypotheses.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'As a closing idea about scientific processes, we want to point out that scientific laws and theories, even those that have been supported by experiments for centuries, can still be changed by new discoveries.']
['Why is this true?', 'This is especially true when new technologies emerge that allow us to observe things that were formerly unobservable.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'Imagine how viewing previously invisible objects with a microscope or viewing Earth for the first time from space may have instantly changed our scientific theories and laws!']
['What is the most important thing about this?', 'The constant retesting and perfecting of our scientific laws and theories allows our knowledge of nature to progress.']
['What is another interesting fact about scientists?', 'For this reason, many scientists are reluctant to say that their studies prove anything.']
['What do scientists say to support their findings?', 'By saying support instead of prove, it keeps the door open for future discoveries, even if they won’t occur for centuries or even millennia.']
['Did you have any questions for me at the beginning of your study?', 'Physicists, like other scientists, make observations and ask basic questions.']
['What are the basic questions scientists ask?', 'To answer these questions, they make measurements with various instruments (e.g., meter stick, balance, stopwatch, etc.).']
['What are the measurements of physical quantities expressed in terms of?', 'The measurements of physical quantities are expressed in terms of units, which are standardized values.']
['How are physical quantities measured?', 'For example, the length of a race, which is a physical quantity, can be expressed in meters (for sprinters) or kilometers (for long distance runners).']
['What is the main reason for standardized values?', 'Without standardized units, it would be extremely difficult for scientists to express and compare measured values in a meaningful way.']
['What is the system of units?', 'In any system of units, the units for some physical quantities must be defined through a measurement process.']
['What are these physical quantities called?', 'These are called the base quantities for that system and their units are the system’s base units.']
['What are the base quantities used for?', 'All other physical quantities can then be expressed as algebraic combinations of the base quantities.']
['What is significant about the system of units?', 'Each of these physical quantities is then known as a derived quantity and each unit is called a derived unit.']

['What was the rationale behind choosing physical quantities?', 'The choice of base quantities is somewhat arbitrary, as long as they are independent of each other and all other quantities can be derived from them.']
['what is the goal of choosing physically precise quantities?', 'Typically, the goal is to choose physical quantities that can be measured accurately to a high precision as the base quantities.']
['Why did the base quantities choose physical quantities?', 'The reason for this is simple.']

['How are the derived units determined?', 'Since the derived units can be expressed as algebraic combinations of the base units, they can only be as accurate and precise as the base units from which they are derived.']
['what is ISQ?', 'Based on such considerations, the International Standards Organization recommends using seven base quantities, which form the International System of Quantities (ISQ).']
['What are the base quantities used to define the SI base units?', 'These are the base quantities used to define the SI base units.']
['who derived the SI base units from the base quantities?', 'lists these seven ISQ base quantities and the corresponding SI base units.']
['What is the SI unit for length?', 'The SI unit for length is the meter (m).']
['What has the meter been defined as?', 'The definition of the meter has changed over time to become more accurate and precise.']
['What was the first definition of the meter?', 'The meter was first defined in 1791 as 1/10,000,000 of the distance from the equator to the North Pole.']
['How did it change?', 'This measurement was improved in 1889 by redefining the meter to be the distance between two engraved lines on a platinum-iridium bar.']
['Where is the bar located?', '(The bar is now housed at the International Bureau of Weights and Meaures, near Paris).']
['Did anyone else change the definition of the meter?', 'By 1960, some distances could be measured more precisely by comparing them to wavelengths of light.']
['How did they define the meter?', 'The meter was redefined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange light emitted by krypton atoms.']
['What other changes were made?', 'In 1983, the meter was given its present definition as the distance light travels in a vacuum in 1/ 299,792,458 of a second.']

['What is the SI unit for mass?', 'The SI unit for mass is the kilogram (abbreviated kg); it was previously defined to be the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept with the old meter standard at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures near Paris.']

['Where are these replicas kept?', 'Exact replicas of the previously defined kilogram are also kept at the United States’ National Institute of Standards and Technology, or NIST, located in Gaithersburg, Maryland outside of Washington D.C., and at other locations around the world.']
['What can you tell me about the standard mass?', 'The determination of all other masses could be ultimately traced to a comparison with the standard mass.']

['what was the iridium cylinder used for?', 'Even though the platinum-iridium cylinder was resistant to corrosion, airborne contaminants were able to adhere to its surface, slightly changing its mass over time.']
['What is the current definition of the kilogram?', 'In May 2019, the scientific community adopted a more stable definition of the kilogram.']

['What is the kilogram defined in terms of?', "The kilogram is now defined in terms of the second, the meter, and Planck's constant, h (a quantum mechanical value that relates a photon's energy to its frequency)."]
['what is the second?', 'The SI unit for time, the second (s) also has a long history.']
['What was its history?', 'For many years it was defined as 1/86,400 of an average solar day.']
['What is the average solar day?', 'However, the average solar day is actually very gradually getting longer due to gradual slowing of Earth’s rotation.']
['What is the importance of accuracy in the fundamental units?', 'Accuracy in the fundamental units is essential, since all other measurements are derived from them.']
['What did they do to make it more accurate?', 'Therefore, a new standard was adopted to define the second in terms of a non-varying, or constant, physical phenomenon.']
['What is significant about the new standard?', 'One constant phenomenon is the very steady vibration of Cesium atoms, which can be observed and counted.']
['What is the basis of the cesium atomic clock?', 'This vibration forms the basis of the cesium atomic clock.']
['What was the final definition of the second?', 'In 1967, the second was redefined as the time required for 9,192,631,770 Cesium atom vibrations.']
['What unit is used to measure current?', 'Electric current is measured in the ampere (A), named after Andre Ampere.']
['How many amperes are in a current?', 'You have probably heard of amperes, or amps, when people discuss electrical currents or electrical devices.']

['What does an ampere have to do with anything?', 'Understanding an ampere requires a basic understanding of electricity and magnetism, something that will be explored in depth in later chapters of this book.']
['What does current do?', 'Basically, two parallel wires with an electric current running through them will produce an attractive force on each other.']

['How does current affect anything?', 'One ampere is defined as the amount of electric current that will produce an attractive force of 2.7  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–7 newton per meter of separation between the two wires (the newton is the derived unit of force).']
['What is the SI unit of temperature?', 'The SI unit of temperature is the kelvin (or kelvins, but not degrees kelvin).']
['What is the name of the person who named the scale?', 'This scale is named after physicist William Thomson, Lord Kelvin, who was the first to call for an absolute temperature scale.']
['What is the basis of the Kelvin scale?', 'The Kelvin scale is based on absolute zero.']

['What is the point at which all thermal energy has been removed from all atoms or molecules in a system?', 'This is the point at which all thermal energy has been removed from all atoms or molecules in a system.']
['What is the temperature of 0 K?', 'This temperature, 0 K, is equal to −273.15 °C and −459.67 °F.']
['What is the Kelvin scale?', 'Conveniently, the Kelvin scale actually changes in the same way as the Celsius scale.']
['How is celsius temperature different?', 'For example, the freezing point (0 °C) and boiling points of water (100 °C) are 100 degrees apart on the Celsius scale.']
['Is this the same for kelvin scale?', 'These two temperatures are also 100 kelvins apart (freezing point = 273.15 K; boiling point = 373.15 K).']
['What did you learn about physical objects or phenomena?', 'Physical objects or phenomena may vary widely.']
['What is the reason for the wide range of sizes of objects?', 'For example, the size of objects varies from something very small (like an atom) to something very large (like a star).']
['What else did you learn about the metric system?', 'Yet the standard metric unit of length is the meter.']
['What is the metric system?', 'So, the metric system includes many prefixes that can be attached to a unit.']
['How are they used?', 'Each prefix is based on factors of 10 (10, 100, 1,000, etc., as well as 0.1, 0.01, 0.001, etc.).']
['How are the metric prefixes and symbols used?', 'Table 1.2 gives the metric prefixes and symbols used to denote the different various factors of 10 in the metric system.']
['What is the metric system convenient for?', 'The metric system is convenient because conversions between metric units can be done simply by moving the decimal place of a number.']
['Why is that?', 'This is because the metric prefixes are sequential powers of 10.']
['How many centimeters are in a meter?', 'There are 100 centimeters in a meter, 1000 meters in a kilometer, and so on.']

['What are some other units that we can use in the metric system?', 'In nonmetric systems, such as U.S. customary units, the relationships are less simple—there are 12 inches in a foot, 5,280 feet in a mile, 4 quarts in a gallon, and so on.']

['What is another advantage of the metric system?', 'Another advantage of the metric system is that the same unit can be used over extremely large ranges of values simply by switching to the most-appropriate metric prefix.']
['What do we use this for?', 'For example, distances in meters are suitable for building construction, but kilometers are used to describe road construction.']

['How is it helpful to measure very small or very large objects?', 'Therefore, with the metric system, there is no need to invent new units when measuring very small or very large objects—you just have to move the decimal point (and use the appropriate prefix).']
['What is the Table 1.3 about?', 'Table 1.3 lists known lengths, masses, and time measurements.']
['What is significant about the table?', 'You can see that scientists use a range of measurement units.']
['What does this wide range demonstrates?', 'This wide range demonstrates the vastness and complexity of the universe, as well as the breadth of phenomena physicists study.']

['What else is significant about the table?', 'As you examine this table, note how the metric system allows us to discuss and compare an enormous range of phenomena, using one system of measurement (Figure 1.16 and Figure 1.17).']
['What is scientific notation?', 'Scientific notation is a way of writing numbers that are too large or small to be conveniently written as a decimal.']
['What is an example of a number?', 'For example, consider the number 840,000,000,000,000.']
['What does 840,000,000 mean?', 'It’s a rather large number to write out.']
['How is it written?', 'The scientific notation for this number is 8.40  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  1014.']
['What is the general format of scientific notation?', 'Scientific notation follows this general format']
['What is the format in which we are studying?', 'In this format x is the value of the measurement with all placeholder zeros removed.']
['What is the actual measurement value of the x-axis?', 'In the example above, x is 8.4.']
['What is the number 10y?', 'The x is multiplied by a factor, 10y, which indicates the number of placeholder zeros in the measurement.']
['What are placeholder zeros?', 'Placeholder zeros are those at the end of a number that is 10 or greater, and at the beginning of a decimal number that is less than 1.']
['What is the factor of 1014?', 'In the example above, the factor is 1014.']
['How does this tell you what to do with the decimal number?', 'This tells you that you should move the decimal point 14 positions to the right, filling in placeholder zeros as you go.']
['Did you move all of the zeros?', 'In this case, moving the decimal point 14 places creates only 13 placeholder zeros, indicating that the actual measurement value is 840,000,000,000,000.']
['What else is important?', 'Numbers that are fractions can be indicated by scientific notation as well.']
['What should we consider for our next question?', 'Consider the number 0.0000045.']
['What is the scientific notation of the number 4.5 $$(times)$$ 10–6?', 'Its scientific notation is 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–6.']
['How is the scientific notation formatted?', 'Its scientific notation has the same format']
['Did you get a correct answer?', 'Here, x is 4.5.']
['What happens to y in this case?', 'However, the value of y in the 10y factor is negative, which indicates that the measurement is a fraction of 1.']
['What do you need to do if the decimal place is negative?', 'Therefore, we move the decimal place to the left, for a negative y.']

['How does the decimal point affect the number?', 'In our example of 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–6, the decimal point would be moved to the left six times to yield the original number, which would be 0.0000045.']
['What is the order of magnitude?', 'The term order of magnitude refers to the power of 10 when numbers are expressed in scientific notation.']
['Why are they said to be of the same order?', 'Quantities that have the same power of 10 when expressed in scientific notation, or come close to it, are said to be of the same order of magnitude.']
['What can you tell me about the next question?', 'For example, the number 800 can be written as 8  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  102, and the number 450 can be written as 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  102.']
['What is the value of y?', 'Both numbers have the same value for y.']
['What are the two values?', 'Therefore, 800 and 450 are of the same order of magnitude.']
['How is the topic used to tell a story?', 'Similarly, 101 and 99 would be regarded as the same order of magnitude, 102.']
['What can you tell me about order of magnitude?', 'Order of magnitude can be thought of as a ballpark estimate for the scale of a value.']
['What is the most common example of this type of estimate?', 'The diameter of an atom is on the order of 10−9 m, while the diameter of the sun is on the order of 109 m.']
['How much difference is there between the two values?', 'These two values are 18 orders of magnitude apart.']
['What kind of units do you need to convert?', 'It is often necessary to convert from one type of unit to another.']

['For what reason do you need to convert the quantities in liters to cups?', 'For example, if you are reading a European cookbook in the United States, some quantities may be expressed in liters and you need to convert them to cups.']
['Who else might need to convert units?', 'A Canadian tourist driving through the United States might want to convert miles to kilometers, to have a sense of how far away his next destination is.']
['Who else might need to convert units?', 'A doctor in the United States might convert a patient’s weight in pounds to kilograms.']
['What are the important parts of this?', 'Let’s consider a simple example of how to convert units within the metric system.']
['What is the first step in solving this problem?', 'First, we need to determine a conversion factor.']
['What is a conversion factor?', 'A conversion factor is a ratio expressing how many of one unit are equal to another unit.']
['How does it compare to a fraction?', 'A conversion factor is simply a fraction which equals 1.']
['How can this be used to find a value?', 'You can multiply any number by 1 and get the same value.']
['What is an example of a conversion factor?', 'When you multiply a number by a conversion factor, you are simply multiplying it by one.']

['What are some examples of these factors?', 'For example, the following are conversion factors: (1 foot)/(12 inches) = 1 to convert inches to feet, (1 meter)/(100 centimeters) = 1 to convert centimeters to meters, (1 minute)/(60 seconds) = 1 to convert seconds to minutes.']
['What do you mean by "Now we can set up our unit conversion."?', 'Now we can set up our unit conversion.']
['How do we set up our unit conversion?', 'We will write the units that we have and then multiply them by the conversion factor (1 km/1,000m) = 1, so we are simply multiplying 80m by 1:']
['When units cancel, what happens?', 'When there is a unit in the original number, and a unit in the denominator (bottom) of the conversion factor, the units cancel.']
['What is the value of seconds in this case?', 'In this case, hours and minutes cancel and the value in seconds remains.']
['What is the main idea of the study material?', 'You can use this method to convert between any types of unit, including between the U.S. customary system and metric system.']
['What else is important?', 'Notice also that, although you can multiply and divide units algebraically, you cannot add or subtract different units.']
['Do you have anything else?', 'An expression like 10 km + 5 kg makes no sense.']
['What is the difference between a meter and a kilometer?', 'Even adding two lengths in different units, such as 10 km + 20 m does not make sense.']
['What do you do instead of dividing the lengths in half?', 'You express both lengths in the same unit.']
['What else does the paper contain?', 'See Appendix C for a more complete list of conversion factors.']
['What is the relevance to science?', 'Science is based on experimentation that requires good measurements.']
['What is the validity of a measurement?', 'The validity of a measurement can be described in terms of its accuracy and its precision (see Figure 1.19 and Figure 1.20).']
['What is the definition of accuracy?', 'Accuracy is how close a measurement is to the correct value for that measurement.']
['What are you measuring?', 'For example, let us say that you are measuring the length of standard piece of printer paper.']
['What is the stated value of the paper?', 'The packaging in which you purchased the paper states that it is 11 inches long, and suppose this stated value is correct.']
['What is important to know about the paper?', 'You measure the length of the paper three times and obtain the following measurements: 11.1 inches, 11.2 inches, and 10.9 inches.']
['How is the accuracy of this measurement?', 'These measurements are quite accurate because they are very close to the correct value of 11.0 inches.']
['Why is that important?', 'In contrast, if you had obtained a measurement of 12 inches, your measurement would not be very accurate.']
['What is important to know about measuring instruments?', 'This is why measuring instruments are calibrated based on a known measurement.']
['How is the instrument calibrated?', 'If the instrument consistently returns the correct value of the known measurement, it is safe for use in finding unknown values.']
['What does precision mean?', 'Precision states how well repeated measurements of something generate the same or similar results.']
['What does the precision of measurements refer to?', 'Therefore, the precision of measurements refers to how close together the measurements are when you measure the same thing several times.']
['What is the range of a measurement?', 'One way to analyze the precision of measurements would be to determine the range, or difference between the lowest and the highest measured values.']
['What is the difference between the lowest and highest values?', 'In the case of the printer paper measurements, the lowest value was 10.9 inches and the highest value was 11.2 inches.']
['How big was the range in inches?', 'Thus, the measured values deviated from each other by, at most, 0.3 inches.']
['What happened because of the range difference?', 'These measurements were reasonably precise because they varied by only a fraction of an inch.']

['How much more variation was there than the measured values?', 'However, if the measured values had been 10.9 inches, 11.1 inches, and 11.9 inches, then the measurements would not be very precise because there is a lot of variation from one measurement to another.']
['What does this include?', 'The measurements in the paper example are both accurate and precise, but in some cases, measurements are accurate but not precise, or they are precise but not accurate.']
['What are some examples of accuracy and precision?', 'Let us consider a GPS system that is attempting to locate the position of a restaurant in a city.']
['What did the restaurant do?', 'Think of the restaurant location as existing at the center of a bull’s-eye target.']
['What did you find most important?', 'Then think of each GPS attempt to locate the restaurant as a black dot on the bull’s eye.']

['What do the measurements show?', 'In Figure 1.21, you can see that the GPS measurements are spread far apart from each other, but they are all relatively close to the actual location of the restaurant at the center of the target.']
['What does this mean?', 'This indicates a low precision, high accuracy measuring system.']

['What figure shows the GPS measurements concentrated quite closely to one another, but they are far away from the target location?', 'However, in Figure 1.22, the GPS measurements are concentrated quite closely to one another, but they are far away from the target location.']
['What does this mean?', 'This indicates a high precision, low accuracy measuring system.']

['Which figure shows the GPS is both precise and accurate, allowing the restaurant to be located?', 'Finally, in Figure 1.23, the GPS is both precise and accurate, allowing the restaurant to be located.']
['What determines the uncertainty of a measurement?', 'The accuracy and precision of a measuring system determine the uncertainty of its measurements.']
['What happens in that case?', 'Uncertainty is a way to describe how much your measured value deviates from the actual value that the object has.']
['What happens if the measurement is not very accurate?', 'If your measurements are not very accurate or precise, then the uncertainty of your values will be very high.']
['What does the term uncertainty mean?', 'In more general terms, uncertainty can be thought of as a disclaimer for your measured values.']
['Can you give me an example of how it is disclaimed?', 'For example, if someone asked you to provide the mileage on your car, you might say that it is 45,000 miles, plus or minus 500 miles.']
['Is that a way to explain uncertainty?', 'The plus or minus amount is the uncertainty in your value.']

['What is the difference between plus and minus?', 'That is, you are indicating that the actual mileage of your car might be as low as 44,500 miles or as high as 45,500 miles, or anywhere in between.']
['Do all measurements have uncertainty?', 'All measurements contain some amount of uncertainty.']

['Do you need to use a specific measurement to determine the length of the paper?', 'In our example of measuring the length of the paper, we might say that the length of the paper is 11 inches plus or minus 0.2 inches or 11.0 ± 0.2 inches.']
['How can you decipher the A?', 'The uncertainty in a measurement, A, is often denoted as δA ("delta A"),']
['Uncertainty about the measuring procedure:', 'Limitations of the measuring device']
['What can affect the accuracy of a measurement?', 'The skill of the person making the measurement Irregularities in the object being measured']
['What is the most important factor in determining the outcome of a game?', 'Any other factors that affect the outcome (highly dependent on the situation)']

['What is an example of uncertainty?', 'In the printer paper example uncertainty could be caused by: the fact that the smallest division on the ruler is 0.1 inches, the person using the ruler has bad eyesight, or uncertainty caused by the paper cutting machine (e.g., one side of the paper is slightly longer than the other.)']
['What is the good practice?', 'It is good practice to carefully consider all possible sources of uncertainty in a measurement and reduce or eliminate them,']
['What is a percent of the measured value?', 'One method of expressing uncertainty is as a percent of the measured value.']
['What does it mean to be percent uncertain?', 'If a measurement, A, is expressed with uncertainty, δA, the percent uncertainty is']
['What is uncertainty in anything calculated from measured quantities?', 'There is an uncertainty in anything calculated from measured quantities.']

['What is an example of uncertainty in calculations?', 'For example, the area of a floor calculated from measurements of its length and width has an uncertainty because the both the length and width have uncertainties.']
['How do you handle uncertainties in calculations?', 'If the measurements in the calculation have small uncertainties (a few percent or less), then the method of adding percents can be used.']

['What does this mean?', 'This method says that the percent uncertainty in a quantity calculated by multiplication or division is the sum of the percent uncertainties in the items used to make the calculation.']

['What else does this method do?', 'For example, if a floor has a length of 4.00 m and a width of 3.00 m, with uncertainties of 2 percent and 1 percent, respectively, then the area of the floor is 12.0 m2 and has an uncertainty of 3 percent (expressed as an area this is 0.36 m2, which we round to 0.4 m2 since the area of the floor is given to a tenth of a square meter).']
['What is the importance of the precision?', 'An important factor in the accuracy and precision of measurements is the precision of the measuring tool.']
['What is a precise measuring tool?', 'In general, a precise measuring tool is one that can measure values in very small increments.']
['What kind of values does it measure?', 'For example, consider measuring the thickness of a coin.']
['How does it differ from a ruler?', 'A standard ruler can measure thickness to the nearest millimeter, while a micrometer can measure the thickness to the nearest 0.005 millimeter.']
['What makes the micrometer more precise?', 'The micrometer is a more precise measuring tool because it can measure extremely small differences in thickness.']
['What is the purpose of a precise tool?', 'The more precise the measuring tool, the more precise and accurate the measurements can be.']

['What else do you have to know about the document?', 'When we express measured values, we can only list as many digits as we initially measured with our measuring tool (such as the rulers shown in Figure 1.24).']
['What are some examples of the most common ones?', 'For example, if you use a standard ruler to measure the length of a stick, you may measure it with a decimeter ruler as 3.6 cm.']
['How did you go about correcting this?', 'You could not express this value as 3.65 cm because your measuring tool was not precise enough to measure a hundredth of a centimeter.']

['What should you know about the last digit in a measured value?', 'It should be noted that the last digit in a measured value has been estimated in some way by the person performing the measurement.']
['What is the reason he did this?', 'For example, the person measuring the length of a stick with a ruler notices that the stick length seems to be somewhere in between 36 mm and 37 mm.']
['What is the person doing then?', 'He or she must estimate the value of the last digit.']
['How do you know that the last digit is not the actual value?', 'The rule is that the last digit written down in a measurement is the first digit with some uncertainty.']
['Are there any other important topics that you have to know about?', 'For example, the last measured value 36.5 mm has three digits, or three significant figures.']
['What does the number of significant figures in a measurement indicate?', 'The number of significant figures in a measurement indicates the precision of the measuring tool.']
['What is the precision of a measuring tool?', 'The more precise a measuring tool is, the greater the number of significant figures it can report.']
['What does special consideration mean?', 'Special consideration is given to zeros when counting significant figures.']
['What is another example given?', 'For example, the zeros in 0.053 are not significant because they are only placeholders that locate the decimal point.']
['What is the difference between 0.053 and 0.055?', 'There are two significant figures in 0.053—the 5 and the 3.']
['What are other examples given?', 'However, if the zero occurs between other significant figures, the zeros are significant.']
['What other examples are given?', 'For example, both zeros in 10.053 are significant, as these zeros were actually measured.']
['How many significant figures are in 10.053?', 'Therefore, the 10.053 placeholder has five significant figures.']
['What is the difference between the zeros in 1300 and 1300?', 'The zeros in 1300 may or may not be significant, depending on the style of writing numbers.']
['What are the possibilities for the zeros in 1300?', 'They could mean the number is known to the last zero, or the zeros could be placeholders.']
['What does special consideration mean?', 'So 1300 could have two, three, or four significant figures.']
['What is the suggested solution to this issue?', 'To avoid this ambiguity, write 1300 in scientific notation as 1.3 × 103.']

['What is a good method for rounding?', 'It is a good idea to keep extra significant figures while calculating, and to round off to the correct number of significant figures only in the final answers.']
['Why is that important?', 'The reason is that small errors from rounding while calculating can sometimes produce significant errors in the final answer.']

['What is the final answer for the first digit?', 'Keeping all significant during the calculation gives 48.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'If the input has fewer significant figures, the answer will also have fewer significant figures.']
['Why is this?', 'Care is also taken that the number of significant figures is reasonable for the situation posed.']

['What is the purpose of the graphing in physics?', 'Most results in science are presented in scientific journal articles using graphs.']
['What is the main reason for using graphs?', 'Graphs present data in a way that is easy to visualize for humans in general, especially someone unfamiliar with what is being studied.']
['Are they useful for anything else?', 'They are also useful for presenting large amounts of data or data with complicated trends in an easily-readable way.']

['What is the best graph for showing how one quantity changes in response to the other?', 'One commonly-used graph in physics and other sciences is the line graph, probably because it is the best graph for showing how one quantity changes in response to the other.']
['What is the line graph used for?', 'Let’s build a line graph based on the data in Table 1.5, which shows the measured distance that a train travels from its station versus time.']
['What are two things that change along the graph?', 'Our two variables, or things that change along the graph, are time in minutes, and distance from the station, in kilometers.']

['What should I do first?', 'Draw the two axes.']
['What is the horizontal axis, or x-axis, called?', 'The horizontal axis, or x-axis, shows the independent variable, which is the variable that is controlled or manipulated.']

['What is the vertical axis?', 'The vertical axis, or y-axis, shows the dependent variable, the non-manipulated variable that changes with (or is dependent on) the value of the independent variable.']
['What is the independent variable in the data above?', 'In the data above, time is the independent variable and should be plotted on the x-axis.']
['What is the dependent variable?', 'Distance from the station is the dependent variable and should be plotted on the y-axis.']
['What else should you do?', 'Label each axes on the graph with the name of each variable, followed by the symbol for its units in parentheses.']
['What else should you do?', 'Be sure to leave room so that you can number each axis.']
['How do you label the x-axis?', 'In this example, use Time (min) as the label for the x-axis.']
['What else must you do?', 'Next, you must determine the best scale to use for numbering each axis.']
['How do you determine the scale?', 'Because the time values on the x-axis are taken every 10 minutes, we could easily number the x-axis from 0 to 70 minutes with a tick mark every 10 minutes.']
['What else should be included in the y-axis scale?', 'Likewise, the y-axis scale should start low enough and continue high enough to include all of the distance from station values.']
['What scale should be used to measure distance?', 'A scale from 0 km to 160 km should suffice, perhaps with a tick mark every 10 km.']
['What else?', 'In general, you want to pick a scale for both axes that 1) shows all of your data, and 2) makes it easy to identify trends in your data.']
['Is there anything else you should know?', 'If you make your scale too large, it will be harder to see how your data change.']
['What else?', 'Likewise, the smaller and more fine you make your scale, the more space you will need to make the graph.']
['What else should be done?', 'The number of significant figures in the axis values should be coarser than the number of significant figures in the measurements.']
['What else do you need to do before you can begin plotting your data?', 'Now that your axes are ready, you can begin plotting your data.']

['What is another reason to use real data?', 'Real data may have some inaccuracies, and the plotted points may not all fall on the trend line.']

['What does the y-intercept tell?', 'The y-intercept, therefore, lets you know immediately where on the y-axis the plot line begins.']

['What is the slope of a perfectly horizontal line?', 'The slope of a perfectly horizontal line will equal zero, while the slope of a perfectly vertical line will be undefined because you cannot divide by zero.']
['What does a positive slope indicate?', 'A positive slope indicates that the line moves up the y-axis as the x-value increases while a negative slope means that the line moves down the y-axis.']

['What does the formula mean?', 'The formula  $$\\(y = mx + b\\)$$  only applies to linear relationships, or ones that produce a straight line.']
['What is another type of line in physics?', 'Another common type of line in physics is the quadratic relationship, which occurs when one of the variables is squared.']

['What other relationship does physics use?', 'One quadratic relationship in physics is the relation between the speed of an object its centripetal acceleration, which is used to determine the force needed to keep an object moving in a circle.']
['What is another type of relationship used in physics?', 'Another common relationship in physics is the inverse relationship, in which one variable decreases whenever the other variable increases.']
['What are some examples of physics?', 'An example in physics is Coulomb’s law.']
['What does the law state?', 'As the distance between two charged objects increases, the electrical force between the two charged objects decreases.']
['What other relationships are there?', 'Inverse proportionality, such the relation between x and y in the equation']

['What are the other kinds of relationships?', 'A third commonly-seen relationship is the exponential relationship, in which a change in the independent variable produces a proportional change in the dependent variable.']
['What are the consequences of this relationship?', 'As the value of the dependent variable gets larger, its rate of growth also increases.']
['What is an example of this type of relationship?', 'For example, bacteria often reproduce at an exponential rate when grown under ideal conditions.']
['Why do they reproduce at an exponential rate?', 'As each generation passes, there are more and more bacteria to reproduce.']
['What happens to the bacterial population when the population is large?', 'As a result, the growth rate of the bacterial population increases every generation.']
['What else would we want to know about the variable?', 'Sometimes a variable can have a very large range of values.']
