['What other options are there?', 'One option is to use a logarithmic (log) scale.']
['What does it mean to use a logarithmic scale?', 'In a logarithmic scale, the value each mark labels is the previous mark’s value multiplied by some constant.']
['What is the log base of a scale?', 'For a log base 10 scale, each mark labels a value that is 10 times the value of the mark before it.']
['What would you write on the log base 10 scale?', 'Therefore, a base 10 logarithmic scale would be numbered: 0, 10, 100, 1,000, etc.']

['How would you use the logarithmic scale?', 'You can see how the logarithmic scale covers a much larger range of values than the corresponding linear scale, in which the marks would label the values 0, 10, 20, 30, and so on.']
['What is a semi-log plot?', 'If you use a logarithmic scale on one axis of the graph and a linear scale on the other axis, you are using a semi-log plot.']
['What can you tell me about the Richter scale?', 'The Richter scale, which measures the strength of earthquakes, uses a semi-log plot.']

['What else can you tell me about log plot?', 'The degree of ground movement is plotted on a logarithmic scale against the assigned intensity level of the earthquake, which ranges linearly from 1-10 (Figure 1.29 (a)).']
['What is a log-log plot?', 'If a graph has both axes in a logarithmic scale, then it is referred to as a log-log plot.']
['What type of radiation?', 'The relationship between the wavelength and frequency of electromagnetic radiation such as light is usually shown as a log-log plot (Figure 1.29 (b)).']
['What is another way to describe this graph?', 'Log-log plots are also commonly used to describe exponential functions, such as radioactive decay.']
['What is the first thing you learn about physics?', 'Our study of physics opens with kinematics—the study of motion without considering its causes.']
['What is motion everywhere?', 'Objects are in motion everywhere you look.']
['What other things are in motion?', 'Everything from a tennis game to a space-probe flyby of the planet Neptune involves motion.']
['what does heart move blood?', 'When you are resting, your heart moves blood through your veins.']
['What does always moving mean?', 'Even in inanimate objects, atoms are always moving.']
['What is the location of an object at any particular time called?', 'The location of an object at any particular time is its position.']
['How do you specify position relative to something?', 'More precisely, you need to specify its position relative to a convenient reference frame.']
['What is the reference frame used for?', 'Earth is often used as a reference frame, and we often describe the position of an object as it relates to stationary objects in that reference frame.']

['What is an example of a moving object?', 'For example, a rocket launch would be described in terms of the position of the rocket with respect to Earth as a whole, while a professor’s position could be described in terms of where she is in relation to the nearby white board.']
['What other examples are there?', 'In other cases, we use reference frames that are not stationary but are in motion relative to Earth.']
['What is an example of this?', 'To describe the position of a person in an airplane, for example, we use the airplane, not Earth, as the reference frame.']
['Does the article provide any more information?', '(See Figure 2.2.)']

['Can you say a word about the reference frame?', "Thus, you can only know how fast and in what direction an object's position is changing against a background of something else that is either not moving or moving with a known speed and direction."]
['What is the coordinate system from which the positions of objects are described?', 'The reference frame is the coordinate system from which the positions of objects are described.']
['What can you do with your classroom?', 'Your classroom can be used as a reference frame.']
['What do the walls of the classroom tell you?', 'In the classroom, the walls are not moving.']
['What is the reason for the classroom being stationary?', 'Your motion as you walk to the door, can be measured against the stationary background of the classroom walls.']
['What can you tell about the reference frame?', 'You can also tell if other things in the classroom are moving, such as your classmates entering the classroom or a book falling off a desk.']
['What else can you tell?', 'You can also tell in what direction something is moving in the classroom.']
['What might you say about the direction of the move?', 'You might say, “The teacher is moving toward the door.”']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Your reference frame allows you to determine not only that something is moving but also the direction of motion.']
['What does this mean?', 'You could also serve as a reference frame for others’ movement.']
['What happens to the other students?', 'If you remained seated as your classmates left the room, you would measure their movement away from your stationary location.']
['What happens when you leave the room?', 'If you and your classmates left the room together, then your perspective of their motion would be change.']
['What does this mean?', 'You, as the reference frame, would be moving in the same direction as your other moving classmates.']
['What else do you learn from this?', 'As you will learn in the Snap Lab, your description of motion can be quite different when viewed from different reference frames.']
['What is the purpose of this study material?', 'As we study the motion of objects, we must first be able to describe the object’s position.']
['What are some starting positions for a car?', 'Before your parent drives you to school, the car is sitting in your driveway.']
['What is the difference between a driveway and a parking space?', 'Your driveway is the starting position for the car.']
['What is your high school?', 'When you reach your high school, the car has changed position.']
['What is the new position of the school?', 'Its new position is your school.']
['What do you want to know about the content in our study material?', 'Physicists use variables to represent terms.']
['What will we use to represent car’s position?', 'We will use d to represent car’s position.']

['What other variable will we use to differentiate between the initial position, d0, and the final position, df?', 'We will use a subscript to differentiate between the initial position, d0, and the final position, df.']
['What other variables will we use?', 'In addition, vectors, which we will discuss later, will be in bold or will have an arrow above the variable.']
['What will we use to represent variables?', 'Scalars will be italicized.']
['How far is the house from the initial position?', "Now imagine driving from your house to a friend's house located several kilometers away."]
['Is the house near or far from the straight line?', 'The distance an object moves is the length of the path between its initial position and its final position.']
['How does the distance vary between two houses?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house depends on your path."]
['How is distance different from the length of a straight line between two points?', 'As shown in Figure 2.5, distance is different from the length of a straight line between two points.']
['Why is this important?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house is probably longer than the straight line between the two houses."]
['What else are we going to discuss?', 'We often want to be more precise when we talk about position.']
['What else do we want to discuss?', 'The description of an object’s motion often includes more than just the distance it moves.']
['What other things do we want to discuss?', 'For instance, if it is a five kilometer drive to school, the distance traveled is 5 kilometers.']

['How much distance did your parent travel after dropping you off at school and driving back home?', 'After dropping you off at school and driving back home, your parent will have traveled a total distance of 10 kilometers.']
['Is there anything else interesting we can discuss?', 'The car and your parent will end up in the same starting position in space.']
['What is the net change in position of an object?', 'The net change in position of an object is its displacement, or  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{d}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What does the Greek letter delta mean?', 'The Greek letter delta,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\)$$, means change in.']

['Are there any other questions I can ask you that relate to this title?', 'If you are describing only your drive to school, then the distance traveled and the displacement are the same—5 kilometers.']
['Are there any other interesting facts about the title?', 'When you are describing the entire round trip, distance and displacement are different.']
['What is the meaning of describe distance?', 'When you describe distance, you only include the magnitude, the size or amount, of the distance traveled.']
['Why is it different from describe displacement?', 'However, when you describe the displacement, you take into account both the magnitude of the change in position and the direction of movement.']

['What do you think we are studying right now?', 'In our previous example, the car travels a total of 10 kilometers, but it drives five of those kilometers forward toward school and five of those kilometers back in the opposite direction.']

['What are the two quantities?', 'If we ascribe the forward direction a positive (+) and the opposite direction a negative (–), then the two quantities will cancel each other out when added together.']
['What is a scalar?', 'A quantity, such as distance, that has magnitude (i.e., how big or how much) but does not take into account direction is called a scalar.']
['What is the second one?', 'A quantity, such as displacement, that has both magnitude and direction is called a vector.']
['What did you learn about distance and displacement?', 'Hopefully you now understand the conceptual difference between distance and displacement.']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'Understanding concepts is half the battle in physics.']
['What is the other half of the passage?', 'The other half is math.']

['What is a stumbling block to new physics students?', 'A stumbling block to new physics students is trying to wade through the math of physics while also trying to understand the associated concepts.']
['What might happen if you struggle with a difficult question?', 'This struggle may lead to misconceptions and answers that make no sense.']
['How do you overcome this?', 'Once the concept is mastered, the math is far less confusing.']
['Do you think we can make sense of displacement in terms of numbers and equations?', 'So let’s review and see if we can make sense of displacement in terms of numbers and equations.']
["How do you calculate an object's displacement?", "You can calculate an object's displacement by subtracting its original position, d0, from its final position df."]
['Is there anything else of note?', 'In math terms that means']

['What do you need to do to assign numbers and/or direction to these quantities?', 'To assign numbers and/or direction to these quantities, we need to define an axis with a positive and a negative direction.']
['How would I know the direction of the axis?', 'We also need to define an origin, or O. In Figure 2.6, the axis is in a straight line with home at zero and school in the positive direction.']
['How would you know that the direction was negative?', 'If we left home and drove the opposite way from school, motion would have been in the negative direction.']
['What would you have assigned it?', 'We would have assigned it a negative value.']
['What did you do with zero kilometers?', 'In the round-trip drive, df and d0 were both at zero kilometers.']
['How about a one way trip to school?', 'In the one way trip to school, df was at 5 kilometers and d0 was at zero km.']
['Why was that number?', 'So,  $$\\(\\Delta\\mathbf{d}\\)$$  was 5 kilometers.']
['What is the relationship between distance and displacement?', 'There is more to motion than distance and displacement.']
['What are other things?', 'Questions such as, “How long does a foot race take?” and “What was the runner’s speed?” cannot be answered without an understanding of other concepts.']
['What do you find interesting about the motion concept?', 'In this section we will look at time, speed, and velocity to expand our understanding of motion.']
['What is the description of how fast or slow an object moves called?', 'A description of how fast or slow an object moves is its speed.']
['What is the difference between speed and distance?', 'Speed is the rate at which an object changes its location.']
['What is it like to be a scalar?', 'Like distance, speed is a scalar because it has a magnitude but not a direction.']
['What does speed depend on?', 'Because speed is a rate, it depends on the time interval of motion.']
['How is the elapsed time calculated?', 'You can calculate the elapsed time or the change in time,  $$\\(\\Delta t\\)$$, of motion as the difference between the ending time and the beginning time']
['What is a common fact about speed?', "When you describe an object's speed, you often describe the average over a time period."]
['What is the average speed of a moving object?', 'Average speed, vavg, is the distance traveled divided by the time during which the motion occurs.']
['How many hours does a car travel at average speed?', 'Suppose, for example, a car travels 150 kilometers in 3.2 hours.']
['How fast does it travel?', 'Its average speed for the trip is']
['What are some key points in the passage?', "A car's speed would likely increase and decrease many times over a 3.2 hour trip."]
['What does an instantaneous speedometer describe?', 'Its speed at a specific instant in time, however, is its instantaneous speed.']
["What does a car's speedometer tell you?", "A car's speedometer describes its instantaneous speed."]
['What is the vector version of speed?', 'The vector version of speed is velocity.']
['What does velocity describe?', 'Velocity describes the speed and direction of an object.']
['What is the difference between velocity and speed?', 'As with speed, it is useful to describe either the average velocity over a time period or the velocity at a specific moment.']
['How does the average velocity differ?', 'Average velocity is displacement divided by the time over which the displacement occurs.']
['What is velocity?', 'Velocity, like speed, has SI units of meters per second (m/s), but because it is a vector, you must also include a direction.']

['What is the direction of the velocity?', 'Furthermore, the variable v for velocity is bold because it is a vector, which is in contrast to the variable v for speed which is italicized because it is a scalar quantity.']
["What are some problems you'll have to solve?", 'Suppose a passenger moved toward the back of a plane with an average velocity of –4 m/s.']

['What can you tell me about the problem?', 'To get more details, we must consider smaller segments of the trip over smaller time intervals such as those shown in Figure 2.9.']
['What else can you tell me about the details?', 'If you consider infinitesimally small intervals, you can define instantaneous velocity, which is the velocity at a specific instant in time.']
['Are there any other differences between the average velocity and instantaneous velocity?', 'Instantaneous velocity and average velocity are the same if the velocity is constant.']
['What is the difference between distance traveled and magnitude of displacement?', 'Earlier, you have read that distance traveled can be different than the magnitude of displacement.']
['How is it different than the magnitude of velocity?', 'In the same way, speed can be different than the magnitude of velocity.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'For example, you drive to a store and return home in half an hour.']
['How long did it take you to drive 6 km?', 'If your car’s odometer shows the total distance traveled was 6 km, then your average speed was 12 km/h.']
['What can you tell me about the round trip?', 'Your average velocity, however, was zero because your displacement for the round trip is zero.']

['What is the value of 9.80 m/s2 labeled g and is referred to as acceleration due to gravity?', 'The value of 9.80 m/s2 is labeled g and is referred to as acceleration due to gravity.']

['What is the force that causes nonsupported objects to accelerate downward?', 'Gravity is the force that causes nonsupported objects to accelerate downward—or, more precisely, toward the center of Earth.']

['What is the cause of force and dynamics drawing our attention?', 'Force is the cause of motion, and motion draws our attention.']
['What can you share that makes the motion so captivating?', 'Motion itself can be beautiful, such as a dolphin jumping out of the water, the flight of a bird, or the orbit of a satellite.']
['What is the study of motion called?', 'The study of motion is called kinematics, but kinematics describes only the way objects move—their velocity and their acceleration.']
['What is the study of the forces that affect the motion of moving objects and systems?', 'Dynamics considers the forces that affect the motion of moving objects and systems.']
['What are the newton’s laws of motion?', 'Newton’s laws of motion are the foundation of dynamics.']
['What are the laws of motion about?', 'These laws describe the way objects speed up, slow down, stay in motion, and interact with other objects.']
['What else can you tell me about the laws of motion?', 'They are also universal laws: they apply everywhere on Earth as well as in space.']
['What does force do?', 'A force pushes or pulls an object.']
['What is the object being moved by a force?', 'The object being moved by a force could be an inanimate object, a table, or an animate object, a person.']
['What is pushing it?', 'The pushing or pulling may be done by a person, or even the gravitational pull of Earth.']
['What is different about force?', 'Forces have different magnitudes and directions; this means that some forces are stronger than others and can act in different directions.']
['What does a cannon do?', 'For example, a cannon exerts a strong force on the cannonball that is launched into the air.']
['What force does a mosquito exert on your arm?', 'In contrast, a mosquito landing on your arm exerts only a small force on your arm.']
['what are forces combine?', 'When multiple forces act on an object, the forces combine.']
['What does combining the forces do?', 'Adding together all of the forces acting on an object gives the total force, or net force.']
['What is a force that acts on an object within the system from outside the system?', 'An external force is a force that acts on an object within the system from outside the system.']
['What is the difference between an internal force and an external force?', 'This type of force is different than an internal force, which acts between two objects that are both within the system.']
['What is the total combined external force?', 'The net external force combines these two definitions; it is the total combined external force.']
['What else is in this section?', 'We discuss further details about net force, external force, and net external force in the coming sections.']
['What is opposite signs?', 'In mathematical terms, two forces acting in opposite directions have opposite signs (positive or negative).']
['What is the negative sign?', 'By convention, the negative sign is assigned to any movement to the left or downward.']

['What can be done about it?', 'If two forces pushing in opposite directions are added together, the larger force will be somewhat canceled out by the smaller force pushing in the opposite direction.']

['What else is important about it?', 'It is important to be consistent with your chosen coordinate system within a problem; for example, if negative values are assigned to the downward direction for velocity, then distance, force, and acceleration should also be designated as being negative in the downward direction.']
['What is our first example of force?', 'For our first example of force, consider an object hanging from a rope.']
['What is the useful tool known?', 'This example gives us the opportunity to introduce a useful tool known as a free-body diagram.']
['What does a free-body diagram represent?', 'A free-body diagram represents the object being acted upon—that is, the free body—as a single point.']
['What are the forces acting on the body called?', 'Only the forces acting on the body (that is, external forces) are shown and are represented by vectors (which are drawn as arrows).']
['What are the only forces shown?', 'These forces are the only ones shown because only external forces acting on the body affect its motion.']
['How do we know that?', 'We can ignore any internal forces within the body because they cancel each other out, as explained in the section on Newton’s third law of motion.']
['What are free-body diagrams useful for?', 'Free-body diagrams are very useful for analyzing forces acting on an object.']

['What is the force of tension?', 'In a free-body diagram, the lengths of the arrows show the relative magnitude (or strength) of the forces.']
['What does it mean to have vectors?', 'Because forces are vectors, they add just like other vectors.']
['What does equal magnitude mean?', 'Notice that the two arrows have equal lengths in Figure 4.2, which means that the forces of tension and weight are of equal magnitude.']
['What is perfectly balanced?', 'Because these forces of equal magnitude act in opposite directions, they are perfectly balanced, so they add together to give a net force of zero.']
['What are the two types of forces?', 'Not all forces are as noticeable as when you push or pull on an object.']

['What happens when the forces act without physical contact?', 'Some forces act without physical contact, such as the pull of a magnet (in the case of magnetic force) or the gravitational pull of Earth (in the case of gravitational force).']

['What are three specific types of forces?', 'In the next three sections discussing Newton’s laws of motion, we will learn about three specific types of forces: friction, the normal force, and the gravitational force.']

['What are the things you have to know about motion?', 'A change in motion is simply a change in velocity: the speed of an object can become slower or faster, the direction in which the object is moving can change, or both of these variables may change.']
['What is the difference between a change in velocity and an acceleration?', 'A change in velocity means, by definition, that an acceleration has occurred.']
['What can cause a change in motion?', 'Newton’s first law says that only a nonzero net external force can cause a change in motion, so a net external force must cause an acceleration.']
['What can acceleration also refer to?', 'Note that acceleration can refer to slowing down or to speeding up.']

['What is acceleration divided by?', 'Acceleration can also refer to a change in the direction of motion with no change in speed, because acceleration is the change in velocity divided by the time it takes for that change to occur, and velocity is defined by speed and direction.']

['What else is true about the equation?', 'In general, when one variable is multiplied by a number, the other variable is also multiplied by the same number.']

['What is a force acting on objects?', 'When the net external force on an object is its weight, we say that it is in freefall.']

['What force acts on the object?', 'On the surface of Earth, when objects fall downward toward Earth, they are never truly in freefall because there is always some upward force due to air resistance that acts on the object (and there is also the buoyancy force of air, which is similar to the buoyancy force in water that keeps boats afloat).']

['What is the difference between mass and weight?', 'It is important to remember that weight and mass are very different, although they are closely related.']

['What are the differences between weight and mass?', 'Mass is the quantity of matter (how much stuff) in an object and does not vary, but weight is the gravitational force on an object and is proportional to the force of gravity.']
['What are the misconceptions?', 'It is easy to confuse the two, because our experience is confined to Earth, and the weight of an object is essentially the same no matter where you are on Earth.']

['What are perfect examples?', 'Everyday experiences, such as stubbing a toe or throwing a ball, are all perfect examples of Newton’s third law in action.']

['What is the law of motion about?', 'Newton’s third law of motion tells us that forces always occur in pairs, and one object cannot exert a force on another without experiencing the same strength force in return.']

['What can you tell me about the action?', 'We sometimes refer to these force pairs as action-reaction pairs, where the force exerted is the action, and the force experienced in return is the reaction (although which is which depends on your point of view).']
['What is the third law of motion?', 'Newton’s third law is useful for figuring out which forces are external to a system.']

['What did you study?', 'From the definition of the angle of rotation,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\theta = \\frac{\\text{Δ}s}{r}\\)$$, we see that  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s = r\\text{Δ}\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What was the result of substituting this into the expression for v?', 'Substituting this into the expression for v gives']
['What is the equation for tangential speed?', 'The equation  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$  says that the tangential speed v is proportional to the distance r from the center of rotation.']

['What is the explanation for the tangential speed of a point on the outer edge of a CD?', 'Consequently, tangential speed is greater for a point on the outer edge of the CD (with larger r) than for a point closer to the center of the CD (with smaller r).']
['Why is this the case?', 'This makes sense because a point farther out from the center has to cover a longer arc length in the same amount of time as a point closer to the center.']
['What is the other explanation?', 'Note that both points will still have the same angular speed, regardless of their distance from the center of rotation.']
['What can you tell me about Figure 6.4?', 'See Figure 6.4.']
['What other examples do you have?', 'Now, consider another example: the tire of a moving car (see Figure 6.5).']
['Is this an example of how physics works?', 'The faster the tire spins, the faster the car moves—large  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  means large v because  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$ .']

['What else did you find out about the tire of the moving car?', 'Similarly, a larger-radius tire rotating at the same angular velocity,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\omega}\\)$$, will produce a greater linear (tangential) velocity, v, for the car.']
['How does this relate to tangential velocity?', 'This is because a larger radius means a longer arc length must contact the road, so the car must move farther in the same amount of time.']
['What is linear velocity and tangential velocity?', 'However, there are cases where linear velocity and tangential velocity are not equivalent, such as a car spinning its tires on ice.']
['What happens when linear velocity and tangential velocity are not equivalent?', 'In this case, the linear velocity will be less than the tangential velocity.']

['What happens when the linear velocity is less than tangential velocity?', 'Due to the lack of friction under the tires of a car on ice, the arc length through which the tire treads move is greater than the linear distance through which the car moves.']
['How does the car on ice move?', 'It’s similar to running on a treadmill or pedaling a stationary bike; you are literally going nowhere fast.']
['What does this topic have to do with circular motion?', 'In the previous section, we defined circular motion.']
['What is the simplest case of circular motion?', 'The simplest case of circular motion is uniform circular motion, where an object travels a circular path at a constant speed.']
['What else should I know about circular motion?', 'Note that, unlike speed, the linear velocity of an object in circular motion is constantly changing because it is always changing direction.']
['What does acceleration have to do with circular motion?', 'We know from kinematics that acceleration is a change in velocity, either in magnitude or in direction or both.']
['How is it related to circular motion?', 'Therefore, an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always accelerating, even though the magnitude of its velocity is constant.']
['What is the acceleration of a body when it is moving?', 'You experience this acceleration yourself every time you ride in a car while it turns a corner.']
['What does executing uniform circular motion mean?', 'If you hold the steering wheel steady during the turn and move at a constant speed, you are executing uniform circular motion.']
['What happens to you during the turn?', 'What you notice is a feeling of sliding (or being flung, depending on the speed) away from the center of the turn.']

['Why does the car turn?', 'This isn’t an actual force that is acting on you—it only happens because your body wants to continue moving in a straight line (as per Newton’s first law) whereas the car is turning off this straight-line path.']
["What do you feel when you don't move?", 'Inside the car it appears as if you are forced away from the center of the turn.']
['What is the fictitious force?', 'This fictitious force is known as the centrifugal force.']
['How does the force affect you?', 'The sharper the curve and the greater your speed, the more noticeable this effect becomes.']
['What is one thing you learned about the passage?', 'Figure 6.7 shows an object moving in a circular path at constant speed.']
['What is the direction of the instantaneous tangential velocity?', 'The direction of the instantaneous tangential velocity is shown at two points along the path.']
['What does acceleration mean?', 'Acceleration is in the direction of the change in velocity; in this case it points roughly toward the center of rotation.']
['What is the center of rotation?', '(The center of rotation is at the center of the circular path).']

['What else did you learn?', 'If we imagine  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s\\)$$  becoming smaller and smaller, then the acceleration would point exactly toward the center of rotation, but this case is hard to draw.']
['What else did you learn?', 'We call the acceleration of an object moving in uniform circular motion the centripetal acceleration ac because centripetal means center seeking.']

['What is the direction of centripetal acceleration?', 'Now that we know that the direction of centripetal acceleration is toward the center of rotation, let’s discuss the magnitude of centripetal acceleration.']

['What is the most significant information in this document?', 'Centripetal acceleration is greater at high speeds and in sharp curves (smaller radius), as you may have noticed when driving a car, because the car actually pushes you toward the center of the turn.']
['How is ac equal to speed squared?', 'But it is a bit surprising that ac is proportional to the speed squared.']
['Does this mean it is four times greater?', 'This means, for example, that the acceleration is four times greater when you take a curve at 100 km/h than at 50 km/h.']
['What can we express ac in terms of?', 'We can also express ac in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity.']

['What can we learn from this?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal acceleration in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity is']
['What forces are involved in a centripetal acceleration?', 'Any force or combination of forces can cause a centripetal acceleration.']

['What are some examples of the normal force?', 'Just a few examples are the tension in the rope on a tether ball, the force of Earth’s gravity on the Moon, the friction between a road and the tires of a car as it goes around a curve, or the normal force of a roller coaster track on the cart during a loop-the-loop.']
['What is the force that causes uniform circular motion?', 'Any net force causing uniform circular motion is called a centripetal force.']
['What is the direction of a centripetal force?', 'The direction of a centripetal force is toward the center of rotation, the same as for centripetal acceleration.']
['What causes the acceleration of mass according to Fnet = ma?', 'According to Newton’s second law of motion, a net force causes the acceleration of mass according to Fnet = ma.']
['Is there an acceleration that the motion causes?', 'For uniform circular motion, the acceleration is centripetal acceleration: a = ac.']
['What is the magnitude of centripetal force, Fc?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal force, Fc, is  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\mathbf{a}_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']

['How is the magnitude expressed?', 'The first expression is in terms of tangential speed, the second is in terms of angular speed:  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\frac{v^{2}}{r}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = mr\\omega^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about the equation?', 'Both forms of the equation depend on mass, velocity, and the radius of the circular path.']

['What else did you learn from the article?', 'Newton’s second law also states that the object will accelerate in the same direction as the net force.']
['What does the object accelerate towards?', 'By definition, the centripetal force is directed towards the center of rotation, so the object will also accelerate towards the center.']
['How can you see what it does?', 'A straight line drawn from the circular path to the center of the circle will always be perpendicular to the tangential velocity.']

['What was the first part of the article?', 'In the section on uniform circular motion, we discussed motion in a circle at constant speed and, therefore, constant angular velocity.']
['What happens when angular velocity is not constant?', 'However, there are times when angular velocity is not constant—rotational motion can speed up, slow down, or reverse directions.']

['When does angular velocity not stay constant?', 'Angular velocity is not constant when a spinning skater pulls in her arms, when a child pushes a merry-go-round to make it rotate, or when a CD slows to a halt when switched off.']
['What happens when a skater pulls and/or the child pushes?', 'In all these cases, angular acceleration occurs because the angular velocity  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  changes.']
['What is the angular acceleration?', 'The faster the change occurs, the greater is the angular acceleration.']

['What is the equation for angular acceleration?', 'In equation form, angular acceleration is']

['What are the units of angular acceleration?', 'The units of angular acceleration are (rad/s)/s, or rad/s2.']
['What is positive direction?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  increases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is positive.']
['What is negative direction?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  decreases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is negative.']
['Does this differ between clockwise and counterclockwise?', 'Keep in mind that, by convention, counterclockwise is the positive direction and clockwise is the negative direction.']

['What would be a positive acceleration?', 'It would be positive when an object that is rotating counterclockwise speeds up.']
['What do these equations mean?', 'These equations mean that the magnitudes of tangential acceleration and angular acceleration are directly proportional to each other.']
['Can you tell me how that works?', 'The greater the angular acceleration, the larger the change in tangential acceleration, and vice versa.']
['What can you tell me about the Ferris Wheel?', 'For example, consider riders in their pods on a Ferris wheel at rest.']

['What can you tell me about the rider?', 'A Ferris wheel with greater angular acceleration will give the riders greater tangential acceleration because, as the Ferris wheel increases its rate of spinning, it also increases its tangential velocity.']
['Does that mean the speed of a car will increase when it is spinning?', 'Note that the radius of the spinning object also matters.']

['Are there any more interesting facts?', 'For example, for a given angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$, a smaller Ferris wheel leads to a smaller tangential acceleration for the riders.']

['How do they relate to each other?', 'For example, if a motorcycle wheel that starts at rest has a large angular acceleration for a fairly long time, it ends up spinning rapidly and rotates through many revolutions.']

['Did you find out anything else in the article?', 'In the case of linear motion, if an object starts at rest and undergoes a large linear acceleration, then it has a large final velocity and will have traveled a large distance.']

['What does kinematics of rotational motion describe?', 'The kinematics of rotational motion describes the relationships between the angle of rotation, angular velocity, angular acceleration, and time.']

['What did Einstein based his theory on?', 'Einstein based his theory on the postulate that acceleration and gravity have the same effect and cannot be distinguished from each other.']
['What did he conclude?', 'He concluded that light must fall in both a gravitational field and in an accelerating reference frame.']
['What happens in a gravitating reference frame?', 'Figure 7.10 shows this effect (greatly exaggerated) in an accelerating elevator.']
['In what direction does the elevator accelerate?', 'In Figure 7.10 (a), the elevator accelerates upward in zero gravity.']
['What else happens in the figure?', 'In Figure 7.10 (b), the room is not accelerating but is subject to gravity.']
['How does the elevator affect light?', 'The effect on light is the same: it “falls” downward in both situations.']
['What is the most important aspect of this passage?', 'The person in the elevator cannot tell whether the elevator is accelerating in zero gravity or is stationary and subject to gravity.']
['What effect does gravity have on light?', 'Thus, gravity affects the path of light, even though we think of gravity as acting between masses, while photons are massless.']

['What happens to starlight during a solar eclipse?', 'Einstein’s theory of general relativity got its first verification in 1919 when starlight passing near the sun was observed during a solar eclipse.']
['What is the figure you mentioned?', '(See Figure 7.11.)']
['What is the sky like during an eclipse?', 'During an eclipse, the sky is darkened and we can briefly see stars.']
['What can you tell me about shift observed?', 'Those on a line of sight nearest the sun should have a shift in their apparent positions.']
['Did this shift occur?', 'Not only was this shift observed, but it agreed with Einstein’s predictions well within experimental uncertainties.']
['Did this discovery create any other sensation?', 'This discovery created a scientific and public sensation.']
['What is the relationship between Einstein and folk hero?', 'Einstein was now a folk hero as well as a very great scientist.']
['What is matter equivalent to?', 'The bending of light by matter is equivalent to a bending of space itself, with light following the curve.']
['What is the concept of space and time?', 'This is another radical change in our concept of space and time.']
['What does it mean that anything with mass or energy is affected by gravity?', 'It is also another connection that any particle with mass or energy (e.g., massless photons) is affected by gravity.']

['What was the first thing you would want to know from our study material?', 'To summarize the two views of gravity, Newton envisioned gravity as a tug of war along the line connecting any two objects in the universe.']
['What is the difference in their views?', 'In contrast, Einstein envisioned gravity as a bending of space-time by mass.']
['What does the weight varies mean?', 'The mass of an object is constant, but its weight varies with the strength of the gravitational field.']
['What does the second law mean?', 'This means the value of g varies from place to place in the universe.']
['what else can be written in terms of g?', 'The relationship between force, mass, and acceleration from the second law of motion can be written in terms of g.']
['What is the force of gravity?', 'In this case, the force is the weight of the object, which is caused by the gravitational attraction of the planet or moon on which the object is located.']
['What can we use this expression for?', 'We can use this expression to compare weights of an object on different moons and planets.']

['What is the second equation?', 'This equation can be used to solve problems involving an object on or orbiting Earth or other massive celestial object.']
['What is a notable fact about the equation?', 'Sometimes it is helpful to equate the right-hand side of the equation to mg and cancel the m on both sides.']
['What is it about?', 'The equation  $$\\(\\frac{r^{3}}{T^{2}} = \\frac{GM}{4\\pi^{2}}\\)$$  is also useful for problems involving objects in orbit.']
['What should you know about that equation?', 'Note that there is no need to know the mass of the object.']
['What else should we know?', 'Often, we know the radius r or the period T and want to find the other.']
['What happens if we know the mass of a planet and the distance from the sun?', 'If these are both known, we can use the equation to calculate the mass of a planet or star.']
['What is linear momentum?', 'Linear momentum is the product of a system’s mass and its velocity.']
['What is linear momentum p?', 'In equation form, linear momentum p is']
['What was your most memorable lesson?', 'You can see from the equation that momentum is directly proportional to the object’s mass (m) and velocity (v).']
['How does this help you?', 'Therefore, the greater an object’s mass or the greater its velocity, the greater its momentum.']
['Is it really the case that a large, fast-moving object has greater momentum than a smaller, slower object?', 'A large, fast-moving object has greater momentum than a smaller, slower object.']

['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is a vector and has the same direction as velocity v. Since mass is a scalar, when velocity is in a negative direction (i.e., opposite the direction of motion), the momentum will also be in a negative direction; and when velocity is in a positive direction, momentum will likewise be in a positive direction.']
['What is the SI unit of momentum?', 'The SI unit for momentum is kg m/s.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is so important for understanding motion that it was called the quantity of motion by physicists such as Newton.']
['What does force influence?', 'Force influences momentum, and we can rearrange Newton’s second law of motion to show the relationship between force and momentum.']
['What did Newton describe his second law of motion as?', 'Recall our study of Newton’s second law of motion (Fnet = ma).']
['What did Newton state his second law of motion in terms of?', 'Newton actually stated his second law of motion in terms of momentum:']
['What is the net external force?', 'The net external force equals the change in momentum of a system divided by the time over which it changes.']
['What is the difference between the final and initial values of momentum?', 'The change in momentum is the difference between the final and initial values of momentum.']
['What is the impulse-momentum theorem?', '$$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{F}}_{\\text{net}}\\text{Δ}t\\)$$is known as impulse and this equation is known as the impulse-momentum theorem.']
['What else do you want to know about the material?', 'From the equation, we see that the impulse equals the average net external force multiplied by the time this force acts.']
['What is the equation for impulse?', 'It is equal to the change in momentum.']
['What is the effect of a force on an object?', 'The effect of a force on an object depends on how long it acts, as well as the strength of the force.']
['What is the most important thing about the material?', 'Impulse is a useful concept because it quantifies the effect of a force.']
['What does this mean to you?', 'A very large force acting for a short time can have a great effect on the momentum of an object, such as the force of a racket hitting a tennis ball.']
['What else does this mean?', 'A small force could cause the same change in momentum, but it would have to act for a much longer time.']

["What happens when Newton's second law is expressed in terms of momentum?", 'When Newton’s second law is expressed in terms of momentum, it can be used for solving problems where mass varies, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{\\text{p}} = \\text{Δ}(m\\mathbf{\\text{v}})\\)$$ .']
['Why is that?', 'In the more traditional form of the law that you are used to working with, mass is assumed to be constant.']
['Is the traditional form a special case of the law?', 'In fact, this traditional form is a special case of the law, where mass is constant.']
['What did the formula for accelerating objects deriving from a function mean?', '$$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{F}}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{\\text{a}}\\)$$  is actually derived from the equation:']
['What is it important to know about conservation of momentum?', 'It is important we realize that momentum is conserved during collisions, explosions, and other events involving objects in motion.']
['What does conserved mean?', 'To say that a quantity is conserved means that it is constant throughout the event.']
['What does it mean that the momentum is conserved?', 'In the case of conservation of momentum, the total momentum in the system remains the same before and after the collision.']
['What other important things did you notice as you were studying the material?', 'You may have noticed that momentum was not conserved in some of the examples previously presented in this chapter.']
['Where did it not conserve momentum?', 'where forces acting on the objects produced large changes in momentum.']
['Did you know why that is the case?', 'The systems of interest considered in those problems were not inclusive enough.']
['What was interesting about this chapter?', 'If the systems were expanded to include more objects, then momentum would in fact be conserved in those sample problems.']

['What is the reason momentum changes for individual objects?', 'It is always possible to find a larger system where momentum is conserved, even though momentum changes for individual objects within the system.']
['What are some of the problems you will have to solve?', 'For example, if a football player runs into the goalpost in the end zone, a force will cause him to bounce backward.']
['What is the impact on him?', 'His momentum is obviously greatly changed, and considering only the football player, we would find that momentum is not conserved.']
['What else can you tell me about the paper?', 'However, the system can be expanded to contain the entire Earth.']
['Does the Earth do anything else after it is hit?', 'Surprisingly, Earth also recoils—conserving momentum—because of the force applied to it through the goalpost.']
['Why is this surprising?', 'The effect on Earth is not noticeable because it is so much more massive than the player, but the effect is real.']

['When two objects are moving at different speeds, what happens to their momentum?', 'Next, consider what happens if the masses of two colliding objects are more similar than the masses of a football player and Earth—in the example shown in Figure 8.4 of one car bumping into another.']

['When two objects are moving at different speeds, how is their momentum conserved?', 'Both cars are coasting in the same direction when the lead car, labeled m2, is bumped by the trailing car, labeled m1.']
['What unbalanced force is on each car?', 'The only unbalanced force on each car is the force of the collision, assuming that the effects due to friction are negligible.']
['What happens to car m1 as a result of the collision?', 'Car m1 slows down as a result of the collision, losing some momentum, while car m2 speeds up and gains some momentum.']
['How does the car system conserve momentum?', 'If we choose the system to include both cars and assume that friction is negligible, then the momentum of the two-car system should remain constant.']
['What did you find that was interesting?', 'Now we will prove that the total momentum of the two-car system does in fact remain constant, and is therefore conserved.']

["What's the change in momentum of car 1?", 'Similarly, the change in momentum of car 2 is  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{2} = \\mathbf{F}_{2}\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  where F2 is the force on car 2 due to car 1, and we assume the duration of the collision  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  is the same for both cars.']

['What is the result of the equation?', 'We know from Newton’s third law of motion that F2 = –F1, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{2} = - \\mathbf{F}_{1}\\text{Δ}t = - \\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{1}\\)$$ .']
['What else does this article have to do with?', 'Because the changes in momentum add to zero, the total momentum of the two-car system is constant.']

['What is the specific definition of work in physics?', 'In physics, the term work has a very specific definition.']

['What is the equation for work?', 'Work, W, is described by the equation']

['What is the difference between homework and work?', 'Homework is not work.']
['What is work?', 'Lifting a rock upwards off the ground is work.']
['What is not work?', 'Carrying a rock in a straight path across the lawn at a constant speed is not work.']
['How many examples are there in this document?', 'The first two examples are fairly simple.']

['Are there other reasons for objects not being moved over a distance?', 'Lifting a rock up off the ground is work because the rock is moving in the direction that force is applied.']

['What happens when the rock is moving forward?', 'Therefore, while some force may be applied to keep the rock up off the ground, no net force is applied to keep the rock moving forward at constant velocity.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Work and energy are closely related.']

['How is energy related to work?', 'You (or an object) also expend energy to do work.']

['What is kinetic energy also called?', 'Kinetic energy is also called energy of motion.']
['What does a moving object have?', 'A moving object has kinetic energy.']
['What is potential energy?', 'Potential energy, sometimes called stored energy, comes in several forms.']

['What is the stored energy an object has as a result of its position above Earth’s surface (or another object in space)?', 'Gravitational potential energy is the stored energy an object has as a result of its position above Earth’s surface (or another object in space).']
['What is potential energy related to?', 'A roller coaster car at the top of a hill has gravitational potential energy.']
['When an object loses energy, what happens to the potential energy?', 'Let’s examine how doing work on an object changes the object’s energy.']
['What is the potential energy of a rock?', 'If we apply force to lift a rock off the ground, we increase the rock’s potential energy, PE.']
['What happens when you drop the rock?', 'If we drop the rock, the force of gravity increases the rock’s kinetic energy as the rock moves downward until it hits the ground.']
['What is the work we do on a rock equal to?', 'The work we do on the rock equals the force we exert multiplied by the distance, d, that we lift the rock.']
['what else is the work on the rock equal to?', 'The work we do on the rock also equals the rock’s gain in gravitational potential energy, PEe.']
['What causes kinetic energy?', 'When we drop the rock the force of gravity causes the rock to fall, giving the rock kinetic energy.']

['What are some examples of the work – energy theorem?', 'When work done on an object increases only its kinetic energy, then the net work equals the change in the value of the quantity $$\\(\\frac{1}{2}m\\mathbf{v}^{2}\\)$$ .']

['What is the metric unit of measurement for both work and energy?', 'The joule (J) is the metric unit of measurement for both work and energy.']
['What does this mean?', 'The measurement of work and energy with the same unit reinforces the idea that work and energy are related and can be converted into one another.']
['What is the unit of force multiplied by distance?', '1.0 J = 1.0 N∙m, the units of force multiplied by distance.']

['What can you tell me about Work and Power?', 'In applications that involve work, we are often interested in how fast the work is done.']

['What are some examples of applications?', 'For example, in roller coaster design, the amount of time it takes to lift a roller coaster car to the top of the first hill is an important consideration.']
['Why is that important?', 'Taking a half hour on the ascent will surely irritate riders and decrease ticket sales.']
['How can we calculate the time it takes to do work?', 'Let’s take a look at how to calculate the time it takes to do work.']
['What kind of work is it?', 'Recall that a rate can be used to describe a quantity, such as work, over a period of time.']
['What is the rate at which work is done?', 'Power is the rate at which work is done.']
['What does rate mean?', 'In this case, rate means per unit of time.']
['How is power calculated?', 'Power is calculated by dividing the work done by the time it took to do the work.']
['What did you learn about work, force, and power?', 'Let’s consider an example that can help illustrate the differences among work, force, and power.']

['What is the example of the woman lifting the TV with a pulley?', 'Suppose the woman in Figure 9.3 lifting the TV with a pulley gets the TV to the fourth floor in two minutes, and the man carrying the TV up the stairs takes five minutes to arrive at the same place.']

['Why did they do the same amount of work?', 'They have done the same amount of work  $$\\(\\left( {\\mathbf{f}d} \\right)\\)$$  on the TV, because they have moved the same mass over the same vertical distance, which requires the same amount of upward force.']
['What was the difference between the two women?', 'However, the woman using the pulley has generated more power.']

["Why did the student's answer to the question be different from the other student's answer?", 'This is because she did the work in a shorter amount of time, so the denominator of the power formula, t, is smaller.']
['How did this affect the man?', '(For simplicity’s sake, we will leave aside for now the fact that the man climbing the stairs has also done work on himself.)']
['What is the unit of measurement for power?', 'Power can be expressed in units of watts (W).']
['What is W used for?', 'This unit can be used to measure power related to any form of energy or work.']
['What is watt?', 'You have most likely heard the term used in relation to electrical devices, especially light bulbs.']
['What is time given?', 'Multiplying power by time gives the amount of energy.']
['What is the amount of energy consumed?', 'Electricity is sold in kilowatt-hours because that equals the amount of electrical energy consumed.']
['What is the name of the person who invented the watt unit?', 'The watt unit was named after James Watt (1736–1819) (see Figure 9.4).']
['What did he discover?', 'He was a Scottish engineer and inventor who discovered how to coax more power out of steam engines.']
['Did you take the final exams?', 'Before proceeding, be sure you understand the distinctions among force, work, energy, and power.']
['What is the best way to explain the force exerted on an object over a distance?', 'Force exerted on an object over a distance does work.']
['What can work do?', 'Work can increase energy, and energy can do work.']
['What is the rate at which work is done?', 'Power is the rate at which work is done.']
['What can potential energy be?', 'We saw earlier that mechanical energy can be either potential or kinetic.']
['What are some examples of energy?', 'We will also see that, in a closed system, the sum of these forms of energy remains constant.']

['What does potential energy have to do with roller coaster cars?', 'Quite a bit of potential energy is gained by a roller coaster car and its passengers when they are raised to the top of the first hill.']
['What is the potential part of energy?', 'Remember that the potential part of the term means that energy has been stored and can be used at another time.']
['What does the potential part mean?', 'You will see that this stored energy can either be used to do work or can be transformed into kinetic energy.']

['When an object that has gravitational potential energy falls, its energy is converted to what?', 'For example, when an object that has gravitational potential energy falls, its energy is converted to kinetic energy.']
['What else do you want to know?', 'Remember that both work and energy are expressed in joules.']
['What figure do you need to refer back to?', 'Refer back to Figure 9.3.']

['What is the equation for the force of gravity?', 'The amount of work required to raise the TV from point A to point B is equal to the amount of gravitational potential energy the TV gains from its height above the ground.']
['Does this just refer to the TV or any other object?', 'This is generally true for any object raised above the ground.']

['What is significant about this equation?', 'If all the work done on an object is used to raise the object above the ground, the amount work equals the object’s gain in gravitational potential energy.']
['What are some more important details about this equation?', 'However, note that because of the work done by friction, these energy–work transformations are never perfect.']

['What does the roller coaster have?', 'It is moving slowly, so it also has a small amount of kinetic energy.']

['How does it accelerate?', 'At the low point much of the original PE has been transformed to KE, and speed is at a maximum.']
['What happens after the low point?', 'As the car moves up the next slope, some of the KE is transformed back into PE and the car slows down.']
['What is the best part of the article?', 'On an actual roller coaster, there are many ups and downs, and each of these is accompanied by transitions between kinetic and potential energy.']

['What else do we have to know?', 'At any point in the ride, the total mechanical energy is the same, and it is equal to the energy the car had at the top of the first rise.']
['Why is that so?', 'This is a result of the law of conservation of energy, which says that, in a closed system, total energy is conserved—that is, it is constant.']

['What does the phrase in a closed system mean?', 'The phrase in a closed system means we are assuming no energy is lost to the surroundings due to friction and air resistance.']

['Does it affect the roller coaster?', 'For the roller coaster, this assumption introduces some inaccuracy to the calculation.']
['What are some examples of the content?', 'Simple machines make work easier, but they do not decrease the amount of work you have to do.']
['In closed systems, what happens to the total amount of energy?', 'Recall that in closed systems the total amount of energy is conserved.']

['How can you change the amount of force you must apply?', 'Although it cannot change the amount of work you do, a simple machine can change the amount of force you must apply to an object, and the distance over which you apply the force.']
['What can a simple machine do?', 'In most cases, a simple machine is used to reduce the amount of force you must exert to do work.']
['What is the down side of this?', 'The down side is that you must exert the force over a greater distance, because the product of force and distance, fd, (which equals work) does not change.']

The mechanical advantage is a number that tells us how many times a simple machine multiplies the effort force.']

['What simple machine is shown in Figure 9.9?', 'The simple machine shown in Figure 9.9 is called a wheel and axle.']

['Is relativity new?', 'Relativity is not new.']
['What year did Galileo explain that motion is relative?', 'Way back around the year 1600, Galileo explained that motion is relative.']

['who does everyone else feel the same way?', 'Everyone else feels the same way.']

['Are there any other examples of relativity?', 'It is all relative.']

['What is light involved in the discussion of relativity?', 'Light is involved in the discussion of relativity because theories related to electromagnetism are inconsistent with Galileo’s and Newton’s explanation of relativity.']
['What was the controversy about?', 'The true nature of light was a hot topic of discussion and controversy in the late 19th century.']
['What did people believe about light?', 'At the time, it was not generally believed that light could travel across empty space.']
['What was the basis of this?', 'It was known to travel as waves, and all other types of energy that propagated as waves needed to travel though a material medium.']
['Was there something that prevented light?', 'It was believed that space was filled with an invisible medium that light waves traveled through.']
['What was the imaginary material called?', 'This imaginary (as it turned out) material was called the ether (also spelled aether).']
['What was thought about the material?', 'It was thought that everything moved through this mysterious fluid.']
['What was thought about the ether?', 'In other words, ether was the one fixed frame of reference.']
['Was this true?', 'The Michelson–Morley experiment proved it was not.']

['What did Albert Michelson and Edward Morley design in 1887?', 'In 1887, Albert Michelson and Edward Morley designed the interferometer shown in Figure 10.2 to measure the speed of Earth through the ether.']
['What was the light beam split into?', 'A light beam is split into two perpendicular paths and then recombined.']

['What is the interference pattern?', 'Recombining the waves produces an inference pattern, with a bright fringe at the locations where the two waves arrive in phase; that is, with the crests of both waves arriving together and the troughs arriving together.']
['Where does a dark fringe appear?', 'A dark fringe appears where the crest of one wave coincides with a trough of the other, so that the two cancel.']

['What is the measurement of the traveling Earth through the ether?', 'If Earth is traveling through the ether as it orbits the sun, the peaks in one arm would take longer than in the other to reach the same location.']
['What would this do?', 'The places where the two waves arrive in phase would change, and the interference pattern would shift.']
['How was this failed?', 'But, using the interferometer, there was no shift seen!']

['What result led to two conclusions: that there is no ether and that the speed of light is the same regardless of the relative motion of source and observer?', 'This result led to two conclusions: that there is no ether and that the speed of light is the same regardless of the relative motion of source and observer.']
['What is the most important thing about this?', 'The Michelson–Morley investigation has been called the most famous failed experiment in history.']

['What was the study material about?', 'A radical new theory was needed, and Albert Einstein, shown in Figure 10.3, was about to become everyone’s favorite genius.']

['What can you tell me about the twin paradox?', 'You may have seen science fiction movies in which space travelers return to Earth after a long trip to find that the planet and everyone on it has aged much more than they have.']

['What is this based on?', 'This type of scenario is a based on a thought experiment, known as the twin paradox, which imagines a pair of twins, one of whom goes on a trip into space while the other stays home.']
['What does this lead to?', 'When the space traveler returns, she finds her twin has aged much more than she.']
['What has happened?', 'This happens because the traveling twin has been in two frames of reference, one leaving Earth and one returning.']
