['What is the most important fact about the material?', 'In general, the nuclei of stable isotopes have less mass then their constituent subatomic particles.']
['What is the energy equivalent of this difference?', 'The energy equivalent of this difference is called the binding energy of the nucleus.']
['What is the binding energy used for?', 'This energy is released during the formation of the isotope from its constituent particles because the product is more stable than the reactants.']
['What is the mass defect?', 'Expressed as mass, it is called the mass defect.']
['What other interesting things did you find in the article?', 'For example, a helium nucleus is made of two neutrons and two protons and has a mass of 4.0003 atomic mass units (u).']
['What is the mass defect?', 'The sum of the masses of two protons and two neutrons is 4.0330 u.']
['What is the mass defect?', 'The mass defect then is 0.0327 u. Converted to kg, the mass defect is 5.0442 × 10–30 kg.']
['How does this translate to energy?', 'Multiplying this mass times c2 gives a binding energy of 4.540 × 10–12 J.']
['Do you think this sounds like a lot?', 'This does not sound like much because it is only one atom.']
['Is this why the energy is so small?', 'If you were to make one gram of helium out of neutrons and protons, it would release 683,000,000,000 J.']
['Is this really so small?', 'By comparison, burning one gram of coal releases about 24 J.']
['What does it mean to you?', 'It’s one of those concepts so ingrained in our everyday lives that, although we know what it means intuitively, it can be hard to define.']
['Is it true that temperature measures heat?', 'It is tempting to say that temperature measures heat, but this is not strictly true.']
['What is the transfer of energy due to a temperature difference?', 'Heat is the transfer of energy due to a temperature difference.']

['What is the instrument that tells us what temperature is?', 'Temperature is defined in terms of the instrument we use to tell us how hot or cold an object is, based on a mechanism and scale invented by people.']
['Is temperature defined in terms of what we measure?', 'Temperature is literally defined as what we measure on a thermometer.']
['What can we learn about this information?', 'Heat is often confused with temperature.']
['What is the difference between adverbs and adjectives?', 'For example, we may say that the heat was unbearable, when we actually mean that the temperature was high.']
['What is the problem with this?', 'This is because we are sensitive to the flow of energy by heat, rather than the temperature.']
['Why is this important?', 'Since heat, like work, transfers energy, it has the SI unit of joule (J).']
['What are the random directions that molecules and atoms are constantly in motion?', 'Atoms and molecules are constantly in motion, bouncing off one another in random directions.']
['What is the energy of motion?', 'Recall that kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and that it increases in proportion to velocity squared.']

['What is the energy associated with heat?', 'Without going into mathematical detail, we can say that thermal energy—the energy associated with heat—is the average kinetic energy of the particles (molecules or atoms) in a substance.']
['What happens when the energy increases?', 'Faster moving molecules have greater kinetic energies, and so the substance has greater thermal energy, and thus a higher temperature.']
['What is the total internal energy of a system?', 'The total internal energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of its atoms and molecules.']
['What is the subcategory of internal energy?', 'Thermal energy is one of the subcategories of internal energy, as is chemical energy.']
['What is one of the most common scales used in the measurement of temperature?', 'To measure temperature, some scale must be used as a standard of measurement.']
['What are the three most commonly used scales?', 'The three most commonly used temperature scales are the Fahrenheit, Celsius, and Kelvin scales.']

['What is one thing you know about the Fahrenheit and Celsius scales?', 'Both the Fahrenheit scale and Celsius scale are relative temperature scales, meaning that they are made around a reference point.']

['What is one thing you learned about the Celsius scale?', 'For example, the Celsius scale uses the freezing point of water as its reference point; all measurements are either lower than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a negative sign), or higher than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a positive sign).']
['What is the boiling point of water on the Celsius scale?', 'The boiling point of water is 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  for the Celsius scale, and its unit is the degree Celsius  (°C(°C(°C ).']
['What are the other types of temperatures?', 'On the Fahrenheit scale, the freezing point of water is at 32 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$, and the boiling point is at 212 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of temperature on this scale?', 'The unit of temperature on this scale is the degree Fahrenheit  (°F(°F(°F ).']

['What is the difference in degrees between the freezing and boiling points of water?', 'Note that the difference in degrees between the freezing and boiling points is greater for the Fahrenheit scale than for the Celsius scale.']
['How does one degree Celsius differ from another one?', 'Therefore, a temperature difference of one degree Celsius is greater than a temperature difference of one degree Fahrenheit.']

['Does this mean there is a difference in degrees between Fahrenheit and Celsius?', 'Since 100 Celsius degrees span the same range as 180 Fahrenheit degrees, one degree on the Celsius scale is 1.8 times larger than one degree on the Fahrenheit scale (because  $$\\(\\frac{180}{100} = \\frac{9}{5} = 1.8\\)$$ ).']
['What can you tell me about this relationship?', 'This relationship can be used to convert between temperatures in Fahrenheit and Celsius (see Figure 11.2).']
['What is the Kelvin scale?', 'The Kelvin scale is the temperature scale that is commonly used in science because it is an absolute temperature scale.']
['What is the lowest temperature?', 'This means that the theoretically lowest-possible temperature is assigned the value of zero.']

['What is the purpose of zero degrees on the Kelvin scale?', 'Zero degrees on the Kelvin scale is known as absolute zero; it is theoretically the point at which there is no molecular motion to produce thermal energy.']

['What is one of the main things we should know about the kelvin scale?', 'On the original Kelvin scale first created by Lord Kelvin, all temperatures have positive values, making it useful for scientific work.']
['What is the abbreviation of the official temperature unit?', 'The official temperature unit on this scale is the kelvin, which is abbreviated as K.']
['What is the freezing point of water?', 'The freezing point of water is 273.15 K, and the boiling point of water is 373.15 K.']
['What is the difference between absolute zero and absolute zero in practice?', 'Although absolute zero is possible in theory, it cannot be reached in practice.']

['What is the lowest temperature ever recorded?', 'The lowest temperature ever created and measured during a laboratory experiment was  $$\\(1.0 \\times 10^{- 10}\\)$$  K, at Helsinki University of Technology in Finland.']

['What does that mean?', 'In comparison, the coldest recorded temperature for a place on Earth’s surface was 183 K (–89 \t°C), at Vostok, Antarctica, and the coldest known place (outside the lab) in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula, with a temperature of 1 K. Luckily, most of us humans will never have to experience such extremes.']

['What is important to know about the Fahrenheit scale?', 'While the Fahrenheit scale is still the most commonly used scale in the United States, the majority of the world uses Celsius, and scientists prefer Kelvin.']
['What else is there to know about the scales?', 'It’s often necessary to convert between these scales.']
['How would you describe the temperature of the Earth?', 'For instance, if the TV meteorologist gave the local weather report in kelvins, there would likely be some confused viewers!']
['How is that converted?', 'Table 11.1 gives the equations for conversion between the three temperature scales.']

['What happens when you change temperature?', 'If two objects at different temperatures are brought in contact with each other, energy is transferred from the hotter object (that is, the object with the greater temperature) to the colder (lower temperature) object, until both objects are at the same temperature.']

['What is heat transferred from one object to the other?', 'There is no net heat transfer once the temperatures are equal because the amount of heat transferred from one object to the other is the same as the amount of heat returned.']
['What are the major effects of heat transfer?', 'One of the major effects of heat transfer is temperature change: Heating increases the temperature while cooling decreases it.']

['What are the other factors?', 'Experiments show that the heat transferred to or from a substance depends on three factors—the change in the substance’s temperature, the mass of the substance, and certain physical properties related to the phase of the substance.']
["Let's start the first question with a simple example.", 'where m is the mass of the substance and ΔT is the change in its temperature, in units of Celsius or Kelvin.']
['What does the symbol c stand for?', 'The symbol c stands for specific heat, and depends on the material and phase.']
['What is the specific heat of a substance?', 'The specific heat is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of 1.00 kg of mass by 1.00 ºC.']
['What is the SI unit of specific heat?', 'The specific heat c is a property of the substance; its SI unit is J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ K) or J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ).']

['What is the temperature change ( $$(Delta T)$$ ) in units of kelvins and degrees Celsius (but not degrees Fahrenheit)?', 'The temperature change ( $$\\(\\Delta T\\)$$ ) is the same in units of kelvins and degrees Celsius (but not degrees Fahrenheit).']
['What is the relationship between specific heat and heat capacity?', 'Specific heat is closely related to the concept of heat capacity.']

['What is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$(text°C)$$?', 'Heat capacity is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ .']
['What is the equation of heat capacity?', 'In equation form, heat capacity C is  $$\\(C = mc\\)$$, where m is mass and c is specific heat.']
['What is the importance of heat capacity?', 'Note that heat capacity is the same as specific heat, but without any dependence on mass.']
['Is mass important in heat capacity?', 'Consequently, two objects made up of the same material but with different masses will have different heat capacities.']
['Why is it different?', 'This is because the heat capacity is a property of an object, but specific heat is a property of any object made of the same material.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about this paper?', 'Values of specific heat must be looked up in tables, because there is no simple way to calculate them.']
['What was the table called?', 'Table 11.2 gives the values of specific heat for a few substances as a handy reference.']

['What did you find interesting from the table?', 'We see from this table that the specific heat of water is five times that of glass, which means that it takes five times as much heat to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water than to raise the temperature of 1 kg of glass by the same number of degrees.']
['What happens when there is a temperature difference?', 'Whenever there is a temperature difference, heat transfer occurs.']
['What is an example of heat transfer?', 'Heat transfer may happen rapidly, such as through a cooking pan, or slowly, such as through the walls of an insulated cooler.']
['What are the different heat transfer methods?', 'There are three different heat transfer methods: conduction, convection, and radiation.']
['What happens to all of these?', 'At times, all three may happen simultaneously.']
['What happens next?', 'See Figure 11.3.']
['What is the process of heat transfer through direct physical contact called?', 'Conduction is heat transfer through direct physical contact.']

['What is the term for the transfer of heat between two objects by direct physical contact?', 'Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.']
['What happens to the contact when it is hot?', 'Sometimes, we try to control the conduction of heat to make ourselves more comfortable.']

['What do we try to control?', 'Since the rate of heat transfer is different for different materials, we choose fabrics, such as a thick wool sweater, that slow down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter.']
['How would you explain that?', 'As you walk barefoot across the living room carpet, your feet feel relatively comfortable…until you step onto the kitchen’s tile floor.']
['What causes the temperature of the liquid to change?', 'This is explained by different rates of heat transfer:']
['What is the difference between this example and your other questions?', 'The tile material removes heat from your skin at a greater rate than the carpeting, which makes it feel colder.']
['What is the important part about that?', 'Some materials simply conduct thermal energy faster than others.']

['What type of material is good at transferring heat?', 'In general, metals (like copper, aluminum, gold, and silver) are good heat conductors, whereas materials like wood, plastic, and rubber are poor heat conductors.']
['What is figure 11.4?', 'Figure 11.4 shows particles (either atoms or molecules) in two bodies at different temperatures.']
['What is the difference in kinetic energy between hot and cold?', 'The (average) kinetic energy of a particle in the hot body is higher than in the colder body.']
['What happens when two particles collide?', 'If two particles collide, energy transfers from the particle with greater kinetic energy to the particle with less kinetic energy.']

['What type of collisions are there?', 'When two bodies are in contact, many particle collisions occur, resulting in a net flux of heat from the higher-temperature body to the lower-temperature body.']
['Does the heat flux depend on the temperature difference?', 'The heat flux depends on the temperature difference  $$\\(\\Delta T = T_{\\text{hot}} - T_{\\text{cold}}\\)$$ .']
['What happens to the body in hot water?', 'Therefore, you will get a more severe burn from boiling water than from hot tap water.']
['What is the process of heat transfer by the movement of a fluid called?', 'Convection is heat transfer by the movement of a fluid.']

['Where does this type of heat transfer occur?', 'This type of heat transfer happens, for example, in a pot boiling on the stove, or in thunderstorms, where hot air rises up to the base of the clouds.']
['What is happening with heat?', 'As the temperature of fluids increase, they expand and become less dense.']
['What can you tell me about the figure?', 'For example, Figure 11.4 could represent the wall of a balloon with different temperature gases inside the balloon than outside in the environment.']
['Why is it expanding?', 'The hotter and thus faster moving gas particles inside the balloon strike the surface with more force than the cooler air outside, causing the balloon to expand.']
['What causes it to rise?', 'This decrease in density relative to its environment creates buoyancy (the tendency to rise).']
['What causes hot air to rise?', 'Convection is driven by buoyancy—hot air rises because it is less dense than the surrounding air.']
['What is an example of air movement?', 'Sometimes, we control the temperature of our homes or ourselves by controlling air movement.']
['What are some ways to control the temperature in your home?', 'Sealing leaks around doors with weather stripping keeps out the cold wind in winter.']
['What are some examples of buoyancy by human design?', 'The house in Figure 11.5 and the pot of water on the stove in Figure 11.6 are both examples of convection and buoyancy by human design.']

['What are some other examples of convection?', 'Ocean currents and large-scale atmospheric circulation transfer energy from one part of the globe to another, and are examples of natural convection.']
['What is the term for the transfer of heat energy?', 'Radiation is a form of heat transfer that occurs when electromagnetic radiation is emitted or absorbed.']

['What other types of radiation are there?', 'Electromagnetic radiation includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared radiation, visible light, ultraviolet radiation, X-rays, and gamma rays, all of which have different wavelengths and amounts of energy (shorter wavelengths have higher frequency and more energy).']
['Can you explain how you feel about the heat transfer?', 'You can feel the heat transfer from a fire and from the sun.']
['What can you tell me about the heat transfer?', 'Similarly, you can sometimes tell that the oven is hot without touching its door or looking inside—it may just warm you as you walk by.']

['What is another example of thermal radiation?', 'Another example is thermal radiation from the human body; people are constantly emitting infrared radiation, which is not visible to the human eye, but is felt as heat.']

['What is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required?', 'Radiation is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required, meaning that the heat doesn’t need to come into direct contact with or be transported by any matter.']
['What other important things should I know about radiation?', 'The space between Earth and the sun is largely empty, without any possibility of heat transfer by convection or conduction.']
['How does heat transfer between them work?', 'Instead, heat is transferred by radiation, and Earth is warmed as it absorbs electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun.']
['What do you think is the most important thing in the content in this section?', 'All objects absorb and emit electromagnetic radiation (see Figure 11.7).']
['What else did you find out?', 'The rate of heat transfer by radiation depends mainly on the color of the object.']
['What color is the black object compared to the white object?', 'Black is the most effective absorber and radiator, and white is the least effective.']
['Did you find that out to be beneficial?', 'People living in hot climates generally avoid wearing black clothing, for instance.']
['What else was interesting in the section?', 'Similarly, black asphalt in a parking lot will be hotter than adjacent patches of grass on a summer day, because black absorbs better than green.']
['How is black different from green?', 'The reverse is also true—black radiates better than green.']

['What did you find out that impacted the color of objects?', 'On a clear summer night, the black asphalt will be colder than the green patch of grass, because black radiates energy faster than green.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about the section?', 'In contrast, white is a poor absorber and also a poor radiator.']
['What does white reflect?', 'A white object reflects nearly all radiation, like a mirror.']
['What has this study material covered?', 'So far, we have learned that adding thermal energy by heat increases the temperature of a substance.']
['Why is that the case?', 'But surprisingly, there are situations where adding energy does not change the temperature of a substance at all!']
['What happens when the temperature of a liquid increases?', 'Instead, the additional thermal energy acts to loosen bonds between molecules or atoms and causes a phase change.']

["What's the significance of latent heat?", 'Because this energy enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change in the system, it is known as latent heat (latent means hidden).']
['What are the three phases of matter that you frequently encounter?', 'The three phases of matter that you frequently encounter are solid, liquid and gas (see Figure 11.8).']

['What is the least energetic state?', 'Solid has the least energetic state; atoms in solids are in close contact, with forces between them that allow the particles to vibrate but not change position with neighboring particles.']
['What other important information can you share with us?', '(These forces can be thought of as springs that can be stretched or compressed, but not easily broken.)']
['What is the difference between gas and liquid?', 'Gas has a more energetic state than liquid, in which particles are broken free of their bonds.']
['What makes the difference between gases and liquids?', 'Particles in gases are separated by distances that are large compared with the size of the particles.']
['What is the most energetic state of all?', 'The most energetic state of all is plasma.']

['Did you know that plasma is the most common state of matter in the universe?', 'Although you may not have heard much about plasma, it is actually the most common state of matter in the universe—stars are made up of plasma, as is lightning.']

['What happens when a gas is heated to the point where particles are pulled apart?', 'The plasma state is reached by heating a gas to the point where particles are pulled apart, separating the electrons from the rest of the particle.']
['What is plasma made of?', 'This produces an ionized gas that is a combination of the negatively charged free electrons and positively charged ions, known as plasma.']
['What is the reason energy is required to melt a solid?', 'Energy is required to melt a solid because the bonds between the particles in the solid must be broken.']

['What happens after the bonds are broken?', 'Since the energy involved in a phase changes is used to break bonds, there is no increase in the kinetic energies of the particles, and therefore no rise in temperature.']
['Why is energy required to vaporize a liquid?', 'Similarly, energy is needed to vaporize a liquid to overcome the attractive forces between particles in the liquid.']
['What is the reason there is no temperature change?', 'There is no temperature change until a phase change is completed.']

['How would you describe this process in a simpler way?', 'The temperature of a cup of soda and ice that is initially at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  stays at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  until all of the ice has melted.']
['What happens in the reverse?', 'In the reverse of these processes—freezing and condensation—energy is released from the latent heat (see Figure 11.9).']
['What can you tell me about the formula and equation?', 'where  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  is the latent heat of fusion, and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  is the latent heat of vaporization.']
['What is the latent heat of fusion?', 'The latent heat of fusion is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between solid and liquid.']
['What is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas?', 'The latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas.']

['What are the standard units for these?', '$$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  are coefficients that vary from substance to substance, depending on the strength of intermolecular forces, and both have standard units of J/kg.']
['What are some of the values for these coefficients?', 'See Table 11.3 for values of  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  of different substances.']
['Is there anything else?', 'Let’s consider the example of adding heat to ice to examine its transitions through all three phases—solid to liquid to gas.']
['What is the temperature of water when energy is added?', 'A phase diagram indicating the temperature changes of water as energy is added is shown in Figure 11.10.']
['What is in this picture?', 'The ice starts out at −20 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, and its temperature rises linearly, absorbing heat at a constant rate until it reaches 0 $$\\(\\text{°}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What happens next?', 'Once at this temperature, the ice gradually melts, absorbing 334 kJ/kg.']
['What happens during this phase change?', 'The temperature remains constant at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  during this phase change.']
['What happens to the liquid water when it is heated?', 'Once all the ice has melted, the temperature of the liquid water rises, absorbing heat at a new constant rate.']
['Is there anything else?', 'At 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, the water begins to boil and the temperature again remains constant while the water absorbs 2256 kJ/kg during this phase change.']
['What happens after the liquid has become steam?', 'When all the liquid has become steam, the temperature rises again at a constant rate.']
['What else did you know about vaporization?', 'We have seen that vaporization requires heat transfer to a substance from its surroundings.']
['What is condensation?', 'Condensation is the reverse process, where heat in transferred away from a substance to its surroundings.']
['What happens when the heat is transferred away?', 'This release of latent heat increases the temperature of the surroundings.']
['What is important to know about condensing a vapor?', 'Energy must be removed from the condensing particles to make a vapor condense.']
['What happens when the warm vapor meets the cold surface?', 'This is why condensation occurs on cold surfaces: the heat transfers energy away from the warm vapor to the cold surface.']

['How can you calculate the energy required to cause the phase change from liquid to vapor?', 'The energy is exactly the same as that required to cause the phase change in the other direction, from liquid to vapor, and so it can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{v}\\)$$ .']
['What else do you know about latent heat?', 'Latent heat is also released into the environment when a liquid freezes, and can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{f}\\)$$ .']

['What did you learn in the previous chapter?', 'We learned in the previous chapter that when two objects (or systems) are in contact with one another, heat will transfer thermal energy from the object at higher temperature to the one at lower temperature until they both reach the same temperature.']
['How does that affect the system?', 'The objects are then in thermal equilibrium, and no further temperature changes will occur if they are isolated from other systems.']
['What causes the systems to interact and change?', 'The systems interact and change because their temperatures are different, and the changes stop once their temperatures are the same.']

['What is the importance of thermal equilibrium?', 'Thermal equilibrium is established when two bodies are in thermal contact with each other—meaning heat transfer (i.e., the transfer of energy by heat) can occur between them.']
['What happens if two systems cannot freely exchange energy?', 'If two systems cannot freely exchange energy, they will not reach thermal equilibrium.']

['What is the state of thermal equilibrium with the sun?', '(It is fortunate that empty space stands between Earth and the sun, because a state of thermal equilibrium with the sun would be too toasty for life on this planet!)']

['What did you study in Section Key Terms?', 'If two systems, A and B, are in thermal equilibrium with each another, and B is in thermal equilibrium with a third system, C, then A is also in thermal equilibrium with C.']

['Does this mean if A is in thermal equilibrium with C, the temperature of B will remain?', 'This statement may seem obvious, because all three have the same temperature, but it is basic to thermodynamics.']
['What is the zeroth law of thermodynamics?', 'It is called the zeroth law of thermodynamics.']

['When was the third law discovered?', 'The explanation is that this law was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics but is so fundamental that scientists decided it should logically come first.']
['Why does the zeroth law need to be considered for newborn babies?', 'As an example of the zeroth law in action, consider newborn babies in neonatal intensive-care units in hospitals.']
['What are neonatal intensive-care units used for?', 'Prematurely born or sick newborns are placed in special incubators.']

['What should be done to keep babies warm in special incubators?', 'These babies have very little covering while in the incubators, so to an observer, they look as though they may not be warm enough.']
['What causes the babies not to be warm enough?', 'However, inside the incubator, the temperature of the air, the cot, and the baby are all the same—that is, they are in thermal equilibrium.']
['What happens if the ambient temperature is too low?', 'The ambient temperature is just high enough to keep the baby safe and comfortable.']
['What is the purpose of these study materials?', 'Before covering the first law of thermodynamics, it is first important to understand the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.']
['What is pressure defined as?', 'Pressure, P, is defined as']
['What is the main concept of the passage?', 'Pressure is defined for all states of matter but is particularly important when discussing fluids (such as air).']

['What are some examples of pressure?', 'You have probably heard the word pressure being used in relation to blood (high or low blood pressure) and in relation to the weather (high- and low-pressure weather systems).']
['What are the examples of?', 'These are only two of many examples of pressures in fluids.']

['What is the relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas?', 'The relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas is given by the ideal gas law.']
['What is the definition of ideal gas?', 'A gas is considered ideal at low pressure and fairly high temperature, and forces between its component particles can be ignored.']
['What does the ideal gas law state?', 'The ideal gas law states that']

['What else should I know about this?', 'where P is the pressure of a gas, V is the volume it occupies, N is the number of particles (atoms or molecules) in the gas, and T is its absolute temperature.']
['What is the constant k called?', 'The constant k is called the Boltzmann constant and has the value  $$\\(k = 1.38 \\times 10^{-23}\\text{J/K}\\text{,}\\)$$']
['Can you explain this further?', 'For the purposes of this chapter, we will not go into calculations using the ideal gas law.']
['What else should we learn from this chapter?', 'Instead, it is important for us to notice from the equation that the following are true for a given mass of gas:']
['What is the unit used in this equation?', 'When volume is constant, pressure is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What is the formula for pressure?', 'When temperature is constant, pressure is inversely proportional to volume.']
['What can we learn from this equation?', 'When pressure is constant, volume is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What was our last point?', 'This last point describes thermal expansion—the change in size or volume of a given mass with temperature.']
['What does the heat do to the liquids?', 'An increase in temperature means that there’s an increase in the kinetic energy of the individual atoms.']

['How does gas expand?', 'Gases are especially affected by thermal expansion, although liquids expand to a lesser extent with similar increases in temperature, and even solids have minor expansions at higher temperatures.']
['Are railroad tracks expandable?', 'This is why railroad tracks and bridges have expansion joints that allow them to freely expand and contract with temperature changes.']

['What is a key element in this document?', 'To get some idea of how pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas are related to one another, consider what happens when you pump air into a deflated tire.']
['What happens to the tire as you pump air into it?', 'The tire’s volume first increases in direct proportion to the amount of air injected, without much increase in the tire pressure.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about the tire?', 'Once the tire has expanded to nearly its full size, the walls limit volume expansion.']

['What else happens with the tire after expansion?', 'If you continue to pump air into tire (which now has a nearly constant volume), the pressure increases with increasing temperature (see Figure 12.4).']
['What is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid?', 'Pressure–volume work is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid.']
['What happens when the volume is increased?', 'Whenever there is a change in volume and external pressure remains constant, pressure–volume work is taking place.']
['What happens when the volume decreases?', 'During a compression, a decrease in volume increases the internal pressure of a system as work is done on the system.']
['What happens when the volume increases?', 'During an expansion (Figure 12.5), an increase in volume decreases the internal pressure of a system as the system does work.']
['What is the formula for work?', 'Recall that the formula for work is  $$\\(W = Fd.\\)$$']
['How can you use the formula for work?', 'We can rearrange the definition of pressure,  $$\\(P = \\frac{F}{A},\\)$$  to get an expression for force in terms of pressure.']

['What kind of work is force acting over a distance?', 'Just as we say that work is force acting over a distance, for fluids, we can say that work is the pressure acting through the change in volume.']
['What is the analogy between pressure and force?', 'For pressure–volume work, pressure is analogous to force, and volume is analogous to distance in the traditional definition of work.']
['What is the first law of thermodynamics?', 'Heat (Q) and work (W) are the two ways to add or remove energy from a system.']
['Are there any other aspects to this?', 'The processes are very different.']
['What is the difference between heat and work?', 'Heat is driven by temperature differences, while work involves a force exerted through a distance.']
['Are they the same in any other way?', 'Nevertheless, heat and work can produce identical results.']
['What is the difference between a hot and cold object?', 'For example, both can cause a temperature increase.']
['What is another example of heat transfer?', 'Heat transfers energy into a system, such as when the sun warms the air in a bicycle tire and increases the air’s temperature.']

['What else should I know?', 'Once the temperature increase has occurred, it is impossible to tell whether it was caused by heat or work.']
['What is the difference between heat and work?', 'Heat and work are both energy in transit—neither is stored as such in a system.']
['What does this mean?', 'However, both can change the internal energy, U, of a system.']

['What is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules called?', 'Internal energy is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules.']

['What is the most important thing to know about energy?', 'It can be divided into many subcategories, such as thermal and chemical energy, and depends only on the state of a system (that is, P, V, and T), not on how the energy enters or leaves the system.']
['What is the first law of thermodynamics?', 'In order to understand the relationship between heat, work, and internal energy, we use the first law of thermodynamics.']

['What does the first law of thermodynamics apply to?', 'The first law of thermodynamics applies the conservation of energy principle to systems where heat and work are the methods of transferring energy into and out of the systems.']
['What can it be used to describe?', 'It can also be used to describe how energy transferred by heat is converted and transferred again by work.']

['What does the first law of thermodynamics state?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy of a closed system equals the net heat transfer into the system minus the net work done by the system.']

['What is the meaning of delta U?', 'Here,  $$\\(\\Delta U\\)$$ is the change in internal energy, U, of the system.']
['What is the net heat transferred into the system?', 'As shown in Figure 12.6, Q is the net heat transferred into the system—that is, Q is the sum of all heat transfers into and out of the system.']
['What is the net work done by the system?', 'W is the net work done by the system—that is, W is the sum of all work done on or by the system.']
['What is the difference between Q and W?', 'By convention, if Q is positive, then there is a net heat transfer into the system; if W is positive, then there is net work done by the system.']
['What is the difference between Q and W?', 'So positive Q adds energy to the system by heat, and positive W takes energy from the system by work.']
['Are there any other important points I should know?', 'Note that if heat transfers more energy into the system than that which is done by work, the difference is stored as internal energy.']
['Did you learn anything about engines?', 'Recall from the chapter introduction that it is not even theoretically possible for engines to be 100 percent efficient.']
['What is the cause of this?', 'This phenomenon is explained by the second law of thermodynamics, which relies on a concept known as entropy.']
['What is entropy?', 'Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.']
['What does entropy also describe?', 'Entropy also describes how much energy is not available to do work.']
['What are some other things to know about entropy?', "The more disordered a system and higher the entropy, the less of a system's energy is available to do work."]
['What is the main idea behind entropy?', 'Although all forms of energy can be used to do work, it is not possible to use the entire available energy for work.']

['What other things can be done with heat?', 'Consequently, not all energy transferred by heat can be converted into work, and some of it is lost in the form of waste heat—that is, heat that does not go toward doing work.']

['What is the field that originated from efforts to convert heat to work, as is done by engines?', 'The unavailability of energy is important in thermodynamics; in fact, the field originated from efforts to convert heat to work, as is done by engines.']

['Did you get pranked with a card and play that card?', 'If so, you have been on the receiving end of a practical joke and, in the process, learned a valuable lesson about the nature of the universe as described by the second law of thermodynamics.']
['What card are you talking about?', 'In the game of 52 pickup, the prankster tosses an entire deck of playing cards onto the floor, and you get to pick them up.']

['What is the value lesson?', 'In the process of picking up the cards, you may have noticed that the amount of work required to restore the cards to an orderly state in the deck is much greater than the amount of work required to toss the cards and create the disorder.']

['What is the second law of thermodynamics?', 'The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any spontaneous process; it never decreases.']

['What is an important implication of this law?', 'An important implication of this law is that heat transfers energy spontaneously from higher- to lower-temperature objects, but never spontaneously in the reverse direction.']
['Why is it never spontaneous?', 'This is because entropy increases for heat transfer of energy from hot to cold (Figure 12.9).']
['What does it mean for entropy to increase at low temperatures?', 'Because the change in entropy is Q/T, there is a larger change in  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$  at lower temperatures (smaller T).']

['why does it increase?', 'The decrease in entropy of the hot (larger T) object is therefore less than the increase in entropy of the cold (smaller T) object, producing an overall increase in entropy for the system.']
['What does this mean?', 'Another way of thinking about this is that it is impossible for any process to have, as its sole result, heat transferring energy from a cooler to a hotter object.']
["Why can't heat transfer energy spontaneously from colder to hotter?", 'Heat cannot transfer energy spontaneously from colder to hotter, because the entropy of the overall system would decrease.']

['What is the most important information that I should know before we begin?', 'Suppose we mix equal masses of water that are originally at two different temperatures, say  $$\\(\\text{20}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{40}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']
['What happens when the two temperatures are combined?', 'The result will be water at an intermediate temperature of  $$\\(\\text{30}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']

['What is the final outcome of a system becoming disordered?', 'Three outcomes have resulted: entropy has increased, some energy has become unavailable to do work, and the system has become less orderly.']
['What happened after that?', 'Let us think about each of these results.']
['What is the first lesson?', 'Mixing the two bodies of water has the same effect as the heat transfer of energy from the higher-temperature substance to the lower-temperature substance.']
['What else does the mixing do?', 'The mixing decreases the entropy of the hotter water but increases the entropy of the colder water by a greater amount, producing an overall increase in entropy.']
['What does this law define?', 'Second, once the two masses of water are mixed, there is no more temperature difference left to drive energy transfer by heat and therefore to do work.']
['What happens to the energy in the water?', 'The energy is still in the water, but it is now unavailable to do work.']
['What is the second law of thermodynamics?', 'Third, the mixture is less orderly, or to use another term, less structured.']

['What are the three results?', 'These three results—entropy, unavailability of energy, and disorder—not only are related but are, in fact, essentially equivalent.']

['What is a specific thing we need to know about the second law?', 'A cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter.']
['What is the most important thing we need to know about the automobile?', 'Nor does a hot, stationary automobile ever spontaneously cool off and start moving.']
['What is one of the examples of the law?', 'Another example is the expansion of a puff of gas introduced into one corner of a vacuum chamber.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about this?', 'The random motion of the gas molecules could take them all back to the corner, but this is never observed to happen (Figure 12.10).']

['What is a simple water wave?', 'Most waves do not look very simple.']
['How do they look?', 'They look more like the waves in Figure 13.10, rather than the simple water wave considered in the previous sections, which has a perfect sinusoidal shape.']
['How do the two simple waves combine?', 'Waves superimpose by adding their disturbances; each disturbance corresponds to a force, and all the forces add.']

['How do the disturbances add?', 'If the disturbances are along the same line, then the resulting wave is a simple addition of the disturbances of the individual waves, that is, their amplitudes add.']
['What is the most important point of the study material?', 'Pure constructive interference occurs when two identical waves arrive at the same point exactly in phase.']
['how is precisely aligned?', 'When waves are exactly in phase, the crests of the two waves are precisely aligned, as are the troughs.']
['What is the figure that shows the tidal flow?', 'Refer to Figure 13.11.']

['What is the pure constructive interference of two waves with the same amplitude?', 'Because the disturbances add, the pure constructive interference of two waves with the same amplitude produces a wave that has twice the amplitude of the two individual waves, but has the same wavelength.']

['What is the main idea of this study material?', 'Figure 13.12 shows two identical waves that arrive exactly out of phase—that is, precisely aligned crest to trough—producing pure destructive interference.']

['What else can you tell me about pure destructive interference?', 'Because the disturbances are in opposite directions for this superposition, the resulting amplitude is zero for pure destructive interference; that is, the waves completely cancel out each other.']

['What is the difference between constructive interference and destructive interference?', 'While pure constructive interference and pure destructive interference can occur, they are not very common because they require precisely aligned identical waves.']

['What else do you want to know about the superposition of most waves that we see in nature?', 'The superposition of most waves that we see in nature produces a combination of constructive and destructive interferences.']
['What are other special cases?', 'Waves that are not results of pure constructive or destructive interference can vary from place to place and time to time.']
['What does varying loudness mean?', 'The sound from a stereo, for example, can be loud in one spot and soft in another.']
['What does the varying loudness mean?', 'The varying loudness means that the sound waves add partially constructively and partially destructively at different locations.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'A stereo has at least two speakers that create sound waves, and waves can reflect from walls.']
['What happens to the sound waves when they reflect from the walls?', 'All these waves superimpose.']

['What is an example of sounds that vary over time from constructive to destructive?', 'An example of sounds that vary over time from constructive to destructive is found in the combined whine of jet engines heard by a stationary passenger.']
['What happens to the volume of the combined sound?', 'The volume of the combined sound can fluctuate up and down as the sound from the two engines varies in time from constructive to destructive.']

['What are the two previous examples?', 'The two previous examples considered waves that are similar—both stereo speakers generate sound waves with the same amplitude and wavelength, as do the jet engines.']
['Did we get any further explanation about the two previous examples?', 'An example of the superposition of two dissimilar waves is shown in Figure 13.13.']
['What is the difference between the previous examples?', 'Here again, the disturbances add and subtract, but they produce an even more complicated-looking wave.']

['Why does it look different than the normal looking wave?', 'The resultant wave from the combined disturbances of two dissimilar waves looks much different than the idealized sinusoidal shape of a periodic wave.']
['What is the difference between standing waves and solitary waves?', 'Sometimes waves do not seem to move and they appear to just stand in place, vibrating.']
['What happens when waves are standing in place?', 'Such waves are called standing waves and are formed by the superposition of two or more waves moving in opposite directions.']
['Can you tell me more about constructive interference?', 'If the two waves have the same amplitude and wavelength, then they alternate between constructive and destructive interference.']
['What was the first example you gave us?', 'Standing waves created by the superposition of two identical waves moving in opposite directions are illustrated in Figure 13.14.']
['What is a good example of standing waves?', 'As an example, standing waves can be seen on the surface of a glass of milk in a refrigerator.']

['What causes the standing waves on the glass of milk in a refrigerator?', 'The vibrations from the refrigerator motor create waves on the milk that oscillate up and down but do not seem to move across the surface.']
["Why don't the waves move across the surface?", 'The two waves that produce standing waves may be due to the reflections from the side of the glass.']
['What can earthquakes cause?', 'Earthquakes can create standing waves and cause constructive and destructive interferences.']

['What are the differences between constructive interference and destructive interference?', 'As the earthquake waves travel along the surface of Earth and reflect off denser rocks, constructive interference occurs at certain points.']
['Are there any other important things I need to know?', 'As a result, areas closer to the epicenter are not damaged while areas farther from the epicenter are damaged.']
['What is a standing wave?', 'Standing waves are also found on the strings of musical instruments and are due to reflections of waves from the ends of the string.']

['What is the name of the figure that shows three standing waves that can be created on a string that is fixed at both ends?', 'Figure 13.15 and Figure 13.16 show three standing waves that can be created on a string that is fixed at both ends.']
['Why does the wave reflect back to where it came from?', 'When the wave reaches the fixed end, it has nowhere else to go but back where it came from, causing the reflection.']

['What are the points where the string does not move?', 'The nodes are the points where the string does not move; more generally, the nodes are the points where the wave disturbance is zero in a standing wave.']
['What are the fixed ends of strings?', 'The fixed ends of strings must be nodes, too, because the string cannot move there.']
['What is the location of maximum amplitude in standing waves called?', 'The antinode is the location of maximum amplitude in standing waves.']

['What is the frequency of standing waves on a string?', 'The standing waves on a string have a frequency that is related to the propagation speed  $$\\(v_{w}\\)$$  of the disturbance on the string.']
['What is the wavelength of standing waves?', 'The wavelength  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is determined by the distance between the points where the string is fixed in place.']

['What is the change in direction of a wave when it bounces off a barrier, such as a fixed end?', 'As we saw in the case of standing waves on the strings of a musical instrument, reflection is the change in direction of a wave when it bounces off a barrier, such as a fixed end.']
['Why is it changed?', 'When the wave hits the fixed end, it changes direction, returning to its source.']
['What do we mean by flips vertically?', 'As it is reflected, the wave experiences an inversion, which means that it flips vertically.']
['What happens to a wave when it hits the fixed end with a crest?', 'If a wave hits the fixed end with a crest, it will return as a trough, and vice versa (Henderson 2015).']
['What is the best example of a symbiotic relationship?', 'Refer to Figure 13.17.']
['What is refraction?', 'Rather than encountering a fixed end or barrier, waves sometimes pass from one medium into another, for instance, from air into water.']
['What happens after that?', 'Different types of media have different properties, such as density or depth, that affect how a wave travels through them.']
['What happens after that?', 'At the boundary between media, waves experience refraction—they change their path of propagation.']
['What happens after the wave bends?', 'As the wave bends, it also changes its speed and wavelength upon entering the new medium.']
['How can you tell me where you want me to refer?', 'Refer to Figure 13.18.']
['What kind of refraction is this?', 'For example, water waves traveling from the deep end to the shallow end of a swimming pool experience refraction.']
['What happens to the waves as they travel?', 'They bend in a path closer to perpendicular to the surface of the water, propagate slower, and decrease in wavelength as they enter shallower water.']
['What is sound?', 'Sound is a wave.']
['What is sound defined to be?', 'More specifically, sound is defined to be a disturbance of matter that is transmitted from its source outward.']
['What is a disturbance?', 'A disturbance is anything that is moved from its state of equilibrium.']
['What is harmonic motion?', 'Some sound waves can be characterized as periodic waves, which means that the atoms that make up the matter experience simple harmonic motion.']
['What is the property of a vibrating string?', 'A vibrating string produces a sound wave as illustrated in Figure 14.2, Figure 14.3, and Figure 14.4.']
['What happens to the surrounding air as a string vibrates?', 'As the string oscillates back and forth, part of the string’s energy goes into compressing and expanding the surrounding air.']
['What happens as the string vibrates?', 'This creates slightly higher and lower pressures.']
['What is the relationship between higher and lower pressures?', 'The higher pressure... regions are compressions, and the low pressure regions are rarefactions.']
['How does the pressure disturbance move through the air?', 'The pressure disturbance moves through the air as longitudinal waves with the same frequency as the string.']
['What happens to the energy?', 'Some of the energy is lost in the form of thermal energy transferred to the air.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of the article?', 'You may recall from the chapter on waves that areas of compression and rarefaction in longitudinal waves (such as sound) are analogous to crests and troughs in transverse waves.']

['What happens when we move further away from a source?', 'The amplitude of a sound wave decreases with distance from its source, because the energy of the wave is spread over a larger and larger area.']
['Why is this?', 'But some of the energy is also absorbed by objects, such as the eardrum in Figure 14.5, and some of the energy is converted to thermal energy in the air.']
['What is the most important thing to know about this topic?', 'Figure 14.4 shows a graph of gauge pressure versus distance from the vibrating string.']

['What can you tell me about the figure?', 'From this figure, you can see that the compression of a longitudinal wave is analogous to the peak of a transverse wave, and the rarefaction of a longitudinal wave is analogous to the trough of a transverse wave.']

['What are the parallels between the transverse wave and longitudinal wave?', 'Just as a transverse wave alternates between peaks and troughs, a longitudinal wave alternates between compression and rarefaction.']
['What is the speed of sound?', 'The speed of sound varies greatly depending upon the medium it is traveling through.']
['What determines the speed of sound in a medium?', 'The speed of sound in a medium is determined by a combination of the medium’s rigidity (or compressibility in gases) and its density.']
['Is the harder the medium, the faster it travels?', 'The more rigid (or less compressible) the medium, the faster the speed of sound.']
['Does the density of the medium have an effect on the speed of sound?', 'The greater the density of a medium, the slower the speed of sound.']
['Does air have an effect on sound?', 'The speed of sound in air is low, because air is compressible.']

['Is liquid or solid faster to travel through?', 'Because liquids and solids are relatively rigid and very difficult to compress, the speed of sound in such media is generally greater than in gases.']
['What is the table for?', 'Table 14.1 shows the speed of sound in various media.']

['What else is important to know?', 'Since temperature affects density, the speed of sound varies with the temperature of the medium through which it’s traveling to some extent, especially for gases.']
['What is the most important information in the article?', 'Sound, like all waves, travels at certain speeds through different media and has the properties of frequency and wavelength.']

['How does sound travel?', 'Sound travels much slower than light—you can observe this while watching a fireworks display (see Figure 14.6), since the flash of an explosion is seen before its sound is heard.']

['What is the equation for the speed of sound?', 'where v is the speed of sound (in units of m/s), f is its frequency (in units of hertz), and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is its wavelength (in units of meters).']
['What is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a wave?', 'Recall that wavelength is defined as the distance between adjacent identical parts of a wave.']
['What is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a sound wave?', 'The wavelength of a sound, therefore, is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a sound wave.']

['What is the distance between adjacent compressions in a sound wave?', 'Just as the distance between adjacent crests in a transverse wave is one wavelength, the distance between adjacent compressions in a sound wave is also one wavelength, as shown in Figure 14.7.']
['What is the frequency of a sound wave?', 'The frequency of a sound wave is the same as that of the source.']
['What is an example of a sound wave?', 'For example, a tuning fork vibrating at a given frequency would produce sound waves that oscillate at that same frequency.']
['What is the frequency of a sound?', 'The frequency of a sound is the number of waves that pass a point per unit time.']
['What is one of the more important properties of sound?', 'One of the more important properties of sound is that its speed is nearly independent of frequency.']

['What does sound speed have to do with?', 'If this were not the case, and high-frequency sounds traveled faster, for example, then the farther you were from a band in a football stadium, the more the sound from the low-pitch instruments would lag behind the high-pitch ones.']
['What does sound speed have to do with instruments?', 'But the music from all instruments arrives in cadence independent of distance, and so all frequencies must travel at nearly the same speed.']
['What is the question related to sound waves?', 'Recall that  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\)$$, and in a given medium under fixed temperature and humidity, v is constant.']
['How is that related to sound waves?', 'Therefore, the relationship between f and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is inverse:']
['What is the relationship between frequency and wavelength of sound?', 'The higher the frequency, the shorter the wavelength of a sound wave.']
['What happens to sound when it travels?', 'The speed of sound can change when sound travels from one medium to another.']

['What happens to frequency when the frequency is driven?', 'However, the frequency usually remains the same because it is like a driven oscillation and maintains the frequency of the original source.']
['how does wavelength change?', 'If v changes and f remains the same, then the wavelength  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  must change.']
['What is the relationship between v and wavelength?', 'Since  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\)$$, the higher the speed of a sound, the greater its wavelength for a given frequency.']
['What was one of the most interesting things you learned in your lessons?', 'In a quiet forest, you can sometimes hear a single leaf fall to the ground.']
['Do you think that fact also pertains to other things?', 'But in a traffic jam filled with honking cars, you may have to shout just so the person next to you can hear Figure 14.9.']
['What is the relationship between loudness and energy?', 'The loudness of a sound is related to how energetically its source is vibrating.']

['What does the cartoon depiction mean?', 'In cartoons showing a screaming person, the cartoonist often shows an open mouth with a vibrating uvula (the hanging tissue at the back of the mouth) to represent a loud sound coming from the throat.']
['What is another example of a cartoon depiction?', 'Figure 14.10 shows such a cartoon depiction of a bird loudly expressing its opinion.']
['What is sound intensity?', 'A useful quantity for describing the loudness of sounds is called sound intensity.']
['How does it relate to the wave?', 'In general, the intensity of a wave is the power per unit area carried by the wave.']
['What is power?', 'Power is the rate at which energy is transferred by the wave.']
['What is the equation form of intensity I?', 'In equation form, intensity I is']
['What is the SI unit for I?', 'where P is the power through an area A. The SI unit for I is W/m2.']
['What else is important about I?', 'The intensity of a sound depends upon its pressure amplitude.']
['How does this influence sound?', 'The relationship between the intensity of a sound wave and its pressure amplitude (or pressure variation Δp) is']

['What is the density of the material in which the sound wave travels, in units of kg/m3?', 'where ρ is the density of the material in which the sound wave travels, in units of kg/m3, and v is the speed of sound in the medium, in units of m/s.']
['What is the unit of Pressure amplitude?', 'Pressure amplitude has units of pascals (Pa) or N/m2.']
['What is the difference between the maximum and minimum pressure in the sound wave?', 'Note that Δp is half the difference between the maximum and minimum pressure in the sound wave.']
['What is the content of this study material?', 'We can see from the equation that the intensity of a sound is proportional to its amplitude squared.']
['What is the difference between p and (p)2?', 'The pressure variation is proportional to the amplitude of the oscillation, and so I varies as (Δp)2.']

['What is the relationship between the sound wave and the air pressure?', 'This relationship is consistent with the fact that the sound wave is produced by some vibration; the greater its pressure amplitude, the more the air is compressed during the vibration.']

['What is the difference between amplitude squared and energy?', 'Because the power of a sound wave is the rate at which energy is transferred, the energy of a sound wave is also proportional to its amplitude squared.']
['What does it describe?', 'You may have noticed that when people talk about the loudness of a sound, they describe it in units of decibels rather than watts per meter squared.']
['What is the SI unit for sound intensity?', 'While sound intensity (in W/m2) is the SI unit, the sound intensity level in decibels (dB) is more relevant for how humans perceive sounds.']
['How does it help?', 'The way our ears perceive sound can be more accurately described by the logarithm of the intensity of a sound rather than the intensity of a sound directly.']
['What does the sound intensity level denote?', 'The sound intensity level β is defined to be']
['How is this important?', 'where I is sound intensity in watts per meter squared, and I0 = 10–12 W/m2 is a reference intensity.']
['What is the reason I0 is chosen as the reference point?', 'I0 is chosen as the reference point because it is the lowest intensity of sound a person with normal hearing can perceive.']
['Does this change the decibel level of a sound?', 'The decibel level of a sound having an intensity of 10–12 W/m2 is β = 0 dB, because log10 1 = 0.']
['What is the threshold of human hearing?', 'That is, the threshold of human hearing is 0 decibels.']
['What is a factor of 10 in intensity?', 'Each factor of 10 in intensity corresponds to 10 dB.']
['What is an example of how to use a factor of 10?', 'For example, a 90 dB sound compared with a 60 dB sound is 30 dB greater, or three factors of 10 (that is, 103 times) as intense.']
['What is another example?', 'Another example is that if one sound is 107 as intense as another, it is 70 dB higher.']
['What is defined in terms of?', 'Since β is defined in terms of a ratio, it is unit-less.']
['How does the decibel help define?', 'The unit called decibel (dB) is used to indicate that this ratio is multiplied by 10.']

['What is the sound intensity level?', 'The sound intensity level is not the same as sound intensity—it tells you the level of the sound relative to a reference intensity rather than the actual intensity.']
['How do we create sounds?', 'People create sounds by pushing air up through their lungs and through elastic folds in the throat called vocal cords.']
['What happens with the folds?', 'These folds open and close rhythmically, creating a pressure buildup.']
['What happens to the air when it travels up and past the vocal cords?', 'As air travels up and past the vocal cords, it causes them to vibrate.']
['What happens when you speak?', 'This vibration escapes the mouth along with puffs of air as sound.']
['What happens when the vocal cords relax or tighten?', 'A voice changes in pitch when the muscles of the larynx relax or tighten, changing the tension on the vocal chords.']
['How can you make your voice louder?', 'A voice becomes louder when air flow from the lungs increases, making the amplitude of the sound pressure wave greater.']
['What is the perception of sound called?', 'Hearing is the perception of sound.']
['What can sound tell us?', 'It can give us plenty of information—such as pitch, loudness, and direction.']
['Do humans have different hearing ranges?', 'Humans can normally hear frequencies ranging from approximately 20 to 20,000 Hz.']
['What about animals?', 'Other animals have hearing ranges different from that of humans.']
['What are the different ranges of sound?', 'Dogs can hear sounds as high as 45,000 Hz, whereas bats and dolphins can hear up to 110,000 Hz sounds.']
['What is interesting about this?', 'You may have noticed that dogs respond to the sound of a dog whistle which produces sound out of the range of human hearing.']
['What are infrasound?', 'Sounds below 20']
['What are sounds below 20,000 Hz called?', 'Hz are called infrasound, whereas those above 20,000 Hz are ultrasound.']
['What is the perception of frequency called?', 'The perception of frequency is called pitch, and the perception of intensity is called loudness.']
['What kind of physics is hearing?', 'The way we hear involves some interesting physics.']
['What is the sound wave that hits our ear called?', 'The sound wave that hits our ear is a pressure wave.']
['What else does the ear convert into?', 'The ear converts sound waves into electrical nerve impulses, similar to a microphone.']

['What is the anatomy of the ear with its division into three parts?', 'Figure 14.11 shows the anatomy of the ear with its division into three parts: the outer ear or ear canal; the middle ear, which runs from the eardrum to the cochlea; and the inner ear, which is the cochlea itself.']
['What is the outer ear called?', 'The body part normally referred to as the ear is technically called the pinna.']
['What is the outer ear called?', 'The outer ear, or ear canal, carries sound to the eardrum protected inside of the ear.']
['What does the middle ear convert sound into?', 'The middle ear converts sound into mechanical vibrations and applies these vibrations to the cochlea.']

['What does the lever system of the middle ear take the force exerted on the eardrum by sound pressure variations, amplifies it and transmits it to the inner ear via the oval window?', 'The lever system of the middle ear takes the force exerted on the eardrum by sound pressure variations, amplifies it and transmits it to the inner ear via the oval window.']
['What does the middle ear protect against?', 'Two muscles in the middle ear protect the inner ear from very intense sounds.']
['How do they protect against the sounds?', 'They react to intense sound in a few milliseconds and reduce the force transmitted to the cochlea.']
['What else did you learn?', 'This protective reaction can also be triggered by your own voice, so that humming during a fireworks display, for example, can reduce noise damage.']
['What can you tell me about the inner ear?', 'Figure 14.12 shows the middle and inner ear in greater detail.']
['What are the fluid inside it?', 'As the middle ear bones vibrate, they vibrate the cochlea, which contains fluid.']
['What does this cause?', 'This creates pressure waves in the fluid that cause the tectorial membrane to vibrate.']
['What is the effect of the motion of the tectorial membrane?', 'The motion of the tectorial membrane stimulates tiny cilia on specialized cells called hair cells.']
['What do these hair cells do?', 'These hair cells, and their attached neurons, transform the motion of the tectorial membrane into electrical signals that are sent to the brain.']
['What can you tell me about your reading?', 'The tectorial membrane vibrates at different positions based on the frequency of the incoming sound.']
['What is the function of the ear?', 'This allows us to detect the pitch of sound.']

['What else can we use this information for?', 'Additional processing in the brain also allows us to determine which direction the sound is coming from (based on comparison of the sound’s arrival time and intensity between our two ears).']
['What are the titles of the references we used?', 'Nave, R. Vocal sound production—HyperPhysics.']
['Where did we locate our References?', 'Retrieved from http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/music/voice.html']
['What is the Doppler effect?', 'The Doppler effect is a change in the observed pitch of a sound, due to relative motion between the source and the observer.']

['What are some examples of the Doppler effect?', 'An example of the Doppler effect due to the motion of a source occurs when you are standing still, and the sound of a siren coming from an ambulance shifts from high-pitch to low-pitch as it passes by.']
['Is there anything else important I should know?', 'The closer the ambulance is to you, the more sudden the shift.']
['What is another important factor?', 'The faster the ambulance moves, the greater the shift.']
['Are there any other examples of this shift in frequency?', 'We also hear this shift in frequency for passing race cars, airplanes, and trains.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects?', 'An example of the Doppler effect with a stationary source and moving observer is if you ride a train past a stationary warning bell, you will hear the bell’s frequency shift from high to low as you pass by.']
["What are some things we'll need to know?", 'Let’s compare three different scenarios:']

['What are the scenarios?', 'Sound waves emitted by a stationary source (Figure 14.14), sound waves emitted by a moving source (Figure 14.15), and sound waves emitted by a stationary source but heard by moving observers (Figure 14.16).']
['What do the scenarios have in common?', 'In each case, the sound spreads out from the point where it was emitted.']

['What did you find in the Doppler effect of sound waves?', 'If the source and observers are stationary, then observers on either side see the same wavelength and frequency as emitted by the source.']

['What else did you find out about the Doppler effect?', 'But if the source is moving and continues to emit sound as it travels, then the air compressions (crests) become closer together in the direction in which it’s traveling and farther apart in the direction it’s traveling away from.']

['What is the significance of this?', 'Therefore, the wavelength is shorter in the direction the source is moving (on the right in Figure 14.15), and longer in the opposite direction (on the left in Figure 14.15).']

['What other important information about the study material will you be reviewing?', 'Finally, if the observers move, as in Figure 14.16, the frequency at which they receive the compressions changes.']

['What happens to the frequency when people move?', 'The observer moving toward the source receives them at a higher frequency (and therefore shorter wavelength), and the person moving away from the source receives them at a lower frequency (and therefore longer wavelength).']
['What is the relationship between wavelength and frequency?', 'We know that wavelength and frequency are related by  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\text{,}\\)$$  where v is the fixed speed of sound.']
['Does the sound speed change depending on where it is moving?', 'The sound moves in a medium and has the same speed v in that medium whether the source is moving or not.']
['How is this related to the doppler effect?', 'Therefore, f multiplied by  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is a constant.']

['Does this mean that the sound waves have a different frequency as they move?', 'Because the observer on the right in Figure 14.15 receives a shorter wavelength, the frequency she perceives must be higher.']
['What other things do you want to know about the article?', 'Similarly, the observer on the left receives a longer wavelength and therefore perceives a lower frequency.']
['What happens in Figure 12.31?', 'The same thing happens in Figure 14.16.']

['What happens when an observer moves toward the source?', 'A higher frequency is perceived by the observer moving toward the source, and a lower frequency is perceived by an observer moving away from the source.']
['What happened in Figure 14.16?', 'In general, then, relative motion of source and observer toward one another increases the perceived frequency.']
['What happens when the relative motion is farther apart?', 'Relative motion apart decreases the perceived frequency.']
['What else did you find interesting in the article?', 'The greater the relative speed is, the greater the effect.']
['What is the plus sign?', 'where fs is the frequency of sound from a source, vs is the speed of the source along a line joining the source and observer, and vw is the speed of sound.']
['How is this different from the minus sign?', 'The minus sign is used for motion toward the observer and the plus sign for motion away from the observer.']
['What is the Doppler effect?', 'Note that the greater the speed of the source, the greater the Doppler effect.']
['What is the frequency perceived by the observer fobs?', 'Similarly, for a stationary source and moving observer, the frequency perceived by the observer fobs is given by']
['what is the plus sign for?', 'where vobs is the speed of the observer along a line joining the source and observer.']
["What's the minus sign for?", 'Here the plus sign is for motion toward the source, and the minus sign is for motion away from the source.']
['What is a plane?', 'Suppose a jet airplane is coming nearly straight at you, emitting a sound of frequency fs.']
['What is an example of an important fact in the document?', 'The greater the plane’s speed, vs, the greater the Doppler shift and the greater the value of fobs.']

["What's another example?", 'Now, as vs approaches the speed of sound, vw, fobs approaches infinity, because the denominator in  $$\\(f_{obs} = f_{s}\\left( \\frac{v_{w}}{v_{w} - v_{s}} \\right)\\)$$  approaches zero.']

['What does this result mean?', 'This result means that at the speed of sound, in front of the source, each wave is superimposed on the previous one because the source moves forward at the speed of sound.']
['What is interesting about this?', 'The observer gets them all at the same instant, and so the frequency is theoretically infinite.']

['What is interesting about this?', 'If the source exceeds the speed of sound, no sound is received by the observer until the source has passed, so that the sounds from the source when it was approaching are stacked up with those from it when receding, creating a sonic boom.']
['What is the definition of a sonic boom?', 'A sonic boom is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.']
['What do you need to learn from this material?', 'An aircraft creates two sonic booms, one from its nose and one from its tail (see Figure 14.17).']
['What was the impact of these on humans?', 'During television coverage of space shuttle landings, two distinct booms could often be heard.']
['What was their significance?', 'These were separated by exactly the time it would take the shuttle to pass by a point.']
['What happens to the observer?', 'Observers on the ground often do not observe the aircraft creating the sonic boom, because it has passed by before the shock wave reaches them.']
['Did they cause harm to anyone?', 'If the aircraft flies close by at low altitude, pressures in the sonic boom can be destructive enough to break windows.']
['What was the result of the crash?', 'Because of this, supersonic flights are banned over populated areas of the United States.']
['How can you get a resonance and beat?', 'Sit in front of a piano sometime and sing a loud brief note at it while pushing down on the sustain pedal.']

['What will happen if you sing a note on a guitar?', 'It will sing the same note back at you—the strings that have the same frequencies as your voice, are resonating in response to the forces from the sound waves that you sent to them.']
['Why is this important?', 'This is a good example of the fact that objects—in this case, piano strings—can be forced to oscillate but oscillate best at their natural frequency.']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'A driving force (such as your voice in the example) puts energy into a system at a certain frequency, which is not necessarily the same as the natural frequency of the system.']
['What happens to the energy over time?', 'Over time the energy dissipates, and the amplitude gradually reduces to zero- this is called damping.']

['What is the frequency at which a system would oscillate if there were no driving and no damping force?', 'The natural frequency is the frequency at which a system would oscillate if there were no driving and no damping force.']

['What is resonance?', 'The phenomenon of driving a system with a frequency equal to its natural frequency is called resonance, and a system being driven at its natural frequency is said to resonate.']

['What kind of toys do most of us play with?', 'Most of us have played with toys where an object bobs up and down on an elastic band, something like the paddle ball suspended from a finger in Figure 14.18.']
['When you play with toys, what do you find fun about it?', 'At first you hold your finger steady, and the ball bounces up and down with a small amount of damping.']
['What other things do you like to do with these toys?', 'If you move your finger up and down slowly, the ball will follow along without bouncing much on its own.']

['Are there any other fun things you can do with these toys?', 'As you increase the frequency at which you move your finger up and down, the ball will respond by oscillating with increasing amplitude.']

['What else can you tell me about the amplitude of the oscillations?', 'When you drive the ball at its natural frequency, the ball’s oscillations increase in amplitude with each oscillation for as long as you drive it.']

['What else is interesting about the resonance and beats?', 'As the driving frequency gets progressively higher than the resonant or natural frequency, the amplitude of the oscillations becomes smaller, until the oscillations nearly disappear and your finger simply moves up and down with little effect on the ball.']
["What's another example?", 'Another example is that when you tune a radio, you adjust its resonant frequency so that it oscillates only at the desired station’s broadcast (driving) frequency.']
['What is another example of a natural frequency?', 'Also, a child on a swing is driven (pushed) by a parent at the swing’s natural frequency to reach the maximum amplitude (height).']
