['Why is that?', 'In all of these cases, the efficiency of energy transfer from the driving force into the oscillator is best at resonance.']
['What kind of interference is there?', 'All sound resonances are due to constructive and destructive interference.']
['What can we find in this material?', 'Only the resonant frequencies interfere constructively to form standing waves, while others interfere destructively and are absent.']

['What is something special about the material?', 'From the toot made by blowing over a bottle to the recognizability of a great singer’s voice, resonance and standing waves play a vital role in sound.']
['What does interference do?', 'Interference happens to all types of waves, including sound waves.']
['What happens to sound waves?', 'In fact, one way to support that something is a wave is to observe interference effects.']
['What does the interference effect do?', 'Figure 14.19 shows a set of headphones that employs a clever use of sound interference to cancel noise.']

['What do you have to know about destructive interference?', 'To get destructive interference, a fast electronic analysis is performed, and a second sound is introduced with its maxima and minima exactly reversed from the incoming noise.']
['What is the most important point of the passage?', 'In addition to resonance, superposition of waves can also create beats.']
['What is another important point?', 'Beats are produced by the superposition of two waves with slightly different frequencies but the same amplitude.']
['What is the final important point?', 'The waves alternate in time between constructive interference and destructive interference, giving the resultant wave an amplitude that varies over time.']
['What is the resultant wave?', '(See the resultant wave in Figure 14.20).']
['What is the frequency of the wave that fluctuates in amplitude, or beats?', 'This wave fluctuates in amplitude, or beats, with a frequency called the beat frequency.']
['What is the equation for beat frequency?', 'The equation for beat frequency is']
['How is this related to sound?', 'where f1 and f2 are the frequencies of the two original waves.']
['What happens at the beat frequency?', 'If the two frequencies of sound waves are similar, then what we hear is an average frequency that gets louder and softer at the beat frequency.']
['What did you hold the fork near?', 'Suppose we hold a tuning fork near the end of a tube that is closed at the other end, as shown in Figure 14.21, Figure 14.22, and Figure 14.23.']

['What did the air column do when the tuning fork was struck?', 'If the tuning fork has just the right frequency, the air column in the tube resonates loudly, but at most frequencies it vibrates very little.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that the air column has only certain natural frequencies.']
['What do the figures show?', 'The figures show how a resonance at the lowest of these natural frequencies is formed.']
['What happens with a disturbance?', 'A disturbance travels down the tube at the speed of sound and bounces off the closed end.']

['Does this make a sound?', 'If the tube is just the right length, the reflected sound arrives back at the tuning fork exactly half a cycle later, and it interferes constructively with the continuing sound produced by the tuning fork.']
['What happens to the incoming and reflected sounds?', 'The incoming and reflected sounds form a standing wave in the tube as shown.']

['What is the maximum air displacement at the open end of the wave?', 'The standing wave formed in the tube has its maximum air displacement (an antinode) at the open end, and no displacement (a node) at the closed end.']
['What is the difference between air displacement at the open and closed ends?', 'Recall from the last chapter on waves that motion is unconstrained at the antinode, and halted at the node.']
['How does this help?', 'The distance from a node to an antinode is one-fourth of a wavelength, and this equals the length of the tube; therefore,  $$\\(\\lambda = \\ 4L\\)$$ .']
['Can we use this to find resonance?', 'This same resonance can be produced by a vibration introduced at or near the closed end of the tube, as shown in Figure 14.24.']

['Which of the following is correct: maxiimum air displacements or whole series?', 'Since maximum air displacements are possible at the open end and none at the closed end, there are other, shorter wavelengths that can resonate in the tube see Figure 14.25).']

['What else does this chapter talk about?', 'Here the standing wave has three-fourths of its wavelength in the tube, or  $$\\(L = \\ \\left( {3/4} \\right)\\lambda\\prime\\)$$, so that  $$\\(\\lambda\\prime\\  = \\ 4L/3\\)$$ .']

['What is the whole series of shorter-wavelength and higher-frequency sounds that resonate in the tube?', 'There is a whole series of shorter-wavelength and higher-frequency sounds that resonate in the tube.']
["What are some of the specific terms we'll be using?", 'We use specific terms for the resonances in any system.']
['What are some examples of these terms?', 'The lowest resonant frequency is called the fundamental, while all higher resonant frequencies are called overtones.']
['Are there other specific terms we use?', 'All resonant frequencies are multiples of the fundamental, and are called harmonics.']
['Are there any more interesting aspects?', 'The fundamental is the first harmonic, the first overtone is the second harmonic, and so on.']
['What is the most important information to know about the harmonics?', 'Figure 14.26 shows the fundamental and the first three overtones (the first four harmonics) in a tube closed at one end.']
['What is the first major topic?', 'The fundamental and overtones can be present at the same time in a variety of combinations.']

['What is the difference between a trumpet and a clarinet?', 'For example, the note middle C on a trumpet sounds very different from middle C on a clarinet, even though both instruments are basically modified versions of a tube closed at one end.']

['What is the difference between a symphony and a concert band?', 'The fundamental frequency is the same (and usually the most intense), but the overtones and their mix of intensities are different.']

['What gives musical instruments (and human voices) their distinctive characteristics?', 'This mix is what gives musical instruments (and human voices) their distinctive characteristics, whether they have air columns, strings, or drumheads.']

["Did you learn that it's important for human speech?", 'In fact, much of our speech is determined by shaping the cavity formed by the throat and mouth and positioning the tongue to adjust the fundamental and combination of overtones.']
['What does v = 4L refer to?', 'where f1 is the fundamental, f3 is the first overtone, and so on.']
['What are the resonant frequencies of a tube?', 'Note that the resonant frequencies depend on the speed of sound v and on the length of the tube L.']
['What is another type of tube?', 'Another type of tube is one that is open at both ends (known as an open-pipe resonator).']
['What are some examples of this?', 'Examples are some organ pipes, flutes, and oboes.']
['What else can you tell me about the air columns?', 'The air columns in tubes open at both ends have maximum air displacements at both ends.']
['Where can I see this?', '(See Figure 14.27).']
['What is the name of the wave that forms as shown?', 'Standing waves form as shown.']
['What is the difference between the fundamental and the overtones?', 'where f1 is the fundamental, f2 is the first overtone, f3 is the second overtone, and so on.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about the article?', 'Note that a tube open at both ends has a fundamental frequency twice what it would have if closed at one end.']
['What is the difference between a tube closed at one end and a tube open at both ends?', 'It also has a different spectrum of overtones than a tube closed at one end.']

['How is this related to sounds?', 'So if you had two tubes with the same fundamental frequency but one was open at both ends and the other was closed at one end, they would sound different when played because they have different overtones.']
['What is an example of this?', 'Middle C, for example, would sound richer played on an open tube since it has more overtones.']

['what makes it richer?', 'An open-pipe resonator has more overtones than a closed-pipe resonator because it has even multiples of the fundamental as well as odd, whereas a closed tube has only odd multiples.']
['What is light?', 'We generally take light for granted, but it is a truly amazing and mysterious form of energy.']
['How does light travel?', 'Think about it: Light travels to Earth across millions of kilometers of empty space.']
['How does it affect the earth?', 'When it reaches us, it interacts with matter in various ways to generate almost all the energy needed to support life, provide heat, and cause weather patterns.']
['Light is a form of what type of energy?', 'Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR).']
['What does the term light usually refer to?', 'The term light usually refers to visible light, but this is not the only form of EMR.']
['What type of radiation is light?', 'As we will see, visible light occupies a narrow band in a broad range of types of electromagnetic radiation.']
['What is an electromagnetic radiation generated by?', 'Electromagnetic radiation is generated by a moving electric charge, that is, by an electric current.']

['What kind of field does an electric current generate?', 'As you will see when you study electricity, an electric current generates both an electric field, E, and a magnetic field, B. These fields are perpendicular to each other.']
['What happens when the moving charge oscillates?', 'When the moving charge oscillates, as in an alternating current, an EM wave is propagated.']
['What happens if the source moves away from it?', 'Figure 15.2 shows how an electromagnetic wave moves away from the source—indicated by the ~ symbol.']

['What is the distance between two wave crests or two wave troughs, expressed in various metric measures of distance?', 'Wavelength—The distance between two wave crests or two wave troughs, expressed in various metric measures of distance Frequency—']

['What is the term for the number of wave crests that pass a point per second, expressed in hertz (Hz or s–1)?', 'The number of wave crests that pass a point per second, expressed in hertz (Hz or s–1) Amplitude:']
['What is the height of the crest above the null point?', 'The height of the crest above the null point']
["What are the questions I'll ask you?", 'As mentioned, electromagnetic radiation takes several forms.']
['What can you tell me about the forms?', 'These forms are characterized by a range of frequencies.']
['What can you tell me about these frequencies?', 'Because frequency is inversely proportional to wavelength, any form of EMR can also be represented by its range of wavelengths.']
['What about wavelengths?', 'Figure 15.3 shows the frequency and wavelength ranges of various types of EMR.']
['Are there any other aspects of radiation that are important to understand?', 'Take a few minutes to study the positions of the various types of radiation on the EM spectrum, above.']

['What is the term for radiation with frequencies lower than those of visible light?', 'Sometimes all radiation with frequencies lower than those of visible light are referred to as infrared (IR) radiation.']
['What are the other types of radiation?', 'This includes radio waves, which overlap with the frequencies used for media broadcasts of TV and radio signals.']
['What can we do with radiation that is higher than visible light?', 'The microwave radiation that you see on the diagram is the same radiation that is used in a microwave oven.']
['What can we do with EMR?', 'What we feel as radiant heat is also a form of low-frequency EMR.']

['What is the high-frequency radiation to the right of visible light sometimes referred to as?', 'All the high-frequency radiation to the right of visible light is sometimes referred to as ultraviolet (UV) radiation.']
['What is the term for radiation that is emitted by the sun?', 'This includes X-rays and gamma (γ) rays.']

['What is the narrow band that is visible light?', 'The narrow band that is visible light extends from lower-frequency red light to higher-frequency violet light, thus the terms are infrared (below red) and ultraviolet (beyond violet).']
['What are the characteristics of EM waves mentioned above?', 'All the EM waves mentioned above are basically the same form of radiation.']
['How do they all travel?', 'They can all travel across empty space, and they all travel at the speed of light in a vacuum.']
['What is the basic difference between types of radiation?', 'The basic difference between types of radiation is their differing frequencies.']
['How does wavelength differ?', 'Each frequency has an associated wavelength.']
['What happens as frequency increases?', 'As frequency increases across the spectrum, wavelength decreases.']
['What does that mean?', 'Energy also increases with frequency.']
['How does this impact the material?', 'Because of this, higher frequencies penetrate matter more readily.']
['What is the table called that lists the properties and uses of the various EM spectrum bands?', 'Some of the properties and uses of the various EM spectrum bands are listed in Table 15.1.']
['What is the narrow band of visible light called?', 'The narrow band of visible light is a combination of the colors of the rainbow.']
['What is included in the electromagnetic spectrum?', 'Figure 15.5 shows the section of the EM spectrum that includes visible light.']

['What are the frequencies corresponding to these wavelengths?', 'The frequencies corresponding to these wavelengths are  $$\\(4.0\\  \\times \\ 10^{14}\\text{~s}^{-1}\\)$$  at the red end to  $$\\(7.9\\  \\times \\ 10^{14}\\text{~s}^{-1}\\)$$  at the violet end.']
['What is the narrow range of the EM spectrum?', 'This is a very narrow range, considering that the EM spectrum spans about 20 orders of magnitude.']
['What are the characteristics of electromagnetic radiation?', 'As a child, you probably learned the color wheel, shown on the left in Figure 15.6.']
['How do you use the color wheel?', 'It helps if you know what color results when you mix different colors of paint together.']
['What color will you get if you combine magenta with yellow?', 'Mixing two of the primary pigment colors—magenta, yellow, or cyan—together results in a secondary color.']
['What secondary color is created when cyan and yellow are mixed?', 'For example, mixing cyan and yellow makes green.']
['What is the process of mixing colors that are different from each other?', 'This is called subtractive color mixing.']
['What is the difference between additive and subtractive color mixing?', 'Mixing different colors of light together is quite different.']
['What is the diagram on the right?', 'The diagram on the right shows additive color mixing.']
['What are the primary colors?', 'In this case, the primary colors are red, green, and blue, and the secondary colors are cyan, magenta, and yellow.']

['What is the difference between mixing pigments and mixing light?', 'Mixing pigments and mixing light are different because materials absorb light by a different set of rules than does the perception of light by the eye.']
['What does subtractive color mixing have to do with black?', 'Notice that, when all colors are subtracted, the result is no color, or black.']
['What color is white light?', 'When all colors are added, the result is white light.']
['What is the opposite of white light?', 'We see the reverse of this when white sunlight is separated into the visible spectrum by a prism or by raindrops when a rainbow appears in the sky.']
['What is a characteristic of electromagnetic radiation?', 'Humans have found uses for every part of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['Are there uses of every frequency?', 'We will take a look at the uses of each range of frequencies, beginning with visible light.']
['What are some of the uses of light?', 'Most of our uses of visible light are obvious; without it our interaction with our surroundings would be much different.']

['Is there anything else I should know about light?', 'We might forget that nearly all of our food depends on the photosynthesis process in plants, and that the energy for this process comes from the visible part of the spectrum.']
['What does photosynthesis do to our surroundings?', 'Without photosynthesis, we would also have almost no oxygen in the atmosphere.']
['What is the low frequency infrared radiation?', 'The low-frequency, infrared region of the spectrum has many applications in media broadcasting.']
['What are some of the applications of radio waves?', 'Television, radio, cell phone, and remote-control devices all broadcast and/or receive signals with these wavelengths.']
['What about radio?', 'AM and FM radio signals are both low-frequency radiation.']
['What is the basic difference between the two?', 'They are in different regions of the spectrum, but that is not their basic difference.']
['What are the abbreviations for amplitude modulation and frequency modulation?', 'AM and FM are abbreviations for amplitude modulation and frequency modulation.']
['What are the two types of radio waves?', 'Information in AM signals has the form of changes in amplitude of the radio waves; information in FM signals has the form of changes in wave frequency.']
['What is the purpose of a microwave oven?', 'Another application of long-wavelength radiation is found in microwave ovens.']
['What do microwave ovens use to cook food?', 'These appliances cook or warm food by irradiating it with EM radiation in the microwave frequency range.']
['What frequency does a microwave oven use?', 'Most kitchen microwaves use a frequency of  $$\\(2.45\\  \\times \\ 10^{9}\\)$$ Hz.']
['What do microwaves do to water?', 'These waves have the right amount of energy to cause polar molecules, such as water, to rotate faster.']
['What is partial charge separation?', 'Polar molecules are those that have a partial charge separation.']
['Why do they give up rotational energy?', 'The rotational energy of these molecules is given up to surrounding matter as heat.']
['What scientists invented a microwave oven?', 'The first microwave ovens were called Radaranges because they were based on radar technology  developed during World War II.']

['What is the most important information in the article?', 'Radar uses radiation with wavelengths similar to those of microwaves to detect the location and speed of distant objects, such as airplanes, weather formations, and motor vehicles.']
['What is the basic difference between Radar and other detection systems?', 'Radar information is obtained by receiving and analyzing the echoes of microwaves reflected by an object.']
['How can the speed of an object be measured?', 'The speed of the object can be measured using the Doppler shift of the returning waves.']
['What is the Doppler shift?', 'This is the same effect you learned about when you studied sound waves.']

['What are some interesting facts about electromagnetic waves?', 'Like sound waves, EM waves are shifted to higher frequencies by an object moving toward an observer, and to lower frequencies by an object moving away from the observer.']
['What are the benefits of this?', 'Astronomers use this same Doppler effect to measure the speed at which distant galaxies are moving away from us.']

['What is the shift in frequency called?', 'In this case, the shift in frequency is called the red shift, because visible frequencies are shifted toward the lower-frequency, red end of the spectrum.']
['What kind of radiation is used in our environment?', 'Exposure to any radiation with frequencies greater than those of visible light carries some health hazards.']
['What is the risk to the cells?', 'All types of radiation in this range are known to cause cell damage.']
['What makes it dangerous to our cells?', 'The danger is related to the high energy and penetrating ability of these EM waves.']
['How does exposure affect the health of the cell?', 'The likelihood of being harmed by any of this radiation depends largely on the amount of exposure.']
['What can be done to prevent exposure to UV radiation from sunlight?', 'Most people try to reduce exposure to UV radiation from sunlight by using sunscreen and protective clothing.']
['How much radiation are used by doctors and other medical personnel?', 'Physicians still use X-rays to diagnose medical problems, but the intensity of the radiation used is extremely low.']
['What are some images from this?', 'Figure 15.8 shows an X-ray image of a patient’s chest cavity.']
['What is a medical-imaging technique that involves no danger of exposure?', 'One medical-imaging technique that involves no danger of exposure is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).']
['What is its use in medicine?', 'MRI is an important imaging and research tool in medicine, producing highly detailed two- and three-dimensional images.']
['What is resonance?', 'Radio waves are broadcast, absorbed, and reemitted in a resonance process that is sensitive to the density of nuclei, usually hydrogen nuclei—protons.']

['What speed does electromagnetic radiation travel at in a vacuum?', 'In a vacuum, all electromagnetic radiation travels at the same incredible speed of 3.00 × 108 m/s, which is equal to 671 million miles per hour.']
['What is the symbol for the constant c?', 'This is one of the fundamental physical constants.']
['What is the symbol c for?', 'It is referred to as the speed of light and is given the symbol c.']

['What is the space between celestial bodies called?', 'The space between celestial bodies is a near vacuum, so the light we see from the Sun, stars, and other planets has traveled here at the speed of light.']
['What is the speed of light in the vacuum of space?', 'Keep in mind that all EM radiation travels at this speed.']
['What does the sun make?', 'All the different wavelengths of radiation that leave the Sun make the trip to Earth in the same amount of time.']
['How long does it take for them to reach earth?', 'That trip takes 8.3 minutes.']

['How long does it take for light from the nearest star to reach Earth?', 'Light from the nearest star, besides the Sun, takes 4.2 years to reach Earth, and light from the nearest galaxy—a dwarf galaxy that orbits the Milky Way—travels 25,000 years on its way to Earth.']
['What is important about the article?', 'You can see why we call very long distances astronomical.']
['What happens when light travels through a physical medium?', 'When light travels through a physical medium, its speed is always less than the speed of light.']
['What other factors contribute to this speed difference?', 'For example, light travels in water at three-fourths the value of c.']
['Does light speed slow down at all in air?', 'In air, light has a speed that is just slightly slower than in empty space: 99.97 percent of c. Diamond slows light down to just 41 percent of c.']
['What happens if a light travels through another medium?', 'When light changes speeds at a boundary between media, it also changes direction.']
['What happens with speed difference?', 'The greater the difference in speeds, the more the path of light bends.']
['How is this affected?', 'In other chapters, we look at this bending, called refraction, in greater detail.']
['What does refraction do?', 'We introduce refraction here to help explain a phenomenon called thin-film interference.']
['What is thin film reflection?', 'This occurs when light is both refracted by and reflected from a very thin film.']
['What is the diagram that shows the path of light through such a thin film?', 'The diagram shows the path of light through such a thin film.']
['What do the symbols n1, n2, and n3 mean?', 'The symbols n1, n2, and n3 indicate that light travels at different speeds in each of the three materials.']
['What else can you tell me about this topic?', 'Learn more about this topic in the chapter on diffraction and interference.']
['What is the figure about?', 'Figure 15.9 shows the result of thin film interference on the surface of soap bubbles.']
['How did it interfere?', 'Because ray 2 travels a greater distance, the two rays become out of phase.']
['What does that mean?', 'That is, the crests of the two emerging waves are no longer moving together.']
['What causes interference?', 'This causes interference, which reinforces the intensity of the wavelengths of light that create the bands of color.']
['Why are the color bands separated?', 'The color bands are separated because each color has a different wavelength.']
['How did the film affect that?', 'Also, the thickness of the film is not uniform, and different thicknesses cause colors of different wavelengths to interfere in different places.']
['What else should you know?', 'Note that the film must be very, very thin—somewhere in the vicinity of the wavelengths of visible light.']
['What is the most important thing to know about polarized sunglasses?', 'You have probably experienced how polarized sunglasses reduce glare from the surface of water or snow.']
['What causes that effect?', 'The effect is caused by the wave nature of light.']
['What does the article talk about?', 'Looking back at Figure 15.2, we see that the electric field moves in only one direction perpendicular to the direction of propagation.']
['Does that mean light from other sources moves in the same direction as the electric field?', 'Light from most sources vibrates in all directions perpendicular to propagation.']
['What is the name of the electric field that vibrates in only one direction?', 'Light with an electric field that vibrates in only one direction is called polarized.']
['What would a diagram of polarized light look like?', 'A diagram of polarized light would look like Figure 15.2.']
['What is a polarizing filter?', 'Polarized glasses are an example of a polarizing filter.']
['What do these glasses do?', 'These glasses absorb most of the horizontal light waves and transmit the vertical waves.']
['Why do they absorb the horizontal waves?', 'This cuts down glare, which is caused by horizontal waves.']
['How do polarizing filters work?', 'Figure 15.10 shows how waves traveling along a rope can be used as a model of how a polarizing filter works.']
['What are vertically polarized waves?', 'The oscillations in one rope are in a vertical plane and are said to be vertically polarized.']
['How about horizontally polarized waves?', 'Those in the other rope are in a horizontal plane and are horizontally polarized.']
['How are the two ropes different?', 'If a vertical slit is placed on the first rope, the waves pass through.']
['What is wrong with the other rope?', 'However, a vertical slit blocks the horizontally polarized waves.']
['What is the direction of the electric field oscillation analogous to?', 'For EM waves, the direction of the electric field oscillation is analogous to the disturbances on the ropes.']
['What is polarized light?', 'Light can also be polarized by reflection.']
['What is polarized horizontally?', 'Most of the light reflected from water, glass, or any highly reflective surface is polarized horizontally.']
['What is the effect of a polarizing lens on light reflected from the surface of water?', 'Figure 15.11 shows the effect of a polarizing lens on light reflected from the surface of water.']
['What can you use the speed of light for?', 'We can use the speed of light, c, to carry out several simple but interesting calculations.']
['How can you calculate if you know how light years apart?', 'If we know the distance to a celestial object, we can calculate how long it takes its light to reach us.']
['What can you do with light and distance?', 'Of course, we can also make the reverse calculation if we know the time it takes for the light to travel to us.']
['What is important to note about light traveling to Earth?', 'For an object at a very great distance from Earth, it takes many years for its light to reach us.']
['Does this mean anything to us?', 'This means that we are looking at the object as it existed in the distant past.']
['What can we learn from this?', 'The object may, in fact, no longer exist.']
['How are light years and miles the same?', 'Very large distances in the universe are measured in light years.']

['What is the distance that light travels in one year?', 'One light year is the distance that light travels in one year, which is  $$\\(9.46\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ kilometers or $$\\(5.88\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ miles (…and 1012 is a trillion!).']
['What is the meaning of luminous flux?', 'The rate at which light is radiated from a source is called luminous flux, P, and it is measured in lumens (lm).']
['What do you want to know about energy-saving light bulbs?', 'Energy-saving light bulbs, which provide more luminous flux for a given use of electricity, are now available.']
['What are energy-saving light bulbs categorized as?', 'One of these bulbs is called a compact fluorescent lamp; another is an LED (light-emitting diode) bulb.']

['How do you compare energy-saving light bulbs accurately?', 'If you wanted to replace an old incandescent bulb with an energy saving bulb, you would want the new bulb to have the same brightness as the old one.']
['What else do you need to know about energy-saving light bulbs?', 'To compare bulbs accurately, you would need to compare the lumens each one puts out.']
['How would you know the lumens per watt?', 'Comparing wattage—that is, the electric power used—would be misleading.']
['How do you get the lumens?', 'Both wattage and lumens are stated on the packaging.']
['How many luminous flux do bulbs have?', 'The luminous flux of a bulb might be 2,000 lm.']
['What does that entail?', 'That accounts for all the light radiated in all directions.']

['What do we really need to know is how much light falls on an object, such as a book, at a specific distance?', 'However, what we really need to know is how much light falls on an object, such as a book, at a specific distance.']
['What is the unit of measurement for illuminance?', 'The number of lumens per square meter is called illuminance, and is given in units of lux (lx).']
['What is the formula for a sphere with a radius of 1 m?', 'Picture a light bulb in the middle of a sphere with a 1-m radius.']
['What is the total surface of the sphere?', 'The total surface of the sphere equals 4πr2 m2.']
['What are you trying to learn about r2 term?', 'The illuminance is now only one-fourth as great, because the r2 term in the denominator is 4 instead of 1.']
['What did you learn about inverse square?', 'Figure 15.12 shows how illuminance decreases with the inverse square of the distance.']
['What are the three ways in which light can travel from a source to another location?', 'There are three ways, as shown in Figure 16.2, in which light can travel from a source to another location.']
['What can come directly from the source?', 'It can come directly from the source through empty space, such as from the Sun to Earth.']
['What else can come directly from the source?', 'Light can travel to an object through various media, such as air and glass.']
['What else can light travel through?', 'Light can also arrive at an object after being reflected, such as by a mirror.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'In all these cases, light is modeled as traveling in a straight line, called a ray.']

['What happens when it encounters another surface?', 'Light may change direction when it encounters the surface of a different material (such as a mirror) or when it passes from one material to another (such as when passing from air into glass).']
['What happens to the light after it changes direction?', 'It then continues in a straight line—that is, as a ray.']
['What does the word ray come from?', 'The word ray comes from mathematics.']
['What does the word mean?', 'Here it means a straight line that originates from some point.']
['What are some other things you found interesting?', 'It is acceptable to visualize light rays as laser rays (or even science fiction depictions of ray guns).']
['How can we describe light?', 'Because light moves in straight lines, that is, as rays, and changes directions when it interacts with matter, it can be described through geometry and trigonometry.']
['What is the name of the part of optics that is described by straight lines and angles?', 'This part of optics, described by straight lines and angles, is therefore called geometric optics.']

['What laws govern how light changes direction when it interacts with matter?', 'There are two laws that govern how light changes direction when it interacts with matter: the law of reflection, for situations in which light bounces off matter; and the law of refraction, for situations in which light passes through matter.']
['What else do we learn about?', 'In this section, we consider the geometric optics of reflection.']
['What do we see when we look into a mirror or squint at sunlight glinting from a lake?', 'Whenever we look into a mirror or squint at sunlight glinting from a lake, we are seeing a reflection.']
['What does the law of reflection state?', 'The law of reflection states:']
['What does that mean?', 'The angle of reflection,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{r}}\\)$$, equals the angle of incidence,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{i}}\\)$$.']
['How else does this law work?', 'This law governs the behavior of all waves when they interact with a smooth surface, and therefore describe the behavior of light waves as well.']
['What is light rays?', 'The reflection of light is simplified when light is treated as a ray.']

['What is important to know about light rays?', 'This concept is illustrated in Figure 16.3, which also shows how the angles are measured relative to the line perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray strikes it.']
['What is the line perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray?', 'This perpendicular line is also called the normal line, or just the normal.']
['What is specular?', 'Light reflected in this way is referred to as specular (from the Latin word for mirror: speculum).']
['What is a rough surface?', 'We expect to see reflections from smooth surfaces, but Figure 16.4, illustrates how a rough surface reflects light.']
['Why does it diffused?', 'Because the light is reflected from different parts of the surface at different angles, the rays go in many different directions, so the reflected light is diffused.']
['What is the purpose of diffused light?', 'Diffused light allows you to read a printed page from almost any angle because some of the rays go in different directions.']
['What other objects have rough surfaces?', 'Many objects, such as people, clothing, leaves, and walls, have rough surfaces and can be seen from many angles.']
['What type of surface do mirrors have?', 'A mirror, on the other hand, has a smooth surface and reflects light at specific angles.']
['How can we tell that the image on a mirror is actually behind it?', 'When we see ourselves in a mirror, it appears that our image is actually behind the mirror.']
['What direction is the light coming from?', 'We see the light coming from a direction determined by the law of reflection.']
['How are the angles determined?', 'The angles are such that our image is exactly the same distance behind the mirror, di, as the distance we stand away from the mirror, do.']

['What do mirror images make objects appear to be?', 'Although these mirror images make objects appear to be where they cannot be (such as behind a solid wall), the images are not figments of our imagination.']
['What do we think mirror images are?', 'Mirror images can be photographed and videotaped by instruments and look just as they do to our eyes, which are themselves optical instruments.']
['What is the difference between a real image and a virtual image?', 'An image in a mirror is said to be a virtual image, as opposed to a real image.']
['What is the difference between a virtual image and a real image?', 'A virtual image is formed when light rays appear to diverge from a point without actually doing so.']
['What figure helps illustrate how a flat mirror forms an image?', 'Figure 16.5 helps illustrate how a flat mirror forms an image.']
['How does it work?', 'Two rays are shown emerging from the same point, striking the mirror, and reflecting into the observer’s eye.']
['What happens to the light rays after they hit the eye?', 'The rays can diverge slightly, and both still enter the eye.']
['What happens after that?', 'If the rays are extrapolated backward, they seem to originate from a common point behind the mirror, allowing us to locate the image.']
['What do they look like?', 'The paths of the reflected rays into the eye are the same as if they had come directly from that point behind the mirror.']

['What can you tell me about the article?', 'Using the law of reflection—the angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence—we can see that the image and object are the same distance from the mirror.']
['What is a virtual image?', 'This is a virtual image, as defined earlier.']
['What are the characteristics of mirrors?', 'Some mirrors are curved instead of flat.']
['What is a mirror that curves outward called?', 'A mirror that curves inward is called a concave mirror, whereas one that curves outward is called a convex mirror.']
['What other objects do you see curving?', 'Pick up a well-polished metal spoon and you can see an example of each type of curvature.']
['Can you tell me about the side of the spoon?', 'The side of the spoon that holds the food is a concave mirror; the back of the spoon is a convex mirror.']
['Does it reflect the image of anything?', 'Observe your image on both sides of the spoon.']

['What can be used to find the point where reflected rays converge or appear to converge, or the point from which rays appear to diverge?', 'Ray diagrams can be used to find the point where reflected rays converge or appear to converge, or the point from which rays appear to diverge.']
['What does the point where rays appear to diverge mean?', 'This is called the focal point, F.']

['What is the focal length?', 'The distance from F to the mirror along the central axis (the line perpendicular to the center of the mirror’s surface) is called the focal length, f. Figure 16.9 shows the focal points of concave and convex mirrors.']
['What kind of mirrors are used to make images?', 'Images formed by a concave mirror vary, depending on which side of the focal point the object is placed.']

['Can a mirror form an image?', 'For any object placed on the far side of the focal point with respect to the mirror, the rays converge in front of the mirror to form a real image, which can be projected onto a surface, such as a screen or sheet of paper']
['What else did you find interesting in this text?', 'However, for an object located inside the focal point with respect to the concave mirror, the image is virtual.']
['What is virtual?', 'For a convex mirror the image is always virtual—that is, it appears to be behind the mirror.']
['How do ray diagrams help?', 'The ray diagrams in Figure 16.10 show how to determine the nature of the image formed by concave and convex mirrors.']
['What are you studying now?', 'You should be able to notice everyday applications of curved mirrors.']
['What are some examples of everyday applications?', 'One common example is the use of security mirrors in stores, as shown in Figure 16.11.']
['What else can you tell me about telescopes?', 'Some telescopes also use curved mirrors and no lenses (except in the eyepieces) both to magnify images and to change the path of light.']
['What is one of the most popular types of telescope?', 'Figure 16.12 shows a Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope.']
["What is the telescope's design?", 'This design uses a spherical primary concave mirror and a convex secondary mirror.']
['What is perforated primary mirror?', 'The image is projected onto the focal plane by light passing through the perforated primary mirror.']

['What is the effective focal length of a telescope?', 'The effective focal length of such a telescope is the focal length of the primary mirror multiplied by the magnification of the secondary mirror.']
['What is the result of combining the two telescopes?', 'The result is a telescope with a focal length much greater than the length of the telescope itself.']
['What is table 16.1 about?', 'A parabolic concave mirror has the very useful property that all light from a distant source, on reflection by the mirror surface, is directed to the focal point.']
['What is in table 16.1?', 'Likewise, a light source placed at the focal point directs all the light it emits in parallel lines away from the mirror.']
['What is the ray diagram in Figure 16.13?', 'This case is illustrated by the ray diagram in Figure 16.13.']
['What is the light source in a car headlight?', 'The light source in a car headlight, for example, is located at the focal point of a parabolic mirror.']

['What is the purpose of Table 16.1?', 'Parabolic mirrors are also used to collect sunlight and direct it to a focal point, where it is transformed into heat, which in turn can be used to generate electricity.']
['What is the application that is shown in Figure 16.14?', 'This application is shown in Figure 16.14.']

['What can you tell me about the application of curved mirror equations?', 'Curved mirrors and the images they create involve a fairly small number of variables: the mirror’s radius of curvature, R; the focal length, f; the distances of the object and image from the mirror, do and di, respectively; and the heights of the object and image, ho and hi, respectively.']
['What else can you tell me about variables?', 'The signs of these values indicate whether the image is inverted, erect (upright), real, or virtual.']
['How do the equations relate to everyday problems?', 'We now look at the equations that relate these variables and apply them to everyday problems.']
['What is so important about this equation?', 'This equation can be rearranged several ways.']
['How is this used?', 'For example, it may be written to solve for focal length.']
['What is the value of magnitude?', 'Magnification, m, is the ratio of the size of the image, hi, to the size of the object, ho.']
['How can we calculate the value of m?', 'The value of m can be calculated in two ways.']
['Is there anything else you should know about this study material?', 'This relationship can be written to solve for any of the variables involved.']
['How many variables can you solve for?', 'For example, the height of the image is given by']
['What is the simplest equation?', 'We saved the simplest equation for last.']
['What is simply twice the focal length?', 'The radius of curvature of a curved mirror, R, is simply twice the focal length.']

['What can we learn from the algebraic sign of the result?', 'A negative di indicates a virtual image; a positive value indicates a real image A negative hi indicates an inverted image; a positive value indicates an erect image']
['Are there any other important signs that are included in this article?', 'For concave mirrors, f is positive; for convex mirrors, f is negative']
['Are there any other important aspects to the content that I need to know?', 'You may have noticed some odd optical phenomena when looking into a fish tank.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects?', 'For example, you may see the same fish appear to be in two different places (Figure 16.16).']

['How does this happen?', 'This is because light coming to you from the fish changes direction when it leaves the tank and, in this case, light rays traveling along two different paths both reach our eyes.']

['What is refraction?', 'The changing of a light ray’s direction (loosely called bending) when it passes a boundary between materials of different composition, or between layers in single material where there are changes in temperature and density, is called refraction.']
['What are some of the applications of refraction?', 'Refraction is responsible for a tremendous range of optical phenomena, from the action of lenses to voice transmission through optical fibers.']
['Why is light reflected when it goes from one material to another?', 'It is because light changes speed when going from one material to another.']

['How does this help the material?', 'This behavior is typical of all waves and is especially easy to apply to light because light waves have very small wavelengths, and so they can be treated as rays.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Before we study the law of refraction, it is useful to discuss the speed of light and how it varies between different media.']
['What other important information did you find in the study material?', 'The speed of light is now known to great precision.']

['What is the value of the speed of light in a vacuum?', 'In fact, the speed of light in a vacuum, c, is so important, and is so precisely known, that it is accepted as one of the basic physical quantities, and has the fixed value']

['what is the approximate value of 3.00 $$(times)$$ 108 m/s used whenever three-digit precision is sufficient?', 'where the approximate value of 3.00  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  108 m/s is used whenever three-digit precision is sufficient.']
['What is an example of a physical property of matter?', 'The speed of light through matter is less than it is in a vacuum, because light interacts with atoms in a material.']

['What is the speed of light dependent on?', 'The speed of light depends strongly on the type of material, given that its interaction with different atoms, crystal lattices, and other substructures varies.']
['What is the index of refraction of a material?', 'We define the index of refraction, n, of a material to be']
['Where is the c in this equation?', 'where v is the observed speed of light in the material.']

['What happens to the speed of light in matter?', 'Because the speed of light is always less than c in matter and equals c only in a vacuum, the index of refraction (plural: indices of refraction) is always greater than or equal to one.']
['What is Figure 16.17?', 'Figure 16.17 provides an analogy for and a description of how a ray of light changes direction when it passes from one medium to another.']
['What is this measured from?', 'As in the previous section, the angles are measured relative to a perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray crosses it.']
['What is the change in direction of the light ray?', 'The change in direction of the light ray depends on how the speed of light changes.']
['What is the relationship between these two?', 'The change in the speed of light is related to the indices of refraction of the media involved.']
['What is the relationship between the index of refraction and the medium?', 'In the situations shown in Figure 16.17, medium 2 has a greater index of refraction than medium 1.']
['What does this mean?', 'This difference in index of refraction means that the speed of light is less in medium 2 than in medium 1.']
['What does this tell you?', 'Note that, in Figure 16.17(a), the path of the ray moves closer to the perpendicular when the ray slows down.']
['What happens when the ray speeds up?', 'Conversely, in Figure 16.17(b), the path of the ray moves away from the perpendicular when the ray speeds up.']
['What happens if you reverse the direction of the path?', 'The path is exactly reversible.']
['What is another example of a reversible process?', 'In both cases, you can imagine what happens by thinking about pushing a lawn mower from a footpath onto grass, and vice versa.']
['What happens to the mower when it goes from the footpath to grass?', 'Going from the footpath to grass, the right front wheel is slowed and pulled to the side as shown.']
['What is the change in direction for light when it goes from a fast medium to a slow one?', 'This is the same change in direction for light when it goes from a fast medium to a slow one.']
['What happens to the mower on the grass?', 'When going from the grass to the footpath, the left front wheel moves faster than the others, and the mower changes direction as shown.']
['What does this mean?', 'This, too, is the same change in direction as light going from slow to fast.']

['What are the two most important factors that determine the direction of a light ray?', 'The amount that a light ray changes direction depends both on the incident angle and the amount that the speed changes.']
['How do these factors interact?', 'For a ray at a given incident angle, a large change in speed causes a large change in direction, and thus a large change in the angle of refraction.']

['What is the exact mathematical relationship between the law of refraction and the law of refraction?', 'The exact mathematical relationship is the law of refraction, or Snell’s law, which is stated in equation form as']

['What are the relevant variables to this formula?', 'Here, n1 and n2 are the indices of refraction for media 1 and 2, respectively, and θ1 and θ2 are the angles between the rays and the perpendicular in the respective media 1 and 2, as shown in Figure 16.17.']
['What is the difference between incident and refracted rays?', 'The incoming ray is called the incident ray and the outgoing ray is called the refracted ray.']
['What are the associated angles to the formula?', 'The associated angles are called the angle of incidence and the angle of refraction.']
['What else can you tell me about this formula?', 'Later, we apply Snell’s law to some practical situations.']
['What is the spreading of white light into the wavelengths of which it is composed?', 'Dispersion is defined as the spreading of white light into the wavelengths of which it is composed.']
['Why does that happen?', 'This happens because the index of refraction varies slightly with wavelength.']
['What is the figure about?', 'Figure 16.18 shows how a prism disperses white light into the colors of the rainbow.']
['What is the process by which light is refracted into a rainbow?', 'Rainbows are produced by a combination of refraction and reflection.']
['What is reflected from the back of a drop of water?', 'Light enters a drop of water and is reflected from the back of the drop, as shown in Figure 16.19.']
['What happens to light when it enters a drop of water?', 'The light is refracted both as it enters and as it leaves the drop.']
['What is the wavelength of light?', 'Because the index of refraction of water varies with wavelength, the light is dispersed and a rainbow is observed.']
['What are some other important things we need to know?', 'A good-quality mirror reflects more than 90 percent of the light that falls on it; the mirror absorbs the rest.']
['What is the most important point made?', 'But, it would be useful to have a mirror that reflects all the light that falls on it.']
['What can we do to get total reflection?', 'Interestingly, we can produce total reflection using an aspect of refraction.']

['What happens when a ray of light strikes the surface between two materials?', 'Consider what happens when a ray of light strikes the surface between two materials, such as is shown in Figure 16.20(a).']
['What happens to the light after it crosses the boundary?', 'Part of the light crosses the boundary and is refracted; the rest is reflected.']

['What happens when the index of refraction for the second medium is less than the first?', 'If, as shown in the figure, the index of refraction for the second medium is less than the first, the ray bends away from the perpendicular.']
['Does this mean anything?', 'Because n1 > n2, the angle of refraction is greater than the angle of incidence—that is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ > $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$ .']
['What is the next important thing to do?', 'Now, imagine what happens as the incident angle is increased.']
['The index of refraction of the first medium decreases, while that of the second increases', 'This causes  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$  to increase as well.']
['What happens after the light bends?', 'The largest the angle of refraction,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$, can be is 90°, as shown in Figure 16.20(b).']

['What is the critical angle for a combination of two materials?', 'The critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, for a combination of two materials is defined to be the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, which produces an angle of refraction of 90°.']
['What is the incident angle for which $$(theta_text2)$$ = 90°?', 'That is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  is the incident angle for which  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ = 90°.']

['What happens if the incident angle is greater than the critical angle?', 'If the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, is greater than the critical angle, as shown in Figure 16.20(c), then all the light is reflected back into medium 1, a condition called total internal reflection.']
['What is Snell’s law?', 'Recall that Snell’s law states the relationship between angles and indices of refraction.']

['What is the angle of refraction when the incident angle equals the critical angle?', 'When the incident angle equals the critical angle ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$= $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$), the angle of refraction is 90° ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$= 90°).']
['What does that mean for snell’s law?', 'Noting that sin 90° = 1, Snell’s law in this case becomes']

['What is the critical angle for total internal reflection?', 'Total internal reflection occurs for any incident angle greater than the critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, and it can only occur when the second medium has an index of refraction less than the first.']
['Does the article discuss what type of light ray?', 'Note that the previous equation is written for a light ray that travels in medium 1 and reflects from medium 2, as shown in Figure 16.20.']
['What is total internal reflection?', 'There are several important applications of total internal reflection.']

['What is the most important application of total internal reflection?', 'Total internal reflection, coupled with a large index of refraction, explains why diamonds sparkle more than other materials.']
['What makes diamonds sparkle?', 'The critical angle for a diamond-to-air surface is only 24.4°; so, when light enters a diamond, it has trouble getting back out (Figure 16.21).']

['Does light have trouble getting out of diamonds?', 'Although light freely enters the diamond at different angles, it can exit only if it makes an angle less than 24.4° with the normal to a given surface.']
['How do diamonds make it hard for light to exit?', 'Facets on diamonds are specifically intended to make this unlikely, so that the light can exit only in certain places.']
['why do diamonds sparkle?', 'Diamonds with very few impurities are very clear, so the light makes many internal reflections and is concentrated at the few places it can exit—hence the sparkle.']
['What does this mean?', 'A light ray that strikes an object that consists of two mutually perpendicular reflecting surfaces is reflected back exactly parallel to the direction from which it came.']
['What happens when these surfaces are perpendicular?', 'This parallel reflection is true whenever the reflecting surfaces are perpendicular, and it is independent of the angle of incidence.']
['What is the name of the object that bounces light from its inside corner?', 'Such an object is called a corner reflector because the light bounces from its inside corner.']

['What kind of objects have corner reflectors designed to return light in the direction from which it originates?', 'Many inexpensive reflector buttons on bicycles, cars, and warning signs have corner reflectors designed to return light in the direction from which it originates.']

['What is perfectly efficient when the conditions for total internal reflection are satisfied?', 'Corner reflectors are perfectly efficient when the conditions for total internal reflection are satisfied.']
['What is the critical angle?', 'With common materials, it is easy to obtain a critical angle that is less than 45°.']
['What are some uses of perfect mirrors?', 'One use of these perfect mirrors is in binoculars, as shown in Figure 16.22.']
['What other application is for periscopes used in submarines?', 'Another application is for periscopes used in submarines.']
['Are fiber optics related to total internal reflection?', 'Fiber optics are one common application of total internal reflection.']

['What can you tell me about fiber optics?', 'In communications, fiber optics are used to transmit telephone, internet, and cable TV signals, and they use the transmission of light down fibers of plastic or glass.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Because the fibers are thin, light entering one is likely to strike the inside surface at an angle greater than the critical angle and, thus, be totally reflected (Figure 16.23).']

['How can the refractive index be adjusted?', 'The index of refraction outside the fiber must be smaller than inside, a condition that is satisfied easily by coating the outside of the fiber with a material that has an appropriate refractive index.']
['Why does it vary?', 'In fact, most fibers have a varying refractive index to allow more light to be guided along the fiber through total internal reflection.']
['What happens to rays when they are reflected around corners?', 'Rays are reflected around corners as shown in the figure, making the fibers into tiny light pipes.']
['what is the most important point in the paragraph?', 'Lenses are found in a huge array of optical instruments, ranging from a simple magnifying glass to the eye to a camera’s zoom lens.']
['What is important about the law of refraction?', 'In this section, we use the law of refraction to explore the properties of lenses and how they form images.']
['What do you find most interesting about the Characteristics of Lenses?', 'Some of what we learned in the earlier discussion of curved mirrors also applies to the study of lenses.']

['What else can you tell me about the Characteristics of lenses?', 'Concave, convex, focal point F, and focal length f have the same meanings as before, except each measurement is made from the center of the lens instead of the surface of the mirror.']

['What can you tell me about the figure 16.25?', 'The convex lens shown in Figure 16.25 has been shaped so that all light rays that enter it parallel to its central axis cross one another at a single point on the opposite side of the lens.']
['What can you tell me about the central axis?', 'The central axis, or axis, is defined to be a line normal to the lens at its center.']
['What is a converging lens called?', 'Such a lens is called a converging lens because of the converging effect it has on light rays.']

['What is the expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens shown in Figure 16.25 to illustrate how the ray changes direction both as it enters and as it leaves the lens?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.25 to illustrate how the ray changes direction both as it enters and as it leaves the lens.']

['What can you tell me about the direction of the ray?', 'Because the index of refraction of the lens is greater than that of air, the ray moves toward the perpendicular as it enters and away from the perpendicular as it leaves.']
['How is this related to the law of refraction?', '(This is in accordance with the law of refraction.)']
['What can you tell me about the converging effect?', 'As a result of the shape of the lens, light is thus bent toward the axis at both surfaces.']
['What are the characteristics of a converging lens?', 'Note that rays from a light source placed at the focal point of a converging lens emerge parallel from the other side of the lens.']
['What can you tell me about converging lens?', 'You may have heard of the trick of using a converging lens to focus rays of sunlight to a point.']
["What's a good trick to use with the lens to focus light?", 'Such a concentration of light energy can produce enough heat to ignite paper.']

['What figure are you studying?', 'Figure 16.26 shows a concave lens and the effect it has on rays of light that enter it parallel to its axis (the path taken by ray 2 in the figure is the axis of the lens).']
['What is a diverging lens?', 'The concave lens is a diverging lens because it causes the light rays to bend away (diverge) from its axis.']

['Is there anything else I should know?', 'In this case, the lens has been shaped so all light rays entering it parallel to its axis appear to originate from the same point, F, defined to be the focal point of a diverging lens.']
['What is focal point?', 'The distance from the center of the lens to the focal point is again called the focal length, or “ƒ,” of the lens.']
['What is the focal length of a diverging lens?', 'Note that the focal length of a diverging lens is defined to be negative.']

['How does the shape of the lens, together with the law of refraction, causes the ray to follow its particular path and diverge?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.26 to illustrate how the shape of the lens, together with the law of refraction, causes the ray to follow its particular path and diverge.']
['What is the power, P, of a lens?', 'The power, P, of a lens is very easy to calculate.']
['What is the reciprocal of the focal length?', 'It is simply the reciprocal of the focal length, expressed in meters']
['What are the units of power?', 'The units of power are diopters, D, which are expressed in reciprocal meters.']
['What else do you know about power?', 'If the focal length is negative, as it is for the diverging lens in Figure 16.26, then the power is also negative.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'In some circumstances, a lens forms an image at an obvious location, such as when a movie projector casts an image onto a screen.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about the article?', 'In other cases, the image location is less obvious.']
['What do we find interesting about thin lenses?', 'We use ray tracing for thin lenses to illustrate how they form images, and we develop equations to describe the image-formation quantitatively.']
['What is the rule for ray tracing?', 'These are the rules for ray tracing:']

['How do you determine these rays?', 'The first ray is one that enters the lens parallel to its axis and passes through the focal point on the other side (rule 1).']
['What happens after the second ray passes through the center of the lens without changing direction?', 'The second ray passes through the center of the lens without changing direction (rule 3).']
['What happens to the third ray?', 'The third ray passes through the nearer focal point on its way into the lens and leaves the lens parallel to its axis (rule 4).']
['What is the image of the top of the person’s head located at?', 'The image of the top of the person’s head is located at this point.']
['What happens next?', 'Rays from another point on the object, such as the belt buckle, also cross at another common point, forming a complete image, as shown.']
['What else happened in the article?', 'Although three rays are traced in Figure 16.27, only two are necessary to locate the image.']

['What is important to know about the image formed in Figure 16.27?', 'The image formed in Figure 16.27 is a real image—meaning, it can be projected.']

['What does projected mean?', 'That is, light rays from one point on the object actually cross at the location of the image and can be projected onto a screen, a piece of film, or the retina of an eye.']

['What else did you learn?', 'In the table, m is magnification; the other symbols have the same meaning as they did for curved mirrors.']
['What are the equations for image formation by lenses?', 'Image formation by lenses can also be calculated from simple equations.']
['What else do we learn about the equations?', 'We learn how these calculations are carried out near the end of this section.']

['What are some common applications of lenses with which we are all familiar?', 'Some common applications of lenses with which we are all familiar are magnifying glasses, eyeglasses, cameras, microscopes, and telescopes.']
['What are telescopes and microscopes related to?', 'We take a look at the latter two examples, which are the most complex.']
['What figure shows the design of a telescope that uses only mirrors?', 'We have already seen the design of a telescope that uses only mirrors in Figure 16.12.']
['What figure is next?', 'Figure 16.29 shows the design of a telescope that uses two lenses.']
['What is the part (a) of the figure?', 'Part (a) of the figure shows the design of the telescope used by Galileo.']
['Why is the part (b) important?', 'It produces an upright image, which is more convenient for many applications.']
['What is part (b)?', 'Part (b) shows an arrangement of lenses used in many astronomical telescopes.']
['What is the part (c)?', 'This design produces an inverted image, which is less of a problem when viewing celestial objects.']
['What is the figure 16.30?', 'Figure 16.30 shows the path of light through a typical microscope.']
['What country first developed the microscope?', 'Microscopes were first developed during the early 1600s by eyeglass makers in the Netherlands and Denmark.']
['What is the simplest compound microscope constructed from?', 'The simplest compound microscope is constructed from two convex lenses, as shown schematically in Figure 16.30.']
['Are these lenses used to create magnification?', 'The first lens is called the objective lens; it has typical magnification values from 5 $$\\(\\times\\)$$  to 100 $$\\(\\times\\)$$ .']
['Are there other types of lenses?', 'In standard microscopes, the objectives are mounted such that when you switch between them, the sample remains in focus.']
['What is a parfocal?', 'Objectives arranged in this way are described as parfocal.']
['What is the eyepiece?', 'The second lens, the eyepiece, also referred to as the ocular, has several lenses that slide inside a cylindrical barrel.']
['How does the eyepiece help focus?', 'The focusing ability is provided by the movement of both the objective lens and the eyepiece.']
['What is the purpose of a microscope?', 'The purpose of a microscope is to magnify small objects, and both lenses contribute to the final magnification.']

['Why is that?', 'In addition, the final enlarged image is produced in a location far enough from the observer to be viewed easily because the eye cannot focus on objects or images that are too close.']
['What is another advantage of using rays diagrams or the thin-lens equations?', 'Real lenses behave somewhat differently from how they are modeled using rays diagrams or the thin-lens equations.']
['What else can you tell me about the content?', 'Real lenses produce aberrations.']
['What is an aberration?', 'An aberration is a distortion in an image.']
['What else do aberrations result from?', 'There are a variety of aberrations that result from lens size, material, thickness, and the position of the object.']
['What is a common type of aberration?', 'One common type of aberration is chromatic aberration, which is related to color.']

['What are chromatic aberration and magnification?', 'Because the index of refraction of lenses depends on color, or wavelength, images are produced at different places and with different magnifications for different colors.']
['What is the law of reflection?', 'The law of reflection is independent of wavelength, so mirrors do not have this problem.']
['What is another advantage for the use of mirrors in optical systems such as telescopes?', 'This result is another advantage for the use of mirrors in optical systems such as telescopes.']
['What is the figure 16.31(a)?', 'Figure 16.31(a) shows chromatic aberration for a single convex lens, and its partial correction with a two-lens system.']

['What is the importance of chromatic aberration?', 'The index of refraction of the lens increases with decreasing wavelength, so violet rays are refracted more than red rays, and are thus focused closer to the lens.']
['What is the difference between a converging and diverging lens?', 'The diverging lens corrects this in part, although it is usually not possible to do so completely.']
['How does this affect the refraction of light?', 'Lenses made of different materials and with different dispersions may be used.']

['What is an example of chromatic aberration?', 'For example, an achromatic doublet consisting of a converging lens made of crown glass in contact with a diverging lens made of flint glass can reduce chromatic aberration dramatically (Figure 16.31(b)).']
['What is the eye?', 'The eye is perhaps the most interesting of all optical instruments.']
['How is it remarkable?', 'It is remarkable in how it forms images and in the richness of detail and color they eye can detect.']
['How can it be corrected?', 'However, our eyes commonly need some correction to reach what is called normal vision, but should be called ideal vision instead.']
['What is the main idea of geometric optics?', 'Image formation by our eyes and common vision correction are easy to analyze using geometric optics.']
['Does Figure 16.32 show basic anatomy of the eye?', 'Figure 16.32 shows the basic anatomy of the eye.']
['What is the cornea and lens?', 'The cornea and lens form a system that, to a good approximation, acts as a single thin lens.']
['What is the retina?', 'For clear vision, a real image must be projected onto the light-sensitive retina, which lies at a fixed distance from the lens.']
['What is the lens of the eye?', 'The lens of the eye adjusts its power to produce an image on the retina for objects at different distances.']
['What does the fovea do?', 'The center of the image falls on the fovea, which has the greatest density of light receptors and the greatest acuity (sharpness) in the visual field.']
['What is the blind spot?', 'There are no receptors at the place where the optic nerve meets the eye, which is called the blind spot.']
['What is the blind spot called?', 'An image falling on this spot cannot be seen.']

['What is discussed about the eye?', 'The variable opening (or pupil) of the eye along with chemical adaptation allows the eye to detect light intensities from the lowest observable to 1010 times greater (without damage).']
['How does it detect light intensities?', 'Ten orders of magnitude is an incredible range of detection.']
['What other functions do the eyes perform?', 'Our eyes perform a vast number of functions, such as sense direction, movement, sophisticated colors, and distance.']
['What is the process of seeing?', 'Processing of visual nerve impulses begins with interconnections in the retina and continues in the brain.']
['How is the brain involved in vision?', 'The optic nerve conveys signals received by the eye to the brain.']
['What are the refractive indices of lenses?', 'Refractive indices are crucial to image formation using lenses.']
['What are refractive indices?', 'Table 16.4 shows refractive indices relevant to the eye.']
['What causes the greatest bending of rays?', 'The biggest change in the refractive index—and the one that causes the greatest bending of rays—occurs at the cornea rather than the lens.']
['What was the biggest change in refractive index?', 'The ray diagram in Figure 16.33 shows image formation by the cornea and lens of the eye.']
['What else does this study have to do with refractive index?', 'The rays bend according to the refractive indices provided in Table 16.4.']
['Why does the cornea bend?', 'The cornea provides about two-thirds of the magnification of the eye because the speed of light changes considerably while traveling from air into the cornea.']
['Does the eye need more magnification than it has?', 'The lens provides the remaining magnification needed to produce an image on the retina.']

['What is the function of the lens?', 'The cornea and lens can be treated as a single thin lens, although the light rays pass through several layers of material (such as the cornea, aqueous humor, several layers in the lens, and vitreous humor), changing direction at each interface.']
['What is the function of the cornea and lens?', 'The image formed is much like the one produced by a single convex lens.']
['What did the images look like?', 'This result is a case 1 image.']
['How does the brain invert images?', 'Images formed in the eye are inverted, but the brain inverts them once more to make them seem upright.']
['What else do you need to know?', 'As noted, the image must fall precisely on the retina to produce clear vision—that is, the image distance, di, must equal the lens-to-retina distance.']
['How is di determined?', 'Because the lens-to-retina distance does not change, di must be the same for objects at all distances.']
['How do you make up for that?', 'The eye manages to vary the distance by varying the power (and focal length) of the lens to accommodate for objects at various distances.']

['What is the figure that shows the ciliary muscles above and below the lens that change the shape of the lens and, thus, the focal length?', 'In Figure 16.33, you can see the small ciliary muscles above and below the lens that change the shape of the lens and, thus, the focal length.']
['What is the most common type of vision correction?', 'The need for some type of vision correction is very common.']
['What are common vision defects?', 'Common vision defects are easy to understand, and some are simple to correct.']
['Are there any other interesting facts?', 'Figure 16.34 illustrates two common vision defects.']

['What is the inability to see distant objects clearly while close objects are in focus?', 'Nearsightedness, or myopia, is the inability to see distant objects clearly while close objects are in focus.']
['What is the cause of nearsightedness?', 'The nearsighted eye overconverges the nearly parallel rays from a distant object, and the rays cross in front of the retina.']
['What is the solution to the problem of a blurry image?', 'More divergent rays from a close object are converged on the retina, producing a clear image.']

['What is the inability to see close objects clearly whereas distant objects may be in focus?', 'Farsightedness, or hyperopia, is the inability to see close objects clearly whereas distant objects may be in focus.']
['What is the cause of farsightedness?', 'A farsighted eye does not converge rays from a close object sufficiently to make the rays meet on the retina.']
['What is the solution to the problem of rays from a distant object?', 'Less divergent rays from a distant object can be converged for a clear image.']
['What is a lens used for?', 'Because the nearsighted eye overconverges light rays, the correction for nearsightedness involves placing a diverging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does this lens do?', 'This lens reduces the power of an eye that has too short a focal length (Figure 16.35(a)).']
['What does the farsighted eye do?', 'Because the farsighted eye underconverges light rays, the correction for farsightedness is to place a converging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does a contact lens do?', 'This lens increases the power of an eye that has too long a focal length (Figure 16.35(b)).']
['What is the purpose of your study?', 'As promised, there are no new equations to memorize.']
['Are there any important calculations?', 'We can use equations already presented for solving problems involving curved mirrors.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Careful analysis allows you to apply these equations to lenses.']
['Do you have any equations you need?', 'Here are the equations you need']

['Are there any other examples of this equation?', 'Remember, this equation is usually more useful if rearranged to solve for one of the variables.']
['What is an example of a syllable?', 'For example,']
['How does that help us study?', 'where hi and ho are the image height and object height, respectively.']
['What else should we know about this material?', 'Remember, also, that a negative di value indicates a virtual image and a negative hi value indicates an inverted image.']
