['What is the main idea of this paper?', 'We know that visible light is the type of electromagnetic wave to which our eyes responds.']
['What does light obey?', 'As we have seen previously, light obeys the equation']

['How do you find c in this equation?', 'where  $$\\(c = 3.00\\  \\times \\ 10^{8}\\)$$  m/s is the speed of light in vacuum, f is the frequency of the electromagnetic wave in Hz (or s–1), and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is its wavelength in m.']
['What is the range of visible wavelengths?', 'The range of visible wavelengths is approximately 380 to 750 nm.']

['What is the difference between a ray and a wave?', 'As is true for all waves, light travels in straight lines and acts like a ray when it interacts with objects several times as large as its wavelength.']
['How is it different when interacting with smaller objects?', 'However, when it interacts with smaller objects, it displays its wave characteristics prominently.']
['What is interference?', 'Interference is the identifying behavior of a wave.']
['What is the image of?', 'In Figure 17.2, both the ray and wave characteristics of light can be seen.']
['The laser beam emitted by the observatory represents what?', 'The laser beam emitted by the observatory represents ray behavior, as it travels in a straight line.']
['What is the wave character?', 'Passing a pure, one-wavelength beam through vertical slits with a width close to the wavelength of the beam reveals the wave character of light.']
['What is interference?', 'Here we see the beam spreading out horizontally into a pattern of bright and dark regions that are caused by systematic constructive and destructive interference.']
['What is interference used for?', 'As it is characteristic of wave behavior, interference is observed for water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['What is interference?', 'That interference is a characteristic of energy propagation by waves is demonstrated more convincingly by water waves.']
['What do we have to work with?', 'Figure 17.3 shows water waves passing through gaps between some rocks.']

['What can you tell me about the wave interference pattern?', 'You can easily see that the gaps are similar in width to the wavelength of the waves and that this causes an interference pattern as the waves pass beyond the gaps.']
['What else can you tell me about the wave pattern?', 'A cross-section across the waves in the foreground would show the crests and troughs characteristic of an interference pattern.']
['What are wave characteristics?', 'Light has wave characteristics in various media as well as in a vacuum.']
['What does wavelength change mean?', 'When light goes from a vacuum to some medium, such as water, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency, f, remains the same.']
['What is the speed of light in a medium?', 'The speed of light in a medium is  $$\\(v = c/n\\)$$, where n is its index of refraction.']
['What are the variables in the equation?', 'If you divide both sides of the equation  $$\\(c = f\\lambda\\)$$  by n, you get  $$\\(c/n = v = f\\lambda/n\\)$$ .']
['What happens after you divide both sides of the equation?', 'Therefore,  $$\\(v = f\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, where  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$  is the wavelength in a medium, and']
['Why is that?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength in vacuum and n is the medium’s index of refraction.']
['What is the wavelength of light in any medium than it is in vacuum?', 'It follows that the wavelength of light is smaller in any medium than it is in vacuum.']

['What other examples of this are there?', 'In water, for example, which has n = 1.333, the range of visible wavelengths is (380 nm)/1.333 to (760 nm)/1.333, or  $$\\(\\lambda_{n} =\\)$$ 285–570 nm.']
['What is the difference between wavelengths and colors?', 'Although wavelengths change while traveling from one medium to another, colors do not, since colors are associated with frequency.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The Dutch scientist Christiaan Huygens (1629–1695) developed a useful technique for determining in detail how and where waves propagate.']
['How did he do that?', 'He used wavefronts, which are the points on a wave’s surface that share the same, constant phase (such as all the points that make up the crest of a water wave).']
['What else did he observe?', 'Huygens’s principle states, “Every point on a wavefront is a source of wavelets that spread out in the forward direction at the same speed as the wave itself.']
['What else can you tell me about the wavefront?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to all of the wavelets.”']
['What is important about Figure 17.4?', 'Figure 17.4 shows how Huygens’s principle is applied.']
['What is the long edge that moves?', 'A wavefront is the long edge that moves; for example, the crest or the trough.']
['What does each point on the wavefront emit?', 'Each point on the wavefront emits a semicircular wave that moves at the propagation speed v.']
['What else is important?', 'These are drawn later at a time, t, so that they have moved a distance  $$\\(s = vt\\)$$ .']
['What is the new wavefront?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to the wavelets and is where the wave is located at time t.']
['What else?', 'Huygens’s principle works for all types of waves, including water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['What will this help you describe?', 'It will be useful not only in describing how light waves propagate, but also in how they interfere.']

['What are some of the questions in this section?', 'For light, you expect to see a sharp shadow of the doorway on the floor of the room, and you expect no light to bend around corners into other parts of the room.']

['How does sound spread out when passing through a door?', 'When sound passes through a door, you hear it everywhere in the room and, thus, you understand that sound spreads out when passing through such an opening.']
['How is this related to wavelength?', 'The answer is that the wavelengths that make up the light are very short, so that the light acts like a ray.']
['How is this related to sound?', 'Sound has wavelengths on the order of the size of the door, and so it bends around corners.']
['What do you find in our study material?', 'If light passes through smaller openings, often called slits, you can use Huygens’s principle to show that light bends as sound does (see Figure 17.5).']
['What is the bending of a wave around the edges of an opening or an obstacle called?', 'The bending of a wave around the edges of an opening or an obstacle is called diffraction.']
['Are there any other interesting facts about diffraction?', 'Diffraction is a wave characteristic that occurs for all types of waves.']
['What does it mean if diffraction is observed for a phenomenon?', 'If diffraction is observed for a phenomenon, it is evidence that the phenomenon is produced by waves.']
['What is an example of diffraction?', 'Thus, the horizontal diffraction of the laser beam after it passes through slits in Figure 17.2 is evidence that light has the properties of a wave.']
['What is it about?', 'The fact that Huygens’s principle worked was not considered enough evidence to prove that light is a wave.']
["Who else wasn't considered enough?", 'People were also reluctant to accept light’s wave nature because it contradicted the ideas of Isaac Newton, who was still held in high esteem.']

['When did they accept it?', 'The acceptance of the wave character of light came after 1801, when the English physicist and physician Thomas Young (1773–1829) did his now-classic double-slit experiment (see Figure 17.7).']
['What happens when light passes through narrow slits?', 'When light passes through narrow slits, it is diffracted into semicircular waves, as shown in Figure 17.8 (a).']
['Where does pure constructive interference occur?', 'Pure constructive interference occurs where the waves line up crest to crest or trough to trough.']
['Where does pure destructive interference occur?', 'Pure destructive interference occurs where they line up crest to trough.']
['How can light make patterns?', 'The light must fall on a screen and be scattered into our eyes for the pattern to be visible.']
['What is an analogous pattern to this?', 'An analogous pattern for water waves is shown in Figure 17.8 (b).']
['How do the two waves move from each other?', 'Note that regions of constructive and destructive interference move out from the slits at well-defined angles to the original beam.']
['What are the angles of the slits?', 'Those angles depend on wavelength and the distance between the slits, as you will see below.']

['What does it mainly focus on?', 'The fact that the wavelength of light of one color, or monochromatic light, can be calculated from its two-slit diffraction pattern in Young’s experiments supports the conclusion that light has wave properties.']
['What did you find interesting about this text?', 'To understand the basis of such calculations, consider how two waves travel from the slits to the screen.']
['What does slits mean?', 'Each slit is a different distance from a given point on the screen.']
['How are wavelengths calculated?', 'Thus different numbers of wavelengths fit into each path.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'Waves start out from the slits in phase (crest to crest), but they will end up out of phase (crest to trough) at the screen if the paths differ in length by half a wavelength, interfering destructively.']
['What does this mean?', 'If the paths differ by a whole wavelength, then the waves arrive in phase (crest to crest) at the screen, interfering constructively.']

['What else was found in the article?', 'More generally, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any half-integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\frac{1}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{3}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{5}{2}\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then destructive interference occurs.']

['Why is this?', 'Similarly, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\lambda,\\ 2\\lambda,\\ 3\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then constructive interference occurs.']
['What is the purpose of this exercise?', 'Figure 17.9 shows how to determine the path-length difference for waves traveling from two slits to a common point on a screen.']

['What is important in this chapter?', 'If the screen is a large distance away compared with the distance between the slits, then the angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  between the path and a line from the slits perpendicular to the screen (see the figure) is nearly the same for each path.']

['Does it help us with anything else?', 'That approximation and simple trigonometry show the length difference,  $$\\(\\Delta L\\)$$, to be  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$, where d is the distance between the slits,']
['What is the order of the interference?', 'The number m is the order of the interference.']
['What is it a part of?', 'For example, m = 4 is fourth-order interference.']
['What is the most important information?', 'Light passing through a single slit forms a diffraction pattern somewhat different from that formed by double slits.']
['What is one example of this information?', 'Figure 17.11 shows a single-slit diffraction pattern.']
['What is the central maximum of the figure?', 'Note that the central maximum is larger than those on either side, and that the intensity decreases rapidly on either side.']
['What is the analysis of single-slit diffraction?', 'The analysis of single-slit diffraction is illustrated in Figure 17.12.']
['What else can you tell me about the article?', 'Assuming the screen is very far away compared with the size of the slit, rays heading toward a common destination are nearly parallel.']
['What does that approximation allow?', 'That approximation allows a series of trigonometric operations that result in the equations for the minima produced by destructive interference.']
['What is the central maximum?', 'When rays travel straight ahead, they remain in phase and a central maximum is obtained.']

['What else is important?', 'However, when rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the original direction of the beam, each ray travels a different distance to the screen, and they can arrive in or out of phase.']

['What else is important?', 'Thus, a ray from the center travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther than the ray from the top edge of the slit, they arrive out of phase, and they interfere destructively.']

['How is that possible?', 'Similarly, for every ray between the top and the center of the slit, there is a ray between the center and the bottom of the slit that travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther to the common point on the screen, and so interferes destructively.']
['What else is important?', 'Symmetrically, there will be another minimum at the same angle below the direct ray.']

['What are some important parts of the study material?', 'To calculate the positions of constructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be an integral multiple, m, of the wavelength.']
['What else did you find interesting about the study material?', '$$\\(\\lambda\\)$$']

['What was your purpose with this paper?', 'where d is the distance between the slits and  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between a line from the slits to the maximum and a line perpendicular to the barrier in which the slits are located.']
['What is half-integral multiple?', 'To calculate the positions of destructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be a half-integral multiple of the wavelength:']
['When did Albert Einstein first talk about photons?', 'In 1917, Albert Einstein was thinking about photons and excited atoms.']
['What did he consider?', 'He considered an atom excited by a certain amount of energy and what would happen if that atom were hit by a photon with the same amount of energy.']
['What would happen to the atom?', 'He suggested that the atom would emit a photon with that amount of energy, and it would be accompanied by the original photon.']
['What else did he think?', 'Those photons could go on to hit other excited atoms, and soon you would have a stream of in-phase photons.']
['Did he ever use these ideas?', 'Such a light stream is said to be coherent.']
['What did he discover about photons?', 'Some four decades later, Einstein’s idea found application in a process called, light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.']
['What does this mean?', 'Take the first letters of all the words (except by and “of”) and write them in order.']
['What word is used to describe the beam of light?', 'You get the word laser (see Figure 17.2 (a)), which is the name of the device that produces such a beam of light.']
['What are the properties of laser beams?', 'Laser beams are directional, very intense, and narrow (only about 0.5 mm in diameter).']
['What are some of the properties of alumina?', 'These properties lead to a number of applications in industry and medicine.']
['What are some of the applications of the telecommunications industry?', 'The following are just a few examples:']
['What was the picture about?', 'This chapter began with a picture of a compact disc (see Figure 17.1).']
['What was the name of the device that was used to store audio and data?', 'Those audio and data-storage devices began replacing cassette tapes during the 1990s.']
['How is the laser beam used to read CDs?', 'CDs are read by interpreting variations in reflections of a laser beam from the surface.']
['What is it used for?', 'Some barcode scanners use a laser beam.']
['What else do you find interesting about the page?', 'Lasers are used in industry to cut steel and other metals.']
['Are they used in space?', 'Lasers are bounced off reflectors that astronauts left on the Moon.']
['How is the Earth-Moon distance calculated?', 'The time it takes for the light to make the round trip can be used to make precise calculations of the Earth-Moon distance.']
['What else do you find interesting on this page?', 'Laser beams are used to produce holograms.']
['How are holograms made?', 'The name hologram means entire picture (from the Greek holo-, as in holistic), because the image is three-dimensional.']
['How is the image created?', 'A viewer can move around the image and see it from different perspectives.']
['What is special about holograms?', 'Holograms take advantage of the wave properties of light, as opposed to traditional photography which is based on geometric optics.']
['What is the process of interference?', 'A holographic image is produced by constructive and destructive interference of a split laser beam.']
['Is there a downside to using laser beams?', 'One of the advantages of using a laser as a surgical tool is that it is accompanied by very little bleeding.']
['How can laser beams help people?', 'Laser eye surgery has improved the vision of many people, without the need for corrective lenses.']
['How is it done?', 'A laser beam is used to change the shape of the lens of the eye, thus changing its focal length.']
['What happens if you pass light through a large number of evenly-spaced parallel slits?', 'An interesting thing happens if you pass light through a large number of evenly-spaced parallel slits.']
['What happens to light passing through a slit?', 'Such an arrangement of slits is called a diffraction grating.']
['How does diffraction gratings work?', 'An interference pattern is created that is very similar to the one formed by double-slit diffraction (see Figure 17.8 and Figure 17.9).']

['What is the process of making a diffraction grating?', 'A diffraction grating can be manufactured by scratching glass with a sharp tool to form a number of precisely positioned parallel lines, which act like slits.']

['What do diffraction gratings do?', 'Diffraction gratings work both for transmission of light, as in Figure 17.13, and for reflection of light, as on the butterfly wings or the Australian opal shown in Figure 17.14, or the CD pictured in the opening illustration of this chapter.']
['What are some uses of diffraction gratings?', 'In addition to their use as novelty items, diffraction gratings are commonly used for spectroscopic dispersion and analysis of light.']
['What makes them particularly useful?', 'What makes them particularly useful is the fact that they form a sharper pattern than do double slits.']
['What else makes them sharper?', 'That is, their bright regions are narrower and brighter, while their dark regions are darker.']
['What is the sharper pattern?', 'Figure 17.15 shows idealized graphs demonstrating the sharper pattern.']
['Can you name a natural source of this material?', 'Natural diffraction gratings occur in the feathers of certain birds.']

['What do the tiny, fingerlike structures in regular patterns do?', 'Tiny, fingerlike structures in regular patterns act as reflection gratings, producing constructive interference that gives the feathers colors not solely due to their pigmentation.']
['What is the name of the effect?', 'The effect is called iridescence.']

['What are diffraction gratings?', 'Diffraction gratings are key components of monochromators—devices that separate the various wavelengths of incoming light and allow a beam with only a specific wavelength to pass through.']
['Are monochromators used in any applications?', 'Monochromators are used, for example, in optical imaging of particular wavelengths from biological or medical samples.']

['What else can be used in these applications?', 'A diffraction grating can be chosen to specifically analyze a wavelength of light emitted by molecules in diseased cells in a biopsy sample, or to help excite strategic molecules in the sample with a selected frequency of light.']
['What other uses do fibers have?', 'Another important use is in optical fiber technologies where fibers are designed to provide optimum performance at specific wavelengths.']
['How is that selected?', 'A range of diffraction gratings is available for selecting specific wavelengths for such use.']
['What are diffraction gratings used for?', 'Diffraction gratings are used in spectroscopes to separate a light source into its component wavelengths.']
['What is light characteristic of the pure substance?', 'When a material is heated to incandescence, it gives off wavelengths of light characteristic of the chemical makeup of the material.']
['How can this be used to identify the pure substance?', 'A pure substance will produce a spectrum that is unique, thus allowing identification of the substance.']
['What else do you want to know about spectroscopes?', 'Spectroscopes are also used to measure wavelengths both shorter and longer than visible light.']
['What is special about such instruments?', 'Such instruments have become especially useful to astronomers and chemists.']
['What is a spectroscope?', 'Figure 17.18 shows a diagram of a spectroscope.']
['What is the content of this document about?', 'Light diffracts as it moves through space, bending around obstacles and interfering constructively and destructively.']
['What happens to light after it bends around obstacles?', 'While diffraction allows light to be used as a spectroscopic tool, it also limits the detail we can obtain in images.']
['What did the document show?', 'Figure 17.19 (a) shows the effect of passing light through a small circular aperture.']
['What else did the figure show?', 'Instead of a bright spot with sharp edges, a spot with a fuzzy edge surrounded by circles of light is obtained.']
['What is a fuzzy edge?', 'This pattern is caused by diffraction similar to that produced by a single slit.']
['What does the document show?', 'Light from different parts of the circular aperture interferes constructively and destructively.']
['Did the effect matter if the aperture is big or small?', 'The effect is most noticeable when the aperture is small, but the effect is there for large apertures, too.']

['What is the diffraction pattern produced by two point light sources that are close to one another?', 'Figure 17.19 (b) shows the diffraction pattern produced by two point light sources that are close to one another.']

['What was the pattern produced by the two light sources?', 'The pattern is similar to that for a single point source, and it is just barely possible to tell that there are two light sources rather than one.']
['What can you tell in Figure 17.19 (c)?', 'If they are closer together, as in Figure 17.19 (c), you cannot distinguish them, thus limiting the detail, or resolution, you can obtain.']
['What is the reason for that limit?', 'That limit is an inescapable consequence of the wave nature of light.']
['What is the resolution of a telescope limited by?', 'There are many situations in which diffraction limits the resolution.']
['What is the pupil?', 'The acuity of vision is limited because light passes through the pupil, the circular aperture of the eye.']

['What is the diffraction-like spreading of light due to?', 'Be aware that the diffraction-like spreading of light is due to the limited diameter of a light beam, not the interaction with an aperture.']

['Was there any other information in the document?', 'Thus light passing through a lens with a diameter of D shows the diffraction effect and spreads, blurring the image, just as light passing through an aperture of diameter D does.']
['What is the resolution of any system having a lens or mirror?', 'Diffraction limits the resolution of any system having a lens or mirror.']
['What is the information about mirrors?', 'Telescopes are also limited by diffraction, because of the finite diameter, D, of their primary mirror.']

['What is the difference between light and sound?', 'Early in the chapter, it was mentioned that when light passes from one medium to another, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency remains constant.']
['What did you find most interesting?', 'The equation']

['what is the key to understanding this article?', 'shows how to the wavelength in a given medium,  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, is related to the wavelength in a vacuum,  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$, and the refractive index, n, of the medium.']
['What is the relevance to the slit experiment?', 'The equation is useful for calculating the change in wavelength of a monochromatic laser beam in various media.']
['What is the analysis of a diffraction grating similar to?', 'The analysis of a diffraction grating is very similar to that for a double slit.']

['How is light diffracted by the grating?', 'As you know from the discussion of double slits in Young’s double-slit experiment, light is diffracted by, and spreads out after passing through, each slit.']
['What does this mean?', 'Rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the incident direction.']
['How is this used in a television?', 'Each ray travels a different distance to a common point on a screen far away.']
['How does this effect the rays?', 'The rays start in phase, and they can be in or out of phase when they reach a screen, depending on the difference in the path lengths traveled.']
['What are the distances between the slits?', 'Each ray travels a distance that differs by  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  from that of its neighbor, where d is the distance between slits.']

['What is the relationship between diffraction and interference?', 'If  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  equals an integral number of wavelengths, the rays all arrive in phase, and constructive interference (a maximum) is obtained.']

['What is the equation for two slits separated by d?', 'Note that this is exactly the same equation as for two slits separated by d.']
['What else did you learn?', 'However, the slits are usually closer in diffraction gratings than in double slits, producing fewer maxima at larger angles.']

['What is the diffraction pattern for a circular aperture?', 'To answer that question, consider the diffraction pattern for a circular aperture, which, similar to the diffraction pattern of light passing through a slit, has a central maximum that is wider and brighter than the maxima surrounding it (see Figure 17.19 (a)).']

['What is the first minimum in the diffraction pattern?', 'It can be shown that, for a circular aperture of diameter D, the first minimum in the diffraction pattern occurs at  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, provided that the aperture is large compared with the wavelength of light, which is the case for most optical instruments.']

['Who developed the diffraction limit to resolution based on diffraction?', 'The accepted criterion for determining the diffraction limit to resolution based on diffraction was developed by Lord Rayleigh in the 19th century.']

['What is the Rayleigh criterion for the diffraction limit to resolution?', 'The Rayleigh criterion for the diffraction limit to resolution states that two images are just resolvable when the center of the diffraction pattern of one is directly over the first minimum of the diffraction pattern of the other.']
['What figure showed Rayleigh limit?', 'See Figure 17.20 (b).']
['What is the first minimum angle?', 'The first minimum is at an angle of  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, so that two point objects are just resolvable if they are separated by the angle']

['what is it about?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength of the light (or other electromagnetic radiation) and D is the diameter of the aperture, lens, mirror, etc., with which the two objects are observed.']
['What are the units of $(theta)$$?', 'In the expression above,  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  has units of radians.']
['What does this mean to us?', 'You may know someone who has an electric personality, which usually means that other people are attracted to this person.']
['What is the basis for this saying?', 'This saying is based on electric charge, which is a property of matter that causes objects to attract or repel each other.']
['What is the difference between electric charge and other charges?', 'Electric charge comes in two varieties, which we call positive and negative.']
['What happens when these two varieties of charge meet?', 'Like charges repel each other, and unlike charges attract each other.']
['Do like charges repel each other?', 'Thus, two positive charges repel each other, as do two negative charges.']
['What does a negative charge attract?', 'A positive charge and a negative charge attract each other.']

['When and how are materials charged?', 'When various materials are rubbed together in controlled ways, certain combinations of materials always result in a net charge of one type on one material and a net charge of the opposite type on the other material.']
['What are the two types of charges?', 'By convention, we call one type of charge positive and the other type negative.']
['When glass is rubbed with silk, what kind of charge does it become?', 'For example, when glass is rubbed with silk, the glass becomes positively charged and the silk negatively charged.']
['What happens when charged?', 'Because the glass and silk have opposite charges, they attract one another like clothes that have rubbed together in a dryer.']
['How are the two materials rubbed together?', 'Two glass rods rubbed with silk in this manner will repel one another, because each rod has positive charge on it.']
['Are there other examples of this?', 'Similarly, two silk cloths rubbed in this manner will repel each other, because both cloths have negative charge.']
['What happened after the two materials were rubbed together?', 'Figure 18.2 shows how these simple materials can be used to explore the nature of the force between charges.']
['What is the specific fact about the two types of charges mentioned in the text?', 'It took scientists a long time to discover what lay behind these two types of charges.']

['What did the ancient Greeks notice about amber?', 'The word electric itself comes from the Greek word elektron for amber, because the ancient Greeks noticed that amber, when rubbed by fur, attracts dry straw.']

['What is an interesting fact in the text?', 'Almost 2,000 years later, the English physicist William Gilbert proposed a model that explained the effect of electric charge as being due to a mysterious electrical fluid that would pass from one object to another.']

['What was the reaction to this model?', 'This model was debated for several hundred years, but it was finally put to rest in 1897 by the work of the English physicist J. J. Thomson and French physicist Jean Perrin.']

['What did Thomson and Perrin study?', 'Along with many others, Thomson and Perrin were studying the mysterious cathode rays that were known at the time to consist of particles smaller than the smallest atom.']
['What did Perrin do to put it to rest?', 'Perrin showed that cathode rays actually carried negative electrical charge.']

["What did Thomson's work lead him to conclude?", 'Later, Thomson’s work led him to declare, “I can see no escape from the conclusion that [cathode rays] are charges of negative electricity carried by particles of matter.”']

['What was the particle that carries the fundamental unit of negative electrical charge?', 'It took several years of further experiments to confirm Thomson’s interpretation of the experiments, but science had in fact discovered the particle that carries the fundamental unit of negative electrical charge.']
['What was this particle called?', 'We now know this particle as the electron.']

['What kind of charge do atoms carry?', 'Atoms, however, were known to be electrically neutral, which means that they carry the same amount of positive and negative charge, so their net charge is zero.']
['Because electrons are negative, some other part of the atom must contain what kind of negative charge?', 'Because electrons are negative, some other part of the atom must contain positive charge.']

['What did Thomason put forth?', 'Thomson put forth what is called the plum pudding model, in which he described atoms as being made of thousands of electrons swimming around in a nebulous mass of positive charge, as shown by the left-side image of Figure 18.3.']

['What was the name of his student?', 'His student, Ernest Rutherford, originally believed that this model was correct and used it (along with other models) to try to understand the results of his experiments bombarding gold foils with alpha particles (i.e., helium atoms stripped of their electrons).']
['What did the results show?', 'The results, however, did not confirm Thomson’s model but rather destroyed it!']

['What did Rutherford find during this time?', 'Rutherford found that most of the space occupied by the gold atoms was actually empty and that almost all of the matter of each atom was concentrated into a tiny, extremely dense nucleus, as shown by the right-side image of Figure 18.3.']
['What did he discover?', 'The atomic nucleus was later found to contain particles called protons, each of which carries a unit of positive electric charge.']
['What are the fundamental particles that carry electric charge?', 'Protons and electrons are thus the fundamental particles that carry electric charge.']
['What are the properties of electrons?', 'Each proton carries one unit of positive charge, and each electron carries one unit of negative charge.']
['What is the opposite of that?', 'To the best precision that modern technology can provide, the charge carried by a proton is exactly the opposite of that carried by an electron.']

['What is coulomb?', 'The SI unit for electric charge is the coulomb (abbreviated as “C”), which is named after the French physicist Charles Augustin de Coulomb, who studied the force between charged objects.']
['Are there other units for charge?', 'The proton carries  $$\\(+ 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C.}\\)$$  and the electron carries  $$\\(-1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C,}\\)$$ .']
['Does it have an electrical charge?', 'The number n of protons required to make +1.00 C is']
['What does 1.00 C of electric charge mean?', 'The same number of electrons is required to make −1.00 C of electric charge.']
['What is the fundamental unit of charge?', 'The fundamental unit of charge is often represented as e.']
['What is the charge on a proton?', 'Thus, the charge on a proton is e, and the charge on an electron is −e.']
['What else can you tell me about e?', 'Mathematically,  $$\\(e = + 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What is the passage about?', 'Because the fundamental positive and negative units of charge are carried on protons and electrons, we would expect that the total charge cannot change in any system that we define.']
['What is the difference between a positive and negative charge?', 'In other words, although we might be able to move charge around, we cannot create or destroy it.']
['what are those things?', 'This should be true provided that we do not create or destroy protons or electrons in our system.']

['how did it change in the twentieth century?', 'In the twentieth century, however, scientists learned how to create and destroy electrons and protons, but they found that charge is still conserved.']
['How did scientists come to that conclusion?', 'Many experiments and solid theoretical arguments have elevated this idea to the status of a law.']
['What does the law of conservation of charge say?', 'The law of conservation of charge says that electrical charge cannot be created or destroyed.']
['What is the law of conservation of charge?', 'The law of conservation of charge is very useful.']
['What does it tell us?', 'It tells us that the net charge in a system is the same before and after any interaction within the system.']

['What must we ensure that no external charge enters the system during the interaction and that no internal charge leaves the system?', 'Of course, we must ensure that no external charge enters the system during the interaction and that no internal charge leaves the system.']
['What does it mean mathematically?', 'Mathematically, conservation of charge can be expressed as']
['What else did you find in the tutorial?', 'Materials can be classified depending on whether they allow charge to move.']
['What are conductors?', 'If charge can easily move through a material, such as metals, then these materials are called conductors.']
['What does conductor mean?', 'This means that charge can be conducted (i.e., move) through the material rather easily.']
['What are insulators?', 'If charge cannot move through a material, such as rubber, then this material is called an insulator.']
['What is an insulator?', 'Most materials are insulators.']
['What makes them insulators?', 'Their atoms and molecules hold on more tightly to their electrons, so it is difficult for electrons to move between atoms.']
['Is there any exception to this rule?', 'However, it is not impossible.']
['What can be done with enough energy?', 'With enough energy, it is possible to force electrons to move through an insulator.']
['What would you not do with a flammable liquid?', 'However, the insulator is often physically destroyed in the process.']
['What would you want to destroy to make the metal conduct?', 'In metals, the outer electrons are loosely bound to their atoms, so not much energy is required to make electrons move through metal.']
['What metals are good conductors?', 'Such metals as copper, silver, and aluminum are good conductors.']
['What are some other materials that can be used to make insulating materials?', 'Insulating materials include plastics, glass, ceramics, and wood.']
['What is the conductivity of some materials?', 'The conductivity of some materials is intermediate between conductors and insulators.']
['What are the semiconductors called?', 'These are called semiconductors.']

['What can you tell me about semiconductors?', 'They can be made conductive under the right conditions, which can involve temperature, the purity of the material, and the force applied to push electrons through them.']
['What are some uses of semiconductors?', 'Because we can control whether semiconductors are conductors or insulators, these materials are used extensively in computer chips.']
['What is the most commonly used semiconductor?', 'The most commonly used semiconductor is silicon.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Figure 18.8 shows various materials arranged according to their ability to conduct electrons.']
['What happens when like charges are placed next to each other?', 'Because like charges repel each other, they will push against each other until they are as far apart as they can get.']
['What happens when they are closer together?', 'Because the charge can move in a conductor, it moves to the outer surfaces of the object.']

['What can you tell me about the outer surfaces of a metal sphere?', 'Figure 18.9(a) shows schematically how an excess negative charge spreads itself evenly over the outer surface of a metal sphere.']
['What is an insulator?', 'The electrons still repel each other, but they are not able to move, because the material is an insulator.']
['How does the force of attraction between two objects?', 'Thus, the excess charge stays put and does not distribute itself over the object.']
['What happened after this situation?', 'Figure 18.9(b) shows this situation.']
['What is a positive charge?', 'Most objects we deal with are electrically neutral, which means that they have the same amount of positive and negative charge.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about transferring negative charge from one object to another?', 'However, transferring negative charge from one object to another is fairly easy to do.']
['what is the negative charge?', 'When negative charge is transferred from one object to another, an excess of positive charge is left behind.']
['What is the positive charge?', 'The positive charge is carried by the proton, which is stuck firmly in the nucleus of atoms, and the atoms are stuck in place in solid materials.']
['Do electrons have to be in atoms or molecules?', 'Electrons, which carry the negative charge, are much easier to remove from their atoms or molecules and can therefore be transferred more easily.']
['How can charge be transferred?', 'Electric charge can be transferred in several manners.']

['What is one of the simplest ways to transfer charge?', 'One of the simplest ways to transfer charge is charging by contact, in which the surfaces of two objects made of different materials are placed in close contact.']

['When materials are separated, what happens to the electrons?', 'If one of the materials holds electrons more tightly than the other, then it takes some electrons with it when the materials are separated.']

['Can rubbing two surfaces together increase the transfer of electrons?', 'Rubbing two surfaces together increases the transfer of electrons, because it creates a closer contact between the materials.']
['What does it do?', 'It also serves to present fresh material with a full supply of electrons to the other material.']
['Can we transfer charge through shoes?', 'Thus, when you walk across a carpet on a dry day, your shoes rub against the carpet, and some electrons are removed from the carpet by your shoes.']
['What happens after the electrons are removed?', 'The result is that you have an excess of negative charge on your shoes.']
['why do we have an excess of charge?', 'When you then touch a doorknob, some of your excess of electrons transfer to the neutral doorknob, creating a small spark.']
['What did you learn about this method?', 'Touching the doorknob with your hand demonstrates a second way to transfer electric charge, which is charging by conduction.']

['What happened after you touched the doorknob?', 'This transfer happens because like charges repel, and so the excess electrons that you picked up from the carpet want to be as far away from each other as possible.']
['Where do they move to?', 'Some of them move to the doorknob, where they will distribute themselves over the outer surface of the metal.']
['What other examples of charging by conduction did you see?', 'Another example of charging by conduction is shown in the top row of Figure 18.10.']
['How is this example set up?', 'A metal sphere with 100 excess electrons touches a metal sphere with 50 excess electrons, so 25 electrons from the first sphere transfer to the second sphere.']
['How many excess electrons did each sphere finish with?', 'Each sphere finishes with 75 excess electrons.']
['What can you tell me about the reasoning applies?', 'The same reasoning applies to the transfer of positive charge.']
['How is the difference between a solid and a liquid?', 'However, because positive charge essentially cannot move in solids, it is transferred by moving negative charge in the opposite direction.']
['What is important about this section?', 'For example, consider the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']

['What happened at the bottom row of Figure 18.10?', 'The first metal sphere has 100 excess protons and touches a metal sphere with 50 excess protons, so the second sphere transfers 25 electrons to the first sphere.']
['What will happen to the first metal sphere after this transfer?', 'These 25 extra electrons will electrically cancel 25 protons so that the first metal sphere is left with 75 excess protons.']
['What was the result of the last sphere?', 'This is shown in the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']
['How many excess protons did the second metal sphere have?', 'The second metal sphere lost 25 electrons so it has 25 more excess protons, for a total of 75 excess protons.']
['What happened in the top row of Figure 18.10?', 'The end result is the same if we consider that the first ball transferred a net positive charge equal to that of 25 protons to the first ball.']

['What can you find in the study material?', 'In this discussion, you may wonder how the excess electrons originally got from your shoes to your hand to create the spark when you touched the doorknob.']
['What is the answer to the question?', 'The answer is that no electrons actually traveled from your shoes to your hands.']

['Why did the electrons on your shoe not move to your feet?', 'Instead, because like charges repel each other, the excess electrons on your shoe simply pushed away some of the electrons in your feet.']
['How did that happen?', 'The electrons thus dislodged from your feet moved up into your leg and in turn pushed away some electrons in your leg.']
['Did that process continue?', 'This process continued through your whole body until a distribution of excess electrons covered the extremities of your body.']

['What else did it do to your body?', 'Thus your head, your hands, the tip of your nose, and so forth all received their doses of excess electrons that had been pushed out of their normal positions.']
['Who was the recipient of electrons?', 'All this was the result of electrons being pushed out of your feet by the excess electrons on your shoes.']
['What is the most interesting fact about polarization?', 'This type of charge separation is called polarization.']

['How does it occur?', 'As soon as the excess electrons leave your shoes (by rubbing off onto the floor or being carried away in humid air), the distribution of electrons in your body returns to normal.']
['How does this affect you?', 'Every part of your body is again electrically neutral (i.e., zero excess charge).']
['What is polarization?', 'The phenomenon of polarization is seen in Figure 18.1.']
['What did the child do to acquire an excess positive charge?', 'The child has accumulated excess positive charge by sliding on the slide.']
['What happens when an excess charge repels itself?', 'This excess charge repels itself and so becomes distributed over the extremities of the child’s body, notably in his hair.']

["What happens to the child's hair when it is exposed to a high voltage?", 'As a result, the hair stands on end, because the excess negative charge on each strand repels the excess positive charge on neighboring strands.']
['What is polarization used for?', 'Polarization can be used to charge objects.']
['What is a specific example of this?', 'Consider the two metallic spheres shown in Figure 18.11.']
['What happens to the two spheres?', 'The spheres are electrically neutral, so they carry the same amounts of positive and negative charge.']
['Are the two spheres touching?', 'In the top picture (Figure 18.11(a)), the two spheres are touching, and the positive and negative charge is evenly distributed over the two spheres.']

['What happens if two objects that have excess positive charge are approached?', 'We then approach a glass rod that carries an excess positive charge, which can be done by rubbing the glass rod with silk, as shown in Figure 18.11(b).']

['What happens to the right sphere?', 'Because opposite charges attract each other, the negative charge is attracted to the glass rod, leaving an excess positive charge on the opposite side of the right sphere.']

['What are these examples of?', 'This is an example of charging by induction, whereby a charge is created by approaching a charged object with a second object to create an unbalanced charge in the second object.']
['What happens if the two objects are separated?', 'If we then separate the two spheres, as shown in Figure 18.11(c), the excess charge is stuck on each sphere.']
['What happens to the two spheres after separation?', 'The left sphere now has an excess negative charge, and the right sphere has an excess positive charge.']
['What does the bottom picture show?', 'Finally, in the bottom picture, the rod is removed, and the opposite charges attract each other, so they move as close together as they can get.']

['What is important in this material?', 'More than 100 years before Thomson and Rutherford discovered the fundamental particles that carry positive and negative electric charges, the French scientist Charles-Augustin de Coulomb mathematically described the force between charged objects.']
['What did he discover?', 'Doing so required careful measurements of forces between charged spheres, for which he built an ingenious device called a torsion balance.']

['What is the name of the device that contains an insulating rod that is hanging by a thread inside a glass-walled enclosure?', 'This device, shown in Figure 18.15, contains an insulating rod that is hanging by a thread inside a glass-walled enclosure.']
['What is hanging by the thread?', 'At one end of the rod is the metallic sphere A.']
['What does it do?', 'When no charge is on this sphere, it touches sphere B. Coulomb would touch the spheres with a third metallic ball (shown at the bottom of the diagram) that was charged.']
['What happens to the spheres?', 'An unknown amount of charge would distribute evenly between spheres A and B, which would then repel each other, because like charges repel.']

['What would cause sphere A to rotate away from sphere B?', 'This force would cause sphere A to rotate away from sphere B, thus twisting the wire until the torsion in the wire balanced the electrical force.']
['What does he do next?', 'Coulomb then turned the knob at the top, which allowed him to rotate the thread, thus bringing sphere A closer to sphere B.']
['Why is this important?', 'He found that bringing sphere A twice as close to sphere B required increasing the torsion by a factor of four.']
['What did he find?', 'Bringing the sphere three times closer required a ninefold increase in the torsion.']
['What did he do next?', 'From this type of measurement, he deduced that the electrical force between the spheres was inversely proportional to the distance squared between the spheres.']
['What is inversely proportional to the distance squared between the spheres?', 'In other words,']
['What is this about?', 'An electrical charge distributes itself equally between two conducting spheres of the same size.']
['What did Coulomb do to figure this out?', 'Knowing this allowed Coulomb to divide an unknown charge in half.']
['Did he know that by repeating this process, it would change the amount of charge?', 'Repeating this process would produce a sphere with one quarter of the initial charge, and so on.']

["What did Coulomb's experiments have to do with spheres and the force?", 'Using this technique, he measured the force between spheres A and B when they were charged with different amounts of charge.']
['What did the measurements show?', 'These measurements led him to deduce that the force was proportional to the charge on each sphere, or']
['What is the equation about?', 'This equation is known as Coulomb’s law, and it describes the electrostatic force between charged objects.']
['What is the constant of proportionality k called?', 'The constant of proportionality k is called Coulomb’s constant.']
['What is the value of the constant k?', 'In SI units, the constant k has the value  $$\\(k = 8.99\\  \\times \\ 10^{9}\\text{N} \\cdot \\text{m}^{\\text{2}}\\text{/C}^{\\text{2.}}\\)$$']
['What is the direction of the force?', 'The direction of the force is along the line joining the centers of the two objects.']
['What does the negative result mean?', 'If the two charges are of opposite signs, Coulomb’s law gives a negative result.']
['What does the positive result mean?', 'This means that the force between the particles is attractive.']
['What does the same signs mean?', 'If the two charges have the same signs, Coulomb’s law gives a positive result.']
['What does the opposite sign mean?', 'This means that the force between the particles is repulsive.']
['How does the repulsive force work?', 'For example, if both  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are negative or if both are positive, the force between them is repulsive.']
['What is the image for this article?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(a).']

['What is the difference between attractive and repulsive force?', 'If  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is a negative charge and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is a positive charge (or vice versa), then the charges are different, so the force between them is attractive.']
['What is the image for the article?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(b).']
['What happens to the electric current when two charges are not moving together?', 'Note that Coulomb’s law applies only to charged objects that are not moving with respect to each other.']

['How does Coulomb’s law affect the force between two objects?', 'The law says that the force is proportional to the amount of charge on each object and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the objects.']
['What is the force proportional to?', 'If we double the charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$, for instance, then the force is doubled.']
['What else is it proportional to?', 'If we double the distance between the objects, then the force between them decreases by a factor of  $$\\(2^{2} = 4\\)$$ .']

['What is the most important thing to know about Coulomb’s law?', 'Although Coulomb’s law is true in general, it is easiest to apply to spherical objects or to objects that are much smaller than the distance between the objects (in which case, the objects can be approximated as spheres).']
['What does Coulomb’s law mean?', 'Coulomb’s law is an example of an inverse-square law, which means the force depends on the square of the denominator.']
['What other inverse-square laws exist?', 'Another inverse-square law is Newton’s law of universal gravitation, which is  $$\\(F = {{Gm_{1}m_{2}}/r^{2}}\\)$$ .']

['What are two important respects that universal gravitation and coulomb’s law differ in?', 'Although these laws are similar, they differ in two important respects: (i) The gravitational constant G is much, much smaller than k ( $$\\(G = 6.67\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 11}\\text{m}^{3}\\text{/kg} \\cdot \\text{s}^{2}\\)$$ ); and (ii) only one type of mass exists, whereas two types of electric charge exist.']

['What is the relationship between gravitation and electric charge?', 'These two differences explain why gravity is so much weaker than the electrostatic force and why gravity is only attractive, whereas the electrostatic force can be attractive or repulsive.']
['What are some other important concepts you need to know?', 'Finally, note that Coulomb measured the distance between the spheres from the centers of each sphere.']
['What did he not explain in his original papers?', 'He did not explain this assumption in his original papers, but it turns out to be valid.']

['What can you tell me about the uniform spherical distribution?', 'From outside a uniform spherical distribution of charge, it can be treated as if all the charge were located at the center of the sphere.']

['What is a force field?', 'You may have heard of a force field in science fiction movies, where such fields apply forces at particular positions in space to keep a villain trapped or to protect a spaceship from enemy fire.']
['What is the difference between force field and a magnetic field?', 'The concept of a field is very useful in physics, although it differs somewhat from what you see in movies.']

['What is a way of conceptualizing and mapping the force that surrounds any object and acts on another object at a distance without apparent physical connection?', 'A field is a way of conceptualizing and mapping the force that surrounds any object and acts on another object at a distance without apparent physical connection.']

['What does a field represent?', 'For example, the gravitational field surrounding Earth and all other masses represents the gravitational force that would be experienced if another mass were placed at a given point within the field.']
['Who proposed the concept of an electric field?', 'Michael Faraday, an English physicist of the nineteenth century, proposed the concept of an electric field.']

['What is the relationship between field and charge?', 'If you know the electric field, then you can easily calculate the force (magnitude and direction) applied to any electric charge that you place in the field.']
['What is an electric field?', 'An electric field is generated by electric charge and tells us the force per unit charge at all locations in space around a charge distribution.']
['What is a charge distribution?', 'The charge distribution could be a single point charge; a distribution of charge over, say, a flat plate; or a more complex distribution of charge.']
['What is the electric field around a charge distribution?', 'The electric field extends into space around the charge distribution.']
['How is the electric field exerted?', 'Now consider placing a test charge in the field.']

['What is a positive electric charge whose charge is so small that it does not significantly disturb the charges that create the electric field?', 'A test charge is a positive electric charge whose charge is so small that it does not significantly disturb the charges that create the electric field.']
['What does the electric field do to the test charge?', 'The electric field exerts a force on the test charge in a given direction.']
['What is the force exerted?', 'The force exerted is proportional to the charge of the test charge.']
['What does the force depend on?', 'For example, if we double the charge of the test charge, the force exerted on it doubles.']
['What is the force per unit charge?', 'Mathematically, saying that electric field is the force per unit charge is written as']
['What did you learn from this document?', 'where we are considering only electric forces.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Note that the electric field is a vector field that points in the same direction as the force on the positive test charge.']
['What are the units of electric field?', 'The units of electric field are N/C.']
['What can we learn from the document?', 'where the absolute value is used, because we only consider the magnitude of the force.']
['What is the magnitude of the electric field?', 'The magnitude of the electric field is then']
['What is the equation for the electric field created by a point charge Q?', 'This equation gives the magnitude of the electric field created by a point charge Q.']
['What is the distance r in the denominator?', 'The distance r in the denominator is the distance from the point charge, Q, or from the center of a spherical charge, to the point of interest.']
['Why does the electric field still exist?', 'If the test charge is removed from the electric field, the electric field still exists.']
['What other features of the electric field are discussed?', 'To create a three-dimensional map of the electric field, imagine placing the test charge in various locations in the field.']

['How do you calculate the electric field?', 'At each location, measure the force on the charge, and use the vector equation  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{E} = {\\overset{\\rightarrow}{F}/q_{\\text{test}}}\\)$$  to calculate the electric field.']
['How do you determine strength?', 'Draw an arrow at each point where you place the test charge to represent the strength and the direction of the electric field.']
['What is the relationship between arrows and the electric field?', 'The length of the arrows should be proportional to the strength of the electric field.']
['What can you do with these arrows?', 'If you join together these arrows, you obtain lines.']
['What is the three-dimensional electric field created by a positive charge?', 'Figure 18.17 shows an image of the three-dimensional electric field created by a positive charge.']

['What are two-dimensional electric field maps shown in Figure 18.18?', 'Just drawing the electric field lines in a plane that slices through the charge gives the two-dimensional electric-field maps shown in Figure 18.18.']
['What do the field lines represent?', 'On the left is the electric field created by a positive charge, and on the right is the electric field created by a negative charge.']
['What do the electric field lines show?', 'Notice that the electric field lines point away from the positive charge and toward the negative charge.']
['How does this help?', 'Thus, a positive test charge placed in the electric field of the positive charge will be repelled.']
['What is consistent with Coulomb’s law?', 'This is consistent with Coulomb’s law, which says that like charges repel each other.']
['How does the law help?', 'If we place the positive charge in the electric field of the negative charge, the positive charge is attracted to the negative charge.']
['What happens for the positive charge?', 'The opposite is true for negative test charges.']
['Is it true that like charges repel each other?', 'Thus, the direction of the electric field lines is consistent with what we find by using Coulomb’s law.']
['What is the equation for the electric field?', 'The equation  $$\\(E = {{k|Q|}/r^{2}}\\)$$  says that the electric field gets stronger as we approach the charge that generates it.']

['What is the relation between distance from the charge and strength of the electric field?', 'For example, at 2 cm from the charge Q (r = 2 cm), the electric field is four times stronger than at 4 cm from the charge (r = 4 cm).']
['What do we see in Figure 18.17 and Figure 18.18?', 'Looking at Figure 18.17 and Figure 18.18 again, we see that the electric field lines become denser as we approach the charge that generates it.']

['Is the density of the electric field lines proportional to the strength of the electric field?', 'In fact, the density of the electric field lines is proportional to the strength of the electric field!']
['What can we learn from this document?', 'Electric-field maps can be made for several charges or for more complicated charge distributions.']
['What can we find from multiple charges?', 'The electric field due to multiple charges may be found by adding together the electric field from each individual charge.']
['what is the single number?', 'Because this sum can only be a single number, we know that only a single electric-field line can go through any given point.']
['What else does this have to do with the information?', 'In other words, electric-field lines cannot cross each other.']
['What do you find interesting in figure 18.19(a)?', 'Figure 18.19(a) shows a two-dimensional map of the electric field generated by a charge of +q and a nearby charge of −q.']
['What is the three-dimensional map of this electric field obtained by?', 'The three-dimensional version of this map is obtained by rotating this map about the axis that goes through both charges.']
['What will happen if you place a positive test charge in this field?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would experience a force in the direction of the field lines at its location.']
['What will it do when it is attracted to a negative charge?', 'It would thus be repelled from the positive charge and attracted to the negative charge.']
['What is the electric field generated by?', 'Figure 18.19(b) shows the electric field generated by two charges of −q.']
['How do the field lines repel each other?', 'Note how the field lines tend to repel each other and do not overlap.']
['What would a positive test charge placed in this field do?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would be attracted to both charges.']

['Is there more to this story?', 'If you are far from these two charges, where far means much farther than the distance between the charges, the electric field looks like the electric field from a single charge of −2q.']

['What did you learn in studying gravity?', 'As you learned in studying gravity, a mass in a gravitational field has potential energy, which means it has the potential to accelerate and thereby increase its kinetic energy.']
['What else did you learn about kinetic energy?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What is a good example of a tool that can be used to pound a nail into a piece of wood?', 'For example, imagine you want to use a stone to pound a nail into a piece of wood.']

['How does this work?', 'You first lift the stone high above the nail, which increases the potential energy of the stone-Earth system—because Earth is so large, it does not move, so we usually shorten this by saying simply that the potential energy of the stone increases.']
['What happens to this potential energy when you drop the stone?', 'When you drop the stone, gravity converts the potential energy into kinetic energy.']
['What happens when the stone hits the nail?', 'When the stone hits the nail, it does work by pounding the nail into the wood.']

['What is the work that a mass can potentially do by virtue of its position in a gravitational field?', 'The gravitational potential energy is the work that a mass can potentially do by virtue of its position in a gravitational field.']

['What else did you learn in studying gravity?', 'Potential energy is a very useful concept, because it can be used with conservation of energy to calculate the motion of masses in a gravitational field.']
['What is an example of a key term in this section?', 'Electric potential energy works much the same way, but it is based on the electric field instead of the gravitational field.']
['What is the electric potential energy of a charged object?', 'By virtue of its position in an electric field, a charge has an electric potential energy.']

['What is potential energy converted to?', 'If the charge is free to move, the force due to the electric field causes it to accelerate, so its potential energy is converted to kinetic energy, just like a mass that falls in a gravitational field.']
['What can kinetic energy be used for?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']

['What is the work that a charge can do by virtue of its position in an electric field?', 'The electric potential energy is the work that a charge can do by virtue of its position in an electric field.']

['What was a similarity between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy?', 'The analogy between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy is depicted in Figure 18.21.']
['What are the examples of gravitational potential energy?', "On the left, the ball-Earth system gains gravitational potential energy when the ball is higher in Earth's gravitational field."]
['What did the example show?', 'On the right, the two-charge system gains electric potential energy when the positive charge is farther from the negative charge.']
['What does it mean to denote gravitational potential energy?', 'Let’s use the symbol  $$\\(U_{G}\\)$$  to denote gravitational potential energy.']
['What happens when a mass falls in a gravitational field?', 'When a mass falls in a gravitational field, its gravitational potential energy decreases.']

['What is the work done by the gravitational field to make the mass accelerate?', 'Conservation of energy tells us that the work done by the gravitational field to make the mass accelerate must equal the loss of potential energy of the mass.']
['What does the symbol do?', 'If we use the symbol  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{gravity}}\\)$$  to denote this work, then']

['What is the formula for the distance of a ball from its initial position to its final position?', 'where F is the force due to gravity, and  $$\\(y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  and  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  are the initial and final positions of the ball, respectively.']
['What is negative direction?', 'The negative sign is because gravity points down, which we consider to be the negative direction.']
['What is the constant gravitational field near Earth’s surface?', 'For the constant gravitational field near Earth’s surface,  $$\\(F = mg\\)$$ .']
['What is the gravitational potential energy of mass?', 'The change in gravitational potential energy of the mass is']

['What is the importance of the $$(y_text, f-)?', 'Note that  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}} - y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  is just the negative of the height h from which the mass falls, so we usually just write  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{']
['What is the most important information in your response?', 'G}} = - mgh\\)$$ .']
['What is the main idea of the current document?', 'We now apply the same reasoning to a charge in an electric field to find the electric potential energy.']

['What is the electric potential energy?', 'The change  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}}\\)$$  in electric potential energy is the work done by the electric field to move a charge q from an initial position  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to a final position  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  ( $$\\(- \\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}}\\)$$ ).']

['How does the work done by the field work?', 'The definition of work does not change, except that now the work is done by the electric field:  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}} = F(x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}})\\)$$ .']
['What else is unique about this?', 'For a charge that falls through a constant electric field E, the force applied to the charge by the electric field is  $$\\(F = qE\\)$$ .']
['Does this have anything to do with the change in potential energy?', 'The change in electric potential energy of the charge is thus']
['What would be the best analogy for this?', 'Figure 18.22 shows how this analogy would work if we were close to Earth’s surface, where gravity is constant.']
['What can we use to explain the analogy?', 'The top image shows a charge accelerating due to a constant electric field.']
['What can we use to explain it?', 'Likewise, the round mass in the bottom image accelerates due to a constant gravitation field.']
['What do they have in common?', 'In both cases, the potential energy of the particle decreases, and its kinetic energy increases.']

['What is meant by the constant electric field?', 'If the electric field is not constant, then the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$  is not valid, and deriving the electric potential energy becomes more involved.']

['How can the equation be used to calculate the electric potential energy of an assembly of two point charges?', 'For example, consider the electric potential energy of an assembly of two point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  of the same sign that are initially very far apart.']
['What do we need to know to apply the equation?', 'We start by placing charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  at the origin of our coordinate system.']
['What else do we need to know about the equation?', 'This takes no electrical energy, because there is no electric field at the origin (because charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is very far away).']
['How does this apply to the equation?', 'We then bring charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  in from very far away to a distance r from the center of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$ .']
['How does this work?', 'This requires some effort, because the electric field of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  applies a repulsive force on charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$ .']
['How can we apply the equation to a situation where two charges are reassembled?', 'The energy it takes to assemble these two charges can be recuperated if we let them fly apart again.']
['How does this apply to the equation?', 'Thus, the charges have potential energy when they are a distance r apart.']

['How do we find the electric potential energy of a pair of point charges?', 'It turns out that the electric potential energy of a pair of point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  a distance r apart is']

['What did you learn about charges?', 'To recap, if charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are free to move, they can accumulate kinetic energy by flying apart, and this kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['How does this work out?', 'The maximum amount of work the two charges can do (if they fly infinitely far from each other) is given by the equation above.']
['What are the signs of these two charges?', 'Notice that if the two charges have opposite signs, then the potential energy is negative.']
['What does the potential energy do?', 'This means that the charges have more potential to do work when they are far apart than when they are at a distance r apart.']

['What does that mean?', 'This makes sense: Opposite charges attract, so the charges can gain more kinetic energy if they attract each other from far away than if they start at only a short distance apart.']
['Are there more other ways we can think of?', 'Thus, they have more potential to do work when they are far apart.']
['What figure summarizes how the electric potential energy depends on charge and separation?', 'Figure 18.23 summarizes how the electric potential energy depends on charge and separation.']

['What is the term for the force applied by a fixed charge Q on any arbitrary test charge q?', 'Recall that to find the force applied by a fixed charge Q on any arbitrary test charge q, it was convenient to define the electric field, which is the force per unit charge applied by Q on any test charge that we place in its electric field.']
['What is your question about electric energy?', 'The same Strategy is used here with electric potential energy:']
['What is the electric potential V?', 'We now define the electric potential V, which is the electric potential energy per unit charge.']
['What is the electric potential called?', 'Normally, the electric potential is simply called the potential or voltage.']
['who named it that?', 'The units for the potential are J/C, which are given the name volt (V) after the Italian physicist Alessandro Volta (1745–1827).']
['What did you study?', 'From the equation  $$\\(U_{\\text{E}} = {{kq_{1}q_{2}}/r}\\)$$, the electric potential a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is']

['What is the energy required per unit charge to bring a charge from infinity to a distance r from a point charge?', 'This equation gives the energy required per unit charge to bring a charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  from infinity to a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the mathematical way of writing this?', 'Mathematically, this is written as']
