['How do we represent left?', '\\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = r} - \\left. \\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = \\infty}\\text{.}\\]$$']
['What is the difference between the equations for the voltaic and the emf?', 'Note that this equation actually represents a difference in electric potential.']

['What is this difference represented by?', 'However, because the second term is zero, it is normally not written, and we speak of the electric potential instead of the electric potential difference, or we just say the potential difference, or voltage).']

['What is the difference in energy per unit charge between two points not infinitely far apart?', 'Below, when we consider the electric potential energy per unit charge between two points not infinitely far apart, we speak of electric potential difference explicitly.']

['What is the difference between energy per unit charge and potential?', 'Just remember that electric potential and electric potential difference are really the same thing; the former is used just when the electric potential energy is zero in either the initial or final charge configuration.']
['What does the text say about electric potential?', 'Now consider the electric potential near a group of charges q1, q2, and q3, as drawn in Figure 18.24.']
['What is the importance of electric potential?', 'The electric potential is derived by considering the electric field.']

['What does the text say about electric potential?', 'Electric fields follow the principle of superposition and can be simply added together, so the electric potential from different charges also add together.']
['What is the result of adding together?', 'Thus, the electric potential of a point near a group of charges is']
['What is the electric potential in a uniform electric field?', 'Now let’s consider the electric potential in a uniform electric field.']

['What did you learn from this lesson?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$, we see that the potential difference in going from  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  in a uniform electric field E is']
['What can you tell me about positive charge?', 'Notice that a positive charge in a region with high potential will experience a force pushing it toward regions of lower potential.']
['What can you tell me about potential?', 'In this sense, potential is like pressure for fluids.']
['What is pressure like?', 'Imagine a pipe containing fluid, with the fluid at one end of the pipe under high pressure and the fluid at the other end of the pipe under low pressure.']
['What happens when pressure is lower?', 'If nothing prevents the fluid from flowing, it will flow from the high-pressure end to the low-pressure end.']
['What can you tell me about pressure?', 'Likewise, a positive charge that is free to move will move from a region with high potential to a region with lower potential.']
['What is the most important factor in determining the amount of energy absorbed by an object?', 'Consider again the X-ray tube discussed in the previous sample problem.']
['How does this change the electric field lines?', 'A single positive charge produces an electric field that points away from it, as in Figure 18.17.']
['What is significant about this field?', 'This field is not uniform, because the space between the lines increases as you move away from the charge.']
['What happens if you combine a positive and a negative charge?', 'However, if we combine a positive and a negative charge, we obtain the electric field shown in Figure 18.19(a).']
['What do you notice about that field?', 'Notice that, between the charges, the electric field lines are more equally spaced.']
['What is the region between the lines of charge called?', 'Now the region between the lines of charge contains a fairly uniform electric field.']

['What is a capacitor?', 'We can extend this idea even further and into two dimensions by placing two metallic plates face to face and charging one with positive charge and the other with an equal magnitude of negative charge.']
['How do you charge them?', 'This can be done by connecting one plate to the positive terminal of a battery and the other plate to the negative terminal, as shown in Figure 18.28.']
['What happens to the electric field between these charged plates?', 'The electric field between these charged plates will be extremely uniform.']
['What is it about plates that makes them so useful?', 'Let’s think about the work required to charge these plates.']
['What is neutral?', 'Before the plates are connected to the battery, they are neutral—that is, they have zero net charge.']

['What are the first positive and the second negative charges?', 'Placing the first positive charge on the left plate and the first negative charge on the right plate requires very little work, because the plates are neutral, so no opposing charges are present.']
["What's next?", 'Now consider placing a second positive charge on the left plate and a second negative charge on the right plate.']

['What must be done to put the two new charges on the plates?', 'Because the first two charges repel the new arrivals, a force must be applied to the two new charges over a distance to put them on the plates.']
['What does this mean?', 'This is the definition of work, which means that, compared with the first pair, more work is required to put the second pair of charges on the plates.']
['What else are you learning?', 'To place the third positive and negative charges on the plates requires yet more work, and so on.']
['What does the work result in?', 'The battery!']
['What is the energy of a chemical reaction?', 'Its chemical potential energy is converted into the work required to separate the positive and negative charges.']
['What happens inside the battery and how does it work?', 'Although the battery does work, this work remains within the battery-plate system.']

['What does conservation of energy tell us?', 'Therefore, conservation of energy tells us that, if the potential energy of the battery decreases to separate charges, the energy of another part of the system must increase by the same amount.']
['What is stored in the electric field?', 'In fact, the energy from the battery is stored in the electric field between the plates.']
['What analogies are used to explain the idea?', 'This idea is analogous to considering that the potential energy of a raised hammer is stored in Earth’s gravitational field.']
['What happens to the hammer if the gravitational field disappears?', 'If the gravitational field were to disappear, the hammer would have no potential energy.']
['What is the article about?', 'Likewise, if no electric field existed between the plates, no energy would be stored between them.']
['What does a capacitor do?', 'If we now disconnect the plates from the battery, they will hold the energy.']
['What will happen with the energy that they hold?', 'We could connect the plates to a lightbulb, for example, and the lightbulb would light up until this energy was used up.']
['What is the reasoning behind these plates holding energy?', 'These plates thus have the capacity to store energy.']
['What is a capacitor?', 'For this reason, an arrangement such as this is called a capacitor.']

['What is an arrangement of objects that, by virtue of their geometry, can store energy an electric field?', 'A capacitor is an arrangement of objects that, by virtue of their geometry, can store energy an electric field.']
['What are they shown in figure 18.29?', 'Various real capacitors are shown in Figure 18.29.']
['What are capacitors usually made from?', 'They are usually made from conducting plates or sheets that are separated by an insulating material.']
['What are the different geometries of capacitors?', 'They can be flat or rolled up or have other geometries.']

['What is the relationship between C and Q?', 'where Q is the magnitude of the charge on each capacitor plate, and V is the potential difference in going from the negative plate to the positive plate.']
['Is this always positive?', 'This means that both Q and V are always positive, so the capacitance is always positive.']
['What is farads?', 'We can see from the equation for capacitance that the units of capacitance are C/V, which are called farads (F) after the nineteenth-century English physicist Michael Faraday.']

['What is the reason for the equation $$(C = Q/V)$$?', 'The equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes sense: A parallel-plate capacitor (like the one shown in Figure 18.28) the size of a football field could hold a lot of charge without requiring too much work per unit charge to push the charge into the capacitor.']
['Why would it require too much work?', 'Thus, Q would be large, and V would be small, so the capacitance C would be very large.']

['What would happen if there was no work?', 'Squeezing the same charge into a capacitor the size of a fingernail would require much more work, so V would be very large, and the capacitance would be much smaller.']
['Why does it seem that capacitance depends on voltage?', 'Although the equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes it seem that capacitance depends on voltage, in fact it does not.']
['Why does it not depend on voltage?', 'For a given capacitor, the ratio of the charge stored in the capacitor to the voltage difference between the plates of the capacitor always remains the same.']
['What determines the capacitance of a capacitor?', 'Capacitance is determined by the geometry of the capacitor and the materials that it is made from.']

['what are the sample problems?', 'Before working through some sample problems, let’s look at what happens if we put an insulating material between the plates of a capacitor that has been charged and then disconnected from the charging battery, as illustrated in Figure 18.30.']
['What happens in this scenario?', 'Because the material is insulating, the charge cannot move through it from one plate to the other, so the charge Q on the capacitor does not change.']
['what else can happen here?', 'An electric field exists between the plates of a charged capacitor, so the insulating material becomes polarized, as shown in the lower part of the figure.']

['What is an electrically insulating material that becomes polarized in an electric field called?', 'An electrically insulating material that becomes polarized in an electric field is called a dielectric.']

['What is the most important thing you can tell me about dielectrics?', 'Figure 18.30 shows that the negative charge in the molecules in the material shifts to the left, toward the positive charge of the capacitor.']
['What causes the negative charge to shift?', 'This shift is due to the electric field, which applies a force to the left on the electrons in the molecules of the dielectric.']
['What happens after the charge shifts?', 'The right sides of the molecules are now missing a bit of negative charge, so their net charge is positive.']
['what are dielectrics?', 'All electrically insulating materials are dielectrics, but some are better dielectrics than others.']
['What makes a good dielectric?', 'A good dielectric is one whose molecules allow their electrons to shift strongly in an electric field.']

['Do electrons escape the electric field?', 'In other words, an electric field pulls their electrons a fair bit away from their atom, but they do not escape completely from their atom (which is why they are insulators).']
['What is the dielectric in a capacitor?', 'Figure 18.31 shows a macroscopic view of a dielectric in a charged capacitor.']

['What can you tell me about the electric-field lines in the capacitor with the dielectric?', 'Notice that the electric-field lines in the capacitor with the dielectric are spaced farther apart than the electric-field lines in the capacitor with no dielectric.']

['What does the dielectric do?', 'This means that the electric field in the dielectric is weaker, so it stores less electrical potential energy than the electric field in the capacitor with no dielectric.']

['how does the energy in the electric field go into stretching these springs?', 'In fact, the molecules in the dielectric act like tiny springs, and the energy in the electric field goes into stretching these springs.']

['why does this make it easier to put more charge on a capacitor?', 'With the electric field thus weakened, the voltage difference between the two sides of the capacitor is smaller, so it becomes easier to put more charge on the capacitor.']
['Can a capacitor with a dielectric have potential energy?', 'Placing a dielectric in a capacitor before charging it therefore allows more charge and potential energy to be stored in the capacitor.']

['What is the capacitance of a capacitor?', 'Because  $$\\(\\kappa\\)$$  is greater than 1 for dielectrics, the capacitance increases when a dielectric is placed between the capacitor plates.']
['What is the dielectric constant of several materials?', 'The dielectric constant of several materials is shown in Table 18.1.']
['What is current?', 'Just as water flows from high to low elevation, electrons that are free to move will travel from a place with low potential to a place with high potential.']
['What is the difference between a battery and a capacitor?', 'A battery has two terminals that are at different potentials.']
['What can you tell me about this?', 'If the terminals are connected by a conducting wire, an electric current (charges) will flow, as shown in Figure 19.2.']

['What is the current called when electrons move from the low-potential terminal of the battery (the negative end) through the wire and enter the high-potential terminal of the battery (the positive end)?', 'Electrons will then move from the low-potential terminal of the battery (the negative end) through the wire and enter the high-potential terminal of the battery (the positive end).']
['What is the definition of electric current?', 'Electric current is the rate at which electric charge moves.']

['How is the current measured?', 'A large current, such as that used to start a truck engine, moves a large amount very quickly, whereas a small current, such as that used to operate a hand-held calculator, moves a small amount of charge more slowly.']

['What is the SI unit for electric current?', 'The SI unit for electric current is the ampere (A), which is named in honor of the French physicist André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836).']
['What is one coulomb per second?', 'One ampere is one coulomb per second, or']

['What is the difference between electric current moving through a wire and water current moving through a pipe?', 'Electric current moving through a wire is in many ways similar to water current moving through a pipe.']
['What is the next question you were asked?', 'To define the flow of water through a pipe, we can count the water molecules that flow past a given section of the pipe.']
['What is the difference between electric current and magnetic current?', 'As shown in Figure 19.3, electric current is very similar.']
['What do we count when we measure the current in a wire?', 'We count the number of electrical charges that flow past a section of a conductor; in this case, a wire.']

['What is the total charge of the particles in Figure 19.3?', 'Assume each particle q in Figure 19.3 carries a charge  $$\\(q = 1\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$, in which case the total charge shown would be  $$\\(\\Delta Q = 5q = 5\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$ .']

['What is the mobile charge in wires?', 'Normally, negative charges—electrons—are the mobile charge in wires, as indicated in Figure 19.2.']
['What do positive charges do?', 'Positive charges are normally stuck in place in solids and cannot move freely.']

['What would happen if they were to move freely?', 'However, because a positive current moving to the right is the same as a negative current of equal magnitude moving to the left, as shown in Figure 19.4, we define conventional current to flow in the direction that a positive charge would flow if it could move.']
['What is the current assumed to be composed of?', 'Thus, unless otherwise specified, an electric current is assumed to be composed of positive charges.']
['I want to read your answers to the question and let me know which one you prefer.', 'Also note that one Coulomb is a significant amount of electric charge, so 5 A is a very large current.']

['What happens to negative charges?', 'In metal wires, as we have seen, current is carried by electrons, so the negative charges move.']
['What else is interesting?', 'In ionic solutions, such as salt water, both positively charged and negatively charged ions move.']
['What is true in all situations?', 'This is also true in nerve cells.']
['What is the most important thing to know about pure positive currents?', 'Pure positive currents are relatively rare but do occur.']

['Who first described current as the direction that positive charges flow through a wire?', 'History credits American politician and scientist Benjamin Franklin with describing current as the direction that positive charges flow through a wire.']
['What was his greatest contribution?', 'He named the type of charge associated with electrons negative long before they were known to carry current in so many situations.']
['What obstacles do electrons encounter?', 'As electrons move through a metal wire, they encounter obstacles such as other electrons, atoms, impurities, etc.']
['How do the electrons escape from these obstacles?', 'The electrons scatter from these obstacles, as depicted in Figure 19.5.']
['Do the electrons lose energy with each interaction?', 'Normally, the electrons lose energy with each interaction.']
['What happens when electrons move?', 'To keep the electrons moving thus requires a force, which is supplied by an electric field.']
['What is the electric field in a wire?', 'The electric field in a wire points from the end of the wire at the higher potential to the end of the wire at the lower potential.']
['What is the electric field used for?', 'Electrons, carrying a negative charge, move on average (or drift) in the direction opposite the electric field, as shown in Figure 19.5.']
["I've finished the introduction, so let me ask you about current: what does it do?", 'So far, we have discussed current that moves constantly in a single direction.']
['What is the significance of direct current?', 'This is called direct current, because the electric charge flows in only one direction.']
['What is the term for direct current?', 'Direct current is often called DC current.']

['What do you mean by current direction alternates back and forth?', 'Many sources of electrical power, such as the hydroelectric dam shown at the beginning of this chapter, produce alternating current, in which the current direction alternates back and forth.']
['What kind of current does this produce?', 'Alternating current is often called AC current.']
['What is the time interval for alternating current?', 'Alternating current moves back and forth at regular time intervals, as shown in Figure 19.6.']
['Do these different types of current all switch directions at the same time?', 'The alternating current that comes from a normal wall socket does not suddenly switch directions.']
['What kind of current does that produce?', 'Rather, it increases smoothly up to a maximum current and then smoothly decreases back to zero.']
['What happens after the current drops back to zero?', 'It then grows again, but in the opposite direction until it has reached the same maximum value.']
['What happens after the current reaches a maximum value?', 'After that, it decreases smoothly back to zero, and the cycle starts over again.']
['What are some devices that use AC?', 'Devices that use AC include vacuum cleaners, fans, power tools, hair dryers, and countless others.']
['What do these devices use to obtain power?', 'These devices obtain the power they require when you plug them into a wall socket.']
['How does this power get to the devices?', 'The wall socket is connected to the power grid that provides an alternating potential (AC potential).']

['What happens to the current when it is in a wall socket?', 'When your device is plugged in, the AC potential pushes charges back and forth in the circuit of the device, creating an alternating current.']
['What is the use of DC?', 'Many devices, however, use DC, such as computers, cell phones, flashlights, and cars.']
['What is one source of DC?', 'One source of DC is a battery, which provides a constant potential (DC potential) between its terminals.']
['How does this affect dc current?', 'With your device connected to a battery, the DC potential pushes charge in one direction through the circuit of your device, creating a DC current.']
['What is another source?', 'Another way to produce DC current is by using a transformer, which converts AC potential to DC potential.']
['What are small transformers used for?', 'Small transformers that you can plug into a wall socket are used to charge up your laptop, cell phone, or other electronic device.']
['What is a transformer that transforms AC voltage into DC voltage?', 'People generally call this a charger or a battery, but it is a transformer that transforms AC voltage into DC voltage.']
['What is the best example of this?', 'The next time someone asks to borrow your laptop charger, tell them that you don’t have a laptop charger, but that they may borrow your converter.']

['What is the difference between electrical current in a wire and water flowing through a pipe?', 'As mentioned previously, electrical current in a wire is in many ways similar to water flowing through a pipe.']
['What did they find out?', 'The water current that can flow through a pipe is affected by obstacles in the pipe, such as clogs and narrow sections in the pipe.']
['What effect do the obstacles have on the flow of current through the pipe?', 'These obstacles slow down the flow of current through the pipe.']

['What can slow down electrical current in a wire?', 'Similarly, electrical current in a wire can be slowed down by many factors, including impurities in the metal of the wire or collisions between the charges in the material.']
['What causes the current to be slowed down?', 'These factors create a resistance to the electrical current.']
['What is resistance?', 'Resistance is a description of how much a wire or other electrical component opposes the flow of charge through it.']

["Who created Ohm's law?", 'In the 19th century, the German physicist Georg Simon Ohm (1787–1854) found experimentally that current through a conductor is proportional to the voltage drop across a current-carrying conductor.']
['What is the relationship between voltage and current?', 'This relationship is called Ohm’s law.']
['Can you explain this relationship?', 'It can be viewed as a cause-and-effect relationship, with voltage being the cause and the current being the effect.']
['Did you have any other information regarding Ohm’s law?', 'Ohm’s law is an empirical law like that for friction, which means that it is an experimentally observed phenomenon.']
['What are the units of resistance?', 'The units of resistance are volts per ampere, or V/A.']
['What does V/A represent?', 'We call a V/A an ohm, which is represented by the uppercase Greek letter omega ( $$\\(\\text{Ω}\\)$$ ).']
['What happens if the voltage is less than the current?', 'Thus,']
['What is the general meaning of Ohm’s law?', 'Ohm’s law holds for most materials and at common temperatures.']
['What is superconductivity?', 'At very low temperatures, resistance may drop to zero (superconductivity).']
['What causes the resistance of materials to increase?', 'At very high temperatures, the thermal motion of atoms in the material inhibits the flow of electrons, increasing the resistance.']
['What is an ohm?', 'The many substances for which Ohm’s law holds are called ohmic.']
['What kind of materials are ohmic?', 'Ohmic materials include good conductors like copper, aluminum, and silver, and some poor conductors under certain circumstances.']
['Does the resistance of ohmic materials change as current changes?', 'The resistance of ohmic materials remains essentially the same for a wide range of voltage and current.']
['What is the most important fact in the passage?', 'Now that we understand the concept of electric current, let’s see what we can do with it.']
['What is the modern lifestyle reliant on?', 'As you are no doubt aware, the modern lifestyle relies heavily on electrical devices.']
['What do these devices consist of?', 'These devices contain ingenious electric circuits, which are complete, closed pathways through which electric current flows.']

['What is the purpose of an electric circuit?', 'The electric circuit guides electric charge from one point to the next, running the charge through various devices along the way to extract work or information.']
['What are some important features of an electric circuit?', 'Electric circuits are made from many materials and cover a huge range of sizes, as shown in Figure 19.8.']

['What are some important dimensions?', 'Computers and cell phones contain electric circuits whose features can be as small as roughly a billionth of a meter (a nanometer, or  $$\\(10^{-9}\\text{m}\\)$$ ).']

['What are the pathways that guide the current in these devices?', 'The pathways that guide the current in these devices are made by ultraprecise chemical treatments of silicon or other semiconductors.']
['What are other dimensions?', 'Large power systems, on the other hand, contain electric circuits whose features are on the scale of meters.']
['What is the reason for the large dimensions of these systems?', 'These systems carry such large electric currents that their physical dimensions must be relatively large.']
['What are the pathways that form electric circuits made from?', 'The pathways that form electric circuits are made from a conducting material, normally a metal in macroscopic circuits.']
['What are some things that copper wires can form?', 'For example, copper wires inside your school building form the electrical circuits that power lighting, projectors, screens, speakers, etc.']
['What can we do to represent an electric circuit?', 'To represent an electric circuit, we draw circuit diagrams.']

['What do the lines represent?', 'The thin black lines in the electric circuit diagram represent the pathway that the electric charge must follow.']
['What can be done with the pathways?', 'These pathways are assumed to be perfect conductors, so electric charge can move along these pathways without losing any energy.']
['Are the wires in circuits perfect?', 'In reality, the wires in circuits are not perfect, but they come close enough for our purposes.']
['What is it that you need to know regarding the zigzag element labeled R?', 'The zigzag element labeled R is a resistor, which is a circuit element that provides a known resistance.']

['What is the longest line represents?', 'The red element in Figure 19.9 is a battery, with its positive and negative terminals indicated; the longer line represents the positive terminal of the battery, and the shorter line represents the negative terminal.']

['What are the steps you have taken in this lesson?', 'Finally, the element labeled ground on the lower left of the circuit indicates that the circuit is connected to Earth, which is a large, essentially neutral object containing an infinite amount of charge.']
['What does the ground determine?', 'Among other things, the ground determines the potential of the negative terminal of the battery.']
['What is the potential of the ground?', 'Normally, the potential of the ground is defined to be zero:  $$\\(V_{\\text{ground}} \\equiv 0\\)$$ .']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that the entire lower wire in Figure 19.10 is at a voltage of zero volts.']

['What is the current?', 'However, we draw the current to show the direction in which positive charge would move.']
['What is the main topic of our study material?', 'On the right side of Figure 19.9 is an analogous water circuit.']
['What happens in the water circuit?', 'Water at a higher pressure leaves the top of the pump, which is like charges leaving the positive terminal of the battery.']
['What happens after the water leaves the pipe?', 'The water travels through the pipe, like the charges traveling through the wire.']
['What happens after it travels through the pipe?', 'Next, the water goes through a sand filter, which heats up as the water squeezes through.']
['Why does it heat up?', 'This step is like the charges going through the resistor.']
['What happens as the charges flow through a resistor?', 'When charges flow through a resistor, they do work to heat up the resistor.']
['What happens after the water flows through the sand filter?', 'After flowing through the sand filter, the water has converted its potential energy into heat, so it is at a lower pressure.']
['What happens to the voltage of the resistor when it is hot?', 'Likewise, the charges exiting the resistor have converted their potential energy into heat, so they are at a lower voltage.']
['What is potential energy per charge?', 'Recall that voltage is just potential energy per charge.']
['What can you tell me about the analogy?', 'Thus, water pressure is analogous to electric potential energy (i.e., voltage).']

['What can you tell me about the water circuit?', 'Coming back to the water circuit again, we see that the water returns to the bottom of the pump, which is like the charge returning to the negative terminal of the battery.']

['What happens when they return to the bottom of the pump?', 'The water pump uses a source of energy to pump the water back up to a high pressure again, giving it the pressure required to go through the circuit once more.']
['What can you tell me about the water pump?', 'The water pump is like the battery, which uses chemical energy to increase the voltage of the charge up to the level of the positive terminal.']
['What is the potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery?', 'The potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery is the voltage rating of the battery.']
['How is this voltage like water pressure?', 'This voltage is like water pressure in the upper pipe.']
['What do they force?', 'Just like a higher pressure forces water to move toward a lower pressure, a higher voltage forces electric charge to flow toward a lower voltage.']
['What pressure does the pump operate at?', 'The pump takes water at low pressure and does work on it, ejecting water at a higher pressure.']
['How can a battery operate at pressure?', 'Likewise, a battery takes charge at a low voltage, does work on it, and ejects charge at a higher voltage.']
['What is the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9?', 'Note that the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9 is the same throughout the circuit.']

['What does that mean?', 'In other words, if we measured the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time at any point in the circuit, we would get the same answer no matter where in the circuit we measured.']
['What else did you know about the electrical circuit?', 'The same is true of the electrical circuit in the same figure.']
['What is true about the electric current?', 'The electric current is the same at all points in this circuit, including inside the battery and in the resistor.']
['What else is true?', 'The electric current neither speeds up in the wires nor slows down in the resistor.']
['What would happen if the charge on a battery was too high or too low?', 'This would create points where too much or too little charge would be bunched up.']
['What is true about the current in a circuit?', 'Thus, the current is the same at all points in the circuit shown in Figure 19.9.']

['What is the current and voltage of a water circuit?', 'Although the current is the same everywhere in both the electric and water circuits, the voltage or water pressure changes as you move through the circuits.']
['How is the water pressure changed?', 'In the water circuit, the water pressure at the pump outlet stays the same until the water goes through the sand filter, assuming no energy loss in the pipe.']

['How is the voltage changed in an electrical circuit?', 'Likewise, the voltage in the electrical circuit is the same at all points in a given wire, because we have assumed that the wires are perfect conductors.']

['What else does this article say?', 'Thus, as indicated by the constant red color of the upper wire in Figure 19.11, the voltage throughout this wire is constant at  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['What happens to the voltage as you go through the resistor?', 'The voltage then drops as you go through the resistor, but once you reach the blue wire, the voltage stays at its new level of  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  all the way to the negative terminal of the battery (i.e., the blue terminal of the battery).']
['What are some examples of the questions?', 'If we go from the blue wire through the battery to the red wire, the voltage increases from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$ to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['What else does the question ask about?', 'Likewise, if we go from the blue wire up through the resistor to the red wire, the voltage also goes from  $$\\(V = 0\\)$$  to  $$\\(V = V_{\\text{battery}}\\)$$ .']

['What else do we need to know about this page?', 'Other possible circuit elements include capacitors and switches.']
['What is the name of the figure that shows the equator and the poles?', 'These are drawn as shown on the left side of Figure 19.12.']
['What is a switch?', 'A switch is a device that opens and closes the circuit, like a light switch.']
['What happens when the switch is open?', 'It is analogous to a valve in a water circuit, as shown on the right side of Figure 19.12.']
['What happens when the switch is closed?', 'With the switch open, no current passes through the circuit.']
['What else did we learn about the switch?', 'With the switch closed, it becomes part of the wire, so the current passes through it with no loss of voltage.']
['What is the capacitor labeled?', 'The capacitor is labeled C on the left of Figure 19.12.']
['What is an analogy for a capacitor in an electrical circuit?', 'A capacitor in an electrical circuit is analogous to a flexible membrane in a water circuit.']

['When the switch is closed, what happens to the capacitor?', 'As this happens, the voltage across the capacitor plates increases.']
['What happens to the membrane in the water circuit?', 'This is like the membrane in the water circuit:']

['How do we use a vacuum pump?', 'Likewise, if we close the valve, the water has nowhere to go and the membrane maintains the water pressure in the pipe between itself and the valve.']

['What is the current that passes through the capacitor or membrane?', 'If the switch is closed for a long time in the electric circuit or if the valve is open for a long time in the water circuit, the current will eventually stop flowing because the capacitor or the membrane will have become completely charged.']
['What does the steady state mean?', 'Each circuit is now in the steady state, which means that its characteristics do not change over time.']

['What is the steady state characterized by?', 'In this case, the steady state is characterized by zero current, and this does not change as long as the switch or valve remains in the same position.']
['What does it mean that no current passes?', 'In the steady state, no electrical current passes through the capacitor, and no water current passes through the membrane.']
['What else did you find interesting in your study?', 'The voltage difference between the capacitor plates will be the same as the battery voltage.']
['What is the pressure behind the membrane?', 'In the water circuit, the pressure behind the membrane will be the same as the pressure created by the pump.']

['How is it similar to the water analogy?', 'Although the circuit in Figure 19.12 may seem a bit pointless because all that happens when the switch is closed is that the capacitor charges up, it does show the capacitor’s ability to store charge.']
['What is another interesting fact about capacitors?', 'Thus, the capacitor serves as a reservoir for charge.']
['What can it store?', 'This property of capacitors is used in circuits in many ways.']
['What are some ways in which capacitors can be used?', 'For example, capacitors are used to power circuits while batteries are being charged.']
['What else does it do?', 'In addition, capacitors can serve as filters.']
['How does this analogy fit?', 'To understand this, let’s go back to the water analogy.']
['What is the analogy?', 'Suppose you have a water hose and are watering your garden.']
['What happens when your friend kinks the hose?', 'Your friend thinks he’s funny, and kinks the hose.']
['What happens if the hose is kinked?', 'While the hose is kinked, you experience no water flow.']
['What happens when he lets go?', 'When he lets go, the water starts flowing again.']
['What happens if he does this really fast?', 'If he does this really fast, you experience water-no water-water-no water, and that’s really no way to water your garden.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Now imagine that the hose is filling up a big bucket, and you are watering from the bottom of the bucket.']

['What happens if your friend kinks the water hose?', 'As long as you had water in your bucket to begin with and your friend doesn’t kink the water hose for too long, you would be able to water your garden without the interruptions.']
['What happens to your friend kinking the water hose?', 'Your friend kinking the water hose is filtered by the big bucket’s supply of water, so it does not impact your ability to water the garden.']
['What can this teach us?', 'We can think of the interruptions in the current (be it water or electrical current) as noise.']
['What happens when a capacitor is added to a circuit?', 'Capacitors act in an analogous way as the water bucket to help filter out the noise.']
['What do capacitors do?', 'Capacitors have so many uses that it is very rare to find an electronic circuit that does not include some capacitors.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Now that we have a basic idea of how electrical circuits work, let’s see what happens in circuits with more than one circuit element.']

['What happens when we use the equivalent resistor in the right circuit?', 'In other words, the same current will flow through the left and right circuits in Figure 19.14 if we use the equivalent resistor in the right circuit.']

['How is the voltage distributed?', 'The sum of these voltages equals the voltage output of the battery, that is']

['What is the most common way people use power?', 'Power is associated by many people with electricity.']

['How long has magnetism been known?', 'People have been aware of magnets and magnetism for thousands of years.']

['Who gave it the name of magnet?', 'The earliest records date back to ancient times, particularly in the region of Asia Minor called Magnesia—the name of this region is the source of words like magnet.']
['What countries are those ancient times found in?', 'Magnetic rocks found in Magnesia, which is now part of western Turkey, stimulated interest during ancient times.']

['What kind of rocks were discovered?', 'When humans first discovered magnetic rocks, they likely found that certain parts of these rocks attracted bits of iron or other magnetic rocks more strongly than other parts.']
['What kind of areas do these attract metal?', 'These areas are called the poles of a magnet.']

['What is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material?', 'A magnetic pole is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material, such as iron.']
['What can you do with poles?', 'For example, the poles of the bar magnet shown in Figure 20.2 are where the paper clips are concentrated.']

['What does opposite pole facing south mean?', 'If a bar magnet is suspended so that it rotates freely, one pole of the magnet will always turn toward the north, with the opposite pole facing south.']
['What did this discovery lead to?', 'This discovery led to the compass, which is simply a small, elongated magnet mounted so that it can rotate freely.']
['What is an example of this?', 'An example of a compass is shown Figure 20.3.']

['What is the pole of the magnet that orients northward called?', 'The pole of the magnet that orients northward is called the north pole, and the opposite pole of the magnet is called the south pole.']

['What is the discovery that one particular pole of a magnet orients northward, whereas the other pole orients southward allowed people to identify the north and south poles of any magnet?', 'The discovery that one particular pole of a magnet orients northward, whereas the other pole orients southward allowed people to identify the north and south poles of any magnet.']
['What was the next information I should know?', 'It was then noticed that the north poles of two different magnets repel each other, and likewise for the south poles.']
['What is the opposite of the north pole of one magnet?', 'Conversely, the north pole of one magnet attracts the south pole of other magnets.']
['What is the analogy between this situation and that of electric charge?', 'This situation is analogous to that of electric charge, where like charges repel and unlike charges attract.']
['Are there any other similarities to this situation?', 'In magnets, we simply replace charge with pole: Like poles repel and unlike poles attract.']
['What is the force between magnets?', 'This is summarized in Figure 20.4, which shows how the force between magnets depends on their relative orientation.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'Consider again the fact that the pole of a magnet that orients northward is called the north pole of the magnet.']
['What are the implications?', 'If unlike poles attract, then the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic North Pole must be a magnetic south pole!']
["What's the other possibility?", 'Likewise, the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic South Pole must be a magnetic north pole.']

['What is the situation depicted in Figure 20.5?', 'This situation is depicted in Figure 20.5, in which Earth is represented as containing a giant internal bar magnet with its magnetic south pole at the geographic North Pole and vice versa.']

['What happens next?', 'If we were to somehow suspend a giant bar magnet in space near Earth, then the north pole of the space magnet would be attracted to the south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['What happens with a compass needle?', 'This is in essence what happens with a compass needle:']
["What is interesting about the Earth's magnet?", 'Its magnetic north pole is attracted to the magnet south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['Is this the end of the quiz?', 'The answer is no:']
['What is the single magnetic pole of a bar magnet?', 'Each half of the bar magnet has a north pole and a south pole.']
['how many poles do two pieces have?', 'You can even continue cutting each piece of the bar magnet in half, and you will always obtain a new, smaller magnet with two opposite poles.']

['what else was interesting?', 'As shown in Figure 20.6, you can continue this process down to the atomic scale, and you will find that even the smallest particles that behave as magnets have two opposite poles.']

['What is the reason for this?', 'In fact, no experiment has ever found any object with a single magnetic pole, from the smallest subatomic particle such as electrons to the largest objects in the universe such as stars.']
['What do magnets always have?', 'Because magnets always have two poles, they are referred to as magnetic dipoles—di means two.']
['What is the difference between magnetic dipoles and electric dipoles?', 'Below, we will see that magnetic dipoles have properties that are analogous to electric dipoles.']
['What are some of the important facts that I should know?', 'Only certain materials, such as iron, cobalt, nickel, and gadolinium, exhibit strong magnetic effects.']
['What is the Latin word for iron?', 'Such materials are called ferromagnetic, after the Latin word ferrum for iron.']
['What are some other important facts about magnetism?', 'Other materials exhibit weak magnetic effects, which are detectable only with sensitive instruments.']

['What is another important fact?', 'Not only do ferromagnetic materials respond strongly to magnets—the way iron is attracted to magnets—but they can also be magnetized themselves—that is, they can be induced to be magnetic or made into permanent magnets (Figure 20.7).']
['What is a permanent magnet?', 'A permanent magnet is simply a material that retains its magnetic behavior for a long time, even when exposed to demagnetizing influences.']

['What happens when magnetized?', 'When a magnet is brought near a previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material, it causes local magnetization of the material with unlike poles closest, as in the right side of Figure 20.7.']
['What happens when a magnet is placed near an unmagnetized piece of iron?', 'This causes an attractive force, which is why unmagnetized iron is attracted to a magnet.']
['What happens on a microscopic scale?', 'What happens on a microscopic scale is illustrated in Figure 7(a).']
['What happens within the material?', 'Regions within the material called domains act like small bar magnets.']
['What do the magnetic poles of individual atoms align within the domain?', 'Within domains, the magnetic poles of individual atoms are aligned.']
['What does each atom act like?', 'Each atom acts like a tiny bar magnet.']
['What are domains oriented in?', 'Domains are small and randomly oriented in an unmagnetized ferromagnetic object.']
['What does this mean to us?', 'In response to an external magnetic field, the domains may grow to millimeter size, aligning themselves, as shown in Figure 7(b).']

['What can be made permanent if the material is heated and then cooled?', 'This induced magnetization can be made permanent if the material is heated and then cooled, or simply tapped in the presence of other magnets.']
['What can be done to a permanent magnet?', 'Conversely, a permanent magnet can be demagnetized by hard blows or by heating it in the absence of another magnet.']
['What would increase the randomness of the domains?', 'Increased thermal motion at higher temperature can disrupt and randomize the orientation and size of the domains.']

['What is the temperature at which a ferromagnetic material cannot be magnetized?', 'There is a well-defined temperature for ferromagnetic materials, which is called the Curie temperature, above which they cannot be magnetized.']
['How high is the Curie temperature for iron?', 'The Curie temperature for iron is 1,043 K (770 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ), which is well above room temperature.']

['What other material has the same definition?', 'There are several elements and alloys that have Curie temperatures much lower than room temperature and are ferromagnetic only below those temperatures.']
['What does this material discuss?', 'We have thus seen that forces can be applied between magnets and between magnets and ferromagnetic materials without any contact between the objects.']
['What happens when the force is applied without contact?', 'This is reminiscent of electric forces, which also act over distances.']

['What is a force field around electric charges?', 'Electric forces are described using the concept of the electric field, which is a force field around electric charges that describes the force on any other charge placed in the field.']
['What does a magnet do?', 'Likewise, a magnet creates a magnetic field around it that describes the force exerted on other magnets placed in the field.']

['Can you tell me what magnetic field lines are used for?', 'As with electric fields, the pictorial representation of magnetic field lines is very useful for visualizing the strength and direction of the magnetic field.']

['What is the direction of magnetic field lines defined to be?', 'As shown in Figure 20.9, the direction of magnetic field lines is defined to be the direction in which the north pole of a compass needle points.']
['How does the needle point away from it?', 'If you place a compass near the north pole of a magnet, the north pole of the compass needle will be repelled and point away from the magnet.']
['How does this affect the direction of field lines?', 'Thus, the magnetic field lines point away from the north pole of a magnet and toward its south pole.']
['What can be learned from magnetic field lines?', 'Magnetic field lines can be mapped out using a small compass.']
['How do you move the compass?', 'The compass is moved from point to point around a magnet, and at each point, a short line is drawn in the direction of the needle, as shown in Figure 20.10.']
['Do joining the lines together give you any results?', 'Joining the lines together then reveals the path of the magnetic field line.']
['What is another way to visualize magnetic field lines?', 'Another way to visualize magnetic field lines is to sprinkle iron filings around a magnet.']
['What happens after you sprinkle them around?', 'The filings will orient themselves along the magnetic field lines, forming a pattern such as that shown on the right in Figure 20.10.']

['What happens when two magnets are brought close together?', 'When two magnets are brought close together, the magnetic field lines are perturbed, just as happens for electric field lines when two electric charges are brought together.']
['What happens when the two poles come together?', 'Bringing two north poles together—or two south poles—will cause a repulsion, and the magnetic field lines will bend away from each other.']
['What is shown in Figure 20.11?', 'This is shown in Figure 20.11, which shows the magnetic field lines created by the two closely separated north poles of a bar magnet.']

['What happens when opposite poles of two magnets are brought together?', 'When opposite poles of two magnets are brought together, the magnetic field lines join together and become denser between the poles.']
['What is the figure that shows the situation?', 'This situation is shown in Figure 20.11.']
['What is magnetic field lines?', 'Like the electric field, the magnetic field is stronger where the lines are denser.']

['What is the density of magnetic field between the two north poles in Figure 20.11?', 'Thus, between the two north poles in Figure 20.11, the magnetic field is very weak because the density of the magnetic field is almost zero.']
['How would this affect a compass?', 'A compass placed at that point would essentially spin freely if we ignore Earth’s magnetic field.']

['What happens if we disregard the magnetic field?', 'Conversely, the magnetic field lines between the north and south poles in Figure 20.11 are very dense, indicating that the magnetic field is very strong in this region.']
['What happens if we align the compass?', 'A compass placed here would quickly align with the magnetic field and point toward the south pole on the right.']
['Are there any other important points I need to know regarding this material?', 'Note that magnets are not the only things that make magnetic fields.']
['What are some other things that make magnetic fields?', 'Early in the nineteenth century, people discovered that electrical currents cause magnetic effects.']

['What was the significance of this observation?', 'This was the first significant evidence that the movement of electric charges had any connection with magnets.']
['What is an electromagnet?', 'An electromagnet is a device that uses electric current to make a magnetic field.']
['Are they able to make magnetic fields?', 'These temporarily induced magnets are called electromagnets.']
