['What do you have to say about the direction of the force?', 'The direction of the force may be found by using another version of the right-hand rule: First, we join the tails of the velocity vector and a magnetic field vector, as shown in step 1 of Figure 20.16.']
['Do you have any more questions?', 'We then curl our right fingers from  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\)$$, as indicated in step (2) of Figure 20.16.']
['How does this work?', 'The direction in which the right thumb points is the direction of the force.']
['What direction is the force going?', 'For the charge in Figure 20.16, we find that the force is directed into the page.']

['How is it applied to this charge?', 'Note that the factor  $$\\(\\sin\\theta\\)$$  in the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ means that zero force is applied on a charge that moves parallel to a magnetic field because  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\sin 0 = 0\\)$$ .']

['What can you tell me about the maximum force?', 'The maximum force a charge can experience is when it moves perpendicular to the magnetic field, because  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\sin 90{^\\circ} = 1\\;\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Did you already know that?', 'Instead of a single charge moving through a magnetic field, consider now a steady current I moving through a straight wire.']
['What is an electric current?', 'An electric current involves charges that move.']
['What is the speed of the charge?', 'If the charges q move a distance  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a time t, then their speed is  $$\\(v = {\\ell/t\\text{.}}\\)$$']
['What else did you learn about this?', 'Inserting this into the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives']
['What is the factor q/t in this equation?', 'The factor q/t in this equation is nothing more than the current in the wire.']
['What is the current in the wire?', 'Thus, using  $$\\(I = {q/t}\\)$$, we obtain']
['What does the equation represent?', 'This equation gives the force on a straight current-carrying wire of length  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a magnetic field of strength B.']
['What is the angle between the current vector and the magnetic field vector?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the current vector and the magnetic field vector.']

['What else is important to know about this equation?', 'Note that  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  is the length of wire that is in the magnetic field and for which  $$\\(\\theta \\neq 0\\;\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in Figure 20.19.']
['What is the direction of the force determined in the same way as for a single charge?', 'The direction of the force is determined in the same way as for a single charge.']
['How does it determine the direction of the force?', 'Curl your right fingers from the vector for I to the vector for B, and your right thumb will point in the direction of the force on the wire.']
['What is the force directed into?', 'For the wire shown in Figure 20.19, the force is directed into the page.']
['What was your main idea?', 'Throughout this section, you may have noticed the symmetries between magnetic effects and electric effects.']
['What is the umbrella?', 'These effects all fall under the umbrella of electromagnetism, which is the study of electric and magnetic phenomena.']
["What happens when they're moving?", 'We have seen that electric charges produce electric fields, and moving electric charges produce magnetic fields.']
['What does a magnetic dipole produce?', 'A magnetic dipole produces a magnetic field, and, as we will see in the next section, moving magnetic dipoles produce an electric field.']
['What is the relationship between electricity and magnetism?', 'Thus, electricity and magnetism are two intimately related and symmetric phenomena.']

['What is the force that a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field experiences?', 'As we learned previously, a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field experiences a force—recall  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$ .']

['What happens to the current when it is applied to a magnetic field?', 'Electric motors, which convert electrical energy into mechanical energy, are the most common application of magnetic force on current-carrying wires.']
['What do motors consist of?', 'Motors consist of loops of wire in a magnetic field.']
['what happens to the loops?', 'When current is passed through the loops, the magnetic field exerts a torque on the loops, which rotates a shaft.']
['What happens when the shaft rotates?', 'Electrical energy is converted to mechanical work in the process.']
['What is the schematic drawing of an electric motor?', 'Figure 20.23 shows a schematic drawing of an electric motor.']

["What's the top segment?", 'Let us examine the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23 to find the torques produced about the axis of the vertical shaft—this will lead to a useful equation for the torque on the loop.']
['What is the hand rule?', 'We take the magnetic field to be uniform over the rectangular loop, which has width w and height  $$\\(\\ell\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in the figure.']
['What else is in the document?', 'First, consider the force on the top segment of the loop.']
['What is the right thumb point?', 'To determine the direction of the force, we use the right-hand rule.']
['What does the magnetic field go?', 'The current goes from left to right into the page, and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page.']
['How do you know if your right thumb is pointing down?', 'Curl your right fingers from the current vector to the magnetic field vector and your right thumb points down.']
['What is said about the top segment?', 'Thus, the force on the top segment is downward, which produces no torque on the shaft.']

['What else is said about the bottom segment?', 'Repeating this analysis for the bottom segment—neglect the small gap where the lead wires go out—shows that the force on the bottom segment is upward, again producing no torque on the shaft.']
['What is the hand rule?', 'Consider now the left vertical segment of the loop.']

['What happens when the force exerted on this segment is perpendicular to the magnetic field?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, we find that the force exerted on this segment is perpendicular to the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.23.']
['What force produces a torque on the shaft?', 'This force produces a torque on the shaft.']

['What else did you learn?', 'Repeating this analysis on the right vertical segment of the loop shows that the force on this segment is in the direction opposite that of the force on the left segment, thereby producing an equal torque on the shaft.']
['What else is the total torque on the shaft?', 'The total torque on the shaft is thus twice the toque on one of the vertical segments of the loop.']

['What is the next step in the process of finding the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins?', 'To find the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins, consider Figure 20.24, which shows a view of the wire loop from above.']

['what happens in this figure?', 'Recall that torque is defined as  $$\\(\\tau = rF\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  where F is the applied force, r is the distance from the pivot to where the force is applied, and θ is the angle between r and F.']
['What happens as the loop spins?', 'Notice that, as the loop spins, the current in the vertical loop segments is always perpendicular to the magnetic field.']
['What happens next?', 'Thus, the equation  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives the magnitude of the force on each vertical segment as  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What happens next?', 'The distance r from the shaft to where this force is applied is w/2, so the torque created by this force is']
['What is the first question that I have for you?', 'If we have a multiple loop with N turns, we get N times the torque of a single loop.']
['What does the equation say?', 'Using the fact that the area of the loop is  $$\\(A = w\\ell\\text{;}\\)$$  the expression for the torque becomes']
['What is the torque on a current-carrying loop in a uniform magnetic field called?', 'This is the torque on a current-carrying loop in a uniform magnetic field.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about the article?', 'This equation can be shown to be valid for a loop of any shape.']
['What can you tell me about this equation?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\tau = NIAB\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  we see that the torque is zero when  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What happens when the wire loop rotates?', 'As the wire loop rotates, the torque increases to a maximum positive torque of  $$\\(w\\ell B\\)$$  when  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['How does it change?', 'The torque then decreases back to zero as the wire loop rotates to  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$  From  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\theta = 360{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{,}\\)$$  the torque is negative.']
['What is significant about the equation?', 'Thus, the torque changes sign every half turn, so the wire loop will oscillate back and forth.']

['What happens if we run the motor in reverse?', 'Consider now what happens if we run the motor in reverse; that is, we attach a handle to the shaft and mechanically force the coil to rotate within the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.26.']

['How does the handle help it rotate?', 'As per the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ —where  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the vectors  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\text{—charges}\\)$$  in the wires of the loop experience a magnetic force because they are moving in a magnetic field.']
['How are the two vectors related?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, where we curl our fingers from vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']
['What do we find when we conduct a current?', 'B}\\)$$, we find that charges in the top and bottom segments feel a force perpendicular to the wire, which does not cause a current.']

['What happens to the charges in the vertical wires?', 'However, charges in the vertical wires experience forces parallel to the wire, causing a current to flow through the wire and through an external circuit if one is connected.']
['What is the name of the device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy?', 'A device such as this that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is called a generator.']
['How is the induced emf found?', 'Because current is induced only in the side wires, we can find the induced emf by only considering these wires.']

['What is the emf in a straight wire moving at velocity v through a magnetic field B?', 'As explained in Induced Current in a Wire, motional emf in a straight wire moving at velocity v through a magnetic field B is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\text{,}\\)$$  where the velocity is perpendicular to the magnetic field.']

['Is it parallel to the magnetic field?', 'In the generator, the velocity makes an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  with B (see Figure 20.27), so the velocity component perpendicular to B is  $$\\(v\\sin\\theta\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Does it matter what angle it makes?', 'Thus, in this case, the emf induced on each vertical wire segment is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  and they are in the same direction.']
['Is there any way to combine the emf around the loop?', 'The total emf around the loop is then']
['What is interesting about this material?', 'Although this expression is valid, it does not give the emf as a function of time.']
['What happens next?', 'To find how the emf evolves in time, we assume that the coil is rotated at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the relationship between the angle and the angular velocity?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is related to the angular velocity by  $$\\(\\theta = \\omega t\\text{,}\\)$$  so that']
['What else do we need to learn?', 'Recall that tangential velocity v is related to angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  by  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What else should we learn about the relationship?', 'Here,  $$\\(r = {w/2}\\)$$, so that  $$\\(v = \\left( {w\\operatorname{/2}} \\right)\\omega\\)$$  and']

['what is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity $$(omega)$$ in a uniform magnetic field B?', 'is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  in a uniform magnetic field B.']
['What is the graph of the emf vs. time?', 'Figure 20.28 shows a generator connected to a light bulb and a graph of the emf vs. time.']
['How does this change?', 'Note that the emf oscillates from a positive maximum of  $$\\(E_{0}\\)$$  to a negative maximum of  $$\\({-E}_{0}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What does this mean?', 'In between, the emf goes through zero, which means that zero current flows through the light bulb at these times.']
['Why does it do this?', 'Thus, the light bulb actually flickers on and off at a frequency of 2f, because there are two zero crossings per period.']
['What is the refresh rate of lights in the United States?', 'In the United States, the frequency of alternating current is 60 Hz, so the lights flicker on and off at a frequency of 120 Hz.']
['Is there anything else you need to know about the flickering lights?', 'This is faster than the refresh rate of the human eye, so you don’t notice the flicker of the lights.']
['Does this change with the seasons?', 'Also, other factors prevent various different types of light bulbs from switching on and off so fast, so the light output is smoothed out a bit.']
['What do electric generators look like in real life?', 'In real life, electric generators look a lot different than the figures in this section, but the principles are the same.']

['What is the source of mechanical energy that turns the coil?', 'The source of mechanical energy that turns the coil can be falling water—hydropower—steam produced by the burning of fossil fuels, or the kinetic energy of wind.']

['What is the most important thing about the study?', 'Figure 20.29 shows a cutaway view of a steam turbine; steam moves over the blades connected to the shaft, which rotates the coil within the generator.']
['What is the second device that exploits magnetic induction?', 'Another very useful and common device that exploits magnetic induction is called a transformer.']

['What do transformers do?', 'Transformers do what their name implies—they transform voltages from one value to another; the term voltage is used rather than emf because transformers have internal resistance.']

['Are there specific examples of transformers?', 'For example, many cell phones, laptops, video games, power tools, and small appliances have a transformer built into their plug-in unit that changes 120 V or 240 V AC into whatever voltage the device uses.']
['What is the figure 20.30 about?', 'Figure 20.30 shows two different transformers.']
['What does the figure show?', 'Notice the wire coils that are visible in each device.']
['What do the wire coils do?', 'The purpose of these coils is explained below.']

['What is the first part of the article?', 'Figure 20.31 shows a laminated-coil transformer, which is based on Faraday’s law of induction and is very similar in construction to the apparatus Faraday used to demonstrate that magnetic fields can generate electric currents.']
['What are the two wire coils called?', 'The two wire coils are called the primary and secondary coils.']
['What is the function of the primary coil?', 'In normal use, the input voltage is applied across the primary coil, and the secondary produces the transformed output voltage.']

['What does the iron core trap?', 'Not only does the iron core trap the magnetic field created by the primary coil, but also its magnetization increases the field strength, which is analogous to how a dielectric increases the electric field strength in a capacitor.']
['What is the function of the secondary coil?', 'Since the input voltage is AC, a time-varying magnetic flux is sent through the secondary coil, inducing an AC output voltage.']

['What else did we cover in the material?', 'For the transformer shown in Figure 20.31, the output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  from the secondary coil depends almost entirely on the input voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  across the primary coil and the number of loops in the primary and secondary coils.']
["Did we cover Faraday's law?", 'Faraday’s law of induction for the secondary coil gives its induced output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  to be']

['what is the formula for the magnetic flux density of a secondary coil?', 'where  $$\\(N_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  is the number of loops in the secondary coil and  $$\\({\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}\\)$$  is the rate of change of magnetic flux.']

['What is the output voltage?', 'The output voltage equals the induced emf  $$\\(\\text{(}V_{\\text{S}} = E_{\\text{S}}\\text{),}\\)$$  provided coil resistance is small—a reasonable assumption for transformers.']

['Why did the magnetic field strength stay equal on both sides?', 'The cross-sectional area of the coils is the same on each side, as is the magnetic field strength, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ/Δ}t\\)$$  is the same on each side.']
['What is the input primary voltage?', 'The input primary voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  is also related to changing flux by']
['What is the transformer equation?', 'This is known as the transformer equation.']

['What does the transformer equals states mean?', 'It simply states that the ratio of the secondary voltage to the primary voltage in a transformer equals the ratio of the number of loops in secondary coil to the number of loops in the primary coil.']

['What can you tell me about transformers?', 'Transformers are widely used in the electric power industry to increase voltages—called step-up transformers—before long-distance transmission via high-voltage wires.']
['What else do transformers do?', 'They are also used to decrease voltages—called step-down transformers—to deliver power to homes and businesses.']

['What is the process by which electric power is generated?', 'The overwhelming majority of electric power is generated by using magnetic induction, whereby a wire coil or copper disk is rotated in a magnetic field.']
['What kind of energy is required to rotate the coils or disk?', 'The primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk can be provided by a variety of means.']
['What do hydroelectric power plants use?', 'Hydroelectric power plants use the kinetic energy of water to drive electric generators.']
['What do power plants use to create electricity?', 'Coal or nuclear power plants create steam to drive steam turbines that turn the coils.']
['What are other forms of energy?', 'Other sources of primary energy include wind, tides, or waves on water.']
['What is the most important factor in generating electricity?', 'Once power is generated, it must be transmitted to the consumer, which often means transmitting power over hundreds of kilometers.']

['What is the voltage of the power plant increased by?', 'To do this, the voltage of the power plant is increased by a step-up transformer, that is stepped up, and the current decreases proportionally because']
['What was the result of this study?', 'The lower current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  in the transmission wires reduces the Joule losses, which is heating of the wire due to a current flow.']
['What is caused by this heating?', 'This heating is caused by the small, but nonzero, resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{wire}}\\)$$  of the transmission wires.']
['How much power was lost to the environment through this heating?', 'The power lost to the environment through this heat is']
['What is the voltage of a transmission line?', 'which is proportional to the current squared in the transmission wire.']

['Why is the current squared proportional?', 'This is why the transmitted current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  must be as small as possible and, consequently, the voltage must be large to transmit the power  $$\\(P_{\\text{transmitted}}\\text{⋅}\\)$$']
['What is the voltage used for transmitting power over long distances?', 'Voltages ranging from 120 to 700 kV are used for transmitting power over long distances.']
['What is the voltage stepped up at the exit of the power station by?', 'The voltage is stepped up at the exit of the power station by a step-up transformer, as shown in Figure 20.32.']

['How much voltage is required to reach the individual homes in a household?', 'Once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center, the voltage is stepped down at a substation to between 5 and 30 kV.']
['What is the voltage at individual homes?', 'Finally, at individual homes or businesses, the power is stepped down again to 120, 240, or 480 V.']
['What is the faradays law of induction?', 'Each step-up and step-down transformation is done with a transformer designed based on Faradays law of induction.']
['What are some important things I should know about power?', 'We’ve come a long way since Queen Elizabeth asked Faraday what possible use could be made of electricity.']
['What did you learn in the preceding section?', 'In the preceding section, we learned that a current creates a magnetic field.']
['What can a magnetic field do?', 'If nature is symmetrical, then perhaps a magnetic field can create a current.']

['What are some notable developments in the field of magnetic fields?', 'In 1831, some 12 years after the discovery that an electric current generates a magnetic field, English scientist Michael Faraday (1791–1862) and American scientist Joseph Henry (1797–1878) independently demonstrated that magnetic fields can produce currents.']

['What is another important discovery?', 'The basic process of generating currents with magnetic fields is called induction; this process is also called magnetic induction to distinguish it from charging by induction, which uses the electrostatic Coulomb force.']
['Why did Faraday become popular?', 'When Faraday discovered what is now called Faraday’s law of induction, Queen Victoria asked him what possible use was electricity.']
['What did he say?', '“Madam,” he replied, “What good is a baby?”']
['What are magnetic fields used for?', 'Today, currents induced by magnetic fields are essential to our technological society.']

['What is an example of a technology that uses magnetism?', 'The electric generator—found in everything from automobiles to bicycles to nuclear power plants—uses magnetism to generate electric current.']

['What other examples of magnetism can you think of?', 'Other devices that use magnetism to induce currents include pickup coils in electric guitars, transformers of every size, certain microphones, airport security gates, and damping mechanisms on sensitive chemical balances.']

['What did Faraday experiment with?', 'One experiment Faraday did to demonstrate magnetic induction was to move a bar magnet through a wire coil and measure the resulting electric current through the wire.']
['What is the diagram of?', 'A schematic of this experiment is shown in Figure 20.33.']
['What did he find out about his experiment?', 'He found that current is induced only when the magnet moves with respect to the coil.']
['Did he say why this was only for current?', 'When the magnet is motionless with respect to the coil, no current is induced in the coil, as in Figure 20.33.']

['Was there anything else?', 'In addition, moving the magnet in the opposite direction (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) or reversing the poles of the magnet (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) results in a current in the opposite direction.']
['what is induced?', 'If a current is induced in the coil, Faraday reasoned that there must be what he called an electromotive force pushing the charges through the coil.']
['What did he think of the experiment?', 'This interpretation turned out to be incorrect; instead, the external source doing the work of moving the magnet adds energy to the charges in the coil.']
['What does the energy have to do with it?', 'The energy added per unit charge has units of volts, so the electromotive force is actually a potential.']
['what was the name of the force that was named after it?', 'Unfortunately, the name electromotive force stuck and with it the potential for confusing it with a real force.']
['What else did you learn?', 'For this reason, we avoid the term electromotive force and just use the abbreviation emf, which has the mathematical symbol  $$\\(\\varepsilon\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the emf?', 'The emf may be defined as the rate at which energy is drawn from a source per unit current flowing through a circuit.']

['What is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit?', 'Thus, emf is the energy per unit charge added by a source, which contrasts with voltage, which is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit.']

["What is the first question I'll be asking you?", 'To understand why an emf is generated in a coil due to a moving magnet, consider Figure 20.34, which shows a bar magnet moving downward with respect to a wire loop.']
['What are some important facts about that figure?', 'Initially, seven magnetic field lines are going through the loop (see left-hand image).']

['What else can you tell me about the figure?', 'Because the magnet is moving away from the coil, only five magnetic field lines are going through the loop after a short time  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  (see right-hand image).']

['What is the most important thing to remember about a magnetic field?', 'Thus, when a change occurs in the number of magnetic field lines going through the area defined by the wire loop, an emf is induced in the wire loop.']
['What can you tell me about the induced emf?', 'Experiments such as this show that the induced emf is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic field.']
['How does the induced emf affect current flow?', 'Mathematically, we express this as']

['What can you tell me about the loop?', 'Note that magnetic field lines that lie in the plane of the wire loop do not actually pass through the loop, as shown by the left-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['What is the arrow coming out of the loop?', 'In this figure, the arrow coming out of the loop is a vector whose magnitude is the area of the loop and whose direction is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.']

['How does the rotation affect the field lines?', 'In Figure 20.35, as the loop is rotated from  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$ to  $$\\({\\theta = 0{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}}\\text{,}\\)$$  the contribution of the magnetic field lines to the emf increases.']

['What is the importance of the perpendicular component?', 'Thus, what is important in generating an emf in the wire loop is the component of the magnetic field that is perpendicular to the plane of the loop, which is  $$\\({B\\cos\\theta}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the analogy to a sail?', 'This is analogous to a sail in the wind.']
['What does this analogy lead to?', 'Think of the conducting loop as the sail and the magnetic field as the wind.']

['What happens to the wind?', 'To maximize the force of the wind on the sail, the sail is oriented so that its surface vector points in the same direction as the winds, as in the right-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['What happens when the wind is perpendicular to the wind?', 'When the sail is aligned so that its surface vector is perpendicular to the wind, as in the left-most loop in Figure 20.35, then the wind exerts no force on the sail.']

['What is the content of this document?', 'Another way to reduce the number of magnetic field lines that go through the conducting loop in Figure 20.35 is not to move the magnet but to make the loop smaller.']
['What happens when the loop area is changed?', 'Experiments show that changing the area of a conducting loop in a stable magnetic field induces an emf in the loop.']

['What is the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area?', 'Thus, the emf produced in a conducting loop is proportional to the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area']
['How is the loop shaped?', 'where  $$\\(B\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is the perpendicular magnetic field and A is the area of the loop.']
['What is the product Ba?', 'The product  $$\\(BA\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is very important.']

['What is the relationship between magnetic flux and the product Ba?', 'It is proportional to the number of magnetic field lines that pass perpendicularly through a surface of area A. Going back to our sail analogy, it would be proportional to the force of the wind on the sail.']
['What is the name of the current that flows through a magnet?', 'It is called the magnetic flux and is represented by  $$\\(\\text{Φ}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of magnetic flux?', 'The unit of magnetic flux is the weber (Wb), which is magnetic field per unit area, or T/m2.']
['What else do you know about Weber?', 'The weber is also a volt second (Vs).']
['How many loops does the magnet need?', 'Finally, for a coil made from N loops, the emf is N times stronger than for a single loop.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus, the emf induced by a changing magnetic field in a coil of N loops is']

['What else do you need to know?', 'The last question to answer before we can change the proportionality into an equation is “In what direction does the current flow?” The Russian scientist Heinrich Lenz (1804–1865) explained that the current flows in the direction that creates a magnetic field that tries to keep the flux constant in the loop.']
['What is an example of a symbiotic relationship?', 'For example, consider again Figure 20.34.']
['What is the function of a bar magnet?', 'The motion of the bar magnet causes the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines that go through the loop to decrease.']
['Why does the current flow upward?', 'Therefore, an emf is generated in the loop that drives a current in the direction that creates more upward-pointing magnetic field lines.']
['What is the right-hand rule?', 'By using the right-hand rule, we see that this current must flow in the direction shown in the figure.']

['Can you tell me more about the equation?', 'To express the fact that the induced emf acts to counter the change in the magnetic flux through a wire loop, a minus sign is introduced into the proportionality  $$\\(\\varepsilon \\propto {{\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}}\\text{.}\\)$$, which gives Faraday’s law of induction.']
['What is the most important thing about Lenz’s law?', 'Lenz’s law is very important.']
['How can this law be applied?', 'To better understand it, consider Figure 20.36, which shows a magnet moving with respect to a wire coil and the direction of the resulting current in the coil.']
['What can you tell me about the figure?', 'In the top row, the north pole of the magnet approaches the coil, so the magnetic field lines from the magnet point toward the coil.']

['What happens to the field lines?', 'Thus, the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}} = B_{\\text{mag}}\\left( \\hat{x} \\right)\\)$$  pointing to the right increases in the coil.']

['What happens when you flip the magnetic field lines?', 'According to Lenz’s law, the emf produced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}} = B_{\\text{coil}}\\left( {- \\hat{x}} \\right)\\)$$  inside the coil pointing to the left.']
['How does this make things work?', 'This will counter the increase in magnetic flux pointing to the right.']

['How can you practice this?', 'To see which way the current must flow, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil,}}\\)$$  and the current will flow in the direction indicated by curling your right fingers.']
['What happens when you point your right hand in the desired direction?', 'This is shown by the image of the right hand in the top row of Figure 20.36.']
['How does the hand in the top row work?', 'Thus, the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(a).']
['What is this section about?', 'In Figure 4(b), the direction in which the magnet moves is reversed.']
['What does this mean?', 'In the coil, the right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  due to the moving magnet decreases.']

['What happens when this happens?', 'Lenz’s law says that, to counter this decrease, the emf will drive a current that creates an additional right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}}\\)$$  in the coil.']

['What is the current?', 'Again, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field, and the current will flow in the direction indicate by curling your right fingers (Figure 4(b)).']
['What is the importance of this statement?', 'Finally, in Figure 4(c), the magnet is reversed so that the south pole is nearest the coil.']
['What happens to the magnet when it is placed in the coil?', 'Now the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  points toward the magnet instead of toward the coil.']
['What happens when the magnet approaches the coil?', 'As the magnet approaches the coil, it causes the left-pointing magnetic field in the coil to increase.']
['What is the direction of the field?', 'Lenz’s law tells us that the emf induced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field pointing to the right.']
['What will happen if the field is pointing to the right?', 'This will counter the increasing magnetic flux pointing to the left due to the magnet.']
['What does the current do?', 'Using the right-hand rule again, as indicated in the figure, shows that the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(c).']
['What is the title of our story of curious significance?', 'Our first story of curious significance begins with a T-shirt.']
['Are you familiar with T-shirts?', 'You are likely aware that wearing a tight black T-shirt outside on a hot day provides a significantly less comfortable experience than wearing a white shirt.']
['Why is that?', 'Black shirts, as well as all other black objects, will absorb and re-emit a significantly greater amount of radiation from the sun.']
['What is a blackbody?', 'This shirt is a good approximation of what is called a blackbody.']
['What is a perfect blackbody?', 'A perfect blackbody is one that absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy that is incident upon it.']
['How does it work?', 'Imagine wearing a tight shirt that did this!']
['What is the good model for this phenomenon?', 'This phenomenon is often modeled with quite a different scenario.']
['How do we describe the different scenario?', 'Imagine carving a small hole in an oven that can be heated to very high temperatures.']

['How does this model work?', 'As the temperature of this container gets hotter and hotter, the radiation out of this dark hole would increase as well, re-emitting all energy provided it by the increased temperature.']
['Does the hole begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased?', 'The hole may even begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased.']
['What color would it glow in as the temperature is increased?', 'Like a burner on your stove, the hole would glow red, then orange, then blue, as the temperature is increased.']
['What happens after it gets hotter?', 'In time, the hole would continue to glow but the light would be invisible to our eyes.']
['What would you say after this point?', 'This container is a good model of a perfect blackbody.']
['What did the analysis of blackbodies lead to?', 'It is the analysis of blackbodies that led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century.']
['What is a figure to examine?', 'Take a moment to carefully examine Figure 21.2.']
['Is there anything else we need to do?', 'The more time you spend interpreting this figure, the closer you will be to understanding quantum physics!']

['What does that do?', 'In other words, it shows how the intensity of radiated light changes when a blackbody is heated to a particular temperature.']

['What is the graph about?', 'The graph shows that when a blackbody acquires a temperature of 3,000 K, it radiates energy across the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What is the energy most intensely emitted at?', 'However, the energy is most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm.']
['What is the name of the portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that is affected by infrared light?', 'This is in the infrared portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['What would a body at this temperature look like to our eyes?', 'While a body at this temperature would appear red-hot to our eyes, it would truly appear ‘infrared-hot’ if we were able to see the entire spectrum.']
['If the mass of an object is greater, what will happen to the energy radiated?', 'As temperature increases, the total amount of energy radiated increases.']

['The greatest radiation intensity changes, temperature changes. The red portion of the graph undergoes what pattern?', 'Regardless of temperature, all red lines on the graph undergo a consistent pattern.']

['One particular wavelength is the most effective radiation in all directions. The intensity of this radiation peaks at what temperature?', 'As the temperature changes, the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity changes.']
['At 4,000 K, the radiation is most intense in what portion of the spectrum?', 'At 4,000 K, the radiation is most intense in the yellow-green portion of the spectrum.']

['At 6,000 K, the blackbody would radiate white hot, due to intense radiation throughout', 'At 6,000 K, the blackbody would radiate white hot, due to intense radiation throughout the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['At 3,950 K, the radiation from the blackbody would be so intense that it would over', 'Because the speed of light is constant, frequency and wavelength are inversely related.']
['What is verified by the leftward movement of the three red lines as temperature is increased?', 'This is verified by the leftward movement of the three red lines as temperature is increased.']
['What is one example of scientific advancement?', 'While in science it is important to categorize observations, theorizing as to why the observations exist is crucial to scientific advancement.']
['What are some important things we should be aware of?', 'It is questions like these that drove significant research at the turn of the twentieth century.']
['Who was Max Planck?', 'And within the context of these questions, Max Planck discovered something of tremendous importance.']

['What was Max Planck trying to figure out?', 'The prevailing theory at the time of Max Planck’s discovery was that intensity and frequency were related by the equation  $$\\(I = \\frac{2kT}{\\lambda^{2}}.\\)$$']

['What did he discover about wavelengths?', 'This equation, derived from classical physics and using wave phenomena, infers that as wavelength increases, the intensity of energy provided will decrease with an inverse-squared relationship.']
['What happens to the wavelengths of light as it moves faster?', 'This relationship is graphed in Figure 21.3 and shows a troubling trend.']
['What did the graph show?', 'For starters, it should be apparent that the graph from this equation does not match the blackbody graphs found experimentally.']

['What does it show that for an object of any temperature, there should be an infinite amount of energy quickly emitted in the shortest wavelengths?', 'Additionally, it shows that for an object of any temperature, there should be an infinite amount of energy quickly emitted in the shortest wavelengths.']
['What is significant about the experiment?', 'When theory and experimental results clash, it is important to re-evaluate both models.']
['What is significant about the ultraviolet catastrophe?', 'The disconnect between theory and reality was termed the ultraviolet catastrophe.']

["What was Planck's Revolution about?", 'Due to concerns over the ultraviolet catastrophe, Max Planck began to question whether another factor impacted the relationship between intensity and wavelength.']
['What did Planck test his hypothesis with?', 'This factor, he posited, should affect the probability that short wavelength light would be emitted.']

['What happens when the factor is reduced?', 'Should this factor reduce the probability of short wavelength light, it would cause the radiance curve to not progress infinitely as in the classical theory, but would instead cause the curve to precipitate back downward as is shown in the 5,000 K, 4,000 K, and 3,000 K temperature lines of the graph in Figure 21.3.']

['What does the factor influence?', 'Planck noted that this factor, whatever it may be, must also be dependent on temperature, as the intensity decreases at lower and lower wavelengths as the temperature increases.']

['What was the breakthrough discovery in physics?', 'The determination of this probability factor was a groundbreaking discovery in physics, yielding insight not just into light but also into energy and matter itself.']
['What other important aspects of the paper?', 'It would be the basis for Planck’s 1918 Nobel Prize in Physics and would result in the transition of physics from classical to modern understanding.']

['What did Max Planck construct in an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor?', 'In an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor, Max Planck constructed a new theory.']

['What was the theory about?', 'This theory, which created the branch of physics called quantum mechanics, speculated that the energy radiated by the blackbody could exist only in specific numerical, or quantum, states.']

['What is the theory?', 'This theory is described by the equation  $$\\(E = nhf,\\)$$  where n is any nonnegative integer (0, 1, 2, 3, …) and h is Planck’s constant, given by  $$\\(h = 6.626\\  \\times \\ 10^{-34}\\text']
['What is the equation for the frequency of a signal?', '{J} \\cdot \\text{s},\\)$$  and f is frequency.']
['What was the basic equation for Planck’s equation?', 'Through this equation, Planck’s probability factor can be more clearly understood.']
['What is the frequency of light?', 'Each frequency of light provides a specific quantized amount of energy.']

['What is the difference between low and high frequencies?', 'Low frequency light, associated with longer wavelengths would provide a smaller amount of energy, while high frequency light, associated with shorter wavelengths, would provide a larger amount of energy.']
['What else did you learn?', 'For specified temperatures with specific total energies, it makes sense that more low frequency light would be radiated than high frequency light.']
['What was the relationship between light and energy?', 'To a degree, the relationship is like pouring coins through a funnel.']
['What would happen if you put a quarter in a funnel?', 'More of the smaller pennies would be able to pass through the funnel than the larger quarters.']

['How do you understand the analogy?', 'In other words, because the value of the coin is somewhat related to the size of the coin, the probability of a quarter passing through the funnel is reduced!']
['Which of the following statements is true?', 'Furthermore, an increase in temperature would signify the presence of higher energy.']
['What happened when the energy level was higher?', 'As a result, the greater amount of total blackbody energy would allow for more of the high frequency, short wavelength, energies to be radiated.']

['What does the peak of the blackbody curve do as the temperature increases?', 'This permits the peak of the blackbody curve to drift leftward as the temperature increases, as it does from the 3,000 K to 4,000 K to 5,000 K values.']
['What is the coin analogy?', 'Furthering our coin analogy, consider a wider funnel.']
['Why is that?', 'This funnel would permit more quarters to pass through and allow for a reduction in concern about the probability factor.']
['What is the main subject of the passage?', 'In summary, it is the interplay between the predicted classical model and the quantum probability that creates the curve depicted in Figure 21.3.']
['How is higher frequency different from frequency?', 'Just as quarters have a higher currency denomination than pennies, higher frequencies come with larger amounts of energy.']

['What makes high frequency light exist?', 'However, just as the probability of a quarter passing through a fixed diameter funnel is reduced, so is the probability of a high frequency light existing in a fixed temperature object.']
['What incredible ideas are important in physics?', 'As is often the case in physics, it is the balancing of multiple incredible ideas that finally allows for better understanding.']
['What do we study next?', 'It may be helpful at this point to further consider the idea of quantum states.']

['What can you tell me about quantum states?', 'Atoms, molecules, and fundamental electron and proton charges are all examples of physical entities that are quantized—that is, they appear only in certain discrete values and do not have every conceivable value.']
['How revolutionary is this concept?', 'On the macroscopic scale, this is not a revolutionary concept.']
['What happens if the string is in the c2 state?', 'A standing wave on a string allows only particular harmonics described by integers.']
['Does going up a hill cause discrete values?', 'Going up and down a hill using discrete stair steps causes your potential energy to take on discrete values as you move from step to step.']
['What else does this study have to do with?', 'Furthermore, we cannot have a fraction of an atom, or part of an electron’s charge, or 14.33 cents.']
['What can you tell me about quantum substructures?', 'Rather, everything is built of integral multiples of these substructures.']
['What kind of questions are we studying?', 'That said, to discover quantum states within a phenomenon that science had always considered continuous would certainly be surprising.']

['What was the first indication that energy was quantized on a small scale as well?', 'When Max Planck was able to use quantization to correctly describe the experimentally known shape of the blackbody spectrum, it was the first indication that energy was quantized on a small scale as well.']

['What was the reaction to his discovery?', 'This discovery earned Planck the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918 and was such a revolutionary departure from classical physics that Planck himself was reluctant to accept his own idea.']

['What was the general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization greatly enhanced by Einstein’s explanation of the photoelectric effect?', 'The general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization was greatly enhanced by Einstein’s explanation of the photoelectric effect (discussed in the next section), which took energy quantization a step further.']
['When light strikes certain materials, what can happen?', 'When light strikes certain materials, it can eject electrons from them.']
['What is the name of the effect this causes?', 'This is called the photoelectric effect, meaning that light (photo) produces electricity.']
['What is one common use of the photoelectric effect?', 'One common use of the photoelectric effect is in light meters, such as those that adjust the automatic iris in various types of cameras.']
['What is another use?', 'Another use is in solar cells, as you probably have in your calculator or have seen on a rooftop or a roadside sign.']
['What are photovoltaic cells used for?', 'These make use of the photoelectric effect to convert light into electricity for running different devices.']
['What is the photoelectric effect?', 'When Max Planck theorized that energy was quantized in a blackbody radiator, it is unlikely that he would have recognized just how revolutionary his idea was.']

["What was Max Planck's idea?", 'Using tools similar to the light meter in Figure 21.5, it would take a scientist of Albert Einstein’s stature to fully discover the implications of Max Planck’s radical concept.']

['What were the revolutionary properties?', 'Through careful observations of the photoelectric effect, Albert Einstein realized that there were several characteristics that could be explained only if EM radiation is itself quantized.']
['What was interesting about the properties?', 'While these characteristics will be explained a bit later in this section, you can already begin to appreciate why Einstein’s idea is very important.']
['What does it mean?', 'It means that the apparently continuous stream of energy in an EM wave is actually not a continuous stream at all.']
['What is the EM wave composed of?', 'In fact, the EM wave itself is actually composed of tiny quantum packets of energy called photons.']
['What does it refer to?', 'where E is the energy of a photon of frequency f and h is Planck’s constant.']

['What is important about photons?', 'A beam from a flashlight, which to this point had been considered a wave, instead could now be viewed as a series of photons, each providing a specific amount of energy see Figure 21.6.']
['Are there any other important aspects of photons?', 'Furthermore, the amount of energy within each individual photon is based upon its individual frequency, as dictated by  $$\\(E = hf.\\)$$']
['What is a result of this?', 'As a result, the total amount of energy provided by the beam could now be viewed as the sum of all frequency-dependent photon energies added together.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Just as with Planck’s blackbody radiation, Einstein’s concept of the photon could take hold in the scientific community only if it could succeed where classical physics failed.']
['What else did the document cover?', 'The photoelectric effect would be a key to demonstrating Einstein’s brilliance.']
['What are the five properties of the photoelectric effect?', 'Consider the following five properties of the photoelectric effect.']

['What is the relationship between these properties and what exactly is meant by photons?', 'All of these properties are consistent with the idea that individual photons of EM radiation are absorbed by individual electrons in a material, with the electron gaining the photon’s energy.']
['What are some of the properties inconsistent with?', 'Some of these properties are inconsistent with the idea that EM radiation is a simple wave.']
['What happens if photons are monochromatic?', 'For simplicity, let us consider what happens with monochromatic EM radiation in which all photons have the same energy hf.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'If we vary the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface, we find the following:']
['What is the threshold frequency?', 'For a given material, there is a threshold frequency f0 for the EM radiation below which no electrons are ejected, regardless of intensity.']
['How did he explain the interaction?', 'Using the photon model, the explanation for this is clear.']
['What was the photon model?', 'Individual photons interact with individual electrons.']
['Why was that?', 'Thus if the energy of an individual photon is too low to break an electron away, no electrons will be ejected.']
['How was the intensity calculated?', 'However, if EM radiation were a simple wave, sufficient energy could be obtained simply by increasing the intensity.']
['What else did you find out?', 'Once EM radiation falls on a material, electrons are ejected without delay.']
['When electrons are ejected without delay, what is the reason?', 'As soon as an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron, the electron is ejected.']
['What else did he discover?', 'If the EM radiation were a simple wave, several minutes would be required for sufficient energy to be deposited at the metal surface in order to eject an electron.']
['What else was he learning?', 'The number of electrons ejected per unit time is proportional to the intensity of the EM radiation and to no other characteristic.']
['How do they calculate that?', 'High-intensity EM radiation consists of large numbers of photons per unit area, with all photons having the same characteristic energy, hf.']
['What else was found in the article?', 'The increased number of photons per unit area results in an increased number of electrons per unit area ejected.']
['What else did they discover?', 'If we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons, we find the following:']
['What else did they find?', 'The maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons is independent of the intensity of the EM radiation.']
['Does this help anything?', 'Instead, as noted in point 3 above, increased intensity results in more electrons of the same energy being ejected.']
['What else did they discover?', 'If EM radiation were a simple wave, a higher intensity could transfer more energy, and higher-energy electrons would be ejected.']
['What else did they find?', 'The kinetic energy KE of an ejected electron equals the photon energy minus the binding energy BE of the electron in the specific material.']
['What can an individual photon give all of its energy to an electron?', 'An individual photon can give all of its energy to an electron.']
['Does it take the energy away?', 'The photon’s energy is partly used to break the electron away from the material.']
['What happens to the remainder of the energy?', 'The remainder goes into the ejected electron’s kinetic energy.']
['What is the equation for the tan of the tan tan?', 'In equation form, this is given by']

['Why is that?', 'where  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  is the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electron,  $$\\(hf\\)$$  is the photon’s energy, and BE is the binding energy of the electron to the particular material.']

['What is the equation for the photoelectric effect?', 'This equation explains the properties of the photoelectric effect quantitatively and demonstrates that BE is the minimum amount of energy necessary to eject an electron.']
['What else did you study about the equation?', 'If the energy supplied is less than BE, the electron cannot be ejected.']
['What is the binding energy of a material?', 'The binding energy can also be written as  $$\\(BE = hf_{0},\\)$$  where  $$\\(f_{0}\\)$$  is the threshold frequency for the particular material.']

['What is the maximum $$(KE_e)$$ versus the frequency of incident EM radiation falling on a particular material?', 'Figure 21.8 shows a graph of maximum  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  versus the frequency of incident EM radiation falling on a particular material.']
['What was the main idea of this paper?', 'While Einstein’s understanding of the photoelectric effect was a transformative discovery in the early 1900s, its presence is ubiquitous today.']

['How is the photoelectric effect used?', 'If you have watched streetlights turn on automatically in response to the setting sun, stopped elevator doors from closing simply by putting your hands between them, or turned on a water faucet by sliding your hands near it, you are familiar with the electric eye, a name given to a group of devices that use the photoelectric effect for detection.']
['What is the first application of the photoelectric effect in devices?', 'All these devices rely on photoconductive cells.']
['What do photoconductive cells do?', 'These cells are activated when light is absorbed by a semi-conductive material, knocking off a free electron.']
['When an electron void is left behind, what happens?', 'When this happens, an electron void is left behind, which attracts a nearby electron.']
['What happens after this?', 'The movement of this electron, and the resultant chain of electron movements, produces a current.']
['How does this current affect the cell?', 'If electron ejection continues, further holes are created, thereby increasing the electrical conductivity of the cell.']
['What does this increase?', 'This current can turn switches on and off and activate various familiar mechanisms.']
['What is the first question you would ask?', 'One such mechanism takes place where you may not expect it.']
['Is there anything else interesting in the first section of your question?', 'Next time you are at the movie theater, pay close attention to the sound coming out of the speakers.']
['Are there any interesting things that you learned from the first section?', 'This sound is actually created using the photoelectric effect!']
['What was the transparent piece of film of varying width?', 'The audiotape in the projector booth is a transparent piece of film of varying width.']
['What happens to the film?', 'This film is fed between a photocell and a bright light produced by an exciter lamp.']
['How is the photocell affected?', 'As the transparent portion of the film varies in width, the amount of light that strikes the photocell varies as well.']
['What is the current in the photoconductive circuit?', 'As a result, the current in the photoconductive circuit changes with the width of the filmstrip.']
['What happens to the current?', 'This changing current is converted to a changing frequency, which creates the soundtrack commonly heard in the theater.']
['What is the most important content in our study material?', 'Although strange to consider, the answer to both questions is yes.']

['What did scientists prior to Einstein have long suspected?', 'Despite the odd nature of photons, scientists prior to Einstein had long suspected that the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation shared properties with our more macroscopic particles.']
['What is the photoelectric effect?', 'This is no clearer than when considering the photoelectric effect, where photons knock electrons out of a substance.']
['What is an established fact?', 'While it is strange to think of a massless particle exhibiting momentum, it is now a well-established fact within the scientific community.']
['What shows macroscopic evidence?', 'Figure 21.10 shows macroscopic evidence of photon momentum.']
['What are the two prominent tails of a comet?', 'Figure 21.10 shows a comet with two prominent tails.']
['What are comet tails composed of?', 'Comet tails are composed of gases and dust evaporated from the body of the comet and ionized gas.']
['What do people not know about the tails?', 'What most people do not know about the tails is that they always point away from the Sun rather than trailing behind the comet.']
['What can I learn about this?', 'This can be seen in the diagram.']

['What is the evidence that the dust particles of the comet are forced away from the Sun when photons strike them?', 'The evidence indicates that the dust particles of the comet are forced away from the Sun when photons strike them.']

['What happens when photons strike?', 'Evidently, photons carry momentum in the direction of their motion away from the Sun, and some of this momentum is transferred to dust particles in collisions.']
['What is the blue tail caused by?', 'The blue tail is caused by the solar wind, a stream of plasma consisting primarily of protons and electrons evaporating from the corona of the Sun.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is conserved in quantum mechanics, just as it is in relativity and classical physics.']

['What is the name of the physicist who discovered the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons in substances?', 'Some of the earliest direct experimental evidence of this came from the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons in substances, a phenomenon discovered by American physicist Arthur H. Compton (1892–1962).']

['what year did this occur?', 'Around 1923, Compton observed that X-rays reflecting from materials had decreased energy and correctly interpreted this as being due to the scattering of the X-ray photons by electrons.']
['What did this mean?', 'This phenomenon could be handled as a collision between two particles—a photon and an electron at rest in the material.']
['What did they find?', 'After careful observation, it was found that both energy and momentum were conserved in the collision.']
['What other things did they find?', 'See Figure 21.11.']
['What did Arthur Compton discover?', 'For the discovery of this conserved scattering, now known as the Compton effect, Arthur Compton was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1929.']
['Was the helium atom determined by Louis de Broglie?', 'was determined by Louis de Broglie.']
['What is the de Broglie relation?', 'In this equation, called the de Broglie relation, h represents Planck’s constant and λ is the photon wavelength.']
['What is photon momentum?', 'We can see that photon momentum is small, since  $$\\(\\mathbf{p} = h/\\lambda.\\)$$  and h is very small.']
['Why do we not ordinarily observe photon momentum?', 'It is for this reason that we do not ordinarily observe photon momentum.']
['What is another reason that mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them?', 'Our mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them, except perhaps in cartoons.']

['What can you tell me about photon momentum?', 'Compton saw the effects of photon momentum because he was observing X-rays, which have a small wavelength and a relatively large momentum, interacting with the lightest of particles, the electron.']
['What is the difference between electromagnetic radiation and sound?', 'We have long known that EM radiation is like a wave, capable of interference and diffraction.']
['What can light be modeled as?', 'We now see that light can also be modeled as particles—massless photons of discrete energy and momentum.']
['What is the particle-wave duality?', 'We call this twofold nature the particle-wave duality, meaning that EM radiation has properties of both particles and waves.']
['What is significant about this?', 'This may seem contradictory, since we ordinarily deal with large objects that never act like both waves and particles.']
['What are some examples of a grain of sand?', 'An ocean wave, for example, looks nothing like a grain of sand.']
['Is this contradictory?', 'However, this so-called duality is simply a term for properties of the photon analogous to phenomena we can observe directly, on a macroscopic scale.']
['What was significant about the passage?', 'See Figure 21.14.']

['Why did we use the term aether?', 'If this term seems strange, it is because we do not ordinarily observe details on the quantum level directly, and our observations yield either particle-like or wave-like properties, but never both simultaneously.']

['What do you mean by this?', 'Since we have a particle-wave duality for photons, and since we have seen connections between photons and matter in that both have momentum, it is reasonable to ask whether there is a particle-wave duality for matter as well.']
['Is there a way to find the answer to this question?', 'The answer, strangely, is yes.']
['What does this mean?', 'The consequences of this are tremendous, as particle-wave duality has been a constant source of scientific wonder during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.']

['What is the most important thing to know about atoms?', 'While often taken for granted, our knowledge of the existence and structure of atoms is the result of centuries of contemplation and experimentation.']

['When did scientists first speculate about the atom?', 'The earliest known speculation on the atom dates back to the fifth century B.C., when Greek philosophers Leucippus and Democritus contemplated whether a substance could be divided without limit into ever smaller pieces.']

["What scientists determined the atom's shape?", 'Since then, scientists such as John Dalton (1766–1844), Amadeo Avogadro (1776–1856), and Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) helped to discover the properties of that fundamental structure of matter.']
['How long did he work for?', 'While much could be written about any number of important scientific philosophers, this section will focus on the role played by Ernest Rutherford (1871–1937).']

['What was his role in the atom?', 'Though his understanding of our most elemental matter is rooted in the success of countless prior investigations, his surprising discovery about the interior of the atom is most fundamental in explaining so many well-known phenomena.']
['What was the accepted model of the atom in the early 1900’s?', 'In the early 1900’s, the plum pudding model was the accepted model of the atom.']

['What model suggested that the atom was a spherical ball of positive charge, with negatively charged electrons scattered evenly throughout?', 'Proposed in 1904 by J. J. Thomson, the model suggested that the atom was a spherical ball of positive charge, with negatively charged electrons scattered evenly throughout.']
['What does the word "pudding" mean?', 'In that model, the positive charges made up the pudding, while the electrons acted as isolated plums.']

['how was this model useful?', 'During its short life, the model could be used to explain why most particles were neutral, although with an unbalanced number of plums, electrically charged atoms could exist.']
['When was this experiment?', 'When Ernest Rutherford began his gold foil experiment in 1909, it is unlikely that anyone would have expected that the plum pudding model would be challenged.']

['How did Rutherford discover the atom?', 'However, using a radioactive source, a thin sheet of gold foil, and a phosphorescent screen, Rutherford would uncover something so great that he would later call it “the most incredible event that has ever happened to me in my life”[James, L. K. (1993).']
['What is the history of this experiment?', 'Nobel Laureates in Chemistry, 1901–1992.']
['What is the location of this information?', 'Washington, DC: American Chemical Society.]']
['What did Rutherford design?', 'The experiment that Rutherford designed is shown in Figure 22.2.']

['Where was this experiment made?', 'As you can see in, a radioactive source was placed in a lead container with a hole in one side to produce a beam of positively charged helium particles, called alpha particles.']
['What were the elements being tested?', 'Then, a thin gold foil sheet was placed in the beam.']
['What happened when the high-energy alpha particles passed through the gold foil?', 'When the high-energy alpha particles passed through the gold foil, they were scattered.']
['What was the result of the scattering?', 'The scattering was observed from the bright spots they produced when they struck the phosphor screen.']
['What is the plum pudding model?', 'The expectation of the plum pudding model was that the high-energy alpha particles would be scattered only slightly by the presence of the gold sheet.']

['What is the supersonic bowling ball?', 'Because the energy of the alpha particles was much higher than those typically associated with atoms, the alpha particles should have passed through the thin foil much like a supersonic bowling ball would crash through a few dozen rows of bowling pins.']

['What are the interior electric charges?', 'Any deflection was expected to be minor, and due primarily to the electrostatic Coulomb force between the alpha particles and the foil’s interior electric charges.']
['How did it do in the end?', 'However, the true result was nothing of the sort.']

['What was wrong with the experiment?', 'While the majority of alpha particles passed through the foil unobstructed, Rutherford and his collaborators Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden found that alpha particles occasionally were scattered to large angles, and some even came back in the direction from which they came!']
['What did they learn from their experiment?', 'The result, called Rutherford scattering, implied that the gold nuclei were actually very small when compared with the size of the gold atom.']

['What was the density of the nucleus?', 'As shown in Figure 22.3, the dense nucleus is surrounded by mostly empty space of the atom, an idea verified by the fact that only 1 in 8,000 particles was scattered backward.']
["What did Rutherford's experiment involve?", 'Although the results of the experiment were published by his colleagues in 1909, it took Rutherford two years to convince himself of their meaning.']
['What was the result of the experiment?', 'Rutherford later wrote: “It was almost as incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.']

['What was the result of the experiment?', 'On consideration, I realized that this scattering backwards ... [meant] ... the greatest part of the mass of the atom was concentrated in a tiny nucleus.”']

['When did Rutherford publish his analysis?', 'In 1911, Rutherford published his analysis together with a proposed model of the atom, which was in part based on Geiger’s work from the previous year.']
['How did the model do?', 'As a result of the paper, the size of the nucleus was determined to be about  $$\\(10^{-15}\\)$$  m, or 100,000 times smaller than the atom.']
['What was this size based on?', 'That implies a huge density, on the order of  $$\\(10^{15}\\)$$  g/cm3, much greater than any macroscopic matter.']
['What is the planetary model?', 'Based on the size and mass of the nucleus revealed by his experiment, as well as the mass of electrons, Rutherford proposed the planetary model of the atom.']

['What does the model say about the electron orbits?', 'The sizes of the electron orbits are large compared with the size of the nucleus, and most of the atom is a vacuum.']

['What is important about the content in the document?', 'In 1896, the French physicist Antoine Henri Becquerel (1852–1908) noticed something strange.']
['What did he observe?', 'When a uranium-rich mineral called pitchblende was placed on a completely opaque envelope containing a photographic plate, it darkened spots on the photographic plate..']
['What did Becquerel do to find the pattern?', 'Becquerel reasoned that the pitchblende must emit invisible rays capable of penetrating the opaque material.']

['Why was he skeptical?', 'Stranger still was that no light was shining on the pitchblende, which means that the pitchblende was emitting the invisible rays continuously without having any energy input!']

['What was the apparent violation of the law of conservation of energy?', 'There is an apparent violation of the law of conservation of energy, one that scientists can now explain using Einstein’s famous equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What did Becquerel’s rays originate from?', 'It was soon evident that Becquerel’s rays originate in the nuclei of the atoms and have other unique characteristics.']
['What is that about?', 'To this point, most reactions you have studied have been chemical reactions, which are reactions involving the electrons surrounding the atoms.']

['What is the role of electrons in the nucleus of an atom?', 'However, two types of experimental evidence implied that Becquerel’s rays did not originate with electrons, but instead within the nucleus of an atom.']
['What happens after an atom is ionized?', 'First, the radiation is found to be only associated with certain elements, such as uranium.']

['What is the ionization state of the uranium atom?', 'In addition, the presence of radiation does not vary with temperature, pressure, or ionization state of the uranium atom.']

['What is the other factor involved in the emission of radiation?', 'Since all of those factors affect electrons in an atom, the radiation cannot come from electron transitions, as atomic spectra do.']
['What is the second piece of evidence?', 'The huge energy emitted during each event is the second piece of evidence that the radiation cannot be atomic.']

['What is ev per event?', 'Nuclear radiation has energies on the order of 106 eV per event, which is much greater than typical atomic energies that are a few eV, such as those observed in spectra and chemical reactions, and more than ten times as high as the most energetic X-rays.']
['What does the structure have to do with it?', 'To answer those questions, it is necessary to look into the structure of the nucleus.']

['How do the nucleons move?', 'Those nucleons have large kinetic energies and, thus, move rapidly in very close contact.']
['Can the nucleons be separated?', 'Nucleons can be separated by a large force, such as in a collision with another nucleus, but strongly resist being pushed closer together.']

['What does it mean if you pack nucleons so close that there is no empty space between them?', 'That is what you expect if you pack nucleons so close that there is no empty space between them.']
['Why is that?', 'After all, the nucleus is very small and its protons, being positive, should exert tremendous repulsive forces on one another.']
['What happens as a result?', 'Considering that, it seems that the nucleus would be forced apart, not together!']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The answer is that a previously unknown force holds the nucleus together and makes it into a tightly packed ball of nucleons.']
['What is this force called?', 'This force is known as the strong nuclear force.']
['What is the force used for?', 'The strong force has such a short range that it quickly fall to zero over a distance of only 10–15 meters.']
['Is it strong all the time?', 'However, like glue, it is very strong when the nucleons get close to one another.']

['What is the balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces what allows the nucleus to maintain its spherical shape?', 'The balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces is what allows the nucleus to maintain its spherical shape.']

['What force exists between protons?', 'Recall that the attractive strong nuclear force exists between any two nucleons and acts over a very short range while the weaker repulsive electromagnetic force only acts between protons, although over a larger range.']

['What is the next step that the nucleus needed to undergo to regain stability?', 'To regain stability, the nucleus needed to undergo a nuclear reaction called alpha (α) decay.']

['What is the most common type of decay?', 'It is the most common type of decay and causes the nucleus to regain equilibrium between its two competing internal forces.']

['What happens after the protons are ejected?', 'During alpha decay, the nucleus ejects two protons and two neutrons, allowing the strong nuclear force to regain balance with the repulsive electromagnetic force.']

['What is the process of changing elemental composition called?', 'The process of changing elemental composition is called transmutation.']

['What happens after the helium nucleus forms?', 'Shortly after decay, the ejected helium ion typically acquires two electrons to become a stable helium atom.']
['What is important to know about transmutation?', 'Finally, it is important to see that, despite the elemental change, physical conservation still takes place.']
['Does physical conservation take place for any of the atoms involved?', 'The mass number of the new element and the alpha particle together equal the mass number of the original element.']
['What else should we know about physical conservation?', 'Also, the net charge of all particles involved remains the same before and after the transmutation.']
['What is it about?', 'Like alpha decay, beta ( βββ ) decay also takes place when there is an imbalance between neutrons and protons within the nucleus.']
['What happens during beta decay?', 'For beta decay, however, a neutron is transformed into a proton and electron or vice versa.']

['What does the transformation of neutron to a proton and electron do?', 'The transformation allows for the total mass number of the atom to remain the same, although the atomic number will increase by one (or decrease by one).']

['What is the process of radioactive dating?', 'Radioactive dating or radiometric dating is a clever use of naturally occurring radioactivity.']

['What is carbon-14?', 'Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon that is produced when solar neutrinos strike  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  particles within the atmosphere.']
['What does this carbon do?', 'Radioactive carbon has the same chemistry as stable carbon, and so it mixes into the biosphere, where it is consumed and becomes part of every living organism.']

['How does carbon-14 radiometric dating work?', 'Carbon-14 has an abundance of 1.3 parts per trillion of normal carbon, so if you know the number of carbon nuclei in an object (perhaps determined by mass and Avogadro’s number), you can multiply that number by  $$\\(1.3\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 12}\\)$$  to find the number of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei within the object.']
['How does it decay?', 'Over time, carbon-14 will naturally decay back to  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  with a half-life of 5,730 years (note that this is an example of beta decay).']
['What happens when an organism dies?', 'When an organism dies, carbon exchange with the environment ceases, and  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{']
['What is the difference between a c)$$ and a c)$$?', 'C}\\)$$  is not replenished.']

['How does this age an object?', 'By comparing the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  in an artifact, such as mummy wrappings, with the normal abundance in living tissue, it is possible to determine the artifact’s age (or time since death).']

['Can carbon-14 dating be used for biological tissues as old as 50 or 60 thousand years?', 'Carbon-14 dating can be used for biological tissues as old as 50 or 60 thousand years, but is most accurate for younger samples, since the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei in them is greater.']

['What is the shroud of turin?', 'One of the most famous cases of carbon-14 dating involves the Shroud of Turin, a long piece of fabric purported to be the burial shroud of Jesus (see Figure 22.25).']
['When was the shroud displayed?', 'This relic was first displayed in Turin in 1354 and was denounced as a fraud at that time by a French bishop.']
['Why was it denounced?', 'Its remarkable negative imprint of an apparently crucified body resembles the then-accepted image of Jesus.']
['Did anyone else denounce the shroud?', 'As a result, the relic has been remained controversial throughout the centuries.']

['What was the carbon-14 dating of the shroud?', 'Carbon-14 dating was not performed on the shroud until 1988, when the process had been refined to the point where only a small amount of material needed to be destroyed.']
['Was this done carefully?', 'Samples were tested at three independent laboratories, each being given four pieces of cloth, with only one unidentified piece from the shroud, to avoid prejudice.']

['What was the shroud?', 'All three laboratories found samples of the shroud contain 92 percent of the  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  found in living tissues, allowing the shroud to be dated (see How Old is the Shroud of Turin?).']

['What is the simplest terms of nuclear fission?', 'In simplest terms, nuclear fission is the splitting of an atomic bond.']

['What is necessary to produce useful energy through nuclear fission?', 'As a result, a physical catalyst is necessary to produce useful energy through nuclear fission.']
