['What did you study during this session?', 'As shown in Figure 22.26, a neutron strike can cause the nucleus to elongate, much like a drop of liquid water.']

['What can we learn about fission?', 'We can enhance the number of fissions produced by neutrons by having a large amount of fissionable material as well as a neutron reflector.']

['What is the minimum amount necessary for self-sustained fission of a given nuclide called?', 'The minimum amount necessary for self-sustained fission of a given nuclide is called its critical mass.']

['What is the self-sustained fission of nuclei called?', 'The self-sustained fission of nuclei is commonly referred to as a chain reaction, as shown in Figure 22.27.']
['What can happen when a chain reaction goes wrong?', 'A chain reaction can have runaway results.']
['Why does it increase exponentially?', 'If each atomic split results in two nuclei producing a new fission, the number of nuclear reactions will increase exponentially.']
['How many atoms does one fission produce?', 'One fission will produce two atoms, the next round of fission will create four atoms, the third round eight atoms, and so on.']
['Are there other interesting facts about fission?', 'Of course, each time fission occurs, more energy will be emitted, further increasing the power of the atomic reaction.']
['What about atomic energy?', 'And that is just if two neutrons create fission reactions each round.']
['Are there any more facts about atomic energy?', 'Perhaps you can now see why so many people consider atomic energy to be an exciting energy source!']
['What is an important fact in the passage?', 'To make a self-sustained nuclear fission reactor with 235U, it is necessary to slow down the neutrons.']
['What can be used to slow down neutrons?', 'Water is very effective at this, since neutrons collide with protons in water molecules and lose energy.']

['What is important to know about neutron flux?', 'Neutron flux must be carefully regulated to avoid an out-of-control exponential increase in the rate of fission.']
['What are control rods used for?', 'Control rods help prevent overheating, perhaps even a meltdown or explosive disassembly.']

['What is the secondary danger of nuclear power?', 'Considerable heat, however, can still be generated by the reactor’s radioactive fission products.']
