['What was the possible military value of uranium?', 'It seemed that the possible military value of uranium had been recognized in Nazi Germany, and that a serious effort to build a nuclear bomb had begun.']
['What was the beginning of this?', 'Alarmed scientists, many of whom fled Nazi Germany, decided to take action.']
['Who was the most famous person?', 'None was more famous or revered than Einstein.']

["What was President Roosevelt's role in the war?", 'It was felt that his help was needed to get the American government to make a serious effort at constructing nuclear weapons as a matter of survival.']
['Did he work with anyone?', 'Leo Szilard, a Hungarian physicist who had emigrated to America, took a draft of a letter to Einstein, who, although a pacifist, signed the final version.']
['What was the letter about?', 'The letter was for President Franklin Roosevelt, warning of the German potential to build extremely powerful bombs of a new type.']
['What was the date of the letter?', 'It was sent in August of 1939, just before the German invasion of Poland that marked the start of World War II.']

['What was the name of the place where the Japanese attacked the US?', 'It was not until December 6, 1941, the day before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, that the United States made a massive commitment to building a nuclear bomb.']
['What did the top secret Manhattan Project aim to do?', 'The top secret Manhattan Project was a crash program aimed at beating the Germans.']

['what was important about the manhattan project?', 'It was carried out in remote locations, such as Los Alamos, New Mexico, whenever possible, and eventually came to cost billions of dollars and employ the efforts of more than 100,000 people.']
['Who was involved in this project?', 'J. Robert Oppenheimer (1904–1967), a talented physicist, was chosen to head the project.']

['What was the first major step in the development of nuclear energy?', 'The first major step was made by Enrico Fermi and his group in December 1942, when they completed the first self-sustaining nuclear reactor.']
['Was the first atomic pile a success?', 'This first atomic pile, built in a squash court at the University of Chicago, proved that a fission chain reaction was possible.']
['What was the superior fission material?', 'Plutonium was recognized as easier to fission with neutrons and, hence, a superior fission material very early in the Manhattan Project.']
['What was the reason for the uranium bomb being developed simultaneously?', 'Plutonium availability was uncertain, and so a uranium bomb was developed simultaneously.']
['What was the gun-type bomb?', 'Figure 22.32 shows a gun-type bomb, which takes two subcritical uranium masses and shoots them together.']
['What happens when they shoot them together?', 'To get an appreciable yield, the critical mass must be held together by the explosive charges inside the cannon barrel for a few microseconds.']
['What was unique about the assembly critical mass?', 'Since the buildup of the uranium chain reaction is relatively slow, the device to bring the critical mass together can be relatively simple.']
['What did the neutron source do?', 'Owing to the fact that the rate of spontaneous fission is low, a neutron source is at the center the assembled critical mass.']
['What was special about plutonium?', 'Plutonium’s special properties necessitated a more sophisticated critical mass assembly, shown schematically in Figure 22.33.']

['What was the implosion technique?', 'A spherical mass of plutonium is surrounded by shaped charges (high explosives that focus their blast) that implode the plutonium, crushing it into a smaller volume to form a critical mass.']
['What was special about this technique?', 'The implosion technique is faster and more effective, because it compresses three-dimensionally rather than one-dimensionally as in the gun-type bomb.']
['What was the neutron source used for?', 'Again, a neutron source is included to initiate the chain reaction.']
['How many times did the test take place?', 'Owing to its complexity, the plutonium bomb needed to be tested before there could be any attempt to use it.']

['On what date did the test named Trinity occur?', 'On July 16, 1945, the test named Trinity was conducted in the isolated Alamogordo Desert in New Mexico, about 200 miles south of Los Alamos (see Figure 22.34).']
['What was the result of the test?', 'A new age had begun.']
['What was the power of the trinity device?', 'The yield of the Trinity device was about 10 kilotons (kT), the equivalent of 5,000 of the largest conventional bombs.']

['What was the result of Japan refusing to surrender?', 'Although Germany surrendered on May 7, 1945, Japan had been steadfastly refusing to surrender for many months, resulting large numbers of civilian and military casualties.']
['How many casualties did the Allies estimate?', 'Invasion plans by the Allies estimated a million casualties of their own and untold losses of Japanese lives.']
['What was the reason for using the bomb?', 'The bomb was viewed as a way to end the war.']
['What was the first bomb used?', 'The first bomb used was a gun-type uranium bomb dropped on Hiroshima on August 6 by the United States.']
['How much damage was caused by the bomb?', 'Its yield of about 15 kT destroyed the city and killed an estimated 80,000 people, with 100,000 more being seriously injured.']
['What was the second bomb used on?', 'The second bomb was an implosion-type plutonium bomb dropped on Nagasaki only three days later.']
['How many people were killed?', 'Its 20-kT yield killed at least 50,000 people, something less than Hiroshima because of the hilly terrain and the fact that it was a few kilometers off target.']
['Did they use any more bombs?', 'The Japanese were told that one bomb a week would be dropped until they surrendered unconditionally, which they did on August 14.']
['What did the United States do after the war?', 'In actuality, the United States had only enough plutonium for one more bomb, as yet unassembled.']

['What is an important part of our study material?', 'Knowing that fusion produces several times more energy per kilogram of fuel than fission, some scientists pursued the idea of constructing a fusion bomb.']

['When was the first fusion bomb detonated?', 'The first such bomb was detonated by the United States several years after the first fission bombs, on October 31, 1952, at Eniwetok Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.']
['What was the result of the bomb?', 'It had a yield of 10 megatons (MT), about 670 times that of the fission bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.']

['Was there any other fusion bombs detonated?', 'The Soviet Union followed with a fusion device of its own in August 1953, and a weapons race, beyond the aim of this text to discuss, continued until the end of the Cold War.']
['What is the figure 22.35?', 'Figure 22.35 shows a simple diagram of how a thermonuclear bomb is constructed.']
['What is the solid form of lithium deuteride?', 'A fission bomb is exploded next to fusion fuel in the solid form of lithium deuteride.']

['What is the reaction of neutrons?', 'Before the shock wave blows it apart,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays heat and compress the fuel, and neutrons create tritium through the reaction  $$\\(n +^{6}\\text{L}\\text{i}\\rightarrow^{3}\\text{H} +^{4}\\text{H}\\text{e}\\)$$ .']
['What is the shell of U?', 'Additional fusion and fission fuels are enclosed in a dense shell of  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$ .']

['What is the reaction of fission?', 'At the same time that the uranium shell reflects the neutrons back into the fuel to enhance its fusion, the fast-moving neutrons cause the plentiful and inexpensive  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$  to fission, part of what allows thermonuclear bombs to be so large.']
['Are these weapons considered the most destructive?', 'Of course, not all applications of nuclear physics are as destructive as the weapons described above.']
['What is the most practical way to produce electricity?', 'Hundreds of nuclear fission power plants around the world attest to the fact that controlled fission is both practical and economical.']
['Why is nuclear power attractive?', 'Given growing concerns over global warming, nuclear power is often seen as a viable alternative to energy derived from fossil fuels.']
['What kind of applications of nuclear physics have become an integral part of modern life?', 'Applications of nuclear physics have become an integral part of modern life.']

['What are some examples of its application?', 'From the bone scan that detects one cancer to the radioiodine treatment that cures another, nuclear radiation has diagnostic and therapeutic effects on medicine.']
['What is nuclear radiation used for?', 'A host of medical imaging techniques employ nuclear radiation.']
['How does nuclear radiation help doctors?', 'First,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  radiation can easily penetrate tissue; hence, it is a useful probe to monitor conditions inside the body.']

['What else can it do?', 'Second, nuclear radiation depends on the nuclide and not on the chemical compound it is in, so that a radioactive nuclide can be put into a compound designed for specific purposes.']
['When a compound is tagged, what is the chemical name of the compound?', 'When that is done, the compound is said to be tagged.']
['What kind of tagged compounds are used for medical purposes?', 'A tagged compound used for medical purposes is called a radiopharmaceutical.']
['What do the radiation detectors determine?', 'Radiation detectors external to the body can determine the location and concentration of a radiopharmaceutical to yield medically useful information.']
['How can this help?', 'For example, certain drugs are concentrated in inflamed regions of the body, and their locations can aid diagnosis and treatment as seen in Figure 22.37.']

['Can radiopharmaceuticals detect diseases?', 'Another application utilizes a radiopharmaceutical that the body sends to bone cells, particularly those that are most active, to detect cancerous tumors or healing points.']
['What can happen with this?', 'Images can then be produced of such bone scans.']
['What else can radiopharmaceuticals do?', 'Clever use of radioisotopes determines the functioning of body organs, such as blood flow, heart muscle activity, and iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.']

['What other forms of radiopharmaceuticals can be used?', 'For instance, a radioactive form of iodine can be used to monitor the thyroid, a radioactive thallium salt can be used to follow the blood stream, and radioactive gallium can be used for cancer imaging.']
['What else should we learn about medical imaging?', 'Once a radioactive compound has been ingested, a device like that shown in Figure 22.38 is used to monitor nuclear activity.']
['What is the device called that uses a piece of lead with holes bored through it?', 'The device, called an Anger camera or gamma camera uses a piece of lead with holes bored through it.']
['What else is needed to narrow the beam?', 'The gamma rays are redirected through the collimator to narrow their beam, and are then interpreted using a device called a scintillator.']
['What else is needed to produce an image?', 'The computer analysis of detector signals produces an image.']

['What else is important about this medical imaging method?', 'One of the disadvantages of this detection method is that there is no depth information (i.e., it provides a two-dimensional view of the tumor as opposed to a three-dimensional view), because radiation from any location under that detector produces a signal.']

['What is single photon-emission computer tomography?', 'Single-photon-emission computer tomography (SPECT) used in conjunction with a CT scanner improves on the process carried out by the gamma camera.']

['What is one interesting thing about this section of the article?', 'Figure 22.39 shows a patient in a circular array of SPECT detectors that may be stationary or rotated, with detector output used by a computer to construct a detailed image.']
['Does it improve contrast between scans?', 'The spatial resolution of this technique is poor, but the three-dimensional image created results in a marked improvement in contrast.']
['What is an example of one type of imaging technique that you will be studying?', 'Positron emission tomography (or PET) scans utilize images produced by  $$\\(\\beta^{+}\\)$$  emitters.']
['What is an example of how these images are produced?', 'When the emitted positron β+ encounters an electron, mutual annihilation occurs, producing two γ rays.']

['What is an example of how that rays are collected?', 'Those  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays have identical 0.511 MeV energies (the energy comes from the destruction of an electron or positron mass) and they move directly away from each other, allowing detectors to determine their point of origin accurately (as shown in Figure 22.40).']

['What is an example of how this scan is done?', 'It requires detectors on opposite sides to simultaneously (i.e., at the same time) detect photons of 0.511 MeV energy and utilizes computer imaging techniques similar to those in SPECT and CT scans.']
['What is an example of the results of PET?', 'PET is used extensively for diagnosing brain disorders.']
['What is an example of what PET can look for?', 'It can note decreased metabolism in certain regions that accompany Alzheimer’s disease.']
['What can PET look for?', 'PET can also locate regions in the brain that become active when a person carries out specific activities, such as speaking, closing his or her eyes, and so on.']
['What is the most important part of this document?', 'We hear many seemingly contradictory things about the biological effects of ionizing radiation.']
['What does contradictory mean?', 'It can cause cancer, burns, and hair loss, and yet it is used to treat and even cure cancer.']
['What kind of simplicity do we have in nature?', 'Once again, there is an underlying simplicity in nature, even in complicated biological organisms.']

['What does ionizing radiation do to molecules within cells?', 'All the effects of ionizing radiation on biological tissue can be understood by knowing that ionizing radiation affects molecules within cells, particularly DNA molecules.']
['How do cells work?', 'Let us take a brief look at molecules within cells and how cells operate.']
['What are the molecules?', 'Cells have long, double-helical DNA molecules containing chemical patterns called genetic codes that govern the function and processes undertaken by the cells.']
['What is the main function of DNA?', 'Damage to DNA consists of breaks in chemical bonds or other changes in the structural features of the DNA chain, leading to changes in the genetic code.']
['How often do we have damage?', 'In human cells, we can have as many as a million individual instances of damage to DNA per cell per day.']
['Does DNA have the ability to repair itself?', 'The repair ability of DNA is vital for maintaining the integrity of the genetic code and for the normal functioning of the entire organism.']
['How does it affect the cells?', 'A cell with a damaged ability to repair DNA, which could have been induced by ionizing radiation, can do one of the following:']
["What is the cell's state of dormancy called?", 'The cell can go into an irreversible state of dormancy, known as senescence.']
['What can a cell do to commit suicide?', 'The cell can commit suicide, known as programmed cell death.']
['What can happen when cells divide unregulated?', 'The cell can go into unregulated cell division, leading to tumors and cancers.']

['What is the most important information of this study material?', 'Since ionizing radiation damages the DNA, ionizing radiation has its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce, including most types of cancer.']
['Why does ionizing radiation has its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce?', 'Thus, cancer cells are more sensitive to radiation than normal cells and can be killed by it easily.']
['What is cancer characterized by?', 'Cancer is characterized by a malfunction of cell reproduction, and can also be caused by ionizing radiation.']
['What is the cause of cancer?', 'There is no contradiction to say that ionizing radiation can be both a cure and a cause.']
['Why is radiation effective against cancer?', 'Radiotherapy is effective against cancer because cancer cells reproduce rapidly and, consequently, are more sensitive to radiation.']
['What is the central problem in radiotherapy?', 'The central problem in radiotherapy is to make the dose for cancer cells as high as possible while limiting the dose for normal cells.']

['What are some methods of treating cancer?', 'The ratio of abnormal cells killed to normal cells killed is called the therapeutic ratio, and all radiotherapy techniques are designed to enhance that ratio.']
['Can you give me some examples of concentrated radiation?', 'Radiation can be concentrated in cancerous tissue by a number of techniques.']
['What is the geometric technique?', 'One of the most prevalent techniques for well-defined tumors is a geometric technique shown in Figure 22.41.']
['What is the narrow beam technique?', 'A narrow beam of radiation is passed through the patient from a variety of directions with a common crossing point in the tumor.']
['What is the advantage of this technique?', 'The technique concentrates the dose in the tumor while spreading it out over a large volume of normal tissue.']
['What is another use of radiation therapy?', 'Another use of radiation therapy is through radiopharmaceuticals.']
['How are radiopharmaceuticals used?', 'Cleverly, radiopharmaceuticals are used in cancer therapy by tagging antibodies with radioisotopes.']
['How are the antibodies extracted from the patient?', 'Those antibodies are extracted from the patient, cultured, loaded with a radioisotope, and then returned to the patient.']
['What happens to the antibodies?', 'The antibodies are then concentrated almost entirely in the tissue they developed to fight, thus localizing the radiation in abnormal tissue.']
['What can you tell me about the cancer therapy method?', 'This method is used with radioactive iodine to fight thyroid cancer.']

['What can you tell me about the therapeutic ratio?', 'While the therapeutic ratio can be quite high for such short-range radiation, there can be a significant dose for organs that eliminate radiopharmaceuticals from the body, such as the liver, kidneys, and bladder.']
['What is the technique limited by?', 'As with most radiotherapy, the technique is limited by the tolerable amount of damage to the normal tissue.']

['What did you find most interesting about the article?', 'To quantitatively discuss the biological effects of ionizing radiation, we need a radiation dose unit that is directly related to those effects.']
['What is this unit called?', 'To do define such a unit, it is important to consider both the biological organism and the radiation itself.']
['What is the energy equivalent of ionization?', 'Knowing that the amount of ionization is proportional to the amount of deposited energy, we define a radiation dose unit called the rad.']
['What is 1/100 of a joule of ionizing energy deposited per kilogram of tissue?', 'It 1/100 of a joule of ionizing energy deposited per kilogram of tissue, which is']
['What would happen if the ionizing radiation was absorbed by the tissue?', 'and the unaffected tissue would have a zero rad dose.']
['What is the difference between radiation dose and energy absorbed?', 'When calculating radiation doses, you divide the energy absorbed by the mass of affected tissue.']
['What is an example of this?', 'You must specify the affected region, such as the whole body or forearm in addition to giving the numerical dose in rads.']
['What is important about the energy per kilogram in 1 rad?', 'Although the energy per kilogram in 1 rad is small, it can still have significant effects.']
['What are some effects of ionizing energy?', 'Since only a few eV cause ionization, just 0.01 J of ionizing energy can create a huge number of ion pairs and have an effect at the cellular level.']
['What is the document about?', 'The effects of ionizing radiation may be directly proportional to the dose in rads, but they also depend on the type of radiation and the type of tissue.']

['What type of radiation is being discussed?', 'That is, for a given dose in rads, the effects depend on whether the radiation is  $$\\(\\alpha\\)$$,  $$\\(\\beta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$, X-ray, or some other type of ionizing radiation.']

['What is the relative biological effectiveness?', 'The relative biological effectiveness (RBE) relates to the amount of biological damage that can occur from a given type of radiation and is given in Table 22.4 for several types of ionizing radiation.']
['What is it about?', 'A final dose unit more closely related to the effect of radiation on biological tissue is called the roentgen equivalent man, or rem.']
['What is rem?', 'A combination of all factors mentioned previously, the roentgen equivalent man is defined to be the dose in rads multiplied by the relative biological effectiveness.']

['What are the two categories of large-scale effects of radiation on humans?', 'The large-scale effects of radiation on humans can be divided into two categories: immediate effects and long-term effects.']
['What is the table about?', 'Table 22.5 gives the immediate effects of whole-body exposures received in less than one day.']
['Why is there a need for greater doses?', 'If the radiation exposure is spread out over more time, greater doses are needed to cause the effects listed.']

['What is the difference between a low dose and a high dose?', 'Any dose less than 10 rem is called a low dose, a dose 10 to 100 rem is called a moderate dose, and anything greater than 100 rem is called a high dose.']
['What are the four basic forces of the universe?', 'Despite the apparent complexity within the universe, there remain just four basic forces.']
['What do these forces do?', 'These forces are responsible for all interactions known to science: from the very small to the very large to those that we experience in our day-to-day lives.']

['What do these forces describe?', 'These forces describe the movement of galaxies, the chemical reactions in our laboratories, the structure within atomic nuclei, and the cause of radioactive decay.']
['What do these forces describe?', 'They describe the true cause behind familiar terms like friction and the normal force.']
['What are the four basic forces known as fundamental?', 'These four basic forces are known as fundamental because they alone are responsible for all observations of forces in nature.']
['What are the four basic forces?', 'The four fundamental forces are gravity, electromagnetism, weak nuclear force, and strong nuclear force.']

['What is the gravitational force most familiar to us because it describes so many of our common observations?', 'The gravitational force is most familiar to us because it describes so many of our common observations.']
['What is the force that causes a dropped ball to fall to the ground?', 'It explains why a dropped ball falls to the ground and why our planet orbits the Sun.']
['What is the gravitational force?', 'It gives us the property of weight and determines much about the motion of objects in our daily lives.']

['Is this force weak compared to other forces?', 'Because gravitational force acts between all objects of mass and has the ability to act over large distances, the gravitational force can be used to explain much of what we observe and can even describe the motion of objects on astronomical scales!']

['What other information about the gravitational force did you see?', 'That said, gravity is incredibly weak compared to the other fundamental forces and is the weakest of all of the fundamental forces.']
['What is the weakest part of the sentence?', 'Consider this:']
['What is the mass of the Earth needed to hold an iron nail to the ground?', 'The entire mass of Earth is needed to hold an iron nail to the ground.']
['What is another interesting fact about gravitation?', 'Yet with a simple magnet, the force of gravity can be overcome, allowing the nail to accelerate upward through space.']
['What is an example of electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is responsible for both electrostatic interactions and the magnetic force seen between bar magnets.']
['What is the relationship between two charged particles?', 'When focusing on the electrostatic relationship between two charged particles, the electromagnetic force is known as the coulomb force.']

['What is another example of the electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is an important force in the chemical and biological sciences, as it is responsible for molecular connections like ionic bonding and hydrogen bonding.']
['What does the electromagnetic force do?', 'Additionally, the electromagnetic force is behind the common physics forces of friction and the normal force.']
['Does the electromagnetic force have an inverse square law?', 'Like the gravitational force, the electromagnetic force is an inverse square law.']
['What is significant about electromagnetic force?', 'However, the electromagnetic force does not exist between any two objects of mass, only those that are charged.']
['When considering the structure of an atom, what is somewhat apparent about the electromagnetic force?', 'When considering the structure of an atom, the electromagnetic force is somewhat apparent.']
['What is held in place by an attractive force from the nucleus?', 'After all, the electrons are held in place by an attractive force from the nucleus.']
['What other force exists within the nucleus?', 'After all, if all protons are positive, it makes sense that the coulomb force between the protons would repel the nucleus apart immediately.']
['What force must exist within the nucleus?', 'Scientists theorized that another force must exist within the nucleus to keep it together.']

['What other force is used to keep the nucleus together?', 'They further theorized that this nuclear force must be significantly stronger than gravity, which has been observed and measured for centuries, and also stronger than the electromagnetic force, which would cause the protons to want to accelerate away from each other.']
['What is the strong nuclear force?', 'The strong nuclear force is an attractive force that exists between all nucleons.']

['What is the strongest force at short ranges?', 'This force, which acts equally between proton-proton connections, proton-neutron connections, and neutron-neutron connections, is the strongest of all forces at short ranges.']
['What happens at 10–13 cm?', 'However, at a distance of 10–13 cm, or the diameter of a single proton, the force dissipates to zero.']
['What is the diameter of a proton?', 'If the nucleus is large (it has many nucleons), then the distance between each nucleon could be much larger than the diameter of a single proton.']
['What kind of decay occurs in beta decay?', 'The weak nuclear force is responsible for beta decay, as seen in the equation  $$\\[{}_{Z}^{A}X_{N}\\operatorname{~\\rightarrow~}\\']
['What is the equation for beta decay?', '~_{Z + 1}^{A}Y_{N–1}~ + ~e~ + ~v.\\]$$  Recall that beta decay is when a beta particle is ejected from an atom.']
['Why do these particles accelerate away from the nucleus?', 'In order to accelerate away from the nucleus, the particle must be acted on by a force.']
['Who first suggested the strong force?', 'Enrico Fermi was the first to envision this type of force.']
['What is the strong force?', 'While this force is appropriately labeled, it remains stronger than the gravitational force.']
['What is the gravitational force?', 'However, its range is even smaller than that of the strong force, as can be seen in Table 23.1.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'The weak nuclear force is more important than it may appear at this time, as will be addressed when we discuss quarks.']

['What is the first thing you would like to know about this study material?', 'Just as it troubled Einstein prior to formulating the gravitational field theory, the concept of forces acting over a distance had greatly troubled particle physicists.']

['What is the mysterious interactions?', 'These mysterious interactions were first considered by Hideki Yukawa in 1935 and laid the foundation for much of what we now understand about particle physics.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Hideki Yukawa’s focus was on the strong nuclear force and, in particular, its incredibly short range.']
['What did Yukawa study?', 'His idea was a blend of particles, relativity, and quantum mechanics that was applicable to all four forces.']

['What kind of particles are the carrier particles?', 'Yukawa proposed that the nuclear force is actually transmitted by the exchange of particles, called carrier particles, and that what we commonly refer to as the force’s field consists of these carrier particles.']

['who would carry the particle?', 'Specifically for the strong nuclear force, Yukawa proposed that a previously unknown particle, called a pion, is exchanged between nucleons, transmitting the force between them.']
['How did pion work?', 'Figure 23.3 illustrates how a pion would carry a force between a proton and a neutron.']

['What do the transmissions involve?', 'In Yukawa’s strong force, the carrier particle is assumed to be transmitted at the speed of light and is continually transferred between the two nucleons shown.']
['Did they find anything else?', 'The particle that Yukawa predicted was finally discovered within cosmic rays in 1947.']
['What is the name of the pion?', 'Its name, the pion, stands for pi meson, where meson means medium mass; it’s a medium mass because it is smaller than a nucleon but larger than an electron.']
['What was Yukawa known for?', 'Yukawa launched the field that is now called quantum chromodynamics, and the carrier particles are now called gluons due to their strong binding power.']
['What is the reason for the particle name change?', 'The reason for the change in the particle name will be explained when quarks are discussed later in this section.']
['What is one of the basic concepts of our study material?', 'As you may assume, the strong force is not the only force with a carrier particle.']
['What is the weak force?', 'Nuclear decay from the weak force also requires a particle transfer.']
['What are the basic concepts of the weak force?', 'In the weak force are the following three: the weak negative carrier, W–; the weak positive carrier, W+; and the zero charge carrier, Z0.']

['Why do they have to carry mass?', 'As we will see, Fermi inferred that these particles must carry mass, as the total mass of the products of nuclear decay is slightly larger than the total mass of all reactants after nuclear decay.']
['What is the carrier particle for the electromagnetic force?', 'The carrier particle for the electromagnetic force is, not surprisingly, the photon.']

['What does it do?', 'After all, just as a lightbulb can emit photons from a charged tungsten filament, the photon can be used to transfer information from one electrically charged particle to another.']
['What is the proposed carrier particle for gravity?', 'Finally, the graviton is the proposed carrier particle for gravity.']

['What is the evidence for the existence of the graviton?', 'While it has not yet been found, scientists are currently looking for evidence of its existence (see Boundless Physics: Searching for the Graviton).']
['What did we study in the Transmitting the Four Fundamental Forces?', 'Figure 23.4 shows a virtual photon transmitted from one positively charged particle to another.']
['What is the transmitted photon referred to as?', 'The transmitted photon is referred to as a virtual particle because it cannot be directly observed while transmitting the force.']
['Did you learn anything else about a photon?', 'Figure 23.5 shows a way of graphing the exchange of a virtual photon between the two positively charged particles.']

['What is the name of the graph of time versus position?', 'This graph of time versus position is called a Feynman diagram, after the brilliant American physicist Richard Feynman (1918–1988), who developed it.']
['What are some significant points about the Feynman diagram?', 'The Feynman diagram should be read from the bottom up to show the movement of particles over time.']

['What is the feynman diagram used to show?', 'In it, you can see that the left proton is propelled leftward from the photon emission, while the right proton feels an impulse to the right when the photon is received.']

['What other significant points about the diagram?', 'In addition to the Feynman diagram, Richard Feynman was one of the theorists who developed the field of quantum electrodynamics (QED), which further describes electromagnetic interactions on the submicroscopic scale.']
['who won the nobel prize for quantum electrodynamics?', 'For this work, he shared the 1965 Nobel Prize with Julian Schwinger and S.I. Tomonaga.']

['What is the name of the diagram that explains the strong force interaction hypothesized by Yukawa?', 'A Feynman diagram explaining the strong force interaction hypothesized by Yukawa can be seen in Figure 23.6.']
['What does the diagram show?', 'Here, you can see the change in particle type due to the exchange of the pi meson.']
['What is in the Table 23.2?', 'The relative masses of the listed carrier particles describe something valuable about the four fundamental forces, as can be seen in Table 23.2.']

['What are W bosons and Z bosons?', 'W bosons (consisting of  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  bosons) and Z bosons ( $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons), carriers of the weak nuclear force, are nearly 1,000 times more massive than pions, carriers of the strong nuclear force.']

['What is the distance that the weak nuclear force can be transmitted?', 'Simultaneously, the distance that the weak nuclear force can be transmitted is approximately  $$\\(\\frac{1}{1,000}\\)$$  times the strong force transmission distance.']
['What is the photon?', 'Unlike carrier particles, which have a limited range, the photon is a massless particle that has no limit to the transmission distance of the electromagnetic force.']
['Do scientists believe the graviton has a mass?', 'This relationship leads scientists to understand that the yet-unfound graviton is likely massless as well.']
['What is the content about?', 'Before looking at all the particles that make up our universe, let us first examine some of the machines that create them.']

['What is the fundamental process in creating unknown particles?', 'The fundamental process in creating unknown particles is to accelerate known particles, such as protons or electrons, and direct a beam of them toward a target.']
['what is the target?', 'Collisions with target nuclei provide a wealth of information, such as information obtained by Rutherford in the gold foil experiment.']
['How does this affect matter?', 'If the energy of the incoming particles is large enough, new matter can even be created in the collision.']
['What is energy?', 'The more energy input or ΔE, the more matter m can be created, according to mass energy equivalence  $$\\(m = \\text{Δ}E/c^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What is energy?', 'Limitations are placed on what can occur by known conservation laws, such as conservation of mass-energy, momentum, and charge.']
['Are there any unknown limitations?', 'Even more interesting are the unknown limitations provided by nature.']
['What are the unknown limitations?', 'While some expected reactions do occur, others do not, and still other unexpected reactions may appear.']
['What do these reactions reveal?', 'New laws are revealed, and the vast majority of what we know about particle physics has come from accelerator laboratories.']
['What is the particle physicist’s favorite indoor sport?', 'It is the particle physicist’s favorite indoor sport.']
['What was our earliest model of a particle accelerator?', 'Our earliest model of a particle accelerator comes from the Van de Graaff generator.']
['What was it used for?', 'The relatively simple device, which you have likely seen in physics demonstrations, can be manipulated to produce potentials as great as 50 million volts.']

['Did it produce new particles?', 'While these machines do not have energies large enough to produce new particles, analysis of their accelerated ions was instrumental in exploring several aspects of the nucleus.']
['What is another equally famous early accelerator?', 'Another equally famous early accelerator is the cyclotron, invented in 1930 by the American physicist, E.O. Lawrence (1901–1958).']
['What was a figure?', 'Figure 23.8 is a visual representation with more detail.']
['What do cyclotrons use to accelerate particles?', 'Cyclotrons use fixed-frequency alternating electric fields to accelerate particles.']
['What happens during acceleration?', 'The particles spiral outward in a magnetic field, making increasingly larger radius orbits during acceleration.']
['What else did you find interesting about accelerators?', 'This clever arrangement allows the successive addition of electric potential energy with each loop.']
['What was the consequence of this?', 'As a result, greater particle energies are possible than in a Van de Graaff generator.']
['What is a synchrotron?', 'A synchrotron is a modification of the cyclotron in which particles continually travel in a fixed-radius orbit, increasing speed each time.']
['What is accelerating voltages?', 'Accelerating voltages are synchronized with the particles to accelerate them, hence the name.']
['Why is orbital radius constant?', 'Additionally, magnetic field strength is increased to keep the orbital radius constant as energy increases.']
['What are the major components of synchrotrons?', 'A ring of magnets and accelerating tubes, as shown in Figure 23.9, are the major components of synchrotrons.']
['What is superconducting magnets?', 'High-energy particles require strong magnetic fields to steer them, so superconducting magnets are commonly employed.']

['What does a large radius orbit mean?', 'Still limited by achievable magnetic field strengths, synchrotrons need to be very large at very high energies since the radius of a high-energy particle’s orbit is very large.']
['What are accelerators used for?', 'To further probe the nucleus, physicists need accelerators of greater energy and detectors of shorter wavelength.']
['What is important about accelerators?', 'To do so requires not only greater funding but greater ingenuity as well.']

['What is the purpose of colliding beams?', 'Colliding beams used at both the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab; see Figure 23.11) near Chicago and the LHC in Switzerland are designed to reduce energy loss in particle collisions.']
['What is another important part of the article?', 'Typical stationary particle detectors lose a large amount of energy to the recoiling target struck by the accelerating particle.']

['What does colliding beams do?', 'By providing head-on collisions between particles moving in opposite directions, colliding beams make it possible to create particles with momenta and kinetic energies near zero.']
['What does colliding beams do?', 'This allows for particles of greater energy and mass to be created.']
['What is a schematic representation of this effect?', 'Figure 23.10 is a schematic representation of this effect.']
['What are some other accelerators?', 'In addition to circular accelerators, linear accelerators can be used to reduce energy radiation losses.']

['What is the largest linear accelerator in the world?', 'The Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (now called the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory) in California is home to the largest such accelerator in the world.']
['What is the first principle of the universe?', '“The first principles of the universe are atoms and empty space.']
['What is the most important thing to know about the universe?', 'Everything else is merely thought to exist…”']

['What is the article about?', '“… Further, the atoms are unlimited in size and number, and they are borne along with the whole universe in a vortex, and thereby generate all composite things—fire, water, air, earth.']
['What are these things made of?', 'For even these are conglomerations of given atoms.']
['What was stated about the atoms?', 'And it because of their solidity that these atoms are impassive and unalterable.”']
["What is the name of one thing that's important to the reading?", 'The search for fundamental particles is nothing new.']
['What other things is he saying?', 'Atomists of the Greek and Indian empires, like Democritus of fifth century B.C., openly wondered about the most finite components of our universe.']
['What happened after that?', 'Though dormant for centuries, curiosity about the atomic nature of matter was reinvigorated by Rutherford’s gold foil experiment and the discovery of the nucleus.']
['What did they think?', 'By the early 1930s, scientists believed they had fully determined the tiniest constituents of matter—in the form of the proton, neutron, and electron.']
['What is the main idea of this document?', 'This would be only partially true.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this paragraph?', 'At present, scientists know that there are hundreds of particles not unlike our electron and nucleons, all making up what some have termed the particle zoo.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this paragraph?', 'While we are confident that the electron remains fundamental, it is surrounded by a plethora of similar sounding terms, like leptons, hadrons, baryons, and mesons.']
['What role do they play in our world?', 'Even though not every particle is considered fundamental, they all play a vital role in understanding the intricate structure of our universe.']
['What is a particle with no substructure and no finite size?', 'A fundamental particle is defined as a particle with no substructure and no finite size.']
['What are some examples of fundamental particles?', 'According to the Standard Model, there are three types of fundamental particles: leptons, quarks, and carrier particles.']
['What are these particles responsible for?', 'As you may recall, carrier particles are responsible for transmitting fundamental forces between their interacting masses.']
['What are leptons?', 'Leptons are a group of six particles not bound by the strong nuclear force, of which the electron is one.']
['What is the third type of particle?', 'As for quarks, they are the fundamental building blocks of a group of particles called hadrons, a group that includes both the proton and the neutron.']
['What was the title of your next question?', 'Now for a brief history of quarks.']
['Who first proposed quarks?', 'Quarks were first proposed independently by American physicists Murray Gell-Mann and George Zweig in 1963.']
['What were the names of the three quark types?', 'Originally, three quark types—or flavors—were proposed with the names up (u), down (d), and strange (s).']
['What was physicists expectation?', 'At first, physicists expected that, with sufficient energy, we should be able to free quarks and observe them directly.']

['Was it not possible to separate the quarks?', 'However, this has not proved possible, as the current understanding is that the force holding quarks together is incredibly great and, much like a spring, increases in magnitude as the quarks are separated.']
['What do physicist think?', 'As a result, when large energies are put into collisions, other particles are created—but no quarks emerge.']
['What is the evidence for the existence of quarks?', 'With that in mind, there is compelling evidence for the existence of quarks.']

['what evidence did they have?', 'By 1967, experiments at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory scattering 20-GeV electrons from protons produced results like Rutherford had obtained for the nucleus nearly 60 years earlier.']

['What did the SLAC scattering experiments show?', 'The SLAC scattering experiments showed unambiguously that there were three point-like (meaning they had sizes considerably smaller than the probe’s wavelength) charges inside the proton as seen in Figure 23.12.']

['What evidence made all but the most skeptical admit that there was validity to the quark substructure of hadrons?', 'This evidence made all but the most skeptical admit that there was validity to the quark substructure of hadrons.']
['What did the model concern physicists relate to?', 'The inclusion of the strange quark with Zweig and Gell-Mann’s model concerned physicists.']

['What is the strange quark?', 'While the up and down quarks demonstrated fairly clear symmetry and were present in common fundamental particles like protons and neutrons, the strange quark did not have a counterpart of its own.']

['What caused scientists to speculate that a fourth quark, yet to be found, also existed?', 'This thought, coupled with the four known leptons at the time, caused scientists to predict that a fourth quark, yet to be found, also existed.']
['What happened in 1974?', 'In 1974, two groups of physicists independently discovered a particle with this new quark, labeled charmed.']
['What is the new quark?', 'This completed the second exotic quark pair, strange (s) and charmed (c).']
['What was discovered in 1974?', 'A final pair of quarks was proposed when a third pair of leptons was discovered in 1975.']
['Did they confirm the final pair in 1975?', 'The existence of the bottom (b) quark and the top (t) quark was verified through experimentation in 1976 and 1995, respectively.']

['What else was interesting in the article?', 'While it may seem odd that so much time would elapse between the original quark discovery in 1967 and the verification of the top quark in 1995, keep in mind that each quark discovered had a progressively larger mass.']
['What is the result of the time elapsed?', 'As a result, each new quark has required more energy to discover.']
['What is one of the most confounding traits of quarks?', 'One of the most confounding traits of quarks is their electric charge.']

['What is the electric charge of an individual quark?', 'Long assumed to be discrete, and specifically a multiple of the elementary charge of the electron, the electric charge of an individual quark is fractional and thus seems to violate a presumed tenet of particle physics.']

['What is an odd construction?', 'The fractional charge of quarks, which are  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{2}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{1}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$, are the only structures found in nature with a nonintegral number of charge  $$\\(q\\)$$ .']
['How does this make the quarks odd?', 'However, note that despite this odd construction, the fractional value of the quark does not violate the quantum nature of the charge.']
['What is a positive thing to note?', 'After all, free quarks cannot be found in nature, and all quarks are bound into arrangements in which an integer number of charge is constructed.']
['What other characteristics can be found?', 'Table 23.3 shows the six known quarks, in addition to their antiquark components, as will be discussed later in this section.']

['What is the term flavor used for?', 'While the term flavor is used to differentiate between types of quarks, the concept of color is more analogous to the electric charge in that it is primarily responsible for the force interactions between quarks.']
['What does he say about the electrostatic force?', 'Note—Take a moment to think about the electrostatic force.']
['What causes attraction and repulsion?', 'It is the electric charge that causes attraction and repulsion.']
['Does he say anything about anti?', 'It is the same case here but with a color charge.']

['What are the three colors available to a quark?', 'The three colors available to a quark are red, green, and blue, with antiquarks having colors of anti-red (or cyan), anti-green (or magenta), and anti-blue (or yellow).']
['What is he trying to prove?', 'After all, the quarks are not actually colored with visible light.']
['What is the reasoning behind the use of colors?', 'The reason colors are used is because the properties of a quark are analogous to the three primary and secondary colors mentioned above.']
['What are the analogies?', 'Just as different colors of light can be combined to create white, different colors of quark may be combined to construct a particle like a proton or neutron.']
['How is this used?', 'In fact, for each hadron, the quarks must combine such that their color sums to white!']
['What is the proton made of?', 'Recall that two up quarks and one down quark construct a proton, as seen in Figure 23.12.']
['What color are the three quarks?', 'The sum of the three quarks’ colors—red, green, and blue—yields the color white.']
['What is the theory of color interaction within particles called?', 'This theory of color interaction within particles is called quantum chromodynamics, or QCD.']
['What is the strong nuclear force explained using?', 'As part of QCD, the strong nuclear force can be explained using color.']
['What is the strongest force?', 'In fact, some scientists refer to the color force, not the strong force, as one of the four fundamental forces.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'Figure 23.13 is a Feynman diagram showing the interaction between two quarks by using the transmission of a colored gluon.']
['What is the charge carrier for the strong nuclear force?', 'Note that the gluon is also considered the charge carrier for the strong nuclear force.']
['What color can the quark flavor have?', 'Note that quark flavor may have any color.']
['What color can it be red or green?', 'For instance, in Figure 23.13, the down quark has a red color and a green color.']
['What else did you find helpful?', 'In other words, colors are not specific to a particle quark flavor.']
['What can be revealingly grouped according to?', 'Particles can be revealingly grouped according to what forces they feel between them.']
['What are particles affected by?', 'All particles (even those that are massless) are affected by gravity since gravity affects the space and time in which particles exist.']

['what are other effects?', 'All charged particles are affected by the electromagnetic force, as are neutral particles that have an internal distribution of charge (such as the neutron with its magnetic moment).']
['What are given to particles that feel the strong and weak nuclear forces?', 'Special names are given to particles that feel the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['What are particles that feel the strong nuclear force?', 'Hadrons are particles that feel the strong nuclear force, whereas leptons are particles that do not.']
['What do all particles feel?', 'All particles feel the weak nuclear force.']
['What is the difference between hadrons and protons?', 'This means that hadrons are distinguished by being able to feel both the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['What are the other distinctions between leptons and hadrons?', 'Leptons and hadrons are distinguished in other ways as well.']
['What other features distinguish them?', 'Leptons are fundamental particles that have no measurable size, while hadrons are composed of quarks and have a diameter on the order of 10–15 m.']
['What are the six particles that make up the list of known leptons?', 'Six particles, including the electron and neutrino, make up the list of known leptons.']
['what else is known about hadrons?', 'There are hundreds of complex particles in the hadron class, a few of which (including the proton and neutron) are listed in Table 23.4.']
['What is the most important thing I should know from your article?', 'There are many more leptons, mesons, and baryons yet to be discovered and measured.']

['Why is that important?', 'The purpose of trying to uncover the smallest indivisible things in existence is to explain the world around us through forces and the interactions between particles, galaxies and objects.']
['How do scientists make a living?', 'This is why a handful of scientists devote their life’s work to smashing together small particles.']
['What is the proton made up of?', 'The proton, like all hadrons, is made up of quarks.']
['What is an example of hadron quark composition?', 'A few examples of hadron quark composition can be seen in Figure 23.14.']
['Are there more examples of hadron quark composition?', 'As shown, each hadron is constructed of multiple quarks.']
['What is the quark charge determined by?', 'As mentioned previously, the fractional quark charge in all four hadrons sums to the particle’s integral value.']
['What is the color composition for each of the four particles?', 'Also, notice that the color composition for each of the four particles adds to white.']
['What are the particles shown constructed of?', 'Each of the particles shown is constructed of up, down, and their antiquarks.']

['What is the quarks strange, charmed, top, and bottom found in only our most exotic particles?', 'This is not surprising, as the quarks strange, charmed, top, and bottom are found in only our most exotic particles.']

['Are there any other interesting facts related to Hadrons and Leptons?', 'You may have noticed that while the proton and neutron in Figure 23.14 are composed of three quarks, both pions are comprised of only two quarks.']
['What does this refer to?', 'This refers to a final delineation in particle structure.']
['What are particles with three quarks called?', 'Particles with three quarks are called baryons.']
['What do they decay into?', 'These are heavy particles that can decay into another baryon.']
['What are two quarks?', 'Particles with only two quarks—a-quark–anti-quark pair—are called mesons.']
['What are the particles of moderate mass that cannot decay into the more massive baryons?', 'These are particles of moderate mass that cannot decay into the more massive baryons.']
['Which figure?', 'Before continuing, take a moment to view Figure 23.15.']
['What is the strong force reimagined as?', 'In this figure, you can see the strong force reimagined as a color force.']
['What do you see in this figure?', 'The particles interacting in this figure are the proton and neutron, just as they were in Figure 23.6.']

['What is the critical concept behind quantum chromodynamics?', 'This reenvisioning of the strong force as an interaction between colored quarks is the critical concept behind quantum chromodynamics.']
['What was one of the first important facts related to this article?', 'Antimatter was first discovered in the form of the positron, the positively charged electron.']
['When was the positron first discovered?', 'In 1932, American physicist Carl Anderson discovered the positron in cosmic ray studies.']

['What did he discover?', 'Through a cloud chamber modified to curve the trajectories of cosmic rays, Anderson noticed that the curves of some particles followed that of a negative charge, while others curved like a positive charge.']
['What did Anderson discover?', 'However, the positive curve showed not the mass of a proton but the mass of an electron.']

['What did Anderson discover after this study?', 'This outcome is shown in Figure 23.16 and suggests the existence of a positively charged version of the electron, created by the destruction of solar photons.']
['What is the difference between matter and antimatter?', 'Antimatter is considered the opposite of matter.']
['What happens in antimatter?', 'For most antiparticles, this means that they share the same properties as their original particles with the exception of their charge.']
['What is opposite charge?', 'This is why the positron can be considered a positive electron while the antiproton is considered a negative proton.']
['What is opposite charge defined as?', 'The idea of an opposite charge for neutral particles (like the neutron) can be confusing, but it makes sense when considered from the quark perspective.']

['What is the quark perspective?', 'Just as the neutron is composed of one up quark and two down quarks (of charge $$\\(+ \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$and $$\\(- \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively), the antineutron is composed of one anti–up quark and two anti–down quarks (of charge  $$\\(- \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$  and $$\\(+ \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively).']
['What does opposite charge have to do with neutrons?', 'While the overall charge of the neutron remains the same, its constituent particles do not!']
['What is the main idea behind this study?', 'A word about antiparticles: Like regular particles, antiparticles could function just fine on their own.']
['What is the difference between matter and antimatter?', 'In fact, a universe made up of antimatter may operate just as our own matter-based universe does.']
['What is interesting about the study?', 'However, we do not know fully whether this is the case.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'The reason for this is annihilation.']

['What is the process of destruction that occurs when a particle and its antiparticle interact?', 'Annihilation is the process of destruction that occurs when a particle and its antiparticle interact.']

['What happens to the particles when they do meet?', 'As soon as two particles (like a positron and an electron) coincide, they convert their masses to energy through the equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$ .']
['Why is this problematic?', 'This mass-to-energy conversion, which typically results in photon release, happens instantaneously and makes it very difficult for scientists to study antimatter.']
['What happened after the photons were released?', 'That said, scientists have had success creating antimatter through high-energy particle collisions.']

['What else has been done regarding antimatter?', 'Both antineutrons and antiprotons were created through accelerator experiments in 1956, and an anti–hydrogen atom was even created at CERN in 1995!']

['What can you tell me about the medical uses of antimatter?', 'As referenced in Figure 22.40, the annihilation of antiparticles is currently used in medical studies to determine the location of radioisotopes.']

['What is the current scientific view of the fundamental components and interacting forces of matter?', 'The Standard Model of the atom refers to the current scientific view of the fundamental components and interacting forces of matter.']

['What are some basic properties of the atom?', 'The Standard Model (Figure 23.17) shows the six quarks that bind to form all hadrons, the six lepton particles already considered fundamental, the four carrier particles (or gauge bosons) that transmit forces between the leptons and quarks, and the recently added Higgs boson (which will be discussed shortly).']
['Are these the only basic particles?', 'This totals 17 fundamental particles, combinations of which are responsible for all known matter in our entire universe!']
['What are the other parts of the Standard Model?', 'When adding the antiquarks and antileptons, 31 components make up the Standard Model.']
['What did the picture show?', 'Figure 23.17 shows all particles within the Standard Model of the atom.']
['What does this chart divide all known particles by?', 'Not only does this chart divide all known particles by color-coded group, but it also provides information on particle stability.']
['What did the color indicate?', 'Note that the color-coding system in this chart is separate from the red, green, and blue color labeling system of quarks.']
['What are the three families of matter?', 'The first three columns represent the three families of matter.']

['What does the first column represent?', 'The first column, considered Family 1, represents particles that make up normal matter, constructing the protons, neutrons, and electrons that make up the common world.']
['What is the second column?', 'Family 2, represented from the charm quark to the muon neutrino, is comprised of particles that are more massive.']
['What is the third column?', 'The leptons in this group are less stable and more likely to decay.']
['What is the fourth column?', 'Family 3, represented by the third column, are more massive still and decay more quickly.']
['What does the order of these families represent?', 'The order of these families also conveniently represents the order in which these particles were discovered.']
['What is the standard model about?', 'The Standard Model also summarizes the fundamental forces that exist as particles interact.']
['What can you tell me about the figure?', 'A closer look at the Standard Model, as shown in Figure 23.18, reveals that the arrangement of carrier particles describes these interactions.']
['What do the shaded areas represent?', 'Each of the shaded areas represents a fundamental force and its constituent particles.']
['What does the red area show?', 'The red shaded area shows all particles involved in the strong nuclear force, which we now know is due to quantum chromodynamics.']

['What does the blue area show?', 'The blue shaded area corresponds to the electromagnetic force, while the green shaded area corresponds to the weak nuclear force, which affects all quarks and leptons.']
['What is the difference between the green area and blue area?', 'The electromagnetic force and weak nuclear force are considered united by the electroweak force within the Standard Model.']
['What is the evidence of the graviton?', 'Also, because definitive evidence of the graviton is yet to be found, it is not included in the Standard Model.']
['What is the standard model?', 'One interesting feature of the Standard Model shown in Figure 23.18 is that, while the gluon and photon have no mass, the Z and W bosons are very massive.']
['What year was the w boson invented?', 'In the 1960s, British physicist Peter Higgs and others speculated that the W and Z bosons were actually just as massless as the gluon and photon.']

['How do the W and Z bosons travel from one particle to another?', 'However, as the W and Z bosons traveled from one particle to another, they were slowed down by the presence of a Higgs field, much like a fish swimming through water.']

['What happens when the particles pass through the Higgs field?', 'The thinking was that the existence of the Higgs field would slow down the bosons, causing them to decrease in energy and thereby transfer this energy to mass.']
['where does the field exist?', 'Under this theory, all particles pass through the Higgs field, which exists throughout the universe.']
['Do the gluon and photon travel through this field as well?', 'The gluon and photon travel through this field as well but are able to do so unaffected.']
['What is the significance of the Higgs field?', 'The presence of a force from the Higgs field suggests the existence of its own carrier particle, the Higgs boson.']
['What does the Higgs boson do?', 'This theorized boson interacts with all particles but gluons and photons, transferring force from the Higgs field.']
['What is more likely to receive force from the Higgs boson?', 'Particles with large mass (like the top quark) are more likely to receive force from the Higgs boson.']
["What was a significant fact in the document you're studying?", 'While it is difficult to examine a field, it is somewhat simpler to find evidence of its carrier.']
['What happened with the LHC in 2012?', 'On July 4, 2012, two groups of scientists at the LHC independently confirmed the existence of a Higgs-like particle.']

['How did the scientists determine the particles?', 'By examining trillions of proton–proton collisions at energies of 7 to 8 TeV, LHC scientists were able to determine the constituent particles that created the protons.']

['What did they find in the data?', 'In this data, scientists found a particle with similar mass, spin, parity, and interactions with other particles that matched the Higgs boson predicted decades prior.']
['When did CERN confirm their finding?', 'On March 13, 2013, the existence of the Higgs boson was tentatively confirmed by CERN.']

['Did CERN receive any awards?', 'Peter Higgs and Francois Englert received the Nobel Prize in 2013 for the “theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin and mass of subatomic particles.”']
['What are the four basic forces?', 'Present quests to show that the four basic forces are different manifestations of a single unified force that follow a long tradition.']

['What was discovered in the nineteenth century?', 'In the nineteenth century, the distinct electric and magnetic forces were shown to be intimately connected and are now collectively called the electromagnetic force.']
['What other connections are there?', 'More recently, the weak nuclear force was united with the electromagnetic force.']
['What other relationships are there between the basic forces?', 'As shown in Figure 23.19, carrier particles transmit three of the four fundamental forces in very similar ways.']

['What is the theory about?', 'With these considerations in mind, it is natural to suggest that a theory may be constructed in which the strong nuclear, weak nuclear, and electromagnetic forces are all unified.']

['What is the search for a correct theory linking the forces, called the Grand Unified Theory (GUT), explored in this section?', 'The search for a correct theory linking the forces, called the Grand Unified Theory (GUT), is explored in this section.']
['What is the name of the person who developed the electroweak theory?', 'In the 1960s, the electroweak theory was developed by Steven Weinberg, Sheldon Glashow, and Abdus Salam.']
['What did this theory propose?', 'This theory proposed that the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are identical at sufficiently high energies.']
['What happened with the theory?', 'At lower energies, like those in our present-day universe, the two forces remain united but manifest themselves in different ways.']

['What was the theory that predicted three short-range carrier particles?', 'One of the main consequences of the electroweak theory was the prediction of three short-range carrier particles, now known as the  $$\\(W^{+},\\)$$ $$\\(W^{-},\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons.']

['What else was predicted with the theory?', 'Not only were three particles predicted, but the mass of each  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 81 GeV/c2, and that of the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 90 GeV/c2.']
['What did this find?', 'In 1983, these carrier particles were observed at CERN with the predicted characteristics, including masses having those predicted values as given in Figure 23.17.']
['Are they really distinct?', 'They are definitely distinct under most circumstances.']
['Why do different particles have different properties?', 'For example, they are carried by different particles and have greatly different strengths.']

['What happens at extremely short distances and at extremely high energies?', 'But experiments show that at extremely short distances and at extremely high energies, the strengths of the forces begin to become more similar, as seen in Figure 23.20.']

['What are the short ranges and large masses of the weak carrier bosons?', 'As discussed earlier, the short ranges and large masses of the weak carrier bosons require correspondingly high energies to create them.']

['How much energy do they need?', 'Thus, the energy scale on the horizontal axis of Figure 23.20 also corresponds to shorter and shorter distances (going from left to right), with 100 GeV corresponding to approximately 10−18 m, for example.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'At that distance, the strengths of the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are the same.']
['What is the energy level of the weak nuclear force?', 'To test this, energies of about 100 GeV are put into the system.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about the weak nuclear forces?', 'When this occurs, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  carrier particles are created and released.']

['What do the carrier particles look like?', 'At those and higher energies, the masses of the carrier particles become less and less relevant, and the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson in particular resembles the massless, chargeless photon.']

['What happens as the energy increases?', 'As further energy is added, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  particles are further transformed into massless carrier particles even more similar to photons and gluons.']

['What is the first question you answered?', 'The extremely short distances and high energies at which the electroweak force becomes identical with the strong nuclear force are not reachable with any conceivable human-built accelerator.']
['How are they reached?', 'At energies of about 1014 GeV (16,000 J per particle), distances of about 10 to 30 m can be probed.']

['What is the maximum energy associated with the LHC?', 'Such energies are needed to test the theory directly, but these are about 1010 times higher than the maximum energy associated with the LHC, and the distances are about 10 to 12 smaller than any structure we have direct knowledge of.']

['What would be the realm of various GUTs, of which there are many, since there is no constraining evidence at these energies and distances?', 'This would be the realm of various GUTs, of which there are many, since there is no constraining evidence at these energies and distances.']
['What can you tell me about the energy?', 'Past experience has shown that anytime you probe so many orders of magnitude further, you find the unexpected.']
['What is not presently possible?', 'While direct evidence of a GUT is not presently possible, that does not rule out the ability to assess a GUT through an indirect process.']
['What are various other events?', 'Current GUTs require various other events as a consequence of their theory.']

['What else are required?', 'Some GUTs require the existence of magnetic monopoles, very massive individual north- and south-pole particles, which have not yet been proven to exist, while others require the use of extra dimensions.']
['What are the consequences of the theories?', 'However, not all theories result in the same consequences.']
['What is a consequence of disproving the existence of magnetic monopoles?', 'For example, disproving the existence of magnetic monopoles will not disprove all GUTs.']
['What is significant about the article?', 'Much of the science we accept in our everyday lives is based on different models, each with their own strengths and limitations.']
['What does this mean?', 'Although a particular model may have drawbacks, that does not necessarily mean that it should be discounted completely.']
['What is one consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed?', 'One consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed is proton decay.']
['What are some of the hypotheses related to the decay?', 'Multiple current GUTs hypothesize that the stable proton should actually decay at a lifetime of 1031 years.']

['How did scientists try to confirm this?', 'While this time is incredibly large (keep in mind that the age of the universe is less than 14 billion years), scientists at the Super-Kamiokande in Japan have used a 50,000-ton tank of water to search for its existence.']
['What was the purpose of the experiment?', 'The decay of a single proton in the Super-Kamiokande tank would be observed by a detector, thereby providing support for the predicting GUT model.']
['What did they find out from this experiment?', 'However, as of 2014, 17 years into the experiment, decay is yet to be found.']
['Is this a fact?', 'This time span equates to a minimum limit on proton life of  $$\\(5.9\\  \\times \\ 10^{33}\\)$$ years.']
['What does this mean to scientists?', 'While this result certainly does not support many grand unifying theories, an acceptable model may still exist.']
['What do the macroscopic and microscopic worlds have in common?', 'Nature is full of examples where the macroscopic and microscopic worlds intertwine.']

['Who discovered that the nature of gravity on Earth that pulls an apple to the ground could explain the motion of the moon and planets so much farther away?', 'Newton realized that the nature of gravity on Earth that pulls an apple to the ground could explain the motion of the moon and planets so much farther away.']
['What did he discover about the interior of the Earth?', 'Decays of tiny nuclei explain the hot interior of the Earth.']
['What is another example of fusion of nuclei?', 'Fusion of nuclei likewise explains the energy of stars.']
['What do the patterns in particle physics seem to be explaining?', 'Today, the patterns in particle physics seem to be explaining the evolution and character of the universe.']
['What else has it to do with the universe?', 'And the nature of the universe has implications for unexplored regions of particle physics.']

["Who recognized hubble's discovery?", 'In 1929, Edwin Hubble observed that all but the closest galaxies surrounding our own had a red shift in their hydrogen spectra that was proportional to their distance from us.']

['What did Hubble recognize the Doppler Effect meant?', 'Applying the Doppler Effect, Hubble recognized that this meant that all galaxies were receding from our own, with those farther away receding even faster.']
['What did this tell us?', 'Knowing that our place in the universe was no more unique than any other, the implication was clear:']
['What was the implication of the discovery of the Big Bang?', 'The space within the universe itself was expanding.']
['How was the space expanding?', 'Just like pen marks on an expanding balloon, everything in the universe was accelerating away from everything else.']
['What is the biggest question relating to this study material?', 'Figure 23.21 shows how the recession of galaxies looks like the remnants of a gigantic explosion, the famous Big Bang.']

['What would have happened if the Big Bang had not occurred?', 'Extrapolating backward in time, the Big Bang would have occurred between 13 and 15 billion years ago, when all matter would have been at a single point.']
['What is the next question?', 'From this, questions instantly arise.']
['What are the biggest questions relating to the Big Bang?', 'For our purposes, the biggest question relating to the Big Bang is this:']
['What does that mean?', 'To fully understand the conditions of the very early universe, recognize that as the universe contracts to the size of the Big Bang, changes will occur.']
['What changes will happen if the universe expands?', 'The density and temperature of the universe will increase dramatically.']
['What happens when this happens?', 'As particles become closer together, they will become too close to exist as we know them.']
['What will happen to the particles?', 'The high energies will create other, more unusual particles to exist in greater abundance.']
['What do you think this means?', 'Knowing this, let’s move forward from the start of the universe, beginning with the Big Bang, as illustrated in Figure 23.22.']
['What is the Planck epoch?', 'The Planck Epoch $$\\(\\left( {0\\rightarrow 10^{-43}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['what is the biggest issue with the planck epoch?', '—Though scientists are unable to model the conditions of the Planck Epoch in the laboratory, speculation is that at this time compressed energy was great enough to reach the immense  $$\\(10^{19}\\)$$  GeV necessary to unify gravity with all other forces.']

['What happens when the energy is not available?', 'As a result, modern cosmology suggests that all four forces would have existed as one force, a hypothetical superforce as suggested by the Theory of Everything.']
['What else do we need to know about the Grand Unification Epoch?', 'The Grand Unification Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{-43}\\rightarrow 10^{-36}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['what happens as the universe expands?', '—As the universe expands, the temperatures necessary to maintain the superforce decrease.']
['What happens when the temperature decreases?', 'As a result, gravity separates, leaving the electroweak and strong nuclear forces together.']
['What happens at the epoch?', 'At this time, the electromagnetic, weak, and strong forces are identical, matching the conditions requested in the Grand Unification Theory.']
['What does the inflationary scenario refer to?', 'The Inflationary Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{- 36}\\rightarrow 10^{- 32}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['What is thought to have happened during this time?', '—The separation of the strong nuclear force from the electroweak force during this time is thought to have been responsible for the massive inflation of the universe.']
['How did the universe expand?', 'Corresponding to the steep diagonal line on the left side of Figure 23.22, the universe may have expanded by a factor of  $$\\(10^{50}\\)$$  or more in size.']
['How did the expansion of the universe change the Earth?', 'In fact, the expansion was so great during this time that it actually occurred faster than the speed of light!']

['What is the inflationary scenario?', 'Unfortunately, there is little hope that we may be able to test the inflationary scenario directly since it occurs at energies near  $$\\(10^{14}\\)$$  GeV, vastly greater than the limits of modern accelerators.']
['What other topics will you be studying?', 'The Electroweak Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{-32}\\rightarrow 10^{-11}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['What happened during the electroweak epoch?', '—Now separated from both gravity and the strong nuclear force, the electroweak force exists as a singular force during this time period.']

['What else happened during this time period?', 'As stated earlier, scientists are able to create the energies at this stage in the universe’s expansion, needing only 100 GeV, as shown in Figure 23.20.']
['What other bosons are released during the electroweak epoch?', 'W and Z bosons, as well as the Higgs boson, are released during this time.']
['What is the next question I should ask you?', 'The Quark Era $$\\(\\left( {10^{-11}\\rightarrow 10^{-6}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['Why is it important to know this information?', '—During the Quark Era, the universe has expanded and temperatures have decreased to the point at which all four fundamental forces have separated.']
['Why is that important?', 'Additionally, quarks began to take form as energies decreased.']

['What happened during the early universe?', 'As the universe expanded, further eras took place, allowing for the existence of hadrons, leptons, and photons, the fundamental particles of the standard model.']
['What did these basic building blocks eventually lead to?', 'Eventually, in nucleosynthesis, nuclei would be able to form, and the basic building blocks of atomic matter could take place.']
['What is the reason we are working backwards?', 'Using particle accelerators, we are very much working backwards in an attempt to understand the universe.']
['What did the model show?', 'It is encouraging to see that the macroscopic conditions of the Big Bang align nicely with our submicroscopic particle theory.']
